HEADLINE: Bush, in Berlin, Calms Some European Fears With Talk of Partnership and Aid 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BERLIN, May 23 

 BODY:
President Bush delivered a well-prepared speech here today that pleased his supporters and surprised some of his critics, touching on sensitive topics without belaboring them and emphasizing the shared values and risks of the trans-Atlantic alliance.
 His host, the Social Democratic chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, , called the address "truly important," noting that Mr. Bush's emphasis on cooperation with allies and international development aid had brushed aside "carefully tended prejudices." 
 Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer, who is from the Green Party, also praised Mr. Bush for understanding that the answer to terrorism was not only military, but included free trade and more foreign aid as an obligation of wealthy nations to the poor. 
But Mr. Fischer was conditional in his plaudits, saying the speech would be "historic" only if "these ideas are really translated into political action."
Robert Kagan, an analyst with the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace noted that the problems of "continental drift" between Washington and Europe had not begun with President Bush, "and Bush can't solve them, even with the best of speeches."
But, Mr. Kagan added, "it was a moving and important speech, if there's anyone left in Europe to be moved."
Mr. Bush discussed the American campaign against terrorism but was careful not to mention Iraq. Many Germans are concerned that the United States could drag them and NATO into a war against Iraq without sufficient consultation or justification.
As Jeffrey Gedmin, director of the Aspen Institute in Berlin, put it, "Bush went as far as he could to be clear and principled about how Sept. 11 has transformed the conversation in America about national security, but without going too far to scare them, because they are scared. 
"Legislators were relieved he didn't mention Iraq and didn't ask too much of them too soon. But every key figure in the government knows that Iraq is coming. But they want it after the elections." Those occur on Sept. 22.
The left was grudging but respectful, despite a showy walkout by four deputies of the reformed East German Communist Party. "The president clearly disarmed verbally," said the party's deputy chairwoman, Petra Pau, meaning that he had toned down his language. "But a difference in political understanding remains."
Winfried Herrmann, a Greens legislator and a pacifist, called it "an astoundingly modest speech" and added, with faint praise: "I expected that he would say something that would force me to leave the hall. That wasn't the case."
Part of the trans-Atlantic "drift" is about self-confidence and the willingness to use power to achieve goals, Mr. Kagan said.
The speech was "a well-written appeal to a common destiny," Mr. Kagan added. "But it isn't a substitute for the huge disparities in power and the equally large difference in attitudes to the use of power. 
"Europeans don't really believe in using power to solve international problems anymore, because their experience in the last decades is that you solve problems by discarding power. That's a good thing, but it's only possible if someone else is there guarding the gate."
Conservatives liked the speech and also noted Mr. Bush's emphasis on aid as an antidote to terrorism. The leader of the Christian Democrats, Angela Merkel, called the speech impressive, saying Mr. Bush "made it clear that we cannot just focus the antiterror effort on military solutions."
Edmund Stoiber, the conservatives' candidate for chancellor, who is currently leading Mr. Schroder in the polls, praised Mr. Bush for concentrating on what unites Europe and America. "Bush rejected unilateralism in the fight against terror," Mr. Stoiber said. "He made it clear that the problem could only be solved together. And with his comparisons with the fight against the Nazis and communism, Bush proved how serious he was."
Margarita Mathiopoulos, director of the Potsdam Center for Trans-Atlantic Security and Military Affairs, said Mr. Bush's emphasis on common historical and cultural vaules was "not anymore a commonplace, and that he said it here in Berlin has a real value -- the wording was sensitive, and his presentation was disarming."
But she echoed concern from conservatives on both sides of the Atlantic that Mr. Bush's warm relationship with the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, is too unskeptical. While Mr. Bush spoke of new relations with Russia as a European-American initiative, in part through NATO, "the warmth he gave to Russia was for me a bit too far," Ms. Mathiopoulos said. 
"We Europeans always get disturbed when Americans engage in this kind of love affair with the Russians," she added. "It's important the cold war is over and we all agree, but there is still a 'but,' and it will affect NATO strategy."
Josef Joffe, chief editor of the weekly Die Zeit, also praised Mr. Bush for highlighting the cultural and moral values that are shared. "He spoke of Luther, St. Francis, the Magna Carta, that is what the West is all about," Mr. Joffe said. "That is the vast weight under our relationship that keeps righting it when it tips."
While not an historic speech, Mr. Joffe said, "it was the right speech at the right moment in the right tone at the right place."

HEADLINE: IN REICHSTAG, BUSH CONDEMNS TERROR AS NEW DESPOTISM 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: BERLIN, May 23 

 BODY:
President Bush stood today in the well of Germany's reconstructed Reichstag and told Parliament that the terrorist groups the United States and its allies are hunting down constitute a "new totalitarian threat," and in a clear reference to Hitler, compared the current struggle to a past generation's battle against those who "killed in the name of racial purity."
 Mr. Bush's speech under the spectacular glass dome of the Reichstag, the symbol of a unified Germany, sought to reassure clearly skeptical Germans about his intentions as he pursues his next steps against terrorism, particularly in Iraq, and presses American interests in environmental protection and aid to developing nations. Many Europeans are also concerned about American policy in the Middle East and about American plans for NATO. 
 During a news conference with Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, he promised to consult with Germany and other allies before taking action against Iraq and its suspected weapons of mass destruction, but he made it clear that he would not back off, saying, "We've got to deal with it." 
Mr. Bush's remarks, the first by an American president in the Reichstag, were received politely. But his appearance was punctuated at one point by a demonstration by four members of a former East German Communist party who unveiled a banner that said "Stop Your Wars." Mr. Bush missed a few beats of his speech, then kept speaking as a few members of Parliament walked out in protest.
Mr. Bush used much of the speech to celebrate Germany's achievements, and Europe's, in the 13 years since the Berlin Wall fell just feet from where he was speaking. "Ours is the first generation in a hundred years that does not expect and does not fear the next European war," he said to applause that even some of his harshest critics seemed to join.
Invoking the resolute declarations of Presidents Kennedy and Reagan during their visits to a divided Berlin, Mr. Bush made his case that the United States, an expanded NATO, and now Russia face a new mission: to defeat regimes that may place nuclear, chemical or biological weapons within reach of terrorists.
"If these regimes and their terrorist allies were to perfect these capabilities, no inner voice of reason, no hint of conscience would prevent their use," he said, charging that terrorists hate "Jews and Christians and all Muslims who disagree with them." 
Turning to members of the Green Party and others in the chamber who have protested America's approach to terrorism as unilateral, extreme and a violation of international law, he said, "Wishful thinking might bring comfort, but not security."
He appeared, at moments, to be invoking the lessons of the 1930's when efforts to appease Hitler failed, and he made it clear he did not plan to repeat the mistake. "Call this a strategic challenge; call it, as I do, the axis of evil; call it by any name you choose, but let us speak the truth." He added, "We must confront this conspiracy against our liberty and against our lives."
In the midst of his 20-hour visit here, Mr. Bush was clearly concerned about dampening expanding questions about the intelligence failures before the Sept. 11 attacks, including questions about what he knew. In his news conference, he insisted that he welcomes a Congressional investigation, but only "in the Intelligence Committee," which, he said, understands "the obligations of upholding our secrets and our sources and methods of collecting intelligence."
He deflected a question about whether he would release the Central Intelligence Agency analysis given to him on Aug. 6 that raised the possibility that Al Qaeda was trying to hijack American aircraft. But a senior administration official said in Washington that Mr. Bush would not set a precedent by turning over to Congress any copies of his classified Presidential Daily Briefing.
Mr. Bush clearly knew he faced a skeptical audience, both in the chamber and across Europe. He seemed to adjust his tone to one of gentle persuasion rather than argument. He repeatedly thanked Germany for its contributions to the fight against the Taliban and Al Qaeda, an action that the Parliament authorized after considerable debate over the first deployment of German troops for battle since World War II.
Carrying the comparisons to World War II and the cold war to the next step, the president said Sept. 11 marked a change of eras as dramatic as Pearl Harbor or the first days of the Berlin blockade, when the United States had to mount an airlift to keep the Western-controlled parts of the city fed.
He carefully stepped around the most contentious subjects of disagreement, including his rejection of the Kyoto Protocol on global warming, his refusal to sign the treaty creating the International Criminal Court, and his decision to aid American steelmakers by imposing large tariffs on foreign-made steel. He started off by thanking the members of Parliament, as they sat in purple seats before jet-black desks, for coming into a special session to hear him. "I can just imagine how my Congress would react if I called them back to hear a speech of mine when they were on vacation," he said to laughter.
As he spoke, Mr. Bush's wife, Laura, who has been touring Europe in recent days, and members of his foreign policy team sat in the sleek glass-and-metal galleries that give the new home of Parliament an airy look inside the walls of the 108-year-old Reichstag building. Also along for the trip, which will include Russia, France and Italy, were Karen Hughes, the influential counselor who is leaving the White House this summer, and, notably, Karl Rove, his longtime policy adviser, whose presence seemed to underscore the expansion of his domestic political portfolio to global matters. 
Quickly, Mr. Bush and his team received a lesson in the politics of modern Europe. No sooner had they entered the chamber than Mr. Bush was both welcomed and directly challenged by the Parliament's president, Wolfgang Thierse, a member of Mr. Schroder's Social Democrats. 
Mr. Thierse complimented the American president for taking the time to assemble a coalition to fight terrorism, declaring, "Your reaction to Sept. 11 proved that all those were wrong who thought a new American unilateralism was emerging." 
But then Mr. Thierse warned, in comments clearly aimed at the visiting president, that the need for such coalitions extends to other arenas. "The pursuit of unilateral interests proves short-sighted more and more frequently," he said, urging Mr. Bush to "continue together on the road mapped out by the Kyoto protocol" and to ratify the court treaty. Mr. Bush made it clear earlier in the day that he has no intention of reconsidering his opposition to the Kyoto treaty.
In his whirlwind tour here, Mr. Bush did no sightseeing. His motorcade speeded through a sealed-off downtown, past both the reminders of the Nazi era and the cranes that are creating a new Berlin in the spaces left after the wall tumbled. He acknowledged at one point this morning his frustration at not seeing more, and not speaking to ordinary Germans -- the closest he came was an invitation-only crowd at a restaurant where he had dessert with Mr. Schroder on Wednesday night. But he said "that's just life in the bubble" of security that surrounds a president. He never mentioned another possible reason, the street protests that greeted his arrival. 
At the same time, he seemed attuned to the city's efforts to come to terms with its past and the historical sensitivities that still pervade the body politic here.
"The history of our time is written in the life of Berlin," he said in his speech. "In this building, the fires of hatred were set that swept across the world," he added, in an allusion to the burning of the Reichstag on Feb. 27, 1933, an act of arson that historians now view as the symbol of the death of parliamentary democracy in Germany as Hitler's National Socialists rose to power.
At another point during the news conference, Mr. Bush used a line about Saddam Hussein that he frequently employs at home, calling him "a dictator who gassed his own people." But it was striking in the context of Berlin: Mr. Bush spoke just a mile from the gathering point where, 60 years ago, Berlin's Jews were collected for transport to the concentration camps where many of them were gassed as well.
Chancellor Schroder did not react to the comment. But at another point, the German leader, who faces a tough election fight this fall, continued to distance himself from Mr. Bush's clear willingness to use military action to unseat Mr. Hussein. With Mr. Bush standing next to him, Mr. Schroder said the world had to "exercise a lot of political pressure" to get international arms inspectors into Iraq. He urged that "we not speculate" about further action in Iraq until further consultations with the Bush administration.

HEADLINE: Pay the Victims, Protect the Church 

BYLINE:  By Dirk Olin; Dirk Olin is national editor of The American Lawyer.

 BODY:
The child sex abuse scandal that has roiled the Catholic Church for the past few months has entered a crucial stage. Lawsuits against the church have been filed in several cities, and settlement talks have collapsed in the highly publicized suits against the archdiocese of Boston over child abuse charges against John Geoghan.
 Meanwhile, Catholic dioceses around the country are facing fund-raising shortfalls: in Chicago Cardinal Francis E. George spoke of the expected cost of child abuse lawsuits this week when he proposed selling the church-owned mansion he lives in. As costs multiply, a need may soon arise for a broad framework to deal with the liability crisis in the Catholic Church. 
 Some plaintiffs' lawyers estimate that the church has already paid out as much as $1 billion in settlements during the past two decades, but even the more conservative estimate of $350 million by the United States Conference of Bishops is staggering enough.
The Catholic Church is crucial as a social services agency. Its charitable works reach into many of our poorest neighborhoods -- staffing hospitals for the indigent, schools for those whose public institutions have failed them, and soup kitchens for the homeless and destitute. Although some of those institutions are at least partially walled off from the church as legal entities, most are still dependent upon the parish for subsidies and labor.
What many of the priests did is horrific, and the tolerance or concealment of that behavior by some church leaders was callous to the point of possible criminality. But exacting punishment for those acts ought not lead to the bankruptcy of institutions on which so many communities still depend.
The financial threat looming from the lawsuits already filed and coming is enormous. Many archdiocesan insurance policies are insufficient or already tapped out. Although most of America's 194 dioceses remain solvent -- holding, as they do, significant hard assets -- they generally lack liquidity. As most parish leaders will tell you, what's collected on Sunday is usually spent on Monday. Many dioceses are also hobbled by a history of amateurish financial management. Many operate with chronic budget deficits.
One way to stave off financial collapse may be to create a victims' restitution fund -- like the one that was created for the families of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks -- that distributes available funds outside the tort system.
Since each diocese is legally autonomous, this approach might require 194 such funds. Even so, this solution -- if coupled with meaningful reforms within the church to end abuse and to report it -- could gain support among the laity and even among the victims.
Plaintiffs would be able to opt out of the fund and pursue individual lawsuits if they chose. And criminal prosecutions could, of course, still proceed. Plaintiffs' counsel and church officials would have to develop rules for administration of the pool of money, raised from insurance and other sources, that would be made available to claimants who agreed to forgo litigation. Prospective donors might well give to such a fund, knowing that it would benefit victims and protect charitable works. The victims would be able to get monetary damages without having to go through the trauma of court battles, and they would be shielded from possible church bankruptcies.
Defining eligibility would, of course, require sophisticated fact-finding. But criteria could be established that would give a reasonable administrator confidence that fraudulent claims were being eliminated. Screenings could be made highly accurate once the church opens it files so that perpetrators' records and patterns of behavior could be compared against complaints.
Though the challenge is substantial, a nonlitigation-based approach to church liability could work. Absent some such strategy, the church and the country face the prospect of mass lawsuits -- think tobacco or asbestos -- stretching from here to the distant future.

HEADLINE: Cash Aside, Is That Prize Meaningful? 

BYLINE:  By WARREN ST. JOHN 

 BODY:
Danny Hillis was sitting at his desk in Los Angeles when he got a telephone call with big news. Mr. Hillis, a computer designer and the chairman of the technology company Applied Minds, had been nominated for something called the Dan David prize. His qualification: nothing less than contributing "to the improvement of the world."
 There was just one problem with the award. "I'd never heard of it," Mr. Hillis said. 
 Suspecting a hoax, Mr. Hillis logged on to the Internet to do a little research. What he found startled him. Not only did a Dan David prize exist, but it was also endowed with $100 million from a Romanian-born photo booth entrepreneur and is to be administered by Tel Aviv University with a grandiose, dignitary-jammed award ceremony tomorrow. The award committee included Henry A. Kissinger and Klaus Schwab, the founder of the World Economic Forum. 
And then there was the prize money: $1 million.
"I was like, wow," Mr. Hillis said.
The Dan David prize is only one among a surprising number of little-known big-money awards established in the last few years by wealthy individuals and foundations vying to be the next Nobel or Pulitzer. The number of international awards over $100,000 has shot up to 100 from about 25 in 1990, says Larry Tise, the president of the International Congress of Distinguished Awards. 
Yet as big-money honors multiply, people in philanthropy have begun to question whether the large awards are an efficient use of resources or simply elaborate marketing gimmicks that siphon funds and energy from serious philanthropic work.
"If you're talking about giving someone a million-dollar pat on the back, I don't find that an effective way of allocating charitable dollars," said Daniel Borochoff, the president of the American Institute of Philanthropy, a group that advises philanthropists. "There's a lot of waste there."
But in doing the crude mathematics of the publicity game, many prize administrators have realized what state lotteries learned a long time ago: the bigger the jackpot, the more coverage it gets. 
"There's a wow factor to an award that has a big amount of money attached to it," said Charles Overby, the chairman of the Freedom Forum, which two years ago named Elian Gonzalez the recipient of its $1 million "Free Spirit Award." Since paying the money to Elian, a Cuban, was illegal, it gave the funds to a charity that supported child refugees -- but not before The Associated Press noted the audaciousness of the selection.
Like the Nobels, some of the new prizes are carefully thought out to reward research in specific disciplines. Last year, Morris Silverman, a New York City businessman who made a fortune in mini-storage, financed the $1 million Albany Medical Center prize to spur medical research. The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation's annual million-dollar prize honors work on global health. The Crown Prince of Dubai endowed the $1 million Zayed Environmental Prize. Then there's the $250,000 William E. Simon Awards for philanthropy, and the $150,000 Peter Gruber Awards for cosmology, genetics and justice.
Other awards are bafflingly vague. The Freedom Forum's Free Spirit Award honors individuals who have "demonstrated an abundance of free spirit." (One of this year's winners was Chuck Yaeger, the legendary test pilot). The Cato Institute's $500,000 Milton Friedman Award, named for the Nobel laureate in economics, is given for nothing more specific than "advancing liberty."
There's no sign of a letup. Mr. Gruber, a financier who started his prizes two years ago to honor, as he put it, "certain disciplines that had not been recognized," is considering new prizes in areas like women's rights.
The prize-giving mania is relatively new. "In the 19th century, it was much more common for recipients to mock prizes and decline them," said James English, an English professor at the University of Pennsylvania, who is writing a book about awards. Prizes were once seen, he said, "as a kind of collective embarrassment."
Now, no matter whether people complain that there are too many prizes, Mr. English said: "Well, there are going to be more. Any field that does not yet have a Nobel attached to it, someone is trying to establish one."
The criticisms of the new awards in the philanthropic world are as varied as the awards themselves. Since prize money is taxed as ordinary income, critics point out, sometimes as much as 40 percent of the award goes directly to government coffers. Nominees are often people, like Mr. Hillis, who don't need the money. And while some prizes, like the MacArthur "genius" grants, often reward work by people in the middle of their careers, many others are given to people whose work is mostly behind them.
"I call them foot-in-the-grave awards," said Pablo Eisenberg, a senior fellow at Georgetown University's Public Policy Institute. "I would rather see awards given at a more crucial time in a person's career." 
Even some prizewinners admit to feeling uncomfortable about their awards. "A prize is an inherently unfair thing," said James Peebles, the Albert Einstein Professor of Science Emeritus at Princeton University and the winner in 2000 of the Peter Gruber Award for cosmology. "I don't know that anyone works in isolation." 
Awards are proliferating largely because they do so much for so many. Recipients like the recognition, and of course, the money. Donors often like the reflected glory, which essentially rebrands a family name. Alfred Nobel is associated less with the source of his fortune -- dynamite -- than with scientific and literary accomplishment, and peace.
"The arrangement bestows a certain prestige on the recipient but reflects back on the name of the donor," Mr. English said. 
To be taken seriously, new prizes need the cooperation of distinguished judges -- or even better, an affiliation with an established academic institution. 
Institutions are quick to grasp the public relations benefits of playing host to awards ceremonies. When Dan David approached Tel Aviv University about administering his prize, the school accepted quickly. "It didn't take me long to say yes," said Itamar Rabinovich, the president of the school. "I saw the huge potential. The million dollars makes a particular statement."
Meanwhile, to keep up with their well-financed competition, established awards are increasing their payments. The Charles Stark Draper Prize in engineering, established in 1988 and administered by the National Academy of Engineering, increased its award to $500,000 in 1999, from $300,000. And the Tyler Environmental Prize, established in 1973 and administered by the University of Southern California, recently doubled its award to $200,000. The Templeton Foundation calculates the payment for its religion prize by adding a few thousand dollars to the payout of the Nobels, which varies annually depending on fluctuations in the value of the Nobel endowment.
Once an organization starts giving out awards, it can only hope the public takes an interest. "You'd like it to be the front page of the national news," said David Boaz, the executive vice president of the Cato Institute. "There's an element of suspense, not that the whole world is waiting, but a few people are waiting and hopefully, over time, more people will be waiting."
At least a few prizes have taken steps to combat the criticism that they are inefficient in the use of funds. The Dan David Prize requires winners to give 10 percent of their prize money, or $100,000, to finance the work of younger scholars. And some prizewinners give their prize money to foundations to support research in their fields. The generosity has a curious effect; some of these newly endowed foundations quickly set up new prizes.
It could be that the glut of large-money prizes is simply a reflection of a broader wave of award-giving in the American culture. Jim Weir of the Awards and Recognition Association in Chicago says the United States is on a kind of prize-giving binge. Corporate awards are growing at 20 percent a year. Even Mr. Weir's organization gives an annual award. For the best award.
A week after that call from the Dan David Prize, Mr. Hillis, 45, got another call to tell him he had won. Now, he is in Tel Aviv to pick up his award, and his check.
"I give a speech and wear a tuxedo," he said. "Or something like that."

HEADLINE: Fortunate Lives and Late-Blooming Fears 

BYLINE:  By Marshall I. Goldman; Marshall Goldman, a 1952 graduate of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, went on to become a professor of economics at Wellesley College.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
May is the season not only for commencements but also for reunions. And just as commencements are a time to look forward, reunions are a time to look back. My undergraduate classmates and I did that at our 50th reunion at the University of Pennsylvania a few days ago.
 What a momentous half-century this has been. In 1952, cold war tension was in the air, and many of us faced the draft. There were not many who foresaw that today the Soviet Union would be no more, China would be toying with free markets and South Korea -- then a war zone -- would be an advanced industrial nation. 
 I wanted to know how my classmates had changed as so much went on around them, so I organized a survey. Nearly 500 of my classmates completed it. In a world that often surprises us, we've done a pretty good job of adapting.
In 1952, 54 percent of these 500 classmates smoked; today only 5 percent do. Almost none of us worried about our diets then; today almost all do, and for good reason. As a group we now are more than three tons heavier than we were 50 years ago; one classmate acknowledges a gain of more than 100 pounds.
Of course we have acquired children. Those who answered the questionnaire reported that collectively they have been parents to 1,300 children who in turn have spawned 1,900 grandchildren. One alumnus is far ahead: he is responsible for 54 of our 87 great-grandchildren.
We seem to have been spared much of the upheaval that has affected more recent graduating classes. Only 7 percent of us have been divorced (although one member boasted that he has had five marriages and is now looking for his sixth partner -- preferably someone much younger than he). Seventy-five percent of us married only once, and a surprisingly large number volunteered that they placed their marriages among their proudest achievements.
We also distinguished ourselves from more recent graduates by the fact that 64 percent served in the military, primarily because of the draft and the Korean War. (The proportion might have been much lower if Penn had been fully coeducational then, as it is today; for the most part, women in our class were admitted only to the school of nursing and the relatively small college for women.)
Only 20 of us, or 4 percent, acknowledged ever having used drugs, including marijuana. However, 77 percent drank alcoholic beverages then, and the same percentage do today. Those who drink less today now slightly exceed those who drink more.
Financially we did very well. Only 2 percent reported finances were a matter of concern. In contrast, 12 percent reported they had a net worth of $5 million or more and another 38 percent had accumulated between $1 million and $5 million. An unusually large number started their own businesses.
Yet despite our wealth, only 9 percent of us contribute $25,000 or more each year to charity.
While the emphasis was on the past, the survey also asked about the future. Not surprisingly, now that we are in our 70's, almost a third of the classmates reported that their biggest concern for the future was their health (a few expressed their appreciation for Viagra).
But health was not the only worry. Another third of the class said terrorism had become their biggest concern, as well as their children's. The class of 1952 was not part of the "greatest generation" -- we were too young to have seen the battlefields of World War II. We were spared the campus upheaval brought on by the war in Vietnam. But it would be fair to say we were the first cold war generation, having come into adulthood with nuclear war and all its implications fully part of our lives. Now for many of us, terrorism seems as threatening, if not more threatening, than the cold war was 50 years ago.

HEADLINE: A Learning Curve for Whittle Venture 

BYLINE:  By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
H. Christopher Whittle, the 54-year-old founder and chief executive of Edison Schools, sat in his stylishly simple Midtown Manhattan office and pondered what his critics have said about him. That he is extravagant. That he exaggerates reality. That he promises more than he can deliver.
 Maybe in the past, allowed Mr. Whittle, a small, casually elegant man with a lopsided grin. But not at Edison, his favorite brainchild and the nation's largest commercial manager of public schools. Here, he said, executives fly coach or pay the difference themselves. And his own salary is just $1 a year, plus stock options. 
 But others see deja vu in Mr. Whittle's stewardship of Edison, whose plan to take over 20 failing schools in Philadelphia this summer has made it a lightning rod in the stormy national debate over school reform. 
Just as he promised more growth than he delivered a decade ago at Channel One, the controversial in-school television news network he once owned, Mr. Whittle last fall led Wall Street to expect Edison to get far more new schools to manage in the coming year than it did.
And just as there were complaints in 1994 about incorrect accounting and unpaid taxes at his earlier media empire, Whittle Communications, Mr. Whittle said last week that Edison had settled a regulatory complaint about its reporting of revenue.
Also, with Edison's overhead consuming a very high 17.3 percent of revenues last year, several investment bankers who have studied Edison's books see echoes of the spending habits that led Mr. Whittle to build a lavish headquarters in Knoxville, just as Whittle Communications was faltering. And once again, those bankers said, Mr. Whittle has surrounded himself with smart, talented people who do not know enough about business and finance to keep Edison out of trouble.
This time, however, more than just Mr. Whittle's personal reputation is at stake, said Thomas Toch, a writer at the National Center on Education and the Economy in Washington who is working on a book about education reform.
Mr. Whittle has become the standard-bearer for people who believe that private-sector management can transform America's public schools, Mr. Toch said, and Edison's ambitious effort in Philadelphia is being widely watched on all sides of the school reform debate. While Mr. Toch said he believed that a marketplace of educational options was inevitable, he said he feared that an Edison failure in Philadelphia "would put the movement back two decades."
Mr. Whittle, who seemed upbeat in a recent interview even after just completing an overnight flight from Los Angeles, explained that Edison, with its public stockholders, is a different world from the private companies he ran in the past -- a world requiring new skills that he is still trying to master.
At his private companies, he said, he would deliberately set goals that were out of reach to inspire extra effort. "But public markets are wired differently," Mr. Whittle said, natty in his signature bow tie and navy sweater vest. "There, the idea is 'under-promise, over-deliver.' " He added, "I had difficulty in that segue."
That difficulty, he acknowledged, is partly to blame for the fact that Edison's stock has plummeted -- it closed last night at $1.26, down 94 percent this year -- just as it needs to raise up to $50 million to finance its expansion this summer in Philadelphia and elsewhere.
But Mr. Whittle seemed undaunted, pointing out that Edison has already defied early skeptics by becoming one of the 50 largest school systems in the country, with about 75,000 students in 22 states. "How many times has this company been declared dead?" he asked rhetorically, a favorite conversational tic. "Multiple times."
Almost as many times as Mr. Whittle himself has been prematurely declared defeated.
"I have a pretty good track record on raising capital," he said, in a voice that still has the soft twang of his native Tennessee. "And my critics would have difficulty establishing that I am not a good crisis manager. I've been through my share."
His business career began in 1968, when he was a student at the University of Tennessee. With a few classmates, including Philip Moffitt, he hatched "Knoxville in a Nutshell," an ad-filled campus guide for incoming freshmen. A decade later, after a constant high-wire scramble for capital, it had grown into the 13-30 Corporation, which offered a host of ingenious media options to advertisers trying to reach under-30 consumers.
The young company hit the national scene with a noisy splash in 1979, when Mr. Whittle and Mr. Moffitt bought Esquire Magazine, a financial invalid which had long been a showcase for America's best editors and writers.
"We were convinced that we could have this thing upright within six months," Mr. Whittle recalled. "But within 90 to 120 days, all of our capital was gone. We had no idea how fast this boat was going down."
But with skeptics ready to gloat, Mr. Whittle helped persuade Esquire's former owner, Associated Newspapers in London, to chip in fresh capital. Mr. Moffitt deftly handled a lively stable of talented young writers, and Esquire was eventually put back on its feet.
In 1986, Mr. Whittle and Mr. Moffitt parted company, dividing their media empire. Mr. Moffitt took Esquire, and in 1987 sold it to the Hearst Corporation. Mr. Whittle took the rest of 13-30, including its popular student publications, and renamed it Whittle Communications.
On his own, Mr. Whittle displayed both his widely acknowledged gifts (salesmanship and fresh ideas) and his self-confessed shortcomings (an appetite for more growth than he can handle, a habit of reaching well beyond his grasp).
In 1989, he unveiled Channel One, and landed in a blistering controversy that prompted California and New York effectively to ban the network from their schools. But Mr. Whittle was able to keep Channel One alive in the face of all opposition, he said.
In 1991, Mr. Whittle introduced what he still calls "my best and most important idea" -- the Edison Project, first envisioned as a chain of private schools across the country. A year later, he recruited Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the president of Yale University, to run Edison, and invested millions in the concept.
Whittle Communications, meanwhile, was falling apart. Mr. Whittle, who was living a princely life as chief executive, had recruited talented but expensive people with little business experience, and his company was losing money at a pace that his investors found alarming.
The backers rebelled in 1994, removing him as chief executive and insisting that the company -- corporate jets, lavish furnishings and palatial headquarters -- be liquidated. Almost all that Mr. Whittle personally salvaged was his stake in Edison, in which he remains a substantial investor.
As Whittle Communications was being dismembered and sold, investment advisers discovered the company had not paid personal property taxes on its Channel One equipment in numerous states, and had used a disputed accounting treatment for some advertising revenue. These problems were exposed in a scathing profile of Mr. Whittle in The New Yorker in October 1994, just as Edison was trying to raise money. A mudbath of unflattering publicity followed.
The headlines made Mr. Whittle a liability for Edison, he said, and his role was sharply curtailed. Reporters who interviewed Mr. Schmidt, Edison's chief executive, in those years got the impression that Mr. Whittle was only vaguely involved.
In fact, according to Edison veterans, Mr. Whittle refused to go away. He sold parts of his own art collection and real estate -- including a sumptuous apartment in the fabled Dakota in Manhattan -- to help finance Edison. In 1998, Mr. Schmidt became chairman, and Mr. Whittle replaced him as chief executive.
Mr. Schmidt says that Mr. Whittle's performance since then shows that he is not the lavish spender he was in 1994. "I knew Chris then, and I know Chris now, and I can tell you, Chris is very smart and he learned a lot," he said.
Besides Mr. Schmidt, other nationally known educators were drawn to Edison by Mr. Whittle, including John E. Chubb, a fellow at both the Brookings Institution and the Hoover Institution at Stanford University and a leading intellectual architect of the charter-school movement. This team says Edison has raised test scores at more than three-fourths of the public schools that it manages.
But on the business side of Edison, Mr. Whittle has once again assembled a creative but financially inexperienced management team that mirrors his own strengths far more than it compensates for his demonstrated failings at things like careful cash-flow analysis. Almost none of his recruits have much, if any, comparable experience at other big companies -- a fact he said he finds unimportant, given the talent and commitment he sees in his staff.
Edison sold stock to the public in late 1999, and the company exceeded analysts' expectations in 2000. But since then, it has fallen short of Mr. Whittle's forecasts. Some investment bankers who have studied Edison say that Mr. Whittle stubbornly failed to heed warnings that profits could not be endlessly postponed without risking a loss of investor confidence.
And then there was Philadelphia.
Gov. Tom Ridge had publicly embraced Mr. Whittle, indicating that Edison would be given dozens of troubled schools to manage. But Mr. Ridge's departure for Washington after the Sept. 11 attacks cost Mr. Whittle an important ally. Public opposition caused further delays -- during which Edison was confronted with questions from the Securities and Exchange Commission about its accounting.
That dispute was settled last week, with Edison promising to improve its internal audit procedures -- a step Mr. Whittle says was already in the works -- and to revise its reported revenue to reflect expenses that are paid on its behalf by its school district clients.
But the S.E.C. matter delayed Edison's plans to raise more money by selling additional shares of stock to the public this spring. And by the time the dispute was settled, the 94 percent fall in Edison's stock price made a public share sale extremely unlikely.
"And you're right," Mr. Whittle said recently. "If we can't finance Philadelphia, we can't do Philadelphia."
His supporters are confident that he will, once again, scramble up the cliff with a fresh supply of cash for his beloved brainchild. He has promised to do so "within weeks," and at a news conference Thursday he said that five potential outside investors were now in serious discussions with the company.
"My expectation is that Chris will be able to raise capital -- and he deserves the capital, in my opinion," said John W. Childs, president of J. W. Childs Associates, a private equity firm in Boston and an early investor in Edison. Mr. Childs, who served on Edison's board until last August, said he thought that Edison's schools were good and its chosen market enormous.
Mr. Childs more than recouped his investment in Edison by selling some of his shares last March at $24.56, many times the $3.40 he paid. Those who bought those shares might not be as hopeful, he acknowledged.
"But if you had bought them from me, I'd counsel you to hold them," he said. "I think the company has plenty of potential."

HEADLINE: Religion Journal; 
A Big Wedding With a Smaller Bill

BYLINE:  By FRANCINE PARNES 

 BODY:
As Rabbi Heshie Hirth of Passaic, N.J., prepares to marry off a daughter this summer, his list of things to do has a novel counterpart: things not to do. That is because he is following guidelines adopted by Orthodox rabbinical authorities to curtail extravagant spending on weddings.
 At what is known as a "guidelines wedding," Rabbi Hirth will use a one-man band, and the music will be spiritual. The cost of decorations -- including flowers, centerpieces, fruit baskets and the bridal canopy -- may not exceed $1,800. Centerpieces are limited to tables for women, who according to tradition sit apart from men. The guidelines also eliminate meat-carving stations; banquet tables displaying desserts; and bars, although wine and liquor may be placed on guests' tables. 
 Under the guidelines, the wedding dinner may not exceed 400 guests, plus children, although additional guests may attend the nondinner portion. For very large families, up to 500 dinner guests are allowed. These numbers may seem generous, but against the backdrop of Jewish weddings with many hundreds of guests and cost $35,000 or more, they represent significant benchmarks.
"I want to fit within the guidelines to make the point that we have to live within our community, within our means," said Rabbi Hirth, dean of a yeshiva where the wedding will be held. "People come to see me in school and say if I am going to make a wedding within guidelines, they will do the same for their daughter."
Without specifying a maximum price, the guidelines seek to preserve family budgets and Jewish ideals.
"A primary goal is to replace $35,000 weddings with $20,000 weddings," said Shia Markowitz, of Monsey, N.Y., who did some of the research that underlies the guidelines.
"We've said: 'People, stop. Stop the peer pressure to create more lavish weddings that cost many thousands of dollars more,' " Mr. Markowitz said, citing showy smorgasbords, orchestras and ice sculptures.
The average wedding in the New York metropolitan area costs nearly $32,000, said Millie Martini Bratten, editor of Bride's Magazine. But expenses multiply in Mr. Markowitz's community of very traditional Orthodox Jews, known as haredim.
"Each family, depending on size, might have to make a wedding six, seven, eight times or more," he said, adding that many families have 10 children or more. 
"People are taking out second and third mortgages on their homes," he said. "One acquaintance went $100,000 in debt after making several weddings."
Chaim Waxman, a sociology professor at Rutgers University who specializes in Jewish studies, said: "Haredi Jews place tremendous emphasis on children, and the marriage of their children is a highlight of one's life. So one spends as much as one can and invites as many people as possible, because, after all, 'They're my community.' "
Extensive family and social networks can lead to Orthodox weddings that draw as many as 1,000 people, Professor Waxman added.
Jewish publications advertise the guidelines, with emblems to attach to invitations. With exceptions, rabbis who have signed the guidelines will not attend nonguideline weddings.
The guidelines could affect tens of thousands of Jews in New York and New Jersey, Professor Waxman said. Nearly two dozen rabbis have signed the guidelines, led by Rabbi Yaakov Perlow, head of the influential Orthodox organization Agudath Israel of America. Introduced at Agudath Israel's convention last November, the guidelines took effect in mid-March. Other regions were encouraged to adopt guidelines.
"I'm sure the guidelines will take effect in the entire country," said Rabbi Shmuel Kamenetsky, a signer from Philadelphia. "New York sets the tone, and it carries over from Philadelphia to Chicago to Los Angeles. The rabbis in each city will make their own rules."
In Los Angeles, David Altschuler, a financial adviser, liked what he read about the guidelines in a Jewish newspaper and is applying them to his daughter's June wedding.
"These guidelines are useful no matter where you are," Mr. Altschuler said. "Why look like you are trying to show off? It's not a nice thing anytime, Jewish or not."
The guidelines also limit engagement parties and encourage belt-tightening at other occasions.
"The signers felt that weddings were the most important topic to take on," said Rabbi Avi Shafran, an Agudath Israel spokesman. "If the response is good, they can suggest particular cutbacks for bar mitzvahs and other celebrations."
The rationale for the guidelines, Rabbi Shafran added, is not only social and economic but also religious. "The concept of modesty, not only in dress but in behavior and expression, is central to the Torah," he said. "Limiting excess, whether in general lifestyle or celebrations, is an inherently Jewish ideal."
Yaakov Salomon, a Flatbush psychotherapist, has already attended a wedding that followed the guidelines. He said he was not insulted that he was invited only to the ceremony.
"I was pleased that my friend felt comfortable enough to say the buck stops here," Mr. Salomon said. "When I met him at the wedding, I half-jokingly said, 'Thank you for not inviting me.' He replied in kind, 'It was my pleasure.' We danced, we embraced, and it was beautiful. I plan to do the same with him at my next child's wedding."
Steven Kohn, who owns the Atrium Plaza, a catering hall in Monsey mainly for Orthodox weddings, said the guidelines eliminated pressure on middle-class families to put on elaborate weddings. "But it would be better for rabbis to educate people to be content with what they have and not to be jealous," he said. "This would solve the root of the problem."
It is too soon to tell how demand for guideline weddings will affect the catering industry. Still, Mr. Kohn said: "You know what happens -- 5 people do it, then 10. Now people will keep up with the Joneses by making a cheaper wedding. They will say, 'If it's good enough for him, it's good enough for me.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Steven Kohn, who owns the Atrium Plaza, a catering hall in Monsey, N.Y., said wedding guidelines being promulgated by Orthodox rabbis could ease financial pressure on middle-class Jewish families. (Richard L. Harbus for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Council Appears to Accept Defeat Of Plan to Raise Taxes This Year 

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
City Council members are beginning to concede privately that they have all but lost the fight to raise taxes this year, even as they maneuver to stake out a negotiating position with the Bloomberg administration over the budget.
 A central disagreement between the Bloomberg administration and the Council in the efforts to make up for a projected deficit of nearly $5 billion for the fiscal year that begins on July 1 has been over whether or not to increase revenue by raising taxes. 
 Mr. Bloomberg has consistently stuck to his position that Albany will not approve tax hikes in an election year, while Council members argue that taxes are necessary to prevent harsh reductions in critical services that they say New Yorkers are unlikely to tolerate. 
The Council had proposed an assortment of taxes, including a surcharge on the personal income tax, restoration of the commuter tax, a higher property tax on absentee landlords and higher taxes on beer, wine and liquor. Under the Council's scenario, the additional revenue, estimated at nearly $1 billion, would help prevent the need to cut programs and projects in areas like education, social services, parks and libraries.
But state legislators will not approve the new taxes unless both sides of City Hall agree that they want them, and there is a growing sense within the Council that with the exception of a huge increase in the cigarette tax, the mayor will not support any new levies until after the November election.
Bill Perkins, the Council's deputy majority leader, said that while council members were still digging in their heels on their proposals, he had "a high degree of hope that in December, after the election, the mayor will see the light and join us, having protected the governor in this election cycle, to try to get the revenues that are going to be necessary, in essentially the manner that we proposed."
Edward Skyler, Mr. Bloomberg's chief spokesman, said that the mayor's position was that now is a terrible time to raise taxes, because doing so would drive away businesses as the city struggles to recover from the effects of Sept. 11 and a sour economy.
But a council member, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that he had heard Mr. Bloomberg say that asking for politically unpopular tax increases now, in an election year, would use up all his good will in Albany, since the city would only have to ask later.
In the meantime, as the Council members continue a public campaign in their districts to increase education spending, their attention has turned in earnest to the grueling task of looking for cuts.
Last Saturday, at the behest of Speaker Gifford Miller, the entire Council broke up into borough delegations and combed over approximately $700 million that they had proposed restoring to the mayor's preliminary budget, with the assignment to reduce those restorations by $200 million. They then spent Sunday looking for alternative cuts to help offset the remaining proposed restorations. Officials from the Council's finance division then sorted through those suggestions and compiled a consensus proposal of sorts.
But yesterday, Mr. Miller gathered the Democratic caucus and told them the administration had proposed restoring only about $40 million of the $700 million or so the Council was originally seeking.
Mr. Skyler would say only, "It's premature to discuss possible restoration numbers until there's agreement on what resources are available." 
But how much money the city may get with Albany's help remains up in the air, apparently locked in a web of negotiations not only over the city's budget but also over school governance and an assortment of other issues.
Lawmakers in Albany have not yet introduced legislation that would grant the city the authority to raise the cigarette tax, saying that they are waiting for the Council to signal that it has reached an agreement with Mr. Bloomberg on what to ask of the state.
Council members are now saying that they are withholding their approval of Mr. Bloomberg's tax proposal, using it as a lever in negotiations with the mayor.
For his part, Mr. Miller said yesterday that the Council would consider any bills drafted by Albany. As for the ongoing negotiations with the mayor, Mr. Miller said the Council has various options.
One of the Council's options is passing a budget of its own over the mayor's objections, which some members say may be necessary.
"I think that the mayor is underestimating the resolve of the City Council," said James Sanders Jr. of Queens. "And I would urge him to use back-door communications if he isn't already, because we are really coming to a crisis here."
Mr. Perkins, who remembers when the Council passed its own budget during the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, said, "Ultimately the administration has the prerogative for spending the money, and so we obviously are cautionary."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Federal Court Ruling Is Victory for Regional Bells
A federal appeals court ordered regulators to reconsider two important rules intended to spur competition in the local phone and high-speed Internet markets. The decision was a victory for the regional bell companies.
 While a defeat for the Federal Communications Commission, which was the defendant, the decision was a political victory for its chairman, Michael K. Powell, above, who has expressed skepticism about the rules. Page C3. 

Lehman Drops Its Bid for Tyco Unit
In a development that further complicates matters for Tyco International, Lehman Brothers Holdings, one of the company's advisers, bid about $5 billion in cash for Tyco's CIT finance unit but then withdrew the offer, executives close to the negotiations said. C4.

Mixed Reaction to US Airways Cuts
The largest US Airways unions left the first round of talks on $950 million in proposed nonmanagement cuts with mixed reactions to the demands. The airline needs the reductions to apply for a federal loan guarantee. C4.

Deal for Miller Brewing Draws Near
South African Breweries is close to clinching a deal to acquire a majority stake in Miller Brewing from the Philip Morris Companies for about $5 billion in cash and stock, people close to the companies said. C2.

Economic Growth Is Revised Down
In its first revision to the gross domestic product, the government said the economy grew at an annual rate of 5.6 percent, down from 5.8 percent reported a month ago. C2.

The French economy grew 0.4 percent in the first quarter of 2002. C2.

Chief of Energy Trader Resigns
William T. McCormick Jr., 57, the chairman and chief executive of CMS Energy, announced his resignation, less than two weeks after the company admitted conducting energy trades that artificially inflated its revenue by more than $4.4 billion. C3.

Richard D. Parsons made his first significant personnel moves as AOL Time Warner's new chief executive. C14.

Oil Prices Fall on Energy Pact
President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin agreed to begin what Mr. Bush called a "major new energy partnership," with more American investment in Russia's oil and gas industry and faster ways for its products to reach world markets. The news sent oil prices down 27 cents, or 1 percent, to $25.88 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. C2.

Japan Banks Move Toward Recovery
After years of losses, deregulation and realignment, Japan's four big banking groups are now being forced to abandon their one-size-fits-all business model and start differentiating themselves to revive their sagging fortunes. C2.

Cooper Tire Settles Accident Suit
Cooper Tire and Rubber has settled a lawsuit over a 1998 auto accident that killed four people and seriously injured two others. The amount of the settlement, which was reached late Thursday, was not disclosed, but Cooper said it would be covered by insurance. C4.

Shares Fall in Lightest Trading Day
In the lightest trading day so far this year, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 111.82 points, or 1.09 percent, to 10,104.26, and the Nasdaq composite dropped 36.14 points, or 2.13 percent, to 1,661.49. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gave up 13.26 points, or 1.21 percent, to 1,083.82. C4.

Markets Closed Memorial Day
United States financial markets, government offices and banks will be closed on Monday in observance of Memorial Day. Financial markets will be open in other countries.

HEADLINE: Colorado's Rain and Snow Ease Fire, but Not Drought 

BYLINE:  By NICK MADIGAN 

DATELINE: DECKERS, Colo., May 24 

 BODY:
Rain and snow, rare visitors to drought-stricken Colorado, tamed a scorching wildfire today in the Pike National Forest, but did little to quell apprehension about the effects of severe drought here and in many parts of the West this summer.
 "Something like this helps, but it's a drop in the bucket," said Makoto Moore, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service who was assigned to the team managing the firefighting here in the depths of the million-acre forest. "We need a prolonged period of cool and wet weather." 
 If the past few months are any indication, such relief does not seem likely soon. What little snow there was on the state's many mountain peaks melted this winter two months ahead of schedule, leaving reservoirs and waterways -- including the Colorado River -- at depths far lower than usual. Coupled with an almost total lack of rain, the shortfall has forced cities, counties and communities to restrict water use, worried whether their reserves will hold out. 
With water for irrigation at a premium, ranchers have begun to auction off livestock to owners of more bountiful pasturelands elsewhere. Recreational fishing, a bastion of Colorado's economy, is headed for a severe downturn as aquatic habitats become gradually sparser. 
At least 35 of Colorado's 64 counties have issued outdoor fire bans, in what may be the state's worst drought in 60 years. Elsewhere, the situation is no better. Wyoming, California, Utah and Montana, as well as Colorado, need more than seven inches of rain to end the drought, experts estimate. 
The lack of rain has drastically affected wheat-growing areas of Kansas and Nebraska, and there is none in the forecast. Dust storms that caused the deaths of two motorists in Lincoln, Neb., on Wednesday prompted officials there to advise drivers to stay off highways on windy days.
On Thursday, livestock farmers urged the Senate Agriculture Committee to provide $500 million in disaster assistance to drought-stricken areas. In New Mexico, a forest fire that has burned more than 4,000 acres in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains north of Santa Fe continued to rage today. Major fires have also hit Arizona.
"The effects of the drought have been more drastic than I originally thought," said Ned Williams, utilities director for Boulder. Its City Council on Tuesday ordered, among other things, that lawns be watered no more than twice a week, and no more than 15 minutes in one spot. Violators face fines or jail. One of the city's public pools will remain closed for the summer.
"The drought is real and the quantity of our water supply is fixed and limited, and has never been at this low a level," Mr. Williams told the council.
In Lafayette, 10 miles east of Boulder, residents may not use a hose to wash cars, and pools may be filled only with the city's permission. In the 31 parks of the Denver Mountain Parks system, officials have banned everything that produces an open flame, like smoking, campfires, fireworks and welding torches. In Denver itself, officials have recommended limits on water use but have not made them mandatory. 
It is in the threat of fires that the drought reveals its greatest impact. Even as the Pike forest fire here, 60 miles southwest of Denver, weakened this morning, two new wildfires sprang to life west of Colorado Springs -- one of them caused by a power line felled by snow and wind.
"The moisture that we've gotten hasn't been around long enough to relieve the fire danger," said Richard Homann, fire division supervisor for the Colorado Forest Service. "We're seeing much more fire activity than in previous years. It's even ahead of the 2000 fire season, which was bad throughout the West. If we keep on the same pace, it will be one of the top five fire seasons in Colorado."
Colorado's fire season, which usually begins in mid-June, sprang to life on April 23, when the so-called Snaking Fire burned 3,000 acres northwest of Bailey. On May 5, the Black Mountain Fire near Evergreen forced the evacuation of 1,700 homes. This week, two major fires erupted near Nucla and Durango.
Even the relatively dense rainfall here overnight -- and snowfall at higher elevations -- failed to satisfy fire officials, who ordered more than 600 firefighters from a half-dozen states back to work this morning on the steep slopes of the Pike Forest.
The fire, which officials said they believed was sparked by lightning, flared up on Tuesday near Schoonover Gulch and within hours forced the evacuation of at least 60 people, including a group of youngsters at a Y.M.C.A. camp at which several buildings were later destroyed. Altogether, about a dozen structures burned by Thursday afternoon, when the fire had cut across some 4,000 acres.
The flames came to within one-third of a mile of Deckers, an unincorporated town made up of a handful of buildings surrounded by Ponderosa pines, Douglas firs and juniper trees. In the wake of the fire, whole hills lay in a ghostly gray haze, the ground and the trees stripped of color and life. 
Along Highway 67, closed to normal traffic, the Horse Creek Cafe and Saloon survived, unlike the hills beyond it. On a dirt road leading to the Y.M.C.A. camp, all that remained of two burned vacation houses were their chimneys. At the camp, Shady Brook Ranch, a garage and two cabins were obliterated. Nearby, a crew of firefighters marched toward the hills, while a tanker truck pumped water from a pond where the children's canoes bobbed by a dock.
"It was pretty touch-and-go there for a while," said Bill Krausser, a contractor whose property at Trail Creek, 15 miles south of Deckers, was within sight of the fire on Wednesday night. 
Mr. Krausser said he got his two horses ready for loading into a trailer, and waited for the worst. As he watched, a black bear came thundering through the property, southbound.
"He was beating feet, heading away from the fire," Mr. Krausser recalled. "Animals are smarter than people, sometimes."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A firefighter working with snow's assistance yesterday on the south side of the fire lines near Deckers, Colo. (Associated Press) Map of Colorado highlighting Deckers: Colorado is on a pace to have one of its worst fire seasons ever.

HEADLINE: Vatican Accepts Resignation Of Milwaukee's Archbishop 

BYLINE:  By LAURIE GOODSTEIN 

 BODY:
The Vatican yesterday accepted the resignation of Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland of Milwaukee, who acknowledged on Thursday that he had paid $450,000 to settle a claim that he sexually assaulted a man two decades ago.
 Supporters of the archbishop, who often challenged Vatican traditionalists on abortion, sexuality and the role of women, said they were saddened that his tenure had ended in disgrace. His critics, on the other hand, were hopeful that his successor would be more attuned to orthodoxy. 
 Archbishop Weakland, now 75, was one of the few remaining bishops appointed before Pope John Paul II's reign who challenged the Curia repeatedly. In 25 years as archbishop of Milwaukee, he placed women in positions of authority in the church, criticized militants in the anti-abortion movement and testified in favor of gay rights. He is the author or co-author of more than a dozen books, on topics like Catholic social teaching, the church since the Second Vatican Council, prayer and Catholic education. 
In the 1980's, he had the stature to lead the American bishops in the drafting of their landmark pastoral letter on the economy, which called for reordering the nation's priorities to reduce poverty and inequality, reform the welfare system and assist organized labor. But his national influence waned in recent years as the conference of American bishops grew more conservative.
"Over the years he has been a pretty inspiring person to progressive Catholics, because he certainly has been an advocate for inclusion of the laity, a greater role for women in the church and for married clergy," said Sister Maureen Fiedler, a founder of the Women's Ordination Conference. "I grieve for him today, and I feel really sad that this has happened." 
Archbishop Weakland, who has denied the accusation of sexual assault but has not addressed the question of whether he had a sexual relationship with his accuser, said through a spokesman yesterday that he would issue a public apology in the future.
He has previously welcomed the attention of the news media, and in 1991 was the subject of a two-part profile in The New Yorker in which he talked about the issue of celibacy and his struggle to control infatuations with women, saying, "I'm falling in love all the time." 
"I have to be on guard not to let my emotions run away," he said then, "not to make excuses to see someone who has set off the spark. So far, I've done pretty well."
In interviews yesterday, some of the archbishop's admirers, and detractors as well, speculated that this scandal was not a case of sexual assault but more likely a consensual homosexual relationship that ended badly. They said they were bothered more by the $450,000 settlement than by the appearance that the archbishop had strayed sexually.
Even his critics -- and they are many -- who maintain that he spent his career undermining church teaching, said they felt pity for him. An anguished letter that he wrote to his accuser in 1980 was made public on Thursday, and in it he said his mother had always warned him "not to put down on paper what I would not want the whole world to read."
"It must be devastating for him to have a private letter that he paid nearly half a million dollars to be suppressed to be bandied about in public," said Helen Hull Hitchcock, director of Women for Faith and Family, a conservative Catholic organization. "Too bad he didn't mind his mama."
With the Vatican's speedy acceptance of Archbishop Weakland's retirement, his duties are being assumed for now by Richard J. Sklba (pronounced SKILL-ba), an auxiliary bishop in the archdiocese.
It is not known when a new archbishop will be named. The process starts with the pope's representative in Washington, who will forward the names of three candidates to the Congregation for Bishops in Rome. That Vatican department sends its choice, usually but not always from among those three, to the pope, who makes the ultimate decision.
Archbishop Weakland was born in Patton, Pa., near Altoona, on April 2, 1927. He became a Benedictine monk at St. Vincent Archabbey in Latrobe, Pa., in 1949. Two years later he was ordained a priest.
"He's an intellectual," said a friend of his, the Rev. Andrew Greeley, a priest and author in Chicago. "He speaks 18 or 19 languages, he's a trained musician, so he's a man of some stature. He impresses people." 
He initially intended to teach music in the Benedictine order, and studied in Europe and at the Juilliard School. At Columbia University, he began a graduate thesis on Ambrosian chant. He did not take it up again until 1996, however, when as archbishop he took a sabbatical and returned to Columbia to finish his research.
Instead of pursuing music, he showed a talent for leadership and rose to become first the abbot at St. Vincent and ultimately, in 1967, the abbot primate, or worldwide leader, of the International Benedictine Confederation. As primate, he was based in the Vatican for 10 years.
Mrs. Hitchcock, a critic of his, said she understood that he had been a thorn in the side of some at the Vatican, and eventually Pope Paul VI decided to name him an archbishop back in his native country.
"They stuck him in what was, from the Italian perspective, a remote region of the United States," Mrs. Hitchcock said.
The Milwaukee Archdiocese today is home to more than 680,000 Catholics, 234 parishes and 255 active diocesan priests.
Archbishop Weakland was popular among his priests, granting most of them unusual autonomy in their parishes. He was an early advocate of allowing girls to be altar servers, and in the 1980's he held "listening sessions" that allowed women to air their views on abortion and birth control.
That episode prompted the Vatican in 1990 to forbid the University of Fribourg in Switzerland, affiliated with the Dominican order, to grant him an honorary doctorate. 
He often tangled with traditionalists in his archdiocese. The Milwaukee chapter of Catholics United for the Faith, with 700 members, recently campaigned against his plan to renovate the Cathedral of St. John the Evangelist. The plan involved redesign of the worship space to de-emphasize the hierarchical aspects of the liturgy.
"It is dangerous to send your child to a Catholic high school or a Catholic grade school in this archdiocese," Al Szews, president of the Milwaukee chapter of Catholics United, said yesterday, "because they don't teach Catholicism. Pop psychology has replaced theology, and unfortunately you end up with individuals who are Catholic nominally but don't understand their faith. And that is the legacy of Archbishop Weakland."
In recent months, Archbishop Weakland was criticized for refusing to identify priests who had been accused of sexual abuse but found by the archdiocese not to be a threat. Victims' groups said that in the past, he had made remarks that showed he did not understand the damage that sexual abuse can cause minors.
In 1988, for instance, he told one newspaper, The Milwaukee Catholic: "Not all adolescent victims are so innocent. Some can be sexually very active and aggressive and often quite streetwise. We frequently try such adolescents for crimes as adults at that age."
But Joe W. Zopp, a lay chaplain with Dignity, an organization of gay Catholics, said yesterday that in Archbishop Weakland the group had found a "loving, caring shepherd who has allowed us to do what we need to do to experience God."
The circumstance of his resignation, Mr. Zopp said, "doesn't change our view of him, and maybe it's because of his own weaknesses that he was able to be forgiving and helpful to other people who have had failings."
"Maybe he's been less judgmental because he knows that he himself was a human being."

HEADLINE: Huge Deficit May Lead Connecticut to Borrow 

BYLINE:  By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 24 

 BODY:
Since Connecticut's legislative session ended on May 8 without a balanced budget for the next fiscal year in place, Democratic state lawmakers and Gov. John G. Rowland have had a hard time agreeing on when to sit down and resume discussing the problem, much less solving it.
 But this week, both sides agreed reluctantly on something else: that for the first time in 11 years, Connecticut will probably need to borrow money to pay off a current budget deficit approaching $800 million. 
 The current fiscal year ends on June 30; just a few months ago, the state's budget gap was a comparably small $350 million. But because of declining sales and income tax receipts and a flagging stock market, the deficit has steadily grown -- by more than $113 million in the last month alone, state officials said.
The 2003 fiscal year looks even worse. New projections by the governor's budget director put a shortfall for that year at about $850 million.
Just a few weeks ago, Mr. Rowland, a fiscally conservative Republican, was ridiculing Democrats who hold the majority in the State Legislature for considering using part of the $595 million in the state's Rainy Day Fund to close the current budget gap. Now the shortfall exceeds the fund's total assets.
Instead of short-term borrowing, Mr. Rowland's budget director, Marc S. Ryan, said on Thursday that the state could carry the deficit into the next year or sell bonds based on revenue expected from the state's share of settlement money from tobacco companies.
This is not the kind of problem Connecticut is accustomed to facing. The last time the state had to borrow money was 1991. Though other states, like New Jersey, are staring at far larger chasms in their annual budgets, Connecticut officials have spent the last several legislative sessions arguing over how much to increase, not trim, spending on education, health care and other state programs.
This year is also the first time the state has had a deficit since the early 1990's, when an economic recession led Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. to sell bonds to cover a gaping $965 million budget gap, just weeks after the Legislature adopted the income tax.

HEADLINE: Olympics Over, Salt Lake City Struggles to Save Its Downtown 

BYLINE:  By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY, May 24 

 BODY:
A hard reality has hit Salt Lake City since the flame for the Winter Olympics was extinguished.
 For a while, when athletes and tourists and reporters from all over the world jammed the wintry streets, the city had the festive feel of a place where things were happening. 
 Alas, downtown Salt Lake City is struggling and has been for some time.
Many downtown stores, especially along Main Street, are in deep trouble. Empty buildings that were spruced up and filled with souvenir shops during the Games have "For Lease" signs plastered on what are now grimy windows. 
Salt Lake City's banks, law firms, tourist attractions and hotels are holding up in its business district about as well as those in most cities, but its retail enterprises -- department stores and small shops -- are still losing customers to suburban malls and stores at a rate no downtown can long stand. In eight years, retail sales have declined more than 20 percent in downtown Salt Lake, including at the big Nordstrom department store.
Einstein Brothers Bagels, a Main Street landmark for years, closed on Wednesday, citing the economic malaise downtown.
Nordstrom, one of the nation's most successful department store chains, served notice a few weeks ago that it would pull out of downtown if it continued losing customers. The history of such departures is that other stores often follow, like tumbling dominoes.
"We've got a mighty tough challenge on our hands," Mayor Ross C. Anderson said. Nordstrom is in the Crossroads Plaza, one of two aging shopping centers on Main Street. The other, the ZCMI Center, is equally worn.
A new mall, Gateway, has sprung up a half a mile west of Main. There is some question whether the downtown can support even a spiffy mall, but not in Nordstrom's view. "We think this is the way to get our numbers back up; otherwise we're going to have to leave entirely," said Blake Nordstrom, the president of the company, which is based in Seattle. "We want to be good corporate citizens, but we can't do it in an old, tired mall with a weak mix of stores."
Major retailers like Nordstrom typically get multimillion-dollar rent write-offs and other sweeteners to move into malls because they draw customers.
Still, moving to Gateway is proving hard for Nordstrom.
It must deal with a promise, politics and as always in Utah, the Mormon church.
To win the city's permission to build Gateway, the developer, the Boyer Development Company, promised never to rent space to a department store like Nordstrom, lest that store bleed business from Main Street. Nordstrom argues that Boyer should be released from the pledge, or downtown Salt Lake City will end up with no Nordstrom at all.
Mayor Anderson and the seven-member City Council contend that a pledge is a pledge. "We can't be responsible for killing the rest of the stores on Main Street," said David L. Buhler, the council chairman. "We have to do what's best for the most people, not just one developer and one store. We all need to keep a dialogue going. But the pledge was part of the deal."
The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints agrees.
The Mormons are not religious bystanders. The church owns one of the Main Street malls, the ZCMI Center, and it owns the land under the other one, the Crossroads. The church has been involved in business for a century and a half, going back to the day Brigham Young paused with his followers at the crest of a pass leading to the Great Salt Lake and declared, "This is the place."
In that place today can be found not only the main temple and headquarters of the Mormon church, one of the world's fastest growing churches, but also a number of Mormon-owned businesses, not the least being the ZCMI Center, an insurance company and a financial firm.
The church owns a third of the business district. In some places it insists that its prohibition of alcohol and other worldly temptations be strictly observed; in other places it does not. "We are business people, too," said the church's presiding bishop, H. David Burton. "We must protect our interests."
Mr. Nordstrom said he has talked himself "blue in the face" with Salt Lake City's municipal, business and church officials in recent years, trying to get the city and the Main Street malls to bring in more upscale stores. He said his company had done all it could to improve its merchandising in Salt Lake.
Bishop Burton conceded that the church and the city might have been slow in responding to the retailing problem downtown. But he said the church was open to new ideas about how to improve the area's business, residential and entertainment mix, and he said he saw the Nordstrom warning as a great opportunity.
"We don't claim to be perfect," he said. "If we handle this crisis right, we can set the course for our city for the second century and a half."
