HEADLINE: A Treaty to 'Reduce and Limit' Warheads and a Declaration of a New Relationship 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the arms reduction treaty signed yesterday by President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin in Moscow and from a joint declaration on strategic security, as provided by the White House. The complete texts are online at nytimes.com/world.

TREATY
Article I
 Each party shall reduce and limit strategic nuclear warheads, as stated by the President of the United States of America on Nov. 13, 2001, and as stated by the President of the Russian Federation on Nov. 13, 2001, and Dec. 13, 2001, respectively, so that by Dec. 31, 2012, the aggregate number of such warheads does not exceed 1700-2200 for each party. Each party shall determine for itself the composition and structure of its strategic offensive arms, based on the established aggregate limit for the number of such warheads. 
 Article II
The parties agree that the Start Treaty remains in force in accordance with its terms. 
Article III
For purposes of implementing this treaty, the parties shall hold meetings at least twice a year of a bilateral implementation commission. 
Article IV
1. This treaty shall be subject to ratification in accordance with the constitutional procedures of each party. This treaty shall enter into force on the date of the exchange of instruments of ratification. 
2. This treaty shall remain in force until Dec. 31, 2012, and may be extended by agreement of the parties or superseded earlier by a subsequent agreement. 
3. Each party, in exercising its national sovereignty, may withdraw from this treaty upon three months written notice to the other party.

DECLARATION
We are achieving a new strategic relationship. The era in which the United States and Russia saw each other as an enemy or strategic threat has ended. . . . We recognize that the security, prosperity and future hopes of our peoples rest on a benign security environment, the advancement of political and economic freedoms and international cooperation. 
The further development of U.S.-Russian relations and the strengthening of mutual understanding and trust will also rest on a growing network of ties between our societies and peoples. We will support growing economic interaction between the business communities of our two countries and people-to-people and cultural contacts and exchanges. 
As co-sponsors of the Middle East peace process, the United States and Russia will continue to exert joint and parallel efforts, including in the framework of the "Quartet," to overcome the current crisis in the Middle East, to restart negotiations and to encourage a negotiated settlement.
Recalling our joint statement of Nov. 13, 2001, on counternarcotics cooperation, we note that illegal drug trafficking poses a threat to our peoples and to international security, and represents a substantial source of financial support for international terrorism. We are committed to intensifying cooperation against this threat, which will bolster both the security and health of the citizens of our countries.
The United States and Russia will endeavor to make use of the potential of world trade to expand the economic ties between the two countries, and to further integrate Russia into the world economy as a leading participant. . . . In this connection, the sides give high priority to Russia's accession to the World Trade Organization on standard terms. 
Success in our bilateral economic and trade relations demands that we move beyond the limitations of the past. We stress the importance and desirability of graduating Russia from the emigration provisions of the U.S. Trade Act of 1974, also known as the Jackson-Vanik Amendment. We note that the Department of Commerce, based on its ongoing thorough and deliberative inquiry, expects to make its final decision no later than June 14, 2002, on whether Russia should be treated as a market economy under the provisions of U.S. trade law. The sides will take further practical steps to eliminate obstacles and barriers, including as appropriate in the legislative area, to strengthen economic cooperation.
The United States and Russia acknowledge the great potential for expanding bilateral trade and investment, which would bring significant benefits to both of our economies. . . . We also welcome the opportunity to intensify cooperation in energy exploration and development, especially in oil and gas, including in the Caspian region.
Battling the scourge of H.I.V./AIDS and other deadly diseases, ending family violence, protecting the environment and defending the rights of women are areas where U.S. and Russian institutions, and especially nongovernmental organizations, can successfully expand their cooperation.
The United States and Russia recognize the profound importance of preventing the spread of weapons of mass destruction and missiles. The specter that such weapons could fall into the hands of terrorists and those who support them illustrates the priority all nations must give to combating proliferation.
In that regard, we will establish joint expert groups to investigate means of increasing the amount of weapons-usable fissile material to be eliminated, and to recommend collaborative research and development efforts on advanced, proliferation-resistant nuclear reactor and fuel cycle technologies. We also intend to intensify our cooperation concerning destruction of chemical weapons.
The United States and Russia call on all countries to strengthen and strictly enforce export controls, interdict illegal transfers, prosecute violators and tighten border controls to prevent and protect against proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. 
The United States and Russia agree that a new strategic relationship between the two countries, based on the principles of mutual security, trust, openness, cooperation and predictability, requires substantive consultation across a broad range of international security issues. To that end we have decided to establish a consultative group for strategic security to be chaired by foreign ministers and defense ministers with the participation of other senior officials.

HEADLINE: TRACES OF TERROR: THE LEGISLATION; 
After Spate of Political Sparring, House Approves an Emergency Spending Bill

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24 

 BODY:
After two days of fierce political sparring, the House early this morning approved a $29 billion emergency spending bill to pay for military operations, domestic security and aid to New York City.
 House Republican leaders pushed the legislation to passage just before 3 a.m., determined to be able to showcase on Memorial Day a vote to support President Bush and the nation's military and counterterrorism operations. 
 The 230-to-138 vote showed wide support for legislation that contains money for military operations in Afghanistan, stepped up intelligence operations, airline security, aid to Israel and the Palestinians and $5.5 billion for New York's recovery efforts.
Still, more than half of the House's Democrats voted against the measure, primarily because Republican leaders slipped in language preparing the way for an increase on the $5.9 trillion ceiling on federal borrowing, avoiding a politically painful direct vote on the issue. The language would allow an increase in the debt ceiling to be included in the final agreement with the Senate on an antiterrorism package. 
The House vote sets up a confrontation with the Senate, which is to consider a more expensive $31 billion version of the bill after the Memorial Day recess. 
President Bush said in a statement today: "I expect the Senate to only spend on what is necessary to fight the war and for our immediate emergency needs. With our nation now at war, now is not the time for unnecessary spending on lower priority terms."
The Senate measure includes more money than the president requested to help local police, firefighters and emergency workers, for port security and to fight bio-terrorism.
The unexpectedly long and bitter House fight over the emergency bill showed just how partisan Congress is becoming as the November elections get closer. Democrats began dragging out the debate after House Republican leaders inserted into the bill a host of political favors for Republicans and the language on the debt ceiling. The favors included a textile protection measure and special Medicare reimbursement rates for selected hospitals.
The Democrats, who plan to present themselves in the fall elections as the stewards of fiscal stability, argued that the return to federal deficits and the need for more borrowing are primarily the result of Mr. Bush's centerpiece $13 trillion, 10-year tax cut. They said that by trying to avoid a direct vote to raise the federal debt ceiling to allow more borrowing, Republicans were trying to escape responsibility for a return to deficits. 
"When it comes time to pay the bill for that tax cut you don't want to be seen," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader.
Republicans, eager for their party to ride Mr. Bush's wartime popularity in the fall, accused Democrats of turning their back on the armed forces. "They retreated from the responsibility to put politics aside when the time comes to strengthen our military," said Representative Tom DeLay, the House majority whip from Texas, at a news conference.
While the House bill was originally projected to cost $29.4 billion, Republicans altered it slightly early this morning and recalculated the costs of some provisions affecting airlines to bring down the cost. The bill freezes until the new fiscal year the $10 billion loan guarantee program Congress created to help airlines after the terrorist strikes.
Senator Tom Daschle, the South Dakota Democrat who is the majority leader, indicated today that he would not make it easy for House Republicans to avoid a direct vote on raising the debt ceiling. He said he planned to try pushing a stand-alone bill through the Senate that would increase the government's $5.95 trillion borrowing limit, probably by about $350 billion, and send it to the House for passage.
Mr. Bush has requested a $750 billion increase, enough to cover anticipated borrowing needs through 2004.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Bush Pledges Partnership With Russians on Energy

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 24 

 BODY:
President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin agreed today to begin what Mr. Bush called a "major new energy partnership," with more American investment in Russia's oil and gas industry and faster ways for its products to reach world markets.
 Today's joint statement, made in a gilded hall of the Kremlin, was seen by analysts more as an American nod to Russia's energy might than as an agenda for concrete action. 
 "It was simply an acknowledgment of what we have come to realize for some time -- that Russia does have a plan for increasing its role in global energy," said Christopher Weafer, head of research at Troika Dialog, a Moscow brokerage firm. 
But the nod is important for Russia, which is just pulling out of a decade of severe economic decline. Russia's huge oil and gas resources and its expanding ability to export them are a source of growing prestige and influence.
"When Mr. Putin makes official visits, he knows he is the second- biggest oil producer, and that half of Europe depends on him for natural gas," said Boris Fyodorov, a former finance minister and a member of the board of Gazprom, Russia's gas monopoly. "That gets him a place at the table."
Russia's developing role in world energy markets drew attention last fall when the OPEC cartel demanded that Russia, which is not a member, cap its rising oil exports to help constrain world supply. When Russia refused, oil prices plummeted.
After entreaties from Mexico and Norway, two other major non-OPEC producers, the largely privately owned Russian oil industry relented and agreed to a small temporary trim in exports early this year; it was lifted last week.
Today's news sent oil prices down 27 cents, or 1 percent, to $25.88 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
While exports were held back a bit, production kept rising, and Russian output is expected to grow 7 percent this year, as companies like Yukos Oil and Sibneft reap the benefits of recent capital investments.
"Those resources can add to the energy security and energy stability in the world," said Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans yesterday at a meeting with his Russian counterpart, German Gref.
Getting the oil to foreign markets has been a challenge. Russia has limited seaport capacity, and neither its ports nor those of former Soviet republics like Latvia can accommodate the immense tankers needed for profitable shipping across the Atlantic or the Pacific.
As a result, little Russian oil reaches the United States now; most goes to Europe. In their joint statement on energy today, President Bush and President Putin agreed to work together to modernize ports, pipelines and refineries to smooth the export flow. Those changes could also make shipments to North America economically viable.
"It's all about the cost of transport," said Mikhail Brudno, vice president for sales at Yukos, Russia's No. 2 producer after Lukoil. "Now it's just not effective, because the transport costs are too high."
Yukos recently bought part of a Slovakian pipeline with an eye on reaching a Mediterranean port that could be used to supply the United States. Lukoil wants to develop a major port in Murmansk with the same goal.
"America is the biggest market -- we can't ignore it," Mr. Brudno said.
Russian crude need not physically reach the United States to benefit American consumers, because oil is a globally traded commodity, and increases in supply anywhere can lower prices everywhere.
"The Russians have a lot of oil to sell, and the U.S. wants to reduce its dependence on the Persian Gulf, but the oil market doesn't work like that," said Leo Drollas, deputy director at the Center for Global Energy Studies in London. "In terms of security of supply, it doesn't matter whether Russian oil goes to Baltimore or Rotterdam; it just matters that it's not left in the ground."
Direct foreign investment has been slow to penetrate Russia, where frequently shifting tax rules, rigid currency controls and other problems can make doing business awkward for foreign companies. But that may be changing. Last fall, Exxon Mobil pledged about $4 billion to begin developing offshore fields in the far east of Russia, and last month, BP showed renewed faith in a formerly troubled investment in Sidanco, a Russian oil company, by increasing its stake.
Mr. Bush today called on American businesses to "take the lead in developing the vast energy resources of Russia and the Caspian."
But Russian energy executives have opposed direct foreign involvement in Russian oil fields. Instead, they say, foreign companies should gain access to Russian crude by buying stock in Russian companies.

HEADLINE: Bush and Putin Sign Pact for Steep Nuclear Arms Cuts 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER and MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 24 

 BODY:
In a day devoted to celebrating what President Bush called "an entirely new relationship" with Russia, he and President Vladimir V. Putin signed a treaty today to commit their nations to the most dramatic nuclear arms cuts in decades. But both men tried to smooth over a disagreement about continued Russian exports of nuclear technology to Iran.
 The three-page Treaty of Moscow was signed early this afternoon inside the Kremlin, in a 300-year-old throne room built by the Russian czars and used today to end what Mr. Bush called "a long chapter of confrontation." While that confrontation has steadily eased since the Soviet empire began to unravel in 1989, the accord today cleared the way for what Mr. Bush and Mr. Putin hailed as a new era of cooperation focused on counterterrorism, trade, Russia's new relationship with NATO and halting the spread of nuclear arms, 
 The treaty commits both countries to reducing their arsenals, now about 6,000 warheads each, to no more than 2,200 at the end of 2012. But then the treaty expires, meaning that either nation would be free to rearm starting the next year unless the agreement was extended or amended. Excerpts, Page A7. 
Critics of the accord contend that it will leave Russia with a large supply of deactivated warheads that could fall into the hands of terrorists if they are not sufficiently guarded, and that it frees the United States to stockpile warheads that can easily be reattached to missiles.
Mr. Bush's aides counter that none of the past arms control deals have regulated the complicated process of actually dismantling warheads.
The treaty was signed almost exactly 30 years after President Nixon and the Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev signed the Antiballistic Missile Treaty and the first of the strategic arms limitations treaties here. Mr. Bush said he had come to end that era, and his national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, said the accord should not be considered the first Russian-American treaty of the 21st century but "the last treaty of the last century."
Nonetheless, either country can withdraw from the treaty with only three months' notice, and when asked today why it was necessary to keep 2,000 nuclear weapons loaded atop missiles, Mr. Bush made it clear that the future was as unpredictable as the Soviet Union's end a decade ago.
"Friends really don't need weapons pointed at each other, we both understand that," Mr. Bush said. "But it's a realistic assessment of where we've been. Who knows what will happen 10 years from now? Who knows what future presidents will say and how they'll react?"
It was just for that reason that Mr. Putin insisted on a formal treaty, rather than what Mr. Bush first proposed, an informal agreement between two presidents. But as Secretary of State Colin L. Powell noted recently, the Senate also demanded a treaty, so that it would be able to review the nuclear arms cuts. Both the Senate and Russia's Parliament are expected to ratify the treaty, but Mr. Bush made no predictions today how long that would take.
He also defended the administration's decision to store many of its warheads as a "quality control" measure. "If you have a nuclear arsenal, you want to make sure that they work," he said.
Mr. Putin added: "Out there, there are other states who possess nuclear arms. There are countries that want to acquire weapons of mass destruction." Neither president mentioned China, but by most estimates it has about two dozen intercontinental ballistic missiles.
While the signing of the treaty was the centerpiece of the day, Mr. Putin's mind was clearly on his country's economic state, only four years after the collapse of the ruble, which sent many foreign investors fleeing. Economic growth is back -- and he talked during a news conference about Russia's need to gain membership in the World Trade Organization, and for the Congress to revoke cold war-era restrictions on economic relations. 
The two leaders' efforts to cement the unpredicted partnership they have developed over the last year hit one sour note: a clear difference of opinion about Russia's continued sale of its nuclear expertise to Iran, one of the countries Mr. Bush has identified as a member of the "axis of evil."
Mr. Bush told reporters, "We spoke very frankly and honestly" about the need to make sure "a nontransparent government run by radical clerics doesn't get their hands on weapons of mass destruction."
But Mr. Putin immediately shot back that cooperation between Iran and Russia was not "of a character that would undermine the process on nonproliferation." He said Russia's aid was entirely focused on nuclear energy projects -- projects that the Bush administration says are unnecessary in an oil-rich nation.
Mr. Putin then threw the issue back at Mr. Bush, noting that "we have some questions concerning development of missile programs in Taiwan," which receives American technological aid, and said that "the U.S. has taken a commitment upon themselves to build similar nuclear power plants in North Korea." This was a reference to a 1994 accord with North Korea, in which the United States committed itself to helping the country build two "proliferation-resistant" nuclear power plants, but only after the North allows further international inspection of its suspected nuclear sites, something Iran has resisted.
This evening a senior administration official said that Mr. Putin had privately assured Mr. Bush that "they are not now, nor would they, do anything to contribute to the Iranian military nuclear program or ballistic missile program." But in that meeting, he also defended Russia's dealings with Iran.
In a flurry of side agreements, Mr. Bush and Mr. Putin inaugurated a "joint experts group" to develop a plan within six months to destroy or convert for commercial use Russia's large stockpile of highly enriched uranium and plutonium. Russia is estimated to have 1,000 tons of such material, and there is considerable debate over how well protected it is.
The United States intelligence agencies have warned for years of the danger that the material could fall into the hands of terrorists, or that underpaid Russian nuclear scientists could divert some of the material to a rogue state or a terrorist group. In news conferences and interviews, Mr. Bush and his aides have not seemed extremely concerned by the prospect, insisting that they have received assurances about the country's nuclear security. 
But in a recent op-ed article in The Washington Post, former Defense Secretary William J. Perry, former Senator Sam Nunn and the former commander of the American strategic nuclear forces, Gen. Eugene Habinger, charged that the administration had no "coherent strategy" to secure the Russian nuclear supplies and had failed to insist on an accurate accounting of existing weapons.
Other experts, like Graham Allison of Harvard, have contended that today's treaty addresses the lesser threat: nuclear warheads controlled by the two governments, rather than nuclear material that may be on the loose. 
The dispute over Iran aside, the summit meeting seemed as warm, if more formal, than the one last November at the Bush ranch in Texas.
Throughout his day, Mr. Bush struck a relaxed, even casual demeanor amid the blindingly gilded splendor of the Kremlin. Early in the day, as cameras began taping the two presidents' remarks after two hours of talks, Mr. Bush was captured slyly removing a candy or gum from his mouth.
Later, as he finished signing the nuclear arms treaty and a strategic relationship agreement in St. Catherine's Hall, the president directed an impish wink at Ms. Rice, who is an expert on the Russian military.
It was Ms. Rice who, three years ago, wrote an article in Foreign Affairs expressing deep suspicion of Mr. Putin and his motives. Tonight she helped celebrate the treaty at a dinner at his house.

HEADLINE: Sound of One Saber Rattling 

BYLINE:  By Max Frankel; Max Frankel, a former executive editor of The Times, served earlier as diplomatic correspondent in Washington and then as bureau chief.

 BODY:
 THE PARADOX
OF AMERICAN POWER
Why the World's Only Superpower
Can't Go It Alone.
By Joseph S. Nye Jr.
222 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $26.
 Take pity on our foreign policy wonks. Gone are the blessedly simple, bipolar days when containment of Soviet power governed and defined American diplomacy and military action. Now the analysts strain to describe the world's chaos. National laws and frontiers are failing to contain not only terrorists but also global corporations, financial speculators, industrial polluters, illegal migrants, drug smugglers, disease bearers. The very idea of sovereign geographic control has lost much of its meaning. 
As Joseph S. Nye Jr. demonstrates in "The Paradox of American Power," there is an almost ludicrous competition for jargon to describe the world's present imbalance of power ("unipolar," "unimultipolar," "hybrid unimultipolar") and for words that might encapsulate a wise foreign policy. He generally scorns "unilateralists" (also known as "triumphalists" or "sovereigntists"), who deem America so dominant that it should just look out for itself -- the folks who were most influential at the Pentagon in the early months of the Bush administration. Nye, a Democratic wonk and the dean of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, champions the cause of "a la carte multilateralists," who mostly (but not always) favor cooperative ventures that balance the interests of collaborating nations -- the types who reside mainly at the State Department. 
Yet for all his experience in government and his worldly common sense, Nye proves in his analyses how mired we all are in the mud of nationalism, unable to devise a genuine transnational policy that would let us begin to function as citizens of the world. He recognizes the need for "a representative form of global governance," for "multilateral laws and institutions that constrain others and provide a framework for cooperation" and maybe even for "a loose constitutional framework" with parts of Europe. But his imagination shrinks from his own logic. He does not much speculate on how we might get from here to there. 
Maybe pre-Sept. 11 America still needed Nye's main message: the "paradox" that although the United States will long remain militarily and economically supreme, it will become increasingly dependent on other peoples to defeat terrorism, protect the environment, control weapons of mass destruction, regulate trade and deal with a host of other borderless problems. Though the "hard power" of our military and economic might will not soon be challenged, he rightly argues that we also need "soft power," the influence and respect that we gain from our democratic values but risk losing by "unilateralism, arrogance and parochialism." 
Surely by the morning of Sept. 12, however, when we were begging Muslim societies to help hunt Osama bin Laden, no go-it-aloner would deny Nye's point. He duly amended his manuscript and even says that the attacks on New York and Washington sounded his alarm "far more effectively than any pen could." But he responds only weakly to his own challenge that "we still need to determine how to use the current decades of our pre-eminence to advance long-term national and global interests." 
How indeed. Nye flirts here and there with genuinely radical propositions, then drowns them in dense prose lest readers mistake him for some kind of idealist. For example, he quotes with obvious approval Daniel Bell's observation that the nation-state has "become too small for the big problems of life and too big for the small problems." Simply put, the nation-state is becoming an obstacle to effective problem-solving. Technology in general, the speed of communication and the information revolution are eroding the control that individual governments once had over their people and corporations. 
But if most governments are fast losing control over their frontiers and economies, it is hard to know how much faith to invest in the idea of national sovereignty, which Nye nonetheless asks us to respect and protect. He is palpably reluctant to explore the implications of his own best, unconventional ideas. 
Near the start of his book, Nye writes, "The impact of American preponderance is softened when it is embodied in a web of multilateral institutions that allow others to participate in decisions and that act as a sort of world constitution to limit the capriciousness of American power." Enmesh America in a "transnational web"? That limits "American capriciousness"? And acts as "a sort of world constitution"? 
Yes. But now see Nye run: two chapters on he insists that he wants no truck with "world government," only "networks" coexisting with "a world formally divided into sovereign states." That retreat soon requires him to list the practices of transnational and offshore supercorporations, which had seemed to be among his problems, as part of his solutions. Then again he concedes that the networks he envisions would not fairly represent public interests. Oh, well, he decides, "our democratic theory has not caught up with global practice." End of vision. 
The worthy but vague prescriptions that close this book resemble the position papers that a diplomatic Polonius might offer the secretaries of state or defense, whom Nye has occasionally served: preserve regional balances; promote free trade; keep open the oceans, the air and cyberspace; cooperate with nations to curb weapons proliferation and to promote peacekeeping and human rights; send aid to developing societies; mediate others' disputes. 
Sadly avoided are the many tough, specific, truly paradoxical tensions that Nye's values produce. How, for instance, can the United States and a few other self-appointed nations wield the Bomb without appearing "unilateral" and "arrogant" to those they exclude from the club? Or by what logic do we haul a Milosevic before a world court whose authority we then refuse to extend to Americans? 
Simply accepted by Nye is the proposition that the highest goal of American foreign policy should be the preservation of our power within a congenial environment of sovereign nations. If to his own logic Nye were true, he would bid us to lead the world in abandoning some of our eroding sovereignty and subscribing to genuinely independent and representative global institutions. That, for a mighty superpower, would be a paradox worthy of notice.

HEADLINE: Peculiar Institution 

BYLINE:  By James Goodman; James Goodman, the author of "Stories of Scottsboro," teaches history at Rutgers University, Newark.

 BODY:
 AT THE HANDS
OF PERSONS UNKNOWN
The Lynching of Black America.
By Philip Dray.
Illustrated. 528 pp. New York:
Random House. $35.
 Sam Hose was a 21-year-old black farm worker in Palmetto, Ga. In April 1899 he approached his white boss, Alfred Cranford, to talk about wages. Hose may have asked Cranford for an advance or for money owed to him. He wanted to visit his mother, who was ill. Hose and Cranford argued. Cranford drew a gun. Hose grabbed an ax and swung. Cranford fell. Hose fled. Cranford died. 
The next day, newspapers reported that the "fiend incarnate" had not only murdered Cranford but also raped his wife. The papers described the crime in pornographic detail and predicted that as soon as Hose was caught he would be "burned at the stake." After a 10-day manhunt, two men found him, at his mother's. They handed him over to the sheriff, who handed him over to a mob.
Word reached Atlanta just as church let out. People rushed to the train station. The railroad added two special excursions to Palmetto. That afternoon, about 5,000 people watched mob leaders cut off Hose's ears, fingers and genitals, before dousing him with kerosene and setting him on fire. 
Historians often say that laymen know little about history. But they understand that if Americans have never heard of Sam Hose or do not know much about lynching, they themselves are largely to blame. Despite many superb historical monographs, there is no modern synthesis, no big, accessible book that brings the latest scholarship to lay readers. This, apparently, is what Philip Dray set out to provide with "At the Hands of Persons Unknown."
Dray, an independent scholar whose previous books include "We Are Not Afraid: The Story of Goodman, Schwerner, and Chaney and the Civil Rights Campaign for Mississippi," admits that he himself knew little about lynching before his first visit to Tuskegee Institute's lynching archives. For him, the word had evoked images of rough frontier justice for cattle rustlers and card cheats, and aberrational racial violence in the South. 
He quickly learned that lynching was not an aberration, in the South or anywhere else. It had begun on the colonial frontier, where the population was sparse and the arm of the law did not reach. In the absence of constables and courts, citizens took the law into their own hands. During the American Revolution, one of those citizens, a Virginian named Charles Lynch, set up his own court to punish plundering Tories. When the Tories sued, the legislature exonerated Lynch, ruling that his actions, though not "strictly warranted by the law," were justified by imminent danger. Today the word "lynch" means to execute without due process of the law.
Before the Civil War, more white people were lynched than black people. Most black people were slaves, private property punished by their masters. Lynching became a distinctly racial ritual only after emancipation. Former slaves wanted to move freely, own land, educate their children and vote. White Southerners wanted them to plant and pick their cotton, preferably as landless, illiterate, disfranchised and utterly dependent laborers. Lynching (and the rape of black women) was a means to ensure they got their way.
Hundreds of African-Americans were lynched each year during Reconstruction, and many times that number each year following the North's retreat in 1877. The peak, but not the end, came in the 1890's, when continuing racial conflict coincided with bitter economic conflict among white Southerners. With cracks in the "solid South" raising the specter of interracial political alliances, huge "spectacle lynchings" reinforced white solidarity across class lines. 
Dray's book is broader than its subtitle suggests. In addition to telling the stories of Sam Hose and scores of other victims of lynching, Dray writes vividly about murders, race riots and several significant trials in which prosecutors and judges recklessly trampled on defendants' civil rights. He devotes half his pages to the century-long struggle against mob violence that began with the agitation of Ida B. Wells. Her research and writings gave the lie to the notion that lynching was necessary to protect white women from bestial black men. Wells discovered that few mob victims were even accused of rape. Most lynchings followed disputes over wages, slight breaches of racial etiquette, accusations of petty theft and attempts by white people to divert attention from their own transgressions. 
But if Dray's book is more than a history of lynching, it is also less. In these pages only "race leaders" fight lynching. Ordinary African-Americans appear simply as victims. Yet when ordinary African-Americans possessed a modicum of political power or economic independence, they attempted to prevent lynchings, whether by standing up to a mob, sneaking a fugitive out of town or forcing a local sheriff to protect him. 
Dray also misses the opportunity to show how all the talk of rape, wholly oppressive to black men and women, also circumscribed the behavior of white women. The assumption was that helpless white women needed protection. White men offered it, but only to those who knew their place. When they didn't, and especially when they dared to look for love or pleasure across the color line, all hell broke loose. 
Still, "At the Hands of Persons Unknown" is filled with history we need to know. If it is not the last (or even the latest) word, it may inadvertently demonstrate that when it comes to lynching, a sweeping synthesis or any other kind of big book is not necessarily what we need. 
Every historical subject demands its own form. Lynching may demand monographs and microhistories (along with novels, photographs and poems), forms in which God -- or the Devil -- is in the details. That's partly because there were so many lynchings: thousands in the century after the Civil War, in thousands of different places, each one densely packed with meaning. 
And it's partly because at the heart of every lynching there is a horrible silence: the victims cannot speak. When we read too many accounts at once, the silence becomes unbearable. Often, the only thing we know about those who were murdered is how they died. Dray can't fill that silence. No historian can. But he has bestowed upon us the gift, and the burden, of some of their names.

HEADLINE: Mosque and State 

BYLINE:  By Robin Wright; Robin Wright, the author of "Sacred Rage: The Wrath of Militant Islam," is a diplomatic correspondent for The Los Angeles Times.

 BODY:
 JIHAD
The Trail of Political Islam.
By Gilles Kepel.
Translated by Anthony F. Roberts.
454 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
The Belknap Press/
Harvard University Press. $29.95.
 No political trend has taken the world more by surprise over the past quarter century than the eruption of militant Islam -- in fomenting revolution in the 1970's, in taking on both superpowers and helping bring one down in the 1980's, and in building a global terror network in the 1990's. For many in the West, the exotic and remote "Mohammedanism" of the preoil, preindependence and pre-Israel days has evolved into the force behind the world's premier security threat. 
So "Jihad: The Trail of Political Islam" will be a welcome respite for anyone who fears the fury associated with militant Islam. Despite the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 and the Palestinian suicide bombings in Israel, Gilles Kepel argues that the trend is, in fact, now on its last legs. The violence is merely a reflection of the movement's failure, not its success. "The attack on the United States was a desperate symbol of the isolation, fragmentation and decline of the Islamist movement, not a sign of its strength and irrepressible might," he writes. And while he concedes that the Israeli-Palestinian conflict may provoke further attacks under the mantle of holy war, violence "has proven to be a deathtrap for Islamists as a whole." 
This is, to say the least, a controversial if intriguing theory. Kepel, an Arabist and a professor at the Institute for Political Studies in Paris, comes to this conclusion in a thoughtful and expansive chronicle of the contemporary Islamist movement from Cairo to Kabul, from Kuala Lumpur all the way to "Londonistan." Divided into two sections, the book covers the rise and predicted fall of the modern militant jihad. 
As Kepel sees it, the onset of the current Islamist movement was symbolized by Egypt's decision in 1966 to hang Sayyid Qutb, one of the most influential early Islamist theorists. Qutb rejected nationalism, which filled a void when the Muslim world was in disarray after colonialism. He believed it weakened the Islamic world by dividing it into more than 50 nations, and he equated it with the pagan state of ignorance before the revelation of Islam to the prophet Muhammad. His best sellers urged the creation of a "new Koranic generation" to build a sequel to the prophet's first Muslim community. Like his contemporaries, who included Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and Pakistan's Mawlana Mawdudi, Qutb redefined the political discourse by offering an alternative vision. His execution reflected the emerging chasm between the state and the Islamists.
The movement became more visible after the 1973 Arab-Israeli war. The Saudi-led oil embargo ultimately generated unprecedented wealth that let the kingdom bankroll Islamist causes worldwide. Three social dynamics -- soaring population, literacy and the pull of the city -- also spurred the trend. The Islamic world's population increased by 50 percent between 1955 and 1970. Some 60 percent of the Muslim world was under 24 years old by 1975. Many were among the first generation to read -- and to have serious aspirations. Disillusioned by autocratic and corrupt regimes, the new generation increasingly turned to various Islamist groups. The decade was capped by Iran's 1979 revolution, which ended 2,500 years of monarchy and proved that Islam could provide a political alternative.
Deepening turmoil marked the 1980's as proliferating militants launched a wave of jihads. The mujahedeen took on Soviet troops in Afghanistan and Hezbollah emerged in Lebanon to take on Israel and the United States. President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt was assassinated. Sudan, Africa's largest country, fell to Islamist control. The first Palestinian intifada in 1987 fostered the rise of Hamas and Islamic Jihad. 
But the most noteworthy facet of the decade, Kepel argues, was the struggle between Khomeini's Islamic republic and Saudi Arabia's Islamic monarchy over which Islamist vision prevailed. Indeed, the best part of this section, which covers a lot of well-trodden ground, is the struggle within the Islamic world. 
The second half of "Jihad" offers the more interesting read, however, because it defies conventional wisdom in evaluating the 1990's. The triumph in Afghanistan, when the pro-Communist government collapsed in 1992, dispersed the war-hardened jihadis back to their homes outside Afghanistan -- and beyond. They radicalized Egypt's Islamist movement, which turned to killing foreign tourists, Coptic Christians and others, and they opened a new battlefront in Algeria after a military coup prevented moderate Islamists from claiming electoral victory. The jihadis also popped up in Bosnia, where they tried to make the war against Serbia part of their cause. They even set up shop in New York, where they carried out the first World Trade Center bombing in 1993. 
Yet Bosnia, Algeria and Egypt actually reflect the movement's failure, Kepel argues, because the Islamists miscalculated. The extremist operations carried out by networks "cut off from any social movement and manipulated by obscure forces, had an effect that was the exact reverse of the one their authors probably hoped for," he writes. A fragile alliance between the young urban poor and the devout middle classes was also unable to endure or confront the state, and the movement eventually split. 
In Bosnia, the 2,000 foreign jihadis failed to inspire and the holy war ended with a Pax Americana in 1995. In Algeria, the jihad collapsed into a "blood-drenched nightmare" that lost popular appeal -- leading one faction to declare a unilateral truce in 1997. It was a disaster that put the wider movement on the defensive. In Egypt, the ruthless 1992-97 campaign by a radical Islamist fringe group killed hundreds but was marginalized through repression and pre-empted by market economics. 
And in Iran, the one place where militant Islam prevailed, the zeal for the Islamic Revolution has also petered out. In the 1997 presidential election, vast numbers voted for a reformer who advocated democratizing society and easing rigid restrictions. So between 1995 and 1997, the author concludes, the "high season of jihad" began to draw to a close in many countries. 
"The failure to transplant jihad was an early indication of two entirely new phenomena that characterized political Islam in the 1990's," Kepel writes. "The first was the gradual opening of a gulf between the ideas of Islamist radicals and the needs of ordinary Muslims, in whose eyes utopian ideals were progressively losing their attraction. Second, there began to emerge among those same ordinary Muslims a blueprint for a Muslim democratic society that went beyond the Islamist model. It was suggested that traditional Islamic culture could find a way to allow Muslims to embrace the modern world without betraying themselves." 
By 2000, the transition to a post-Islamist period had already begun, Kepel maintains. It was reflected in elections from Indonesia to Morocco, where revamped Islamist parties increasingly "set aside the sovereignty of God" and ran for office -- whenever allowed. "Many Islamist parties and movements were bent on winning recognition as democrats and on denouncing repression by reference to the universal Western principles of human rights," he says.
Kepel's theory may have seemed more convincing when "Jihad" was first published in France in 2000, well before the Sept. 11 attacks. He has updated it for the English translation and, he contends, the World Trade Center and Pentagon attacks only reinforce his conclusion. Rejecting compromise, Al Qaeda, the organization of Osama bin Laden, and other extremist groups turned to "raw terrorism in its most spectacular and destructive form" to try to revive their cause in a new millennium. Although the remaining cells are still a deadly security threat, Kepel contends that they find it increasingly difficult to inspire or recruit, leaving them farther away from taking power than ever. 
"Jihad" -- a word that actually means "effort" or "struggle" and reflects what all Muslims are supposed to do to observe the faith's values -- is a compelling read that makes an appealing case. It caters to the specialist in its detail and scope, however. And it is weakest in explaining the bigger picture. Kepel writes about Islamist political goals and military tactics, but too little about Islam itself. In the West, Christianity went through a Reformation that paved the way for the Age of Enlightenment and the birth of modern democracy -- a 400-year course that is still not quite complete. Islam is now just beginning to struggle with its own reformation, a process of reinterpreting the Koran and blending religious traditions with modern society. The past quarter century of militancy is a part of this broader process -- a phase of history that is definitely not over.

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 747 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks 

BYLINE:  By Scott Veale

 BODY:
 EMPIRE FALLS, by Richard Russo. (Vintage Contemporaries, $14.95.) A writer whose fiction is grounded in the aches and dreams of bumptious, blue-collar New Englanders sets his new novel (which won a Pulitzer Prize) in a dying mill town in Maine, where a large cast of finely observed characters -- chief among them the likable, if unfulfilled, manager of the Empire Grill -- play out their lives with as much grace and gusto as they can muster. "Russo is brave enough to conceive a large ambition but too smart to overreach," A. O. Scott wrote in the Book Review last year. "His humane sympathy for weakness and self-deception . . . does not rule out stern satiric judgment."

KIKI'S PARIS: Artists and Lovers 1900-1930, by Billy Kluver and Julie Martin. (Abrams, $19.95.) Model, painter, cabaret singer and world-class bon vivant, Kiki was so popular she was elected "Queen of Montparnasse." She also knew everyone in a neighborhood famously crowded with creative spirits, from Picasso to Cocteau. The many photographs in this homage accompany "a carefully researched text that is always amusingly written and bristling with information," Edmund White wrote here in 1989.

COME UP AND SEE ME SOMETIME, by Erika Krouse. (Washington Square/Pocket, $12.) This first story collection is filled with smart, sassy 30-ish women who insist on owning up to their own pain as they grapple mightily with the problem of finding and hanging on to love. Krouse's "arsenal is stocked with . . . potent, original stuff," Maria Russo said in the Book Review in 2001.

A WHALE HUNT: How a Native American Village Did What No One Thought It Could, by Robert Sullivan. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $13.) The author recounts his two-year vigil with the Makah Indians of Neah Bay, Wash., as they sought to restore their tribal tradition of hunting the gray whale, a pursuit hampered by animal-rights protesters, internal squabbling and, above all, a lack of know-how (the tribe stopped whaling a generation before). "Sullivan has a very Ishmael-like talent for being both funny and generous," Nathaniel Philbrick wrote here in 2000. In The Eternal Frontier: An Ecological History of North America and Its Peoples, by Tim Flannery (Grove, $16), a Tocqueville of American biogeography bravely tackles the continent's last 65 million years, surveying an evolutionary work in progress in which waves of invaders adapt and become extinct, clearing the way for new immigrant species. Last year in these pages, David Quammen said, "Flannery synthesizes a vast range of scientific studies and a decent selection of historical and cultural writings, leavening those with his own forceful ideas."

IN CUBA I WAS A GERMAN SHEPHERD, by Ana Menendez. (Grove, $12.) A daughter of Cuban exiles explores the interlocking obsessions of two sets of Cubans -- those at home and those in Florida -- whose clashing voices have aged into futility and craziness after 40 years of separation. In 2001 our reviewer, Richard Eder, called these "achingly wise stories about the Cuba in Miami and, in ghostly pentimento, the Miami in Cuba."

NEXT: The Future Just Happened, by Michael Lewis. (Norton, $13.95.) These linked essays argue that the Internet -- far from being a disappointment -- has succeeded in rearranging the fundamental social order through a populist electronic uprising led by young prodigies who are subverting their elders' clunky old regime. "In a tone both ominous and bemused . . . Lewis suggests that they'll soon be running everything," Walter Kirn said here last year. He "writes best when he's personalizing . . . economic change."

O'NEILL: Life With Monte Cristo, by Arthur and Barbara Gelb. (Applause, $24.95.) In the first book of a three-volume rewriting of their 1962 "O'Neill," the authors (Arthur Gelb is a former theater critic and was later managing editor of The Times) re-examine the great American playwright in light of new archival material and insights into his life and work. "Their research and dedication are impressive," Margot Peters wrote in these pages in 2000.

1831: YEAR OF ECLIPSE, by Louis P. Masur. (Hill & Wang, $14.) A solar eclipse was just one of many notable events in America that year: slavery, abolitionism, Indian rights and religious revivalism were among the major moral and political issues at center stage. This novel "gives insight into the character of the United States and . . . entertains with the stories it provides," David Traxel said here last year. Scott Veale

CORRECTION-DATE: May 26, 2002

 CORRECTION:
The New & Noteworthy Paperbacks column on Page 20 of the Book Review today refers incorrectly to "1831: Year of Eclipse," by Louis P. Masur. It is nonfiction, not a novel.

BYLINE:  By Joseph Siano 

 BODY:
 BY A LAKE IN TEXAS: The 40-room Lake Austin Spa Resort, about a half-hour outside Austin, Tex., in the Hill Country, is offering extra nights at no extra charge through Sept. 30. LINGER IN ROME: The Cavalieri Hilton, on 15 acres near the Vatican, will add extra nights for multi-night stays through Sept. 15. Pay for three nights and get four. A five-night stay earns two more nights. And for the cost of a one-week stay, you get 10 nights. Doubles start at $348 a night, with V.A.T. and buffet breakfast, at 1.12 euros to the dollar. The reopening rates, which start at $249 weekdays and $159 weekends, include a daily breakfast and manager's reception. The hotel is adjacent to a 16-screen movie theater. Call (800) 362-2779 or visit www.embassysuites.com.

VERMONT RETREAT: Through Sept. 12, the 15-room Three Mountain Inn, in Jamaica in south-central Vermont about 30 miles east of Manchester, is taking 20 percent off two- and three-night packages. A third night (with another dinner) is $195 regardless of room choice. The inn, in a building dating from 1791, was renovated three years ago and has a pool; (800) 532-9399 or www.threemountaininn.com.

The coupon is valid through April 15, 2003; a cart is extra. Other restrictions apply. JOSEPH SIANO

HEADLINE: Travel Advisory: Correspondent's Report; 
Car-Rental Rates Low As Bookings Creep Up

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
THE sharp drop in auto rentals immediately after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks was not as well known to the public as the battering suffered by airlines and hotels, but its effect was about as bad.
 In the week after the attacks, bookings at a number of rental car companies plunged by 50 percent, primarily because more than two-thirds of cars are rented at airports, and travelers were shunning airports and airplanes. Profits of the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, which owns Dollar Rent a Car Systems and Thrifty Inc., fell 83 percent in the third quarter of 2001. In the same quarter, ANC Rental Corporation, the owner of Alamo Rent a Car and National Car Rental, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, citing a drop in business. 
 The paucity of bookings led most of the major rental car companies -- whose rentals and revenues were softening even before Sept. 11 because of the weak economy -- to lay off as much as 20 percent of their staff and reduce the number of cars in their fleets by an average of 30 percent.
For car renters, this added up to confusion and inconvenience, which still has not been straightened out. The reduction in rental cars has meant that customers who try to book at the last minute may wind up not only without the car of their choice, but without a car altogether.
For now, though, there are signs that rental car bookings are slowly creeping upward, as corporate and leisure travel pick up. On April 18, Dollar Thrifty reported a 31.7 percent increase in first-quarter net income over the same period last year. And a survey in March of 200 corporate travel managers, conducted by the National Business Travel Association in Alexandria, Va., found that 65 percent of the managers said they had seen demand for travel increase by up to 10 percent since January, while a large majority of managers expected business travel to recover within the next 12 months.
There are still solid bargains to be had for car rentals, according to William A. Maloney, the chief operating officer of the American Society of Travel Agents. He said that many good deals were available "whether you rent for a day, a few days or a week."
Many bargains can be found on the Web sites of the rental car companies, in travel sections of newspapers, on Internet sites such as Yahoo, Expedia, Orbitz, Priceline and Travelocity, and from airline frequent flier programs. Continental Airlines, for example, is offering members of its One Pass program discounts through June on Alamo, Avis and Hertz rental cars, including free days, double upgrades or double miles.
In addition, where rental cars are readily available there are more models to select from, including minivans, S.U.V.'s and convertibles, as well as the traditional models.
Bob Briggs, the executive vice president of business development and marketing for Carlson Wagonlit Travel in North America, said that all travel companies are struggling and as a result, "Everybody's looking for more business, and the way to get it is by price." And now that it is spring, he said, the best prices are to be found in such warm weather destinations as Florida, Arizona, Las Vegas and Southern California.
In its annual review of the rental-car industry published last month, Consumer Reports said there were signs that rates had begun climbing in recent months. But it found that so far this year the average cost of a three-day rental was down about 10 percent from last year -- to $100.56 from $112.26.
Of the eight rental car companies surveyed in 11 large United States and Canadian cities, from Atlanta to Toronto to Washington, Dollar's three-day rate of $85.59 was lowest, while Hertz's three-day rate at the same locations was highest, at $113.21 (not including taxes or fees).
When it comes to rental cars, there are few if any tax havens, but renters tired of the same old thing can find a variety of unusual choices, although not in great numbers or in many locations.
For example, in Santa Monica, Calif., Global Electric Motorcars, a DaimlerChrysler company, and EV Rental Cars have teamed up to rent two- and four-passenger GEMs, electrical vehicles designed for short trips. They are charged by plugging into a household outlet. The introductory rate is $25 for one hour, $45 for two hours and $80 a day.
Budget Rent a Car of Beverly Hills, whose 2,000-car fleet consists of more than 80 models, is renting Bentley Azures for $1,800 a day. The company recently added 20 BMW Mini Coopers at its offices in and around Los Angeles. The car will rent for $125 a day. Or, as the company puts it, "for just $125 a day."

HEADLINE: The Trials of Job Hunting Beyond a Certain Size 

BYLINE:  By MELINDA LIGOS 

 BODY:
When 390-pound Robert Diaz goes on a job interview, he goes to almost desperate lengths to appear smaller.
 When he's waiting in the reception area, he tries to cover his belly with his portfolio. When he is walking into an interview, he treads delicately, almost tiptoeing through the office. And when he sits down in front of his prospective boss's desk, he never plops down in his chair, he eases himself into it. 
 Still, nothing can really hide his frame, and few hiring managers, if any, can get past it. 
"Usually, the interview is over almost as soon as they see me," says Mr. Diaz, a resident of Flushing, Queens, who has been looking for a job as a law librarian since last fall after spending the last 10 years in business for himself as a math tutor. When he left his last professional position at a law firm in 1992, he weighed only 270 pounds. Now, he says, as soon as he walks in the door for an interview, he gets the same reaction from employers.
"Their eyes immediately dart down to my belly," he says. "Then, there's a brief look of shock. And then they want to get me out of their office as quickly as possible."
Discrimination against overweight workers is nothing new. In fact, employment lawyers say it has been on the rise since the economy tightened. "In this job market, anything considered to be a flaw, including obesity, is going to be a drawback," said Richard S. Corenthal, a lawyer with Meyer, Suozzi, English & Klein in Mineola, N.Y.
Still, even as people like Mr. Diaz struggle to get a job, obese workers are slowly gaining protection against discrimination under many states' disability laws.
In April of this year, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled that so-called morbid obesity -- defined as obesity which causes other medical problems like arthritis, asthma and others -- is a handicap that may be protected under the state's antidiscrimination laws. In that case, Regina A. Viscik, a woman who weighed more than 400 pounds, was fired after just four days on the job as an assistant for the Fowler Equipment Company in 1988.
Part of Ms. Viscik's job was to travel back and forth many times to a fax machine, a task made difficult because of arthritis and other conditions brought on by her weight, according to her lawyer, Christopher Kelly, a partner at the Reppert, Kelly law firm in Westfield, N.J.
After four days, "Her boss basically said, 'I'm sorry, but we need someone who can move around a little quicker,' " Mr. Kelly said. A spokesman for Fowler said Ms. Viscik was fired for making too many personal phone calls.
Mr. Kelly heralds the ruling as a victory for those whose obesity leads to physical handicaps. Other states have adopted even more liberal laws relating to discrimination against overweight people.
Four jurisdictions in the country -- San Francisco; Santa Cruz, Calif.; Michigan and the District of Columbia -- have all adopted weight-based discrimination laws. San Francisco's was recently tested when Jennifer Portnick, a 240-pound aerobics instructor, filed a complaint with the city's Human Rights Commission last September contending that she was rejected for a job with Jazzercise Inc. because of her size. The case was recently settled, and Jazzercise says it will no longer require prospective instructors to appear svelte as long as they are in good shape.
New York's human rights laws recognize obesity as a disability and forbid most employers to discriminate against such workers, according to Mr. Corenthal.
Adoptions of such laws are indications that discrimination against overweight job seekers may soon become as taboo as sexual or racial discrimination, says Josephine Tucker, co-chairwoman of the employment law division of Morrison & Foerster, a law firm with offices in Irvine, Calif.
"If you've just put on a few extra pounds, you're still not going to be protected," Ms. Tucker said. "But if you're truly obese, you may be." As more states adopt such laws, Ms. Tucker says, prospective employers may become more wary of making comments to job seekers about their weight, even in a joking manner.
"Employers know that they can't make a racist joke to a job seeker, or question whether their sex will prevent them from doing a job," Ms. Tucker says. "But many don't realize yet that they can't say to a fat person, 'Are you going to be able to do the job quickly enough?' "
Such quips still abound in the workplace, regardless of the antidiscrimination laws in place in many states, says Dr. Kelli Friedman, a research associate at Structure House, a residential weight-loss center in Durham, N.C. In a study of its patients conducted last July, 25 percent said they felt they were not hired for a job because of their weight. Others complained of being passed up for promotions or receiving bad assignments.
Such discrimination often stems from the common myths that overweight people are slower or less motivated than their slimmer counterparts, says Jeffrey E. Christian, chief executive of Christian & Timbers Inc., a Cleveland recruiting firm with offices in New York. Mr. Christian often coaches obese job seekers to address an employer's concerns directly. "I tell them to say something like, 'As you can see, I'm a big woman, and some people may not think I can get as much work done as others. As a result, I've had to work harder than everyone else.' "
"Get that issue off the table quickly so that the employer can remember something else about the interview besides the fact that you're overweight," Mr. Christian advises.
But tactics like these may not be enough to sway some employers. In one recent interview for a librarian position at a publishing firm, Mr. Diaz says his interviewer asked him to follow him to an office down the hall, but kept turning around and looking worriedly at Mr. Diaz as they walked. "He was kind of mumbling to himself, and I could tell he was very concerned about something," Mr. Diaz said. As soon as they got to the man's office, Mr. Diaz realized what the problem was.
"His office was decorated in a Japanese motif, and he had these really small black-lacquer chairs," he said. Mr. Diaz was about to sit down, when the man asked him if he would mind standing throughout the interview. "He told me the chairs were too delicate," Mr. Diaz says. The interview lasted only five minutes, and both men knew that Mr. Diaz would not be back for a second. "He just seemed disgusted at having to even speak to me," Mr. Diaz said.
At another recent interview at an insurance company, Mr. Diaz says, a prospective employer explained that some employees took a half-hour for lunches, while others opted to take an hour, and joked, "You look like an hour-lunch guy."
"I had to laugh along with her, because I wanted to appear agreeable," he says. But he admits that the comments still stung. "I'm trying to develop a tough shell, or I'm going to have my feelings hurt all the time."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert Diaz, a former law librarian, must contend with responses to his weight. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dining Out; 
Feasts for the Mind as Well as for the Body

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA BROOKS 

 BODY:
FEEDING the body as well as the intellect might well be the goal of bookshops that incorporate cafes in their premises. There aren't enough in Connecticut to be called a trend. Even so, bibliophiles are happy to have these treasured few.
 Of all the bookstore cafes, the Traveler restaurant is the most unusual. In a free-standing building on a hilly bank just off I-84, near the Massachusetts line, this is a real dining room, seating 126 people, with a full-fledged kitchen that serves breakfast, lunch and dinner. Down a short flight of stairs in the cellar is a bona fide second-hand bookstore (which is also reachable directly from the parking lot, at ground level), whose old books are arranged by categories like a library. 
 But the restaurant dominates. Surrounding the numerous tables and booths are overflowing bookcases. The minute my companion and I sat down on the glassed-in porch, a smiling waitress told us we could help ourselves to a free book apiece. "If you come on Wednesday, you can have three books and two free ones on Saturday." Later, in speaking by phone to Art Murdock, the owner, I learned that the Traveler gives away 100,000 books a year, many of which they acquire from library sales. 
After placing our order, we browsed among dozens of books in every imaginable category, including encyclopedias and Reader's Digest anthologies. By the time our lunch arrived, we had chosen our treasures, a Russell Baker memoir and a Spanish novel we had once owned, but misplaced years ago. As a starter, we shared Cheddar hot bites (explosive jalapeno peppers in beer batter stuffed with Wisconsin Cheddar), served with a salsa dip -- a delight at $5.29. While lunching, we enjoyed the pastoral view of a grassy hillside, "patrolled" by an enormous wooden moose (the work, we were told, of John Bash, an Ellington sculptor) and a small pond beyond. 
There's nothing fancy about Traveler's decor, with its rustic knotty pine walls, nor its food. Our brief sampling of the sizable, economically priced menu included fried clam strips, which had scant flavor but came with freshly made cole slaw and a mountain of delicious French fries for $8.99. A packed lobster roll made a fine lunch, but we should have skipped the commercial-tasting strawberry-rhubarb pie. There is a limited wine and beer selection. 
Credit cards accepted. Hours: 7 a.m.-8 p.m. daily. Route 84, exit 74, Union. (860) 684-4920.
I was much taken by the jaunty air of the R. J. Cafe, tucked into the rear of R. J. Julia Booksellers on Madison's main street. A separate business, the cafe is owned and run by Nancy's Coffee Cafe, with its own patio and parking lot. The widely known bookshop stages many events, with celebrity authors like Anne Rice and Garrison Keillor, many of whom pop into the cafe for coffee or a snack after their signings (so I was told) -- a bonus that cafe patrons seem to enjoy. 
There are just seven tables inside, another six on the patio, so I felt lucky on a recent visit to snare a table with a window seat, covered with cushions, by a bowed window. 
Soups are a specialty (cream of mushroom and curry pumpkin bisque were especially winning), as are the daily quiches. I was partial also to the lemon basil chicken salad sandwich and grilled balsamic chicken sandwich. For $6.49 you can get a huge bowl of soup and a hearty half sandwich. The lemon and poppy seed pound cakes, among many choices, were both excellent. 
No alcoholic beverages are served, but patrons are permitted to bring their own.
Credit cards accepted. Hours: 8 a.m.-9 p.m. Monday through Thursday, 8 a.m.-10 p.m. Friday and Saturday, 9 a.m.-5 p.m. Sunday. 768 Boston Post Road, Madison. (203) 318-0706.
Atticus Cafe seems to gobble up more and more space in the busy, popular Attucus Bookstore in New Haven. The cafe began 25 years ago with a couple of tables, a counter and display cases at the edge of the shop. Now there are 18 tables for two, plus two large tables for groups. 
Its own bakery, Chabaso, supplies the delicious muffins, scones, sweet rolls, breads and desserts to this bustling cafe. Soups and sandwiches are the mainstay here, and I recently savored a robust white bean and vegetable soup and a cup of real Rhode Island clam chowder, full of clams and vegetables. A good deal is the $6.95 tab for a cup of soup and half sandwich. Mine was ham and melted Cheddar on excellent focaccia; the half was enormous.
No alcoholic beverages are served. Credit cards accepted. Hours: 8 a.m.-midnight daily. 1082 Chapel Street, New Haven. (203) 776-4040.
Someone has a sense of humor at the Book Trader Cafe, in a used bookstore near the Yale campus. Its many blackboard-listed sandwiches include a Tom Soy-er (vegetarian), Jane Rare (roast beef with goat cheese), Vonegut veggie, Ham-ingway (ham and cheese) and Tale of Two Turkeys (two types of turkey sandwiches). Most everything is made on the premises, including the chutneys and most baked goods. The somewhat cramped quarters are relieved by a glass-enclosed atrium with tables. In warm weather, there is an open-air area as well. 
No alcoholic beverages are served. Credit cards accepted on orders over $10. Hours: 7:30 a.m.-9 p.m. Monday through Wednesday, 7:30 a.m.-11 p.m. Thursday through Saturday, 10 a.m.-9 p.m. Sunday. 1140 Chapel Street, New Haven. (203) 787-6147.

HEADLINE: Postings: A Gallery, a Foundation and a Partnership, for West 13th Street Building; 
Purchasing and Sharing

BYLINE:  By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
Two years ago, when a partnership of three Manhattan developers offered to buy the three-story building at 415 West 13th Street, between Ninth Avenue and Washington Street, it found that the Sperrone Westwater Gallery in SoHo also had its eyes on the building. So did the Bohen Foundation in Manhattan, which supports the arts.
 But rather than bid up the price, the competitors decided to join forces to buy the 45,000-square-foot building, which runs through the block between 13th and 14th Streets. Bohen, which is in SoHo, bought the first floor and a third of the basement, and the gallery, on Greene Street, bought the second floor and another third of the basement. 
 The development partnership acquired the third floor, the remainder of the basement and the right to use the excess air rights and construct an additional five floors. It also agreed to build new entrances and new stairways and to install new elevators and heating and cooling systems. The partnership, of William Schaffel, Charles Blaichman and Phillip Katz, is acting as the building's developer.
The cost of the building and of redevelopment, scheduled for completion this fall, will total about $20 million. The developers plan to convert their portion of the building into a commercial condominium and to add the five floors atop the half of the building that faces 13th Street, which will almost double the square footage of the existing structure. Because a concrete sheer wall was required for structural reasons, it will now serve as a dividing line between what will become two buildings -- one fronting on 415 West 13th Street, the other on 412 West 14th Street.
In buying 415 West 13th Street, the purchasers agreed that after their renovations, they would sell the building facing 14th Street back to the original building's former owner, Sam Chen, the founder of Expedi Printing, who moved his company last year to Brooklyn. Mr. Katz said that the developers are now negotiating to retain and then renovate the 14th Street building.
Steven Kratchman, the architect for the buildings, said that the addition of the five floors required reinforcing the existing columns, expanding the foundation footings and using lightweight metal panels on the upper floors to reduce the new loads. 
The new floors will be clad in black glazed brick and black enameled lightweight aluminum panels, instead of the original yellow brick, to make a clean break between the new and the older floors.
The Sinvin Realty Corporation, which will seek tenants or buyers for Floors 3 through 8, expects annual rents to be $38 to $48 a square foot. EDWIN McDOWELL

CORRECTION-DATE: June 2, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Postings column last Sunday about the expansion of a building that runs between West 13th and 14th Streets in Manhattan omitted the name of the design architect. It is Selldorf Architects; Steven Kratchman was the architect of record.

HEADLINE: School Budget Votes: More F's Than Usual 

BYLINE:  By LINDA SASLOW 

 BODY:
FACING proposed tax rate increases that averaged nearly 10 percent, Long Islanders rejected 20 of 126 school budgets on Tuesday, the highest failure rate since statewide same-day school district voting started seven years ago.
 Much of the voter reluctance was traced to the Island's economic slowdown. But taxpayer nervousness over a reassessment of county taxes due next year was not the torpedo that many educators had expected in Nassau County, where school budgets fared better than in Suffolk. Of 56 Nassau districts, only 5 budgets were defeated, in Bethpage, Farmingdale, Herricks, Lawrence and Plainedge. Voters approved double-digit school tax increases in Elmont, Freeport, Garden City, Roslyn and Jericho. Roosevelt, where a new state takeover was completed this month, passed a school budget increase of 18 percent, but carrying a tax increase of only 5.4 percent thanks to an infusion of money from the state. 
 In Suffolk County, budgets were rejected in 15 of the 70 districts, including the Island's two largest districts: Sachem and Brentwood.
"Everyone suspected that this would be a more difficult year," said Richard Hawkins, president of the Suffolk County Council of Superintendents. "After 30 percent of the school budgets were defeated in New Jersey, we were prepared for the worst. On the heels of Sept. 11, with New York State's tenuous fiscal position and the high costs of unfunded mandates, the implementation of the higher standards and increasing student enrollments, we all knew that these were difficult times."
Budgets carrying double-digit tax increases were defeated in the Three Village school district in Setauket and in all three Eastport-South Manor districts -- two K-6 districts and one high school district. Also defeated were budgets in Central Islip, Connetquot, Fishers Island, Hampton Bays, Harborfields, Riverhead, Smithtown and Wyandanch. All will have a second, final chance to resubmit budgets, with or without revisions. 
Sachem's budgets have been rejected three times in two years. Last year, when the budget was voted down twice, the district was forced by law to adopt an austerity budget that eliminated all spending for improving school buildings and purchasing instructional and non-instructional equipment. The district has to decide whether to re-submit its 2002-2003 budget or remain on austerity.
"Being on austerity is a silent killer," the Sachem superintendent, James Ruck, said. "After 2000, when our voters approved a $228 million bond for reconfiguration of the district, they voted down last year's budget because they thought they had given us enough for the capital project. This year, many voters didn't understand that 40 percent of the increase in the budget was for the debt service on the project that they had already approved."
School districts had to notify voters by April 29 of their proposed budgets and proposed tax increases, but state aid packages were not announced until five days before Tuesday's voting. For many districts, the news that Albany had agreed to boost school aid statewide by $420 million, including $73 million for Long Island schools, came too late to make a difference.
John Sonedecker, the Three Village superintendent, said that although the additional $1 million in state aid pegged for his district would have meant a tax rate reduction of one percent, it was announced too late to make a difference at the polls.
"We did an exit survey as voters left the polls," he said. "We found that the community thought it was a good budget, but they didn't think they could afford it."
For Rocky Point, however, getting the word out was a good move. Following the news that the district would be getting more state aid than had been proposed, a tax increase of 33 percent dropped to 12.1 percent.. Late last week, the district did a mass mailing to the community, sent fliers home with every student and initiated a phone campaign. The effort paid off, Superintendent James Gerardi said, when the budget passed.
In Nassau, school districts whose budgets failed were not those with the highest tax increases. Herricks voters rejected a proposed tax increase of 8.8 percent. By contrast, in Hewlett-Woodmere, one of the county's wealthier districts, voters passed a budget with a tax increase of 13 percent, while voters in Freeport, one of the county's poorer districts, said yes to a school budget with a tax increase of 17.9 percent.
