HEADLINE: A Little More Money for Farmers Who Put Milk on the Table 

BYLINE:  By HARLAN J. LEVY 

 BODY:
MAVIS COLLINS, an Enfield dairy farmer, has been in love with cows and the farming life for most of her 55 years. But lately, running the Powder Hill Farm, an average-size Connecticut farm with 85 cows on 240 acres, has been a bittersweet money-losing experience.
 Mavis and her husband, Jack Collins, inheritor of the 125-year-old family heirloom, have had to take out bank loans since 1995 to survive. Then in September, things got worse with the end of federal price supports that had kept losses at manageable levels. The family had to "think seriously about whether milking cows was going to be possible any more," Ms. Collins said sadly. "We're cash-poor, and we live from check to check." 
 A third-generation dairyman, Peter Charter, has had the same experience with his 60 milking cows on 130 acres in rural Ellington. He and his wife, Verna, say they need to sell gravel and lumber to "keep from having to sell the farm."
But help arrived on May 13 when President Bush signed a 10-year $190 billion farm subsidy bill. It includes a new three-year $1.3 billion milk price-support program. On June 1, the guarantee price minimum will be $1.46 a gallon, 33 cents more than what farmers currently get under the market price set monthly by the United States Department of Agriculture. The new amount is still about a nickel less than the average farmer's production cost for a gallon of milk. 
The market price, which is supposed to reflect true market conditions, has been fluctuating between $1.12 and $1.16 a gallon in the Northeast district over the last few months.
Under the new law's formula, dairy farmers will not get the full difference between the market price and the artificially set $1.46 minimum, but rather 45 percent of that difference. For example the farmer would receive the market price plus about 15 cents (which is 45 percent of the difference between the market price and the minimum). That's better than the former program, the five-year-long Northeast Dairy Compact, which also set the minimum price at $1.46 per gallon, but only for milk that consumers drink. It did not include milk used for ice cream, cheese, cottage cheese, and powdered milk, which all are, on average, 45 percent of most farms' production. 
Meanwhile, the farmers were getting only about $1 a gallon for the milk that went into those products while their cost remained the same as for the milk sold for drinking. The new program maintains the minimum for all classes of milk.
But milk prices won't be going up, state Agriculture Commissioner Shirley Ferris said. Under the new law, consumers will not have to directly pay 2 to 3 cents per gallon to help meet the price guarantee, as they did under the Northeast Dairy Compact. The U.S.D.A. will pay the tab, Ms. Ferris said, "and I don't have a problem with that. I relate this to the minimum wage law."
"We definitely need it," Ms. Collins said. "No matter which farmer you speak to these days, it's very rare that the milk check can cover all of our bills each month just to keep the farm running and not our personal bills."
Milk prices have been "so bad," Mr. Charter said, "that we're netting what we got in the 1970's. In New England we have to go out and look for other sources of money to keep the door open."
To break even, dairy farmers need about $1.50 a gallon, said Gabe Moquin, State Agriculture deputy director. The new price support program will help, he said. 
Five years ago, Connecticut had 270 dairy farmers. Today there are 215, and the average age of those farmers is 55 to 60. The state has been losing dairy farmers at a rate of 10 percent a year. "Without the new program," Mr. Moquin said, "we would probably double the number going out of business to 20 percent a year. So it'll encourage farmers to remain in business," fighting the trend of ever-larger farms near metropolitan areas dominating their markets.
It's important that the state maintains its dairy farms, Ms. Ferris said. "We could never exist with just a few large farms close to the city," she added. "They couldn't meet the demand, and the small farmers out in the hinterlands would get socked with transportation expenses that they could not pass on to the consumer" because of the low federally set market prices. 
"That would mean less fresh milk in the state," Ms. Ferris said, "and that's why the federal government regulates milk." 
As Ms. Collins sees it, she and her fellow dairy farmers need to supplement their income with other products to survive. The Collinses' son-in-law, Anthony Bellafronte, runs an ice cream shop on the farm -- with 30 flavors -- from March through October. The family has an active compost business as well. 
The Collinses' 22-year-old son, John, wants to continue in the family business, Ms. Collins said, and their 25-year-old daughter, Tracey, hopes to open a vegetable stand later this year. "The new farm bill gives my son more encouragement to keep farming," Ms. Collins said, "but if it doesn't continue, he would seriously have to find work off the farm, and we would have to eliminate some of our helpers."
When the Northeast Milk Compact expired in September, Ms. Collins said, dairy farmers immediately began to lag on bill payments. "Now it will take a while to catch up to compensate for the loss," she said.
The new law stabilizes the milk price for dairy farmers, Mr. Moquin said. 
"It takes out some of the peaks and valleys of pricing milk to the consumer, who ought to be able to expect a fairly level price in the supermarket," he said.
Still, farmers are giving up, Mr. Moquin said, due to the rising cost of land, capital improvements, labor, insurance, grain to feed the cows, taxes, and services.
But the Collinses and Charters say they won't quit. 
"Everybody does various things to keep from selling the farm," Mr. Charter said. 
Ms. Collins says she has dairy farming in her blood. She was raised on an English dairy farm and graduated from an agricultural college west of London before taking a long holiday in Connecticut. Her temporary work on the Collins farm turned permanent when she married into the family.
"When the boss couldn't pay me any more, he let me marry his son," she joked. 
"It's a good life, and I wouldn't choose any other life. And if we have to work seven days a week, we will, because we really don't mind, as long as we can keep those bills paid up," she said.
Consumers get much more than just readily available fresh milk, Ms. Ferris said. "In this state, probably 60 to 70 percent of the working landscape is utilized by dairy farmers. They're good for the economy. They're good for tourism, and they're good for the environment."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Mavis and Jack Collins, left, run the Powder Hill Farm in Enfield. They got help when President Bush signed a 10-year $190 billion farm subsidy bill. "It's very rare that the milk check can cover all of our bills each month," Ms. Collins said. (Photographs by C. M. Glover for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ART REVIEWS; 
Drills and Blowdryers Rendered as Still Lifes

BYLINE:  By D. Dominick Lombardi 

 BODY:
 "The Spring Show"
Main Street Gallery, 26 Main Street, Dobbs Ferry, through June 2. (914) 674-9171.
 Main Street Gallery is a commercial gallery that normally features the work of artists from New York City, Connecticut, upstate New York and Westchester County.
For this exhibit, the gallery's director, Peggie Blizard, and her husband, Larry, are showing their own paintings and drawings separately in each of the gallery's two main rooms.
Ms. Blizard said her husband was "fascinated with chaos," a fact that is abundantly clear when viewing his work. What matters most here, is what Mr. Blizard sees in chaos.
In his drawings, not so innocent angels frolic and romp through otherwise benign real-life situations causing havoc that largely goes unnoticed. 
One of the winged pranksters gets caught in the act, however, in "The Dormer Window" (2000).
His paintings are airy and loosely rendered, and viewers should have fun trying to decipher the complex narrative aspect of his work.
Ms. Blizard's paintings are far more focused and realistic. She paints still lifes, selecting power tools and other small appliances like blow dryers as her subjects. 
Sometimes, like in "Power Drill" (2001), she adds a highly textured, monochrome background that nicely contrasts the precision used to render her subjects.

"Inaugural Exhibition"
The Studio, 2 Maryland Avenue, Armonk through July 27. (914) 273-1452.
For the inaugural show in their new space, Tedd and Katie Stratis selected more than 60 works of art from 23 regional artists. The Studio is both an indoor gallery space and a sculpture garden, which allows them to display large, outdoor sculptures as well as small works on paper.
J. Pindyck Miller's "Hawaiian Holiday" (1980's) is this exhibition's most impressive outdoor piece. It is painted yellow, which gives it far greater presence than its 5 1/2-by-12-foot mass would normally command. Add to this its elegant voids and strong shadows, and one is left with the suggestion of depth and perspective that is normally encountered in representational painting.
In the indoor space, Mr. Pindyck Miller has two mixed media works titled "Wooster Collage No. 9 -- Fleurs d'Hiver" and "Wooster Collage No. 10 -- Smoke" (both 2001). 
The eroded surfaces of the paper used to create these collages has the look of decollage, which is a reductive process of tearing into existing layers of posted theater bills.
The minimization of elements in these two works are reminiscent of Robert Motherwell's collages.
Adrienne Cullom's "Mask for Celebrating Magnificent Traditions" (2001) is a soft, mask-like sculpture made of knotted fiber. Visitors should find this work to be one of her most interesting, since it is the most abstract of the three. On the other hand, Ms. Cullom's "Orchestration of Lines" (1998) is less successful and far too derivative of Frank Stella's cigar smoke prints. 
Joyce Wenglowski's "Between Places" (2000) depicts an empty subway station. The expressive painting style, the intense contrast of the cool grays against the stark yellows, and the exaggerated way in which she indicates perspective brings to mind this underground experience.

"Rough/Havana/Refined"
Henaine Fine Art, 6 North Pearl Street, 404-F, Port Chester, through June 12. (914) 939-5334.
Leslie Long loves tropical places. As a photographer, this Westchester resident is looking for special cultural experiences and has apparently found one in Havana. 
Her show at Henaine Fine Art reveals the almost surreal quality of a crumbling city of Havana that, despite its economic woes, is rich in culture and life. 
For this exhibition, Ms. Long offers 17 black and white archival gelatin silver prints all taken in Havana, in March 2001.
Photographs like "Celebrating" and "Twirling" show a city in disrepair; still functioning and driven by an undying human spirit. 
"Railing" shows that a decayed stairwell can be beautiful and poetic if one takes the time to look. "Drinking" portrays a newly emptied daiquiri glass against a shimmering field of soft highlights that form a fluid composition not unlike a predawn, artificially illuminated rainy city street.
This contrast between the clarity of the foreground and the blurry background can be seen again in the aforementioned "Celebrating," whereas the opposite occurs in works like "Cruise Ship: Leaving" and "Preening" where the foreground fades and the background comes into focus giving the work a political, albeit tentative undertone.
The angle or vantage point of the photographer's lens in works like "Floating" and "Resting" adds a voyeuristic quality while "Whispering," which depicts a young man peering through an open doorway into a classroom almost seems awkward, even intrusive.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "Resting," left, by Leslie Long is in "Rough/Havana/Refined," an exhibition at Henaine Fine Art in Port Chester.; Detail of J. Pindyck Miller's "Hawaiian Holiday," above, part of the "Inaugural Exhibition," an exhibition at the Studio in Armonk.; Detail of "Still Life With Pink Boxes," below, by Peggie Blizard, which is part of "The Spring Show" at Main Street Gallery in Dobbs Ferry.

HEADLINE: Trying to Foreclose on Foreclosure 

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
THURSDAYS can be busy days for Joseph Bonner. 
 Two Thursdays ago, for example, Mr. Bonner sold 20 properties in Hudson County, N.J., in an hour and a half. 
 Mr. Bonner is not a wildly successful real estate agent, and the properties were not the hottest new listings on the market. He is the executive assistant to Joseph T. Cassidy, the sheriff of Hudson County, and the properties he sells are in foreclosure. 
"So far this year, we've issued about 250 new numbers," Mr. Bonner said, referring to the case numbers assigned to foreclosure sales scheduled by the sheriff's office. "There's no telling how many of those will actually end up being sold."
In fact, mortgage experts say, while the number of mortgage delinquencies has increased in the last five years or so, the proportion of homes that end up being sold through foreclosure has been declining. And that, the experts say, is largely because of lenders' intensified efforts to work out arrangements with delinquent borrowers that let them avoid foreclosure and stay in their homes whenever possible.
Among those arrangements are special forbearance agreements, where the lender may temporarily reduce mortgage payments; mortgage modification plans, where the borrower refinances the mortgage to one with a lower monthly payment; and partial claims, in which the Department of Housing and Urban Development will provide certain homeowners with the money necessary to make a delinquent mortgage current.
The key to taking advantage of a lender's willingness to help, however, is a borrower's willingness to confront a problem before it spirals out of control. The borrowers must contact their lender, a lawyer or a debt counseling agency, while at the same time avoiding the opportunists who descend on them once a lender has started foreclosure.
"Foreclosure is never a surprise," said David Petrovich, executive director of the Society for the Preservation of Continued Homeownership, a not-for-profit loan-counseling organization in Oakhurst, N.J. "As soon as you miss that first payment, you know you're in trouble. And if you're not making your mortgage payment, you're probably not paying your other bills, either. That's when the phone starts ringing, people start demanding money, and you're really at your wit's end."
In the midst of that maelstrom, Mr. Petrovich said, many borrowers will be contacted by any number of individuals or organizations that offer to help the homeowner avoid foreclosure. And while many of those offers may be legitimate, he said, others could leave the homeowner worse off than before.
"There is a proliferation of scamsters out there," Mr. Petrovich said. Some homeowners against whom foreclosure actions have been filed are contacted by individuals who try to persuade them to avoid the stigma of foreclosure by having the homeowner signing over title to the house to them and then remain in the house as their tenants.
"They tell you to pay them rent and they'll work out something with the mortgage lender," Mr. Petrovich said. Meanwhile, he said, the so-called benefactor makes no payments on the mortgage, works out no arrangement with the lender and collects rent from the resident until the foreclosure sale takes place. 
"If anyone asks you to sign your house over to avoid foreclosure," Mr. Petrovich said, "run the other way."
But that does not mean the homeowner can ignore the problem. The machinery of foreclosure can start very shortly after the first payment is missed.
Bruce J. Bergman, an East Meadow, N.Y., lawyer who is author of the three-volume "Bergman on New York Mortgage Foreclosures" (Matthew Bender, 2002), said most mortgages provide that if a borrower does not make payments as required, the lender can demand that the entire balance of the loan, which might otherwise be due 20 or 30 years later, be paid immediately.
Mr. Bergman pointed out, however, that the widely used Fannie Mae/Freddie Mac mortgage form requires the lender to send a 30-day cure letter to the borrower. He explained that such a letter gives the borrower 30 days to bring payments current or face acceleration of the balance of the loan. "After the 30 days have passed, the lender basically has the option of saying we no longer wish to accept the arrears, but we declare due now the entire balance of the loan.
"As a practical matter," Mr. Bergman said, "most lenders will attempt to collect arrears and will not start foreclosure proceedings for at least three months or more." When a foreclosure is started, he said, the lender's attorney will typically search the public records to determine whether anyone else has any liens on the property and name those parties as defendants in the foreclosure action. That step ensures that whoever buys the property at the foreclosure sale will get title free of liens. Identifying, tracking down and serving other lienholders with the foreclosure papers, however, "can take many months," Mr. Bergman said.
When the necessary parties have been served and the time for filing answers to the suit has expired, he said, the lender's lawyer takes steps leading up to the home's sale. In New York, Mr. Bergman said, the lender typically asks the court to appoint a referee to compute the sum due under the mortgage and, once that has been determined, asks the court to issue a judgment of foreclosure and sale. 
"The judgment of foreclosure and sale provides that a sale shall be conducted under the direction of the referee," Mr. Bergman said, adding that after running the required advertisements of the sale -- a process that takes about four weeks -- the referee conducts the sale at the scheduled time and place.
IN most foreclosure auctions, sales prices can range from as little as $100, if the lender is the only bidder, to the amount owed to the lender or even more if the bidding is intense. 
"The whole world is free to bid at a foreclosure sale," Mr. Bergman said, "and once the hammer falls, the homeowner no longer owns the property." He added that in New York, the successful bidder must typically post with the referee a deposit of 10 percent of the sale price in the form of cash, certified check or bank check. The balance, he said, is due within 30 days, a factor that makes buying at a foreclosure sale difficult for most ordinary people.
(In New Jersey, after a court has issued a judgment of foreclosure, the sheriff in the county where the property is situated conducts the foreclosure sale and requires a deposit of 20 percent from the successful bidder. But the borrower has a right of redemption, that is, the right to reclaim ownership of the property by paying all amounts due on the loan -- including late charges and legal fees -- for up to 10 days after the sale. In New York there is no right of redemption, and in Connecticut there is no right of redemption after a foreclosure sale has been confirmed by a court.)
While a homeowner can arrange a so-called workout to avoid foreclosure at any stage, the experts agree that the faster a borrower acts, the better his chances.
"Early intervention is absolutely the key," said Joseph Sakole, vice president of loss mitigation for Fannie Mae. "The sooner a borrower in trouble contacts his lender, the easier it will be for the lender to help solve the problems." In fact, he said, most lenders and mortgage service companies have foreclosure prevention departments.
Fannie Mae, a government-created company that buys residential mortgage loans on the secondary market, has recently created a number of Home Saver Solutions for borrowers who fall behind on their mortgage, Mr. Sakole said. For example, he said, one of the "easiest fixes" Fannie Mae lenders can provide occurs when a borrower misses a single payment. "Basically, if this is a one-time occurrence, we'll work out a pay plan so that the borrower can spread out the arrearages over five months," he said. Such a workout, he added, is most useful for borrowers who have had a temporary drop in income, possibly because of a job loss or unexpected bills. Since the idea is to catch an incipient problem before it becomes a significant one, Mr. Sakole said, the borrower needs to notify the lender immediately.
It is also possible for homeowners who have fallen behind on their mortgages to take advantage of some other strategies intended to avoid foreclosure.
Adam Glantz, a spokesman for HUD, said that in some cases, lenders will agree to a "special forbearance," whereby the lender may provide for a temporary reduction or suspension of mortgage payments to let a homeowner in arrears recover. In most cases, Mr. Glantz said, those most likely to qualify for a special forbearance have temporarily lost jobs or incurred unusual expenses and can prove that they will be able to make future mortgage payments.
Another possibility, Mr. Glantz said, is a mortgage modification. 
"You may be able to refinance the debt or extend the term of your mortgage loan," he said, explaining that if current interest rates are significantly less than the interest rate on the mortgage, the lender might be willing to refinance the loan to a lower rate, reducing the monthly payment. As with other arrangements made with lenders, Mr. Glantz said, the borrower must be able to convince the lender that he is in a position to make the new mortgage payments.
In some cases, he said, homeowners who have loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration and who are behind in their mortgage payments may be able to get a "partial claim" from HUD. Mr. Glantz explained that if an F.H.A. loan was delinquent for between four months and a year and the lender had not yet started a foreclosure, a partial claim may be possible if the borrower can show that he can resume the regular monthly payments.
WITH a partial claim, he said, HUD provides the money to the lender to bring the mortgage current in exchange for the borrower's agreeing to repay the money to HUD -- interest free -- when the property is sold.
But why would lenders be willing to go so far to help out borrowers who are not making payments?
"Because your lender doesn't want to own your house," said Douglas Duncan, chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association, a trade organization based in Washington.
Mr. Duncan pointed out that there were other potential solutions to mortgage problems that lenders might consider. If there is enough equity in the house to pay off the mortgage should the house be sold, the lender may hold off on foreclosing, provided that the lender believes the borrower is making a good-faith effort to sell the home at a reasonable price.
In addition, he said, a lender may agree to a "deed in lieu of foreclosure." With that, he said, the lender agrees to accept title to the house from the borrower instead of foreclosing.
"That gives the lender more flexibility in disposing of the property," Mr. Duncan said. "And the borrower doesn't end up with a foreclosure judgment against him."
The last resort for borrowers who are in over their heads, of course, is bankruptcy. And while filing for bankruptcy will usually delay a foreclosure sale for a few months, the homeowner generally loses the house in the end. Under certain circumstances, however, filing for bankruptcy can prevent a foreclosure sale and keep a homeowner in the home.
Mr. Bergman, the East Meadow lawyer, said that when a homeowner files for bankruptcy, the foreclosure proceeding is immediately suspended, or "stayed." In "straight" bankruptcies filed under Chapter 7 of the Bankruptcy Code -- which results in the permanent forgiveness of all of a debtor's dischargeable debts -- the lender usually asks the court to lift the stay and allow the foreclosure to proceed. If there is no equity in the property -- meaning the market value of the house does not exceed the amount owed -- that request is usually granted, he said. 
If there is equity in the property, however, Mr. Bergman said, it is likely that the court will permit the trustee to sell the property to satisfy the mortgage debt and to help pay off other debts of the debtor. 
With a bankruptcy petition filed under Chapter 13 of the Bankruptcy Code, however, the person filing the petition is basically asking for a restructuring of the debt rather than the total discharge of all debts. In such a case, Mr. Bergman said, the bankruptcy court will assess the homeowner's financial condition to determine whether it is feasible for the homeowner to pay off all accrued debt -- including arrears on the mortgage -- in monthly installments over a period of years.
"The maximum number of years you can get is five years," Mr. Bergman said, adding that once a Chapter 13 bankruptcy petition is filed, the homeowner must remain current with his monthly mortgage payments. 
One key to getting a Chapter 13 bankruptcy, as with any other strategy that will prevent a foreclosure, is to consult with an expert as soon as possible.
"Timing is critical," said Vincent J. Freccia III, a Stamford, Conn., lawyer who specializes in foreclosures. He said that it is much easier for a borrower who is only one or two months behind to work out a deal with a lender -- or to qualify for a Chapter 13 bankruptcy -- than for a borrower who is six or seven months in arrears. And the earlier a borrower can get to an expert, he said, the more time the expert has to explore potential options.
"In most cases, there isn't any legal defense to the foreclosure," Mr. Freccia said. "But if I can manage to get the homeowner a little extra time before the foreclosure sale, he might be able to refinance or sell the house on his own."
Homeowners without the means to hire a lawyer can generally get free counseling from nonprofit agencies like Neighborhood Housing Services of New York City.
KEN DAVIS, program director for foreclosure prevention in the organization's Brooklyn office -- there are 10 offices throughout the city -- said that his office alone provides free foreclosure counseling to more than 400 homeowners each year. 
"The first thing we do is tell them to bring in the last four months' bank statements, some recent pay stubs, a copy of their tax return and a written explanation as to why they fell behind," Mr. Davis said. "Then we prepare a budget that details what the homeowner can afford to pay and we submit it to the lender."
In many cases, he said, if the homeowner has a job and the ability to continue making payments and has not fallen too far behind, a competent housing counselor can work out some kind of arrangement to stop the foreclosure and keep the person in the home.
Even if such an arrangement cannot be worked out, Mr. Davis said, it may be possible for the counselor to arrange what is known as a "preforeclosure short sale." With that, he said, the lender allows the homeowner to sell the property -- even though the sale price will be less than the amount due on the loan -- and then forgives the remaining balance.
(A state-by-state list of housing counseling organizations can be found on the Web site of the Department of Housing and Urban Development at www.hud.gov. While there are legitimate and effective counseling services not on the HUD list, including Internet-based companies that charge for their services, homeowners should check with their local Better Business Bureau or state attorney general's office to determine whether a company has been the subject of any complaints.)
"The biggest mistake people make when they're in trouble," Mr. Davis said, "is not doing anything."

HEADLINE: CENSUS; 
In a Twist, Female-Led Families Gain

BYLINE:  By RICHARD LEZIN JONES 

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
IN a sign of the persistent gap between rich and poor even in flush times -- the number of New Jersey residents living in poverty increased slightly in the past decade, according to census information made public last week.
 But over the same period, the number of poor households headed by women with young children -- long one of poverty's most intractable demographic segments -- fell to its lowest level in the last 20 years. 
 Analysts said that the disparate findings could indicate that many of the reforms to the welfare system were beginning to take hold, driving more single mothers into the work force. The figures may also show that the celebrated tide of economic prosperity during the 1990's did not lift all boats. 
"The rich got richer, the poor got poorer and the middle class stagnated," said Barrie Peterson, of Seton Hall University's Institute on Work. "That's the numbers. The question is, 'Gee, if this is happening during a boom time, what's the matter here?' That's one of the fundamental questions that needs to be asked."
Census figures show that from 1990 to 2000 the number of families in New Jersey living below the poverty level -- defined under federal guidelines as about $18,000 for a family of four -- grew about two-thirds of a percentage point to 6.25 percent.
The decade also saw the portion female-led households with children under age 5 fall more than 8 percentage points to 37.25 percent.
The latest numbers represent a continuation of a 20-year-long trend that has seen the percentage of such households fall by nearly a quarter since 1980, when 61.20 percent lived in poverty.
Mr. Peterson said that the drop in poverty in households led by women might be attributable to any number of factors, including a decline in the state's birth rate to the increased availability of child care (allowing more single mothers to work) to women having more success in winning delinquent child-support payments in recent years.
That decline also runs counter to an increase in the percentage of single New Jerseyans living in poverty, which rose about a percentage point, to 8.5 percent.
"It's kind of counterintuitive that the group that has been pushed more into poverty has been individuals," said Andrew A. Beveridge, a sociology professor at Queens College who conducted the poverty analyses for The New York Times.
While the disparities in the figures might make it more difficult to identify a dominant trend, Professor Beveridge agreed that they might suggest that the economic prosperity of the 1990's was relatively limited in scope and not just in New Jersey.
"In places like Connecticut, New York, the boom did not penetrate to the immigrant community, to the minority community, to some of the people we don't see and know," he said. "So, if you were upper-, middle- or in the higher classes, there was a boom."
But the numbers indicate that the boom may have bypassed many others, particularly those in the state's largest urban areas. Of the state's four most populous cities, Paterson saw the greatest increase in the percentage of poor families, which grew by more than 3 percent. Paterson, New Jersey's third-largest city, also saw the largest increase in the percentage of female-led households with young children living in poverty; the number grew by more than 3 percent from 1990 to 2000.
Of the state's largest municipalities, only Jersey City saw declines in the percentages of both families and female-led households living in poverty. Jersey City also noted declines in the percentage of individuals living in poverty.
The census figures about poor single women and children may dovetail with a report released last week by a children's advocacy group that New Jersey children were faring better than they had in a decade by such measures as infant mortality and child deaths.
The report, "Kids Count," by the Annie E. Casey Foundation, also found that the state must still contend with its share of nettlesome issues. The report indicated that more babies were born underweight in New Jersey and that more children were living with only one parent.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Alice Chen, Joshua Plotkin

 BODY:
Alice Siau-In Chen, a daughter of Dr. Lin-Lin Chen and Dr. Ching-Jygh Chen of Jackson, Miss., is to be married today to Joshua Benjamin Plotkin, a son of Janet Bufe Plotkin and Dr. 
Irving H. Plotkin of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. F. Washington Jarvis, an Episcopal priest, will officiate at a ceremony blending elements of Judaism and Buddhism at the Harvard University chapel in Cambridge.
 The bride, 28, and bridegroom, 26, met at Harvard, where she graduated magna cum laude and he summa cum laude. 
 The bride, who will be known as Alice Chen-Plotkin, received a master's degree in biological sciences from Oxford University, where she was a Rhodes scholar. She is now a fourth-year medical student at Harvard and received a Paul and Daisy Soros Fellowship for New Americans. Her parents are ophthalmologists at the University of Mississippi Medical Center in Jackson, where the bride's father is the department chairman.
The bridegroom received a master's degree in mathematical biology from Princeton, where he is a candidate for a doctorate in applied mathematics. He also researches theoretical biology at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, of which he is a member. He was recently named a junior fellow of the Harvard Society of Fellows, where in July he will begin doing applied mathematical research. 
His father, who was the vice president for forensic economics until March at Arthur D. Little, the consulting company in Cambridge, now is the managing director for tax services in Boston for PriceWaterhouseCoopers, the accounting firm. The bridegroom's mother retired as the head tutor at the Carroll School, a private school for language-disabled children in Lincoln, Mass., and is a board member of the Rockport Chamber Music Festival in Massachusetts and the Friends of McLean Hospital in Belmont, Mass.

HEADLINE: Bush and Latin America 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "U.S. Hasn't Kept Promises to Latin America, Critics Say" (news article, May 19) speaks of "a sense of betrayal by many countries in the region" in reaction to the Bush administration's Latin America policy. Having followed the United States' advice as to how to manage their economies and having expected a closer and more profitable relationship with the United States, they now find the United States increasingly indifferent to their plight. 
 Argentines may have a special peeve, for while President Bush now asserts that he knows nothing of Enron, he acted as a lobbyist for Enron in 1988. He urged the privatization of Argentina's publicly owned energy system and insisted that Enron be given first option to buy up gas, electricity, water and other Argentine utilities. By and large, Enron was given that option, with the same disastrous results that Enron brought everywhere.

WAYNE S. SMITH
Senior Fellow
Center for International Policy
Washington, May 20, 2002

SECTION: Section 14; Column 4; The City Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2621 words

HEADLINE: Passing the Torch 

BYLINE:  By ANNE HEMMETT STERN 

 BODY:
NEW YORKERS take for granted the essentials of city life: takeout, MetroCards, yellow cabs, all part of the daily thrum. For decades, New Yorkers haven't thought twice about waking up at 3 a.m. with a longing for kiwi or popcorn because they know the Korean-owned delis are there. 
 These beacons of convenience have brightened the slate-gray streets since the late 60's and 70's, when waves of Koreans stepped in to replace the city's aging Italian and Jewish greengrocers. Whether white-collar or working-class, the newcomers struggled to find jobs and often wedged their ambitions between narrow store walls, much like the grocer father in Chang-rae Lee's acclaimed 1995 novel "Native Speaker," a quintessential member of the first generation. 
 They labored mightily, pioneering the all-night grocery, and in the process creating a now familiar imprint around the city. Chris Choi, secretary general of the Korean Grocers Association, estimates that Koreans own 2,000 grocery-delis out of 3,000 grocery-related businesses in the five boroughs. 
More than 30 years have elapsed since the first generation of Koreans began tempting New Yorkers with their wares. Many have already retired. Who is minding the store now? The expected answer -- those immigrants' children -- is almost always wrong.
"There's no desire on the parents' part to have their kids take over the stores," said Fred Carriere, vice president and executive director of the Korea Society. "They want their kids to go to Harvard and become doctors and lawyers."
As a result, today's Korean delis are typically managed by more recent Korean immigrants. Some of these later arrivals belong to what is known as the "ilchom ose" or "1.5" generation, born there, raised here. Others came as adults, on student visas or sponsored by relatives. But regardless of their roots, today's city greengrocers differ markedly from their predecessors. 
To the customer hurrying in at the end of the day for the makings of dinner, the faces behind the counter may look the same, if younger and less careworn. But few of the new breed plan to make careers of running groceries, as their predecessors did. 
Some pursue the business reluctantly, looking for ways to branch out or escape entirely. Others long for a 9-to-5 job and time with their children. Still others echo the earlier grocers in energy but have transformed the business to offer products far beyond the labor-intensive fruits and vegetables favored by their elders.
For all of them, the economics of running a small business in the city have grown more complex, especially after Sept. 11. Here are the stories of three members of the new generation.
IN a rare quiet moment one recent afternoon, Chang Hwan Han stole a little time from his workday to read a few pages of a biography of the Mongol Emperor Kublai Khan. With his beard and long ponytail, Mr. Han, 36, looks like the laid-back graduate student he was a decade ago. He seems almost perplexed to be a grocer, as though he is still puzzling out how he made the journey from scholar to convenience store owner. 
The journey began in 1976, when his parents arrived in New York with three sons under 11 and 300 hardcover books, "all mine," Mr. Han said. His father got a job at a friend's grocery on the Upper West Side and, within a year, opened his own store, the Han Family Market, at Broadway and West 93rd Street. Financing came from a "kye," the Korean version of the rotating credit club whose members contribute equally to a communal pool.
The Hans lived in a one-bedroom apartment near the store. Though the family practiced Confucianism, the boys attended St. Hilda's and St. Hugh's, an Episcopal school in Morningside Heights.
Like just about all Korean grocers of the day, Chang's parents were on duty 18 hours a day, seven days a week. By age 11, Chang was helping out after school and during vacations. He made a game of wrapping heads of lettuce. 
"I used to be able to package one case under eight minutes or something," he said. And he would tell himself, "I'm just as good as these grownups." He liked being with his parents. But he never imagined he would one day own a store himself.
In 1984, when Mr. Han was still in his teens, his family bought a house in Englewood, N.J., one of the suburban communities that attracted many of the city's successful Korean grocers. Mr. Han went on to receive a bachelor's degree in Asian studies and political science from the University of Michigan and began a master's program at Stanford, much to the delight of his mother.
"She wanted me to be a professor," he said. "She figured I'm not going to be a lawyer, so she thought, you know, professor's not bad."
But he took a leave in 1992 to nurse his father, who was dying, and never returned. Borrowing money from relatives, he took over a lunch place in Philadelphia, sold it two years later, and used the proceeds to put a down payment on an uncle's grocery on Broadway near West 79th Street.
Despite the name, Sirius Vegetables, vegetables are a small part of the inventory. Rows of flowers bedeck the sidewalk beneath the store's blue awning. Under the gleaming silver ceiling, the nearly 2,000-square-foot space is stocked for every household need.
In some ways, Mr. Han is retracing his parents' footsteps. When his mother died in 1998, he moved his family into the house in Englewood. His two sons, 5 and 7, go to his old school.
But there are differences. Unlike most of his father's generation, who turned to kyes because borrowing from a bank was almost impossible, Mr. Han has been able to secure bank loans.
Running a grocery in the current economic climate is a challenge, and individual grocers are intensely private about costs. But Harry Chun, founder and executive director of the Korean Produce Association, which represents merchants in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, estimates that the average Manhattan grocery takes in $80,000 a month. Most of this, about 60 percent, goes to merchandise. Nearly 30 percent goes to wages, rent, taxes and utilities. The remaining 10 percent, about $8,000 a month, is profit.
Although 2,000 people pass through Mr. Han's store daily, individual sales are modest. In January, when he renewed his lease, the rent jumped 50 percent. Because of the uncertainty he has been "desperately trying to get out of that grocery business."
He added, "If Victoria's Secret wants to come in, you're out of there."
Another departure from the pioneering generation is expansion into related businesses to help a merchant escape from pure greengrocering. Mr. Han has branched out into restaurants and now runs two. Two years ago he opened Emo's, on Second Avenue near 81st Street, featuring fledgling actors as waiters and music from the Beatles to Alicia Keys. Emo's has a decidedly American flavor, and the spicing of traditional Korean dishes like kal bi, succulent marinated short ribs, is muted to accommodate a Western palate. At Rice Bowl, which Mr. Han opened last fall on Broadway near 71st Street, a staff of friendly students serves a variety of ready-made Asian foods in a trendy, cafeteria-style setting with decor heavy on wood and umber-hued fixtures.
For Mr. Han, the restaurants are the next step. "All I've done is small businesses," he said. "Am I going to go work for AT&T all of a sudden? So what do you do? You've got to scramble."
DANIEL YANG once dreamed of directing movies and television shows. Today, at 44, he is unexpectedly committed to his grocery businesses, though his sense of purpose is tinged with disappointment.
Mr. Yang came to America in 1982 after studying theater design at the Art University of Seoul and completing three years of compulsory military service. He was 25. His goal was a degree from the University of Wisconsin. 
But tuition and living expenses ate up his savings in less than a semester, and he couldn't find a job. At a friend's suggestion, he moved to New York, where he soon shared a fifth-floor one-bedroom walkup in Jamaica, Queens.
For the next three years, Mr. Yang studied communications at York College, part of the City University system, and earned the money to pay the modest tuition by working 12-hour days on weekends and during vacations at a Korean deli on Second Avenue. It was there, in 1985, that he met a young Frenchwoman named Collette Rouille, who managed an uncle's restaurant a few doors down. The couple married six months later, and at his wife's request, Mr. Yang renamed himself Daniel. She said his real given name, Dong Kyu, sounded too much like "thank you."
When he graduated in 1986, his uncertain command of English limited his options. 
"I had to open a little eye on finding some strengths for my life," he said. "When I graduated from school, you know, it was very hard to get a job for the field that I studied for. Because English is my second language, I cannot express and communicate same as American does." He considered returning to Korea but thought it too much to ask of his wife. "Steadily my dreams faded away," he said.
For a few years, he managed a Korean grocery on the Upper East Side, and in 1992 he and a partner bought Hudson Gourmet, south of 10th Street. While the first generation dealt primarily in labor-intensive fruit and vegetables, the sandwiches, salads and packaged goods favored by their successors require less menial work and yield a higher profit margin. At Hudson Gourmet, fruits and vegetables are only a tenth of the inventory.
Within a year, Mr. Yang arranged to buy out his partner for $210,000. For three years, he worked 13-hour days, seven days a week, to pay off that expense. The hard work gave him hope. 
"It was like marathon running all day long," he said. "Sometimes I felt like I had fire on my feet."
His attitude stands in contrast to that of members of the 1.5 generation, who are generally discouraged from greengrocering even though some make it their life work. Its members speak fluent, if gently accented, English, and they see themselves as American as well as Korean, and thus as having more options than those who arrive as adults. Mr. Yang's perspective seems closer to that of the first generation. 
"I still feel like I'm sitting in somebody else's chair," he said, "like I'm renting the chair."
In an effort to expand his options, last fall he opened Kaffe Deli Market Place on Remsen Street in Brooklyn Heights. "I had the 'grand opening' on Sept. 10," he said. "The next day there was a lot of smoke." But he is sanguine about prospects for the Brooklyn store, despite its tough start.
"I can handle it," he said the other day, hands clasped over one knee of his carefully pressed jeans as he sat in the tidy back dining area. "If I'll be dying on the floor in one of my stores, I'll be happy, because I did my best."
His goal is to open a megastore specializing in organic produce. He wants to move from his apartment in Astoria, Queens, to Long Island for the benefit of his son and daughter, 8 and 15, who he hopes will work in what he calls "fancy jobs" when they grow up. 
He also hopes to feel less as if he is renting another person's chair. 
"I would like to settle down," he said, "try to feel like home in every way."
PLANTED firmly behind the checkout counter of Bear Farm on Broadway near 105th Street, Elizabeth Lee, 34, is a whirlwind of activity. Swiveling from register to counter and back, she weighs produce, rings it up and bags it, processing each customer's purchases as quickly as a pieceworker on an assembly line. "O.K., how are you?" she asks an elderly woman who struggles to convey her shopping from basket to counter. "I got it. Just let me take care of everything." 
Nearby, her husband stands on a milk crate, restocking shelves. As laconic as his wife is loquacious, he carefully places one apple atop another as if building a pyramid of cards.
Despite the couple's immersion in their work, Ms. Lee hopes they will leave the grocery business soon. 
"My question to myself is, 'Do I want to work 13-hour days for the rest of my life?' " she said. "Do I want to throw $100 at my kid and say, 'Go play with your friends because Mommy doesn't have time to be with you?' I want to suffer here for a few years and then get out."
Ms. Lee's path to Bear Farm was anything but direct. She was born Young Oak Doe just south of the boundary between North and South Korea. In 1968, her mother fell in love with a Mexican-American G.I. and followed him back to the United States, leaving behind her husband and infant daughter. Seven years later, married to the soldier, the mother reappeared, scooped up her daughter and whisked her to the largely Mexican-American city of Salinas, Calif. 
"What's that language you're speaking?" the mother asked when her daughter came home from school speaking Spanish. "This is English, no?" the child replied.
But she quickly adapted to her new homeland. At 19, she changed her name to Elizabeth and became an American citizen. At 25, she moved to New York, and six years later she met a Korean immigrant named Sing Lee, soon to rename himself Tommy Lee, at a friend's wedding. They married two months later. 
At the time, Ms. Lee was working for a Flushing importer, her husband was employed by a Manhattan wig wholesaler, and the couple had no intention of going into the grocery business. 
"We wanted to live a 9-to-5-job life and try to save some money together," Ms. Lee said. "To live a very moderate life, go to movies, have dinner together. Not all the headache of running a business." 
They acquired the store a year after their marriage simply to help out a relative; the owner, Mr. Lee's sister, was on the verge of bankruptcy. As part of a continuing investigation into wage practices in greengroceries, the state attorney general's office had ordered her to pay her six workers $62,500 in back salary. To make the purchase, the Lees borrowed from a friend -- how much, they wouldn't say -- and hope to be out of debt by year's end. 
The hours are less grueling and more flexible than those of the first generation. But the going is still as hard as the concrete floor on which the Lees stand 13 hours a day, five days a week. They leave their Flushing apartment at 7 each weekday morning and return after 10 at night. Except on weekends, when Ms. Lee stays home and her husband works half days, they don't see much of their 7-month-old son. 
"Right now me and my husband are in that kind of hard stage," Ms. Lee said. "But the American dream doesn't happen overnight; white picket fences, you know?"
Like most second-generation grocers, the Lees use a distributor, saving themselves the previous generation's daily grind of predawn drives to the Hunts Point wholesale market in the Bronx, not to mention the discrimination that confronted their predecessors. Harry Chun of the Korean Produce Association tells stories of bleary-eyed first-generation grocers who were told by wholesalers that prime parking spaces were reserved for whites. Now that 60 percent of the buyers are Korean, the market is more welcoming.
The Lees are not certain that their lease on Bear Farm will be renewed when it expires next year. As rents throughout the city continue to rise, commercial leases are getting shorter. "Everything is at the whim of the landlord," said Song Soo Kim, president of the Korean American Small Business Services Center, a 16-year-old organization in Flushing. "The landlord is king."
Ms. Lee has recently become a distributor for Market America, a company that sells consumer products. She dreams of supporting her husband while he spends time with their son, studies English and computers, and plays tennis. "Me and my husband are thinking about a lot of things," she said. "Right now it's kind of, you know, scary."

PERSON: Iqbal Z. Quadir 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
Helping the Poor, Phone by Phone

BYLINE:  By SUSAN E. REED 

 BODY:
IN the early 1990's, when Iqbal Z. Quadir was looking for investors to back his idea for a mobile phone network in Bangladesh, he said he was turned down by an executive at a cellular telephone company in New York who told him, "We're not the Red Cross."
That mind-set, which interprets investment in the third world as charity, not an opportunity for profit, is what keeps countries poor, Mr. Quadir said. 
 "In the United States we either give charity to the poor or we ignore them, and neither one helps them," he said. "Business is a proven method of solving their problems in a sustainable way." 
 At the end of last year, Mr. Quadir showed how third-world ventures can be profitable -- and provide a useful service -- when GrameenPhone, the cellphone company he founded in Bangladesh, made $27 million in pretax profits. It turned that profit after just five years -- far sooner than many first-world start-ups.
The experience of Mr. Quadir, now a lecturer in public policy at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, contradicts the conventional wisdom from luminaries like Bill Gates, who has said that there is no market for such sophisticated devices in places of widespread poverty and illiteracy as well as unreliable electricity. Through his foundation, Mr. Gates has sought to first improve the health of the poor.
To Mr. Quadir, the two approaches are not mutually exclusive. He says the poor will improve their own health as they become richer, and he sees cellphones as tools of production, not consumption.
With help from Telenor, the Norwegian telecommunications giant, and Grameen Bank, an established lender in Bangladesh, GrameenPhone began operations in 1997. Investment to date has totaled nearly $200 million. The enterprise has two tiers: it sells phones and time to urban customers, and it sponsors Village Phone, a program in which people without phone service in rural areas take out small loans for cellphones and buy air time at cost. Most borrowers are women; Grameen Bank's founder, Muhammad Yunus, has said they are better credit risks.
The borrowers then charge other villagers the market rate to make calls. GrameenPhone now has 575,000 subscribers in 12,000 villages. In fact, at a time when growth is slowing in the American and European cellphone markets, the number of GrameenPhone subscribers is rising rapidly. 
A native of Bangladesh, Mr. Quadir, 43, was in a unusual position to put the deal together because he bridges many worlds. He holds two master's degrees from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, one in finance, the other in applied economics. He helped establish Atrium Capital, a Wall Street investment bank, but one day, when Atrium's computer system was not working and he could not conduct business, he was reminded of his boyhood in Bangladesh: In 1971, when transportation was disrupted by war, he spent an entire day walking, trying to find medicine for his younger brother. But he returned empty-handed. That day in his Wall Street office, he concluded that "connectivity is productivity" and soon set out to prove it in Bangladesh.
He saw an opportunity to provide a needed service there and to make money by going into a wide-open market. The per capita income in Bangladesh is one-hundredth of what it is in the United States, "so you need 100 Bangladeshis to provide the buying power of one American," he said.
Just because they have as much income, though, does not mean those 100 Bangladeshis will buy the way one American does. "It's reasonably self-evident that they will buy a lot more bread and a lot fewer cellphones," said Raymond Fisman, an assistant professor of economics at Columbia University's Graduate School of Business. Nearly all the potential investors who were approached by Mr. Quadir expressed such skepticism. Sixteen, mainly in the United States, turned him down. Mr. Quadir worked four years, without salary, to get his vision financed.
Mr. Quadir now serves on the boards of many organizations, like DigitalDivide.org, that are devoted to finding ways to combine public and private financing to help entrepreneurs in emerging markets.
Combining financing this way is not new. The International Finance Corporation, the private investment wing of the World Bank, does so often. But there is less interest among private investors in developing the infrastructure or expanding services that can actually reach the mass population, said Daniel Crisafulli, a loan officer at the finance group.
Many investors simply do not want to negotiate with foreign governments, which often expect high fees to gain access to their markets.
Mr. Quadir was fortunate. The Bangladesh government did not charge an up-front licensing fee, because he believes it expected cellphones to be a marginal business for the very rich. GrameenPhone now has more subscribers than the government-owned telephone company.
Despite Mr. Quadir's aversion to a charitable business approach, GrameenPhone would not have gotten off the ground without financing from private investors who were also interested in philanthropy.
Joshua Mailman, who founded the Social Venture Network, a group of entrepreneurs and investors concerned about social justice and the environment, gave Mr. Quadir $125,000 to begin the project and to travel from Bangladesh to the United States and Europe. Mr. Mailman is among the 12 board members of Gonophone, GrameenPhone's New York-based holding company. Others include Ben Cohen, of Ben and Jerry's Ice Cream, and Arnold Hiatt, the former chief executive of Stride Rite. 
With his classes at Harvard done for the semester, Mr. Quadir, Gonophone's president, may soon be leading this group on an investment adventure even more difficult than in Bangladesh: setting up a cellphone network in Afghanistan. Even if the political situation there stabilizes, there is no reliable banking system or telecommunications infrastructure. Mr. Quadir envisions starting a small lending system and a cellphone network at the same time.
The biggest challenge for Mr. Quadir will be to prove he can replicate GrameenPhone's success in other, very different countries. "I have done it before," he said.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
No Stampede, Yet, to Technology

BYLINE:  By DAN COLARUSSO 

 BODY:
JONATHAN COHEN, the director of investor relations at Mercator Software, has received several calls recently from portfolio managers wanting to "kick the tires" of that small company, which helps other businesses integrate their computer systems.
 Some professional investors have taken the trouble to study the client lists of the company, which is based in Wilton, Conn., and to scrutinize its financial statements, Mr. Cohen said. But that has not led to heightened demand for its stock, which is languishing at $2.35 a share, down from a high of almost $150 in early 2000. 
 Many investors have been studying small and midsize high-technology companies like Mercator, hoping to uncover a stock that will soar whenever the two-year tech slump ends. But there has hardly been a stampede back into the sector. With the pain of recent losses still fresh, many professionals are especially cautious, demanding lean operations, clean balance sheets, substantial cash reserves and significant market share in companies' core businesses. 
"I want to find a company that has aligned itself with a major trend, has a clean story and knows what it wants to be when it grows up," said Jeff Bernstein, co-manager of the ING Midcap Opportunities fund. He is based in New York with ING Investments, a unit of ING, the Dutch investment bank.
Investing in a technology stock today requires "stepping back and looking at the whole landscape to see where dollars are being spent right now," said Hank Hagey, an analyst on the technology team of Citigroup Asset Management.
Mercator has been hurt by the fact that companies have not been spending heavily on information technology, acknowledged Kenneth J. Hall, its chief financial officer. "We can't control how long the information technology recession will last," Mr. Hall said. "But we can control our costs and cash flow to weather these times and do enough research and development to be in a strong position to recapture revenues" when higher spending resumes.
Now run by a management team hired in January 2001, Mercator raised $16 million cash from private investors in December and reduced its work force by 29 percent. It cut its negative cash flow from operations to $650,000 in the first quarter from $8.1 million in the year-earlier period. The time that its customers take to pay bills, an important consideration for tech companies, has fallen to 63 days, on average, from 107.
Carl Palmieri, a private investor who runs a computer distribution company in Bridgeport, Conn., said he started buying Mercator stock 18 months ago; in that time, the stock once dropped to 95 cents a share. Mr. Palmieri said that he now owns 44,000 shares and that he expects to buy an additional 20,000 in the next month.
"I've played with technology stocks in the past, but I think at this point there are software stocks that are undervalued, especially in system integration, which is still in its infancy," he said. He is impressed, he added, with Mercator's client list, which includes I.B.M., Nestle and major health care and banking companies.
THE stock rallied briefly to $10.15 in January, but much of its recent fall can be attributed to the company's declining revenue, which slipped to $27.4 million in the first quarter of 2002 from $28.7 million in the period last year.
Many investors remain on the sidelines. "There are investors who have recognized and appreciated what management has done, and others who are disappointed because of the year-over-year revenues," Mr. Hall, the chief financial officer, said.
Across the sector, revenues may not improve substantially until corporate technology spending ramps up. Analysts like Mr. Hagey have been assessing whether the prices of individual stocks already reflect expectations of future returns. They are also looking closely at balance sheets. "We want to see killer balance sheets because we don't know when an investment is going to work," said John Morosani, a managing director at ING Furman Selz Capital Management in New York, a private asset management arm of ING. Mr. Morosani focuses on small-capitalization value stocks. "If a company's not making money," he said, "we want something where there's so much cash, it can survive for a few years."
Among companies with adequate cash reserves, he said, are Ultratech Stepper, a leader in technology to solder wires to microchips in flat panel displays and mobile communication devices. Its shares, which he owns in client accounts, are at $15.05, down from a 52-week high of $26.56; he said he has paid an average of $16.80. The company has $7.50 a share in cash, he said.
Similarly, Forrester Research, a technology consulting company in Cambridge, Mass., is trading at $19.98, down more than 60 percent in the last two years, but has almost $9 a share in cash, he said.
In the case of Ultratech, he said the company's technology, which allows thinner products to be made, gave it a competitive edge in its field. It already holds a 90 percent market share in one important business and 60 percent in another, he said.
"When people say 'never' about these stocks, you know it's wrong but you don't know how long it's going to take," he said. With enough cash to weather a downturn, he said, "as long as the company is retaining its position in the industry, it'll be there when the cycle turns."
Some analysts say they can differentiate between cyclical stocks and the boom-and-bust darlings of the past bull market.
Mr. Bernstein, whose fund is down 5.7 percent this year, versus an average of 7 percent for its peer group, said semiconductor and semiconductor equipment stocks had always been predictably cyclical and had reached a market bottom. "They always get overdone at the top of markets and overdone on the bottom," he said. "But in an up cycle, chip prices don't comes down for a couple of years. In a down cycle, it's very painful. At the bottom, you can't figure out what could possibly go right." His fund holds two stocks in those areas, Fairchild Semiconductor and Lam Research.
Shares of chip companies have risen from September lows but have not taken off. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index is down 4.3 percent for the year and has had some gyrations.
MR. HAGEY says the technology stocks that will probably recover first have products that help corporate customers improve productivity from their present computer systems. "In this environment, the big theme is maximizing the current infrastructure to squeeze more value out of it," he said, pointing to companies that focus on storing and managing data across computer systems.
Mr. Bernstein likes stocks with an old-fashioned commodity: earnings. "In the early days, investors couldn't value tech stocks on earnings so they had to pay some multiple of a company's sales," he said. "They're not going to do that anymore. That's a concept from four years ago that stopped working two years ago."
Some portfolio managers, though, are sticking with the sector's biggest names. "It's a Darwinian story developing, where the biggest and best companies can continue to spend on research and development, and it can be very scary for competitors," said Michael F. Holland, the manager of the Holland Balanced fund in New York. He said that his fund, down 4.3 percent for the year, has "suffered" because it has held onto I.B.M., Microsoft and Intel but that he believes these stocks will lead a recovery.
Other investors are avoiding prominent technology companies -- like Cisco Systems, Sun Microsystems and EMC. Mr. Bernstein, for one, said he believes that they are too mature to benefit as much as some smaller companies when the sector recovers. "When their businesses come back, their growth rates aren't going to be that exciting," he said.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Do 401(k)'s Give Workers An Illusion Of Wealth?

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
IN the long economic expansions of the 1980's and 90's, the wealth of middle Americans seemed to rise. Their stock portfolios and home ownership gave them the appearance of growing richer. But now it turns out that net worth went down, not up.
 That is disheartening, and counter-intuitive. After all, middle Americans did benefit from stock portfolios and homes, increasing their wealth as these assets rose in value. Yet add in all the other forms of household wealth, as Edward N. Wolff, a New York University economist, does, and balance sheets change for the worse. 
 The main culprit is shrinking pension wealth, although it is not alone. Rising debt, particularly mortgage debt and home equity loans, also took back from wealth what rising home prices had conferred. There is stealth in the damage. People focus on the balances in their 401(k) accounts, for example, and fail to realize that company-paid pensions, now gradually disappearing, would have made them wealthier than saving on their own for retirement.
Not noticing the deterioration in their wealth, they even substitute 401(k) accounts for other forms of savings, putting money in one pot while removing it from another.
"I think the 401(k) is a real scam," Mr. Wolff said. "People get their monthly statements and they say, 'Wow, look at how much money is in my 401(k),' and they don't see what has disappeared."
Let's be clear who we mean by middle Americans. They are not the 20 percent of all households whose breadwinners are paid $75,000 a year or more. Those households have increased their total wealth since 1983, the starting point of Mr. Wolff's study. Many have never been richer. That is not the case for the median household, with an annual income of $50,000 or so.
Refine the households even more. Consider those whose breadwinners are 47 to 64, old enough to have accumulated wealth. Add up their wealth from all sources -- stocks, bonds, homes, pensions, savings accounts -- as Mr. Wolff has done.
He calculates that the median wealth was $162,800 in 1998, the last year for which government wealth data is available. Adjusted for inflation, the same calculation for that age group in 1983 produced $188,100 in wealth at the median. (Half the households had more, half less.) That is a 13.5 percent decline in wealth, and the loss was similar for almost all the households with annual incomes of $35,000 to $75,000, Mr. Wolff found.
The middle class in America is defined by this income range. Nearly 35 percent of households qualify. Their wealth, after falling from 1983 to 1998, has at best leveled off since then, given the stock market sell-off and the recession.
How would Mr. Wolff reverse the loss? "The most desirable thing may be to re-establish the old defined-benefit pension system," he said, referring to the company-funded pensions that guarantee fixed annual benefit payments in retirement.
Among middle-income households, the breadwinners in 42.4 percent had defined-benefit pension plans in 1998, down from 68.9 percent in 1983. But the number of 401(k) accounts, a k a defined-contribution plans, soared. Some 69.2 percent of households had them in 1998, up from 7.4 percent in 1983. 
MR. WOLFF, a recognized expert in wealth and income, is not without challengers. Some say that his definition of net worth leaves out the value of a family's cars, or that the survey data of 1983 and 1998 are dissimilar enough to flaw comparisons. Others question his calculation of the present value of future pensions.
Mr. Wolff contends, for example, that a 50-year-old expecting a $20,000 annual company pension at the age of 65, and suddenly forced to fund it himself, would have to have accumulated $200,000 in savings by now. Ergo, a $20,000 future company pension represents $200,000 in present wealth. The 401(k) savings of households in the 47-to-64 age group, in contrast, average only $69,000.
But for Mr. Wolff's $200,000 to make sense, said Eric Engen, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, "you have to assume that people don't change employers and they collect the promised pension over enough years."
Whatever the caveats, Mr. Wolff's main point is now widely accepted: The swing from company-guaranteed pensions to 401(k)-style plans has definitely lessened wealth -- and also relieved employers of billions of dollars in pension obligations.
"You cannot simply dismiss Wolff's findings," Mr. Engen said.
Stagnant wages, the rising cost of education, divorce, layoffs -- all these and more help to explain why household wealth is shrinking. The heartbreak, however, lies in the self-delusion that silences protest. Mesmerized by 401(k)'s, too many households fail to notice what's missing.

HEADLINE: Business; 
The Test Is When the Going Gets Tough

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN 

 BODY:
 LAWRENCE A. BOSSIDY contends that too many chief executives do not know how to make their organizations deliver results. In an interview, he explained that view -- and what should be done to improve corporate governance.
 WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN

Q. Some of your suggestions are basic management advice, yet you say American business leaders need your book to execute better. Why?

A. Two things happened. First, when economies are growing rapidly as they were in the mid-1990's, it was less challenging to run a business. You could get away with a lot of errors. But as growth diminishes and global competition intensifies, the question of execution becomes more important. We forget what it takes to run the basics.
Second, people got promoted in that rapid growth environment and were able to excel. But when it turns to a difficult economic environment, they're not nearly as capable.

Q. Why do some chief executives appear out of touch with their own businesses?

A. I don't know they're out of touch any more than they used to be. It's just that the demands on them are higher. The market is more demanding, and even their own employees are more demanding. It's more difficult and challenging to be a C.E.O. than ever before.

Q. What happened to Richard A. McGinn at Lucent?

A. He was an appealing person and a persuasive guy. But he was spending most of his time in the external environment. He didn't have his hands on what was happening inside.

Q. You wrote that AT&T, under C. Michael Armstrong, was out of touch with both internal and external realities. What happened?

A. He put together a strategy that required each link to work. If one didn't work, the rest of the strategy would fall apart. Armstrong is a decent guy, but this book was an effort to get the issues before other people to help them.

Q. You seem skeptical of chief executives who bill themselves as intellectuals. Why?

A. I'm not against people who are smart. That's one of the requirements to be successful. We all want smart people working for us. But you have to be more than smart. You have to translate your ideas and concepts into reality. If you can't make that transition, chances of success are limited.

Q. Do you think that chief executives have an image problem after the episodes involving Enron, Global Crossing and the like?

A. I do. The C.E.O.'s were probably overemphasized in their importance and significance in the 90's. The opposite is occurring now. Just as the period of the 90's when they got extolled came to an end, this period will pass, too.

Q. Can you believe that Kenneth L. Lay simply didn't know what was happening inside Enron?

A. Whatever happened down there, he wasn't as close as he should have been.

Q. It seems some chief executives are doing things that just aren't ethical. Do you agree?

A. I think there are some these days and there always have been. The American governance system is better than any other in the world by a factor of 10. There will be incidents over time. I'm not denying that there aren't issues before us now, but when you look at the issue over time, I don't think that ethics is a significant issue.

Q. How would you tweak our corporate governance to spot problems earlier?

A. In the first instance, you have to make sure the people running the enterprise are highly ethical. In declining-company situations, when the executives are out selling options and the employees can't, that's got to stop. I think that will happen.

Q. What about the idea of consulting and auditing at the same time?

A. That ought to stop.

Q. Are boards doing their jobs?

A. On boards, audit committees ought to stay more involved so they know what's going on in a company. But they only know what management tells them. To look at them as the last bastion isn't right. At the end of the day, management has to know how to reach for results without going over the ethical barrier. Yes, we can do some things in corporate governance to make it better. Our system isn't perfect. And it needs to be reinforced from time to time.

Q. Is high compensation part of the chief executive's image problem?

A. There was very little question of compensation of C.E.O.'s when they had rapidly growing share prices and shareholders were being rewarded. But it's wrong when heavy rewards are given when the stock price is not going forward. If you match compensation with results, you're not going to be subjected to a lot of questions.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/James R. Norris and Michael M. Meyer; 
C & B Mid Cap Value Portfolio

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
CASH flow is the ultimate measure of the value of a business, say James R. Norris and Michael M. Meyer, co-managers of the $31 million C & B Mid Cap Value Portfolio.
 "Cash flow from the business should keep pace with its earnings," Mr. Meyer said from their office in Charlotte, N.C. "Otherwise, it's an indication that management is using accounting shenanigans to prop up the company's earnings." 
 The fund returned 23.6 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, compared with 8 percent for its group of midcap value funds and a loss of 5 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to Morningstar Inc. It returned 21.4 percent in the last 12 months, versus 3.3 percent for its group and a 13.8 percent decline in the S.& P. 500. 
Mr. Norris, 43, and Mr. Meyer, 36, work for Cooke & Bieler L.P. in Philadelphia, the fund's adviser; it manages about $2.1 billion for institutions and individuals. 
The managers search for the fund's 30 to 50 stocks among roughly 1,800 United States companies with market capitalizations of $500 million to $5 billion. They sum up their strategy as the "three C's of investing": conservatively run companies with high levels of cash flow and strong competitive advantages.
To find conservative management, they look for low levels of debt. The ratio of debt to total capitalization for the portfolio companies is 26 percent, versus 40 percent for the Russell Midcap Value index.
Other indications of a conservative approach, Mr. Meyer said, are solid, realistic plans for the future growth of the business and effective reinvestment of capital in business operations, share buybacks, dividend payments or acquisitions.
Cash flow, Mr. Norris said, should be high relative to a company's sales and should grow consistently -- ideally, over the last 10 years. Competitive advantages, Mr. Meyer said, can be found in brand loyalty, economies of scale, proprietary products or patents, low-cost production and breadth of product lines or distribution.
The fund aims to buy companies that sell for discounts of 40 percent or more to its estimate of their worth -- a calculation of the present value of the company's projected earnings and cash flow for the next 10 years. They sell shares that achieve what they consider full value, or when the company's competitive advantage erodes.
In March, the managers bought shares of Dionex, a Sunnyvale, Calif., manufacturer of equipment used for ion chromatography, a technology for evaluating impurities in liquids. The fund paid $24.50, on average; the stock now trades at $25.88, compared with what they estimate as an intrinsic value of $40 a share. Dionex holds important patents, Mr. Norris said, and its high recurring revenue has created positive free cash flow every year in the last decade.
Another company with strong cash flow is the Pall Corporation, an East Hills, N.Y., maker of filters for industrial, commercial and medical applications. The managers paid $19.69 for the stock, on average, starting in March. It closed on Friday at $23.05; the managers' estimate it is worth $30 a share. Pall's acquisition of the filtration business of the United States Filter Corporation will add to debt, but cash flow should cover interest payments, Mr. Meyer said.
The managers also like Parametric Technology, a Needham, Mass., maker of mechanical design software. The company has a secure market position, Mr. Norris said, because of the high costs of retraining engineers on new software products. The company is rolling out software that lets companies coordinate product design among farflung offices. This new software business should turn profitable in the next two years, he said, adding, "the share price is very cheap relative to the core business, and we get the new business for free."
They bought shares in April, paying $4.74, on average. The stock closed on Friday at $3.40, compared with an estimated intrinsic value of $13 a share.
