HEADLINE: To Build a Country, Build a Schoolhouse 

BYLINE:  By Amartya Sen; Amartya Sen, master of Trinity College, Cambridge, is honorary president of Oxfam. He received the Nobel Prize in economics in 1998.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, England 

 BODY:
Isaiah Berlin has argued: "Men do not live only by fighting evils. They live by positive goals." The advice was not aimed at the leaders of the war on terror: Berlin was speaking more than 40 years ago. But his idea is worth the attention of current world leaders. And one of the most important positive goals has already been identified by the United Nations: universal primary education by 2015.
 I am aware that when I argue that basic education for all can transform the miserable world in which we live, I sound a little like a Victorian gentlewoman delivering her favorite recipe for progress. As it happens, however, extensive empirical studies have demonstrated the critical role of basic education in economic and social development in Europe and North America as well as in Asia, Africa and Latin America. 
 When Japan set out in the 19th century to catch up with the Western nations, its Fundamental Code of Education, issued in 1872, expressed the public commitment to make sure that there must be "no community with an illiterate family, nor a family with an illiterate person." Kido Takayoshi, one of the leaders of Japanese reform, explained the basic idea: "Our people are no different from the Americans or Europeans of today; it is all a matter of education or lack of education." By 1910 Japan was almost fully literate, at least for the young, and by 1913, though still very much poorer than Britain or America, Japan was publishing more books than Britain and more than twice as many as the United States. The concentration on education was responsible, to a large extent, for the nature and speed of Japan's economic and social progress.
Later on, China, Taiwan, South Korea and other economies in East Asia followed similar routes. Explanations of their rapid economic progress often cite their willingness to make good use of the global market economy, and rightly so. But that process was greatly helped by the emphasis all of these countries placed on basic education. Widespread participation in a global economy would have been hard to accomplish if people could not read or write -- or produce according to specifications or instructions.
The contribution of basic education to development is not, however, confined to economic progress. Education has intrinsic importance; the capability to read and write can deeply influence one's quality of life. Also, an educated population can make better use of democratic opportunities than an illiterate one. Further, an ability to read documents and legal provisions can help subjugated women and other oppressed groups make use of their rights and demand more fairness. And female literacy can enhance women's voices in family affairs and reduce gender inequality in other fields, a benefit to men as well as women, since women's empowerment through literacy tends to reduce child mortality and very significantly decrease fertility rates.
The lives that are most burdened and impoverished by over-frequent bearing and rearing of children are those of young women. A greater voice of young women in family decisions tends, therefore, to cut down birth rates sharply. For example, the fertility rates in the different districts that make up India vary extremely widely, from almost 5 (roughly, five children per couple) in some districts to less than 1.7 in some others. Empirical investigations by Mamta Murthi and Jean Dreze indicate that only two general variables significantly help to explain these differences: female literacy and female economic participation.
In sub-Saharan Africa, 40 percent of primary-age children have no opportunity for schooling. Around the world, there are currently 125 million children who have never, at any time, seen the inside of a classroom. A well coordinated global initiative on basic education is crucial. To be sure, it is also important that the priority of basic education be fully accepted and pursued by the developing countries themselves. But a global approach to schooling can inspire initiatives and bring ongoing efforts together, as well as help with resources.
The need for a new kind of partnership -- a global alliance -- on schooling is hard to exaggerate. The time to live by positive goals has certainly come -- not least for the leaders of G-8 countries who meet at a summit next month in Canada.

HEADLINE: How to Keep Cargo Safe, and Rolling 

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
When shipments of auto parts were held at the Canadian border for two days after the Sept. 11 attacks, Detroit shuddered. In the end, the halt in cargo shipments at the nation's borders and ports proved a brief hiccup. But it was a vivid reminder of just how dependent the modern economy had become on the efficient transportation of goods and parts that arrive just in time for assembly. 
 These days, for example, a personal computer is a veritable global smorgasbord of chips, disks and other gear, so the international supply pipeline provides the industry's lifeblood. "The interdependence risk is so much greater in today's global economy," observed Warren R. Starr, a principal at Booz Allen Hamilton. 
 To date, the focus of the Transportation Security Administration, which Congress created last November, has understandably been on passenger-airline security. But cargo is next -- by air, ship and rail -- and both the House and Senate are preparing legislation to improve the monitoring and surveillance of those shipments.
The security risks from cargo, experts say, are real and worrying. In Senate testimony earlier this year, Rob Quartel, a former federal maritime commissioner, said that each of the semitrailer-size steel containers -- which arrive in the United States at the rate of 2,000 an hour -- should "be treated as a potential weapon of mass destruction." They can be used to carry everything from bombs to terrorists.
Yet tougher security measures carry economic risks. Robert Delaney, vice president of Cass Information Systems, a logistics company in Bridgeton, Mo., warned that greatly increasing the number of containers that are opened and inspected by hand, as some have proposed, could "bring commerce to its knees."
The productivity and cost-saving gains of the current system -- fueled by deregulation, technology and just-in-time manufacturing -- have been striking. Since 1980, inventory costs as a percentage of economic activity have declined to 14 percent, from 25 percent.
Instead of increasing physical inspections, some government officials and industry executives advocate a concept they call "pushing the border back." The term means a closer, more refined tracking of cargo before it arrives at a port of entry. The way to do that, they say, is to improve the collection and sorting of the information generated from shippers, owners, freight forwarders and others involved in cargo shipments.
Such an effort would require that a government agency -- the Transportation Security Administration and the Customs Service are the leading candidates -- have a consolidated database. It would also require cooperation by the government and transportation companies. "The government cannot be the only eyes and ears of the security system," said Edward M. Emmett, president of the National Industrial Transportation League, a trade group for freight shippers.
The intent of the information-gathering and cargo-profiling would be to establish the equivalent of fast and slow lanes for cargo, determined by security rating. Such a system would require additional investment, experts say, but not a lot because so much of the cargo transportation industry is already a sophisticated user of technology -- a model that FedEx pioneered. 
"The industry has worked for the last 20 years to put more visibility and more efficiency into the system," said Mr. Quartel, chairman of Freightdesk Technologies, a supplier of freight-management software in Dunn Loring, Va.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cargo ships line up at Port Newark. Some 2,000 containers arrive in the United States every hour. Those involved shipping fear that added security will cut deeply into gains in efficiency and cost. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
In New Era, Corporate Security Looks Beyond Guns and Badges

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
HELP WANTED: Chief Security Officer.
 Ominously, vaguely, federal officials are again warning Americans to be on alert for some sort of terrorist attack. Will corporate America be ready? 
 In the months since the Sept. 11 attack on New York destroyed the World Trade Center towers, killed thousands of workers and disrupted dozens of companies, businesses have been forced to review their notions of corporate security. And with those assessments has come realization that the job calls for a new kind of corporate security executive -- one with breadth of experience, analytic skills, business acumen and leadership qualities. The job, in other words, calls for a chief security officer, or C.S.O., as the emerging term of art would have it. 
The security field's leading professional organization is drawing up a detailed description of the skills and responsibilities of the job. The elusive ideal is an executive not only familiar with the physical security of people and property, but also fluent in the digital security of computers and information -- roughly equal parts top cop, business manager and computer geek. 
Executive headhunters are recruiting people who fit the description and, with their talents suddenly much in demand, chief security officers can earn more than $400,000 a year. A new magazine, called CSO, is scheduled to begin publication in September.
And yet, for all the activity, "the truly broad-based candidates are relatively rare," said Lance Wright, a vice president of Boyden Global Executive Search, a recruiter. Despite the talent scouting by headhunters, companies are apparently taking their time in hiring senior security executives. A survey of 390 large companies last month by Christian & Timbers, a search firm, found that while 95 percent said they needed to hire a chief security officer, only 8 percent said they had begun the recruiting.
And a separate study, "The Changing Nature of the Chief Security Officer," from the Giga Information Group, a research firm, found that while large corporations were increasing their security budgets and that some senior security executives' salaries were well into six figures others were making as little as $70,000. 
With its eye on criminality and terrorism, the security field is "a different world and an unfamiliar world to a lot of mainstream businesspeople," said Timothy Williams, a former Cincinnati policeman with an M.B.A. who directs corporate and systems security for Nortel Networks, the big communications equipment maker. But different though it may be, Mr. Williams said, "security is a business process" -- a matter of setting priorities and strategy, establishing processes and measuring their effectiveness.
The C.S.O. title is meant to suggest that security matters are becoming a more important and integral part of corporate life. Roughly 15 years ago, another three-letter corporate title started to surface, C.I.O., or chief information officer. It was initially greeted with skepticism, even derision. 
But C.I.O. was more than a name; it was a recognition that information technology was not just electronic plumbing or a narrow specialty, but something that could affect the mainstream business, strategy and competitiveness. The C.I.O. is now an established and respected executive job at most major corporations.
It is too early to tell whether the C.S.O. will eventually reach comparable stature. But even before Sept. 11, the corporate security field had been steadily evolving in response to the major business and technological developments of the last two decades. Globalization, deregulation, outsourcing, just-in-time inventory practices, the embrace of information technology and the rise of the Internet have all brought greater openness and efficiency, along with new vulnerabilities.
The people managing security at large corporations have also changed with the times, well beyond the "guns and badges" days of mainly overseeing building security guards and investigations of the "who stole the petty cash" variety. In today's open economy, a point of access in security terms is not just a headquarters office or a factory gate, but also a computer network connection that could be a gateway to a company's customer databases or product designs.
The senior security manager has "gone from a corporate cop guy to a real business position," said Grant Crabtree, vice president for corporate security at the Alltel Corporation, a provider of wireless phone service and other telecommunications services, based in Little Rock, Ark.
Senior security officers have typically climbed the corporate ranks through one of two distinct paths, as experts in either physical security or data security. The physical security people usually are former police officers, military officers or federal agents, while the data security people tend to be former computer scientists, engineers and programmers.
Mr. Williams, 50, of Nortel is no newcomer to the field. He has spent 22 years in corporate security, including stints at Procter & Gamble and Boise Cascade, and he is also a co-author of a well-regarded book on fraud. 
A few years ago, he set up a 15-person global security council at Nortel, composed of senior managers in departments including real estate, finance, information technology, manufacturing and procurement. Its purpose, Mr. Williams explained, was to be able to take a comprehensive approach to security matters "across all the core businesses and functions."
Fifteen minutes after the first hijacked jetliner hit the World Trade Center in September, Mr. Williams, working from his office in Nashville, convened the council by conference call, as colleagues checked employee databases and travel itineraries to see if any Nortel employees were on the plane or in the World Trade Center. None were. 
For the next several months, in weekly calls, the group monitored a review and tightening of security programs at the company, which has more than 40,000 employees in Canada, the United States and overseas. Like many companies, Nortel re-examined and fine-tuned all kinds of basic security, like reception desk and ID card procedures, as well as safeguards for limiting to authorized employees and suppliers the right to remote access to the company's computer networks. Mr. Williams, like other security officers interviewed for this article, declined to discuss the changes in detail. 
But one new measure was adding a security section to Nortel's internal Web site, which includes country-risk reports for traveling employees, emergency procedures for building evacuations and recent news articles on physical and data security. For anyone with questions, the site has a link to send e-mail messages to Mr. Williams or other security staff members.
At General Motors, James Christiansen, 43, the chief information security officer, came up through the data security ranks. His computing career began at 19, as a programmer writing code to automate the calculation of electrical rates and customer billing for a utility company in Utah. As his programming skills broadened, he became more interested in security technology and in business, earning both undergraduate and M.B.A. degrees.
General Motors hired Mr. Christiansen in November from Visa International, where he was a senior vice president. His title is a new one at G.M., but the company had begun recruiting him months before Sept. 11, an indication that information security had already become a priority for senior management. A big part of the comeback story at General Motors in recent years has been its use of information technology to forge closer links with suppliers, shorten product design-and-development cycles and manage its worldwide operations.
Yet operating in a global, networked world, where collaboration and information sharing are essential, brings new security risks. The access to computer networks for employees, suppliers or contractors that can make a company more nimble and fleet-footed also makes a company far more vulnerable to theft, sabotage and information-warfare attacks.
"It is the digitization of the enterprise that drives the importance of information security to the top," Mr. Christiansen said recently in his Detroit office. "Our car designs are all mathematical models. You don't make a single car, a single truck, without a computer system -- actually, several of them."
Major manufacturing corporations like General Motors have been adapting their supply pipelines for years. In 1996, G.M. learned a costly lesson in the potential pitfalls of just-in-time inventory practices when an 18-day strike at two factories that supplied brakes shut down 26 assembly plants, reducing quarterly earnings by $900 million. Afterward, the company reorganized its manufacturing and supply channels so that production of critical parts was more diversified and flexible, making it far less susceptible to the loss of a single plant or two.
Mr. Christiansen's job is to make similar, risk-reducing steps for the data networks that connect the company's operations and people. "It is the equivalent of G.M.'s nervous system," he said, "and if it were knocked out, it would be as if suddenly your arms and legs don't work anymore."
Mr. Christiansen must make sure that, beyond any physical attacks, such cyberweapons as an industrial-strength denial-of-service software attack, a self-replicating worm or a computer virus cannot bring the network down. Clever software tools -- so-called intrusion engines, neural-network technology and the like -- can help limit the damage from network sabotage like the Nimbda worm, which cost companies around the world an estimated $500 million last fall.
Yet the more important safeguard, Mr. Christiansen said, is designing computer systems and putting in place employee procedures to reduce risks before the problems occur. "Security isn't technology," he said. "Security is process, though it is enabled by technology." 
The American Society for Industrial Security, a professional organization with 32,000 members, wants to hasten the evolution of the field. In the last few months, the organization has been developing a detailed description of the preferred qualifications and responsibilities for "the new position of chief security officer." The work is not finished, but the draft proposal says the chief security officer -- who would ideally hold a graduate degree in business or law -- should be a senior executive with strong analytic, strategic and communications skills in addition to security expertise.
"For corporate North America, 9/11 was a wake-up, bar none," said Mr. Williams of Nortel, who worked on the society's job-description document. "There will be a lasting effect, and many corporations recognize they need security leadership. But there is also a real need within the security field to broaden itself."

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
As Jupiter crumbles,its pieces may help build a new order of Web researchers.

BYLINE:  By Saul Hansell 

 BODY:
IN the whirlwind of the Internet economy, amid the frivolity.coms and e-nough-already business models, there were a bunch of companies that filled real needs but that were nonetheless swept away by the storm.
 Some of those are already being rebuilt on sounder financial footing by others -- for example, the grocery business, where Albertson's and Safeway are investing in online ordering services a year after the $1 billion failure of WebVan. 
 And it is now the case with Jupiter Media Metrix, once one of the most prominent Internet research firms, whose components are being bought by rivals who want to continue in the same business. Three weeks ago, the company sold its key patents and international contracts to NetRatings, its main competitor.
And in the next 60 days, the company hopes to find buyers for its Media Metrix business -- once the leader in measuring Web audiences -- as well as its Jupiter research unit, formerly a foremost cybersage. The consensus among media and research executives, however, is that there are few buyers willing to pay much more than token sums for either piece. 
Jupiter Media Metrix, which is based in New York and was formed by the 2000 merger of Media Metrix and Jupiter Communications, is running out of cash as its business atrophies. In the most recent quarter, its revenues were $10.8 million, down 64 percent from a year earlier.
In retrospect, the merger hastened the company's decline by reinforcing its dependence on dot-com clients and Internet-oriented services. The year it spent combining two dissimilar cultures could have been used by each of its component companies to diversify their revenues and batten down the hatches as the storm clouds massed.
And yet, no matter how much the market for online advertising may have shrunk, it is not going away. So advertisers will still need a way to measure the size and composition of Web sites' audiences. Likewise, companies will still seek seers and gurus who try to forecast the future -- or at least make them feel more secure in their uncertainty.
Indeed, Robert Becker, the chief executive of Jupiter Media Metrix, holds out some hope that with the cash it has raised selling pieces of the ratings business the company might be able to continue in the research business.
"We have hit bottom, and we are bouncing along it," Mr. Becker said last week. "This space is not as big as we thought when everyone had to buy Jupiter research because the Internet was a crazy, unbelievable new thing," he said. "But we have a real market, real products and real customers."
Investors are hardly convinced. Jupiter's shares had a rally of sorts last week. The stock was at 13 cents on May 7, before the company announced the NetRatings deals. On Friday, the shares closed at 32 cents. But that still valued the company at only $11.48 million. (If shares do not rise above $1 by June, the company faces delisting by Nasdaq.)
In October 2001, Jupiter, already seeing its cash gauge moving toward empty, agreed to be bought outright by NetRatings for $71 million. But that purchase was blocked by the Federal Trade Commission, which objected because NetRatings would have been left with a monopoly on the Web audience measurement business.
NetRatings is a much smaller company, but it has two advantages. To begin with, 65.5 percent of it is owned by VNU, the Dutch conglomerate that operates the Nielsen Media Research television rating business. Also, NetRatings used the Internet bubble as an opportunity to take in money, rather than spend it. At the height of the boom, it sold more than $300 million in stock to the public, and used the interest on that stash to fund its operating losses.
The ultimate effect of the F.T.C.'s earlier move is that NetRatings will still wind up with the greatest share of the ratings business, but at a far lower cost, while Jupiter's shareholders and employees will be far worse off.
Last month, NetRatings bought Jupiter's AdRelevance division -- which lets companies keep track of what ads their rivals are placing -- for $8.5 million.
In the NetRatingsdeal, Jupiter sold the contracts for its audience measurement business outside of the United States for $2 million. At the same time NetRatings paid $15 million for the patents on Media Metrix's technology to create software that can track Web users -- the online equivalent to the meters used by the Nielsen television ratings. Jupiter had been suing NetRatings for patent infringement, and that potential claim was seen as one of the company's most significant remaining assets.
The deal, in fact, allows Jupiter Media Metrix -- or any company that buys it -- to continue to use the patents in the United States, but only for three years. So it is hard to imagine that the company could remain a serious rival to NetRatings.
While NetRatings does not get the revenue from Jupiter's ratings contracts in the United States, neither does it incur the expense of shutting down its domestic or international networks of tens of thousands of users who have their Web use monitored. In the merger, it had planned to eliminate this service and other duplications at a cost of $45 million.
NetRatings has received a break on another front, too. The same week as its Media Metrix deal, it agreed to buy from VNU for $9.6 million the 80 percent of its overseas unit, e-Ratings, that it does not already own. NetRatings originally was going to buy e-Ratings in October, when it was going to buy Jupiter, so it could combine the international operations; the price had been set at $16 million.
"We will wind up paying $35 million for most of what was going to cost us $130 million," said William Pulver, NetRatings' chief executive.
These deals leave little value in Jupiter's United States ratings business, which it is still trying to sell. ComScore, a Reston, Va., market research company that also measures Web audience behavior, is interested in buying the Media Metrix client contracts, said Gian Fulgoni, comScore's chief executive. But it has no interest in the company's employees or its panel of users. ComScore has a different methodology it says is better and cheaper for measuring the use of Internet sites.
The fate of the Jupiter research business is even less certain. The two most probable buyers -- Forrester Research and Gartner -- have decided not to buy it, as many of Jupiter's top analysts leave for greener pastures.
Gartner is having enough trouble getting its rival to Jupiter, called G2, off the ground to be interested in expanding in that business, people close to Gartner say.
And Forrester already serves many of Jupiter's clients, leaving little reason to buy the firm, according to George F. Colony, Forrester's chief executive. So far Forrester has avoided Jupiter's fate by pursuing other research topics -- like pure technology and supply-chain issues -- that have not been as hard hit as Web forecasting. And while Mr. Colony says he is confident that the research business will rebound, he acknowledges that it has not happened yet.
"Change is the gasoline that drives our business forward," he said. "And in 2001 and 2002, there is not much wind blowing on the change front."

HEADLINE: Fine Wines Are Hot Lots for Auction Houses of New York 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
Bang! Jamie Ritchie's gavel cracked the 10:10 a.m. silence in Sotheby's main salesroom on a recent Saturday, and a 12-bottle case of 1982 Chateau Cheval Blanc, a St.-Emilion, fetched $11,750 at auction.
 An hour earlier in Midtown, Morrell & Company's British wine auctioneer, David Molyneux-Berry, disposed of a bottle of 1966 Chateau Latour for $345 (including the 15 percent buyer's premium). A magnum of 1961 Dom Perignon Champagne bottled for Earl Spencer and readied in 1981 to commemorate the marriage of his daughter, Lady Diana Spencer, to the Prince of Wales, went for $5,750. The sale took place, as usual, in the Grand Havana Room, a private cigar club on top of 666 Fifth Avenue. 
 Auctions of rare and fine wines are a big business in New York. The rivalry among houses has steadily heated up in New York since 1999, when New York displaced London as the wine auction capital of the world. 
The business seems to be showing robust growth despite the recession and the aftereffects of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, fed by wealthy New Yorkers and bargain-hunters who fancy a bottle of fine wine and relish a rush of auction fever. 
In early May, the already crowded field got another competitor when Zachys, a wine emporium in Scarsdale, N.Y., announced its return to the auction arena, five months after its seven-year partnership with Christie's dissolved. At a fancy luncheon at Restaurant Daniel that Zachys gave to celebrate its return, Fritz Hatton, one of its two new auctioneers, reviewed the economics of the wine auction world. "Before the New York wine auction law was passed" in 1993, he said, "sales of wine at auction in the U.S. totaled about $14 million. Eight years later, the total was $69 million, of which $43 million was hammered down in New York." (London's total was $26.2 million.) 
In overtaking London, New York achieved a status that London had taken centuries to develop. The first wine auction by the founder of Christie's, James Christie, was on Dec. 5, 1766, in London. 
Nearly 236 years later, the British colonists' thirsty successors still covet claret -- an English term for red Bordeaux. A boom in vintage Bordeaux, blue-chip Burgundies and California cult wines like Screaming Eagle cabernet sauvignon has been fueled mainly by brick-and-mortar auction houses, immeasurably by online sales and profitably by Americans' ever-rising sophistication about wine as a commodity.
Entering the market as a solo competitor, Zachys is pitting itself against tough rivals: Sotheby's and its partner, Aulden Cellars; Christie's and its new partner, the New York Wine Warehouse, a Long Island City boutique; the independent Acker Merrall & Condit, an Upper West Side merchant; and the independent Morrell, a Rockefeller Plaza store, which also owns a wine-bar-cum-cafe and plans a restaurant downtown.
The world's top-grossing wine auction for 2001, held by Sotheby's/Aulden Cellars in December, brought in $4,285,738. By contrast, in the art world, in one evening two Monets can fetch $43 million, which explains why the New York-based executives in Sotheby's and Christie's wine departments are not boldface names. But in winedom, speculators perceive the departments as lucrative mini-powerhouses.
When New York State's auction law was put into place in 1993, it included a provision intended to protect wine merchants against a potential loss of business: It required any auction house seeking to hold regular wine sales to join with a wine merchant who had owned a license for 10 straight years. Merchants, though, have been free to start auction divisions alone. In 1994, Morrell held New York's first auction, and the market has been growing ever since.
Mr. Hatton said business was good. "In spite of negative stock market trends in 2001, total sales of wine at auction in the U.S. rose 5 percent," he said. "If, at the beginning of 2001, you owned the basket of wines measured by the Wine Spectator Auction Index, and had resisted the temptation to drink or sell the wines, by the end of the year their value would have increased by 16 percent." 
What astonished professionals like Mr. Ritchie, the British-born senior vice president of Sotheby's wine department, was that the aftermath of the terrorist attacks not only did not impair auction sales, it might have galvanized them. "The whole fall season was incredible," he said. "After 9/11, there was a feeling that people sought out wine to drink. People were entertaining more at home." 
The Sotheby's/Aulden sale on Sept. 21 and 22 grossed $2,892,566, with 79 percent of the lots sold. An unidentified American paid $40,250 -- twice the high estimate -- for 12 bottles of 1969 Romanee-Conti from the Domaine de la Romanee-Conti, perhaps the greatest red Burgundy estate of all.
In Sotheby's $4,285,738 auction, in which 95 percent of the lots were sold, a South American, triumphing in gladiatorial telephone bidding with another collector, paid $167,500 for seven bottles of 1978 Montrachet from the Domaine de la Romanee-Conti. "A world record price for white Burgundy at auction," Sotheby's said; it had assessed the consignment at $7,000 to $10,000. 
Local collectors, fearing burglary or worse, shun publicity. A former restaurateur from Long Island, clad in a T-shirt and jeans like many customers at Sotheby's, would discuss his 9,000-bottle, $2 million cellar only on the condition of anonymity.
His passion is the rarest and costliest of the rare: huge bottles called imperials (the equivalent of 8 regular bottles), jeroboams (6 bottles of wine) and salmanazars (12 bottles). "If a producer makes only 100 imperials and I buy 5 at auction, I own 5 percent of his year's production," he said. As the supply dwindles, the resale price escalates, he said. 
One bidder at Sotheby's recent sale was Kevin A. Swersey, a principal in the Manhattan-based Connoisseur's Advisory Group, which advises high-net-worth individuals on managing fine wine. Sitting with a color-coded catalog in his lap, a paddle in one hand and consulting on a cellphone in the other, he bid scrappily for his affluent clients. A case of 1943 La Tache, a red from the Domaine de la Romanee-Conti, opened at $7,000, and he wore down opponents until he won it for $18,212 (including a recently instituted 17.5 percent buyer's premium).
Bargain-hunters who cannot afford an agent's commissions and shun absentee bidding can cherry-pick at Acker Merrall's auctions at the Inter-Continental Central Park South. In the periodically sleepy room, odd lots like a lone bottle of 1982 Chateau Talbot, a Bordeaux red, and unusual finds like six bottles of Domaine du Closel's 1990 Cuvee Speciale, a white from Savennieres in the Loire, might be bought at $70 and $180, respectively.
Acker Merrall, whose small staff is run by John Kapon, the 30-year-old 80-hour-a-week president, grossed $10,617,483 in New York in 2001, plus $2,497,299 more in separate sales in Los Angeles and San Francisco. In addition, the company has run monthly online auctions since last summer and has realized $1,615,712 from them, Mr. Kapon said. 
While Jeff Zacharia, the president of Zachys, is bullish about the prospects for growth and profitability in wine auctions, Michael Aaron, the chairman of Sherry-Lehmann, perhaps America's most famous wine store, has doubts.
After Sherry-Lehmann's five-year partnership with Sotheby's ended in 1999, Mr. Aaron contemplated returning independently, then junked the notion in favor of concentrating on retail sales and service. While in auctions, his sales grew 5 percent a year; since then, the rate has been 10 to 15 percent, he said.
Referring to the rivals in New York as well as Butterfields in San Francisco and a new Chicago company, Edward Roberts International, both of which many Easterners view as marginal, Mr. Aaron said, "With seven houses competing for a limited quantity of wine put up for auctions, and the costs of auctions very high, the profits may be low." His assessment excluded online houses like WineBid.com, in Seattle, which opened in 1996 and, a spokeswoman said, has grown to annual sales of $15 million. 
Since 1994, the auction market has expanded from the standbys -- French classics, mostly -- to include Italian, Australian and California wines at auction. A few Oregon and Washington wines have become staples. Ursula J. Hermacinski, who is widely considered America's leading wine auctioneer and has just joined Zachys, was asked whether, in light of the rising reputation of New York wines, she had found any Long Island or Finger Lakes wines suitable for auction. "No, not yet," she replied. "It's only a matter of time."
Time, and romance, write the script of wine auctions. Buyers who attend Christie's sale this Thursday and Friday in Midtown will be offered a bottle of 1907 Heidsieck & Company Monopole Gout Americain Champagne (estimated at $700 to $1,000). It was recovered in 1998 from the wreck of a Swedish schooner sunk in 1916 by a German submarine. The consignment, 3,000 bottles, was intended for the Russian Imperial Army. The Baltic Sea's depths and cold enabled them to survive both Czar Nicholas II and the Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Uneasy in Victory As Starters Scuffle

BYLINE:  By IRA BERKOW 

DATELINE: BOSTON 

 BODY:
IT was only the second inning last night at Fenway Park, that crazy quilt of a ballyard, and the Red Sox were intent last night on continuing to make life miserable for a Yankees starter. They had been unkind to Roger Clemens and David Wells on successive days, and they were showing little respect very quickly for another Bomber ace.
 First Brian Daubach, the left fielder, cracked a Mike Mussina pitch high into the night sky and it landed just below the McDonald's sign in the center-field bleachers. 
 Mussina hardly had time to ungrit his teeth from the blow when the next batter, Shea Hillenbrand, slammed another Mussina offering a considerable distance as well, this one sailing over the architecturally challenged left-field wall. 
It was just two weeks ago, against Oakland here, that Daubach and Hillenbrand had back-to-back homers. Maybe no one informed Mussina of this peril.
In the blink of an eye, the score was 2-0, and it was going to be uphill if the Yankees were to win the fourth game of this series and draw within a game of Boston, which sits atop the American League East.
Mussina is not only a veteran pitcher, and a hugely successful one, but he is also an economics graduate of Stanford. He understands that the market can fluctuate, and that patience, as well as a lively fastball and a blistering curve, is a virtue.
So he mopped his brow with the backside of his glove and returned to his labors with the steadfastness of one checking the sides of a ledger.
In the Yankee dugout sat the manager, Joe Torre. The captain of a stable, championship vessel for the last several years, Torre is not one to fret so early in a ballgame, and so early in a season. But he had to be somewhat concerned.
After all, before the season started, he said that this pitching staff was the deepest he had ever had. And just before yesterday's game, he was saying that the Red Sox were as formidable as they had been in years because their pitchers were good -- and healthy.
Not so his staff. At least his starters. Orlando Hernandez was scratched as a starter recently and placed on the disabled list. Andy Pettitte has been on the D.L. with tendinitis in his elbow. He threw in a minor league game in Sarasota and was supposed to throw 60 to 70 pitches and got through only 34.
David Wells got knocked around Saturday afternoon and left the game after three and two-thirds innings, though the bullpen was typically strong and saved the game. He has talked recently about back problems that may jeopardize his career.
Roger Clemens, the day before that, also took his lumps, and was fortunate not to get the loss. He also went three and two-thirds innings. He gave up five earned runs and nine hits and struck out but two, his shortest outing of the season. He will be 40 in August, and though he often appears to be 40 going on 20, age does have a way of sneaking up.
Tonight in Chicago, the Yankees will start the right-hander Mike Thurman, whom no one will confuse with Allie Reynolds or Vic Raschi, or Roger Clemens. He was just called up from Columbus, the Yankees' Class AAA farm club. He has pitched parts of five seasons in the majors, all with Montreal, and has a less than distinguished career earned run average of 5.04.
This is stopgap to be sure, but the fact nonetheless is: there are unanswered questions. And the fear is that the present may be prologue. Ted Lilly has been a pleasant surprise as an effective starter, even though he has a 1-4 record. He still leads the starters with a 2.93 E.R.A. Perhaps he is more motivated than the others because he earns a mere $237,000 a year.
So here was Mussina, going for his seventh victory against two losses this season, and getting out of the second with no further damage. And then the Yankees' bats exploded. Which is not so strange; they are tied for second in the American League in runs scored, and are first in home runs.
In the fourth, Jason Giambi was hit by a pitch, then Jorge Posada belted a homer over the Green Monster off the left-handed starter Darren Oliver to tie the score. In the fifth, Alfonso Soriano hit one over Trot Nixon's head in right and it landed just over the fence, 383 feet from home plate, as Nixon bounced off the wall like a pinball. Giambi homered with two on to extend the lead to 6-2. The inning still wasn't over, and Ron Coomer hit another homer with one on to make it 8-2.
This should have given Mussina a comfortable cushion. But, as it is with Yankees starters in recent times, he demonstrated a sense of the dramatic. And in the Red Sox' half of the fifth, he allowed a single, a double, a single, a single and a run-scoring double play. The Red Sox were challenging, at 8-5.
Soriano homered a second time, in the sixth, and Mussina held the Red Sox for one more inning, before he was replaced to start the seventh by Mike Stanton.
The line on Mussina: six innings, seven hits, five earned runs, a walk, five strikeouts, two homers. Not necessarily a performance to frame. He wound up the winning pitcher -- the Yanks won, 14-5 -- but he had the Yankee bats (including six home runs) and the Yankee bullpen to thank.
While Yankee starting-pitching concerns may not necessarily have mounted last night, they weren't what one might call diminished either.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mike Mussina was not at his best but was bailed out by the offense. (Vincent Laforet/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: California Scheming 

 BODY:
It has been two years since the meltdown in California's energy markets began. Despite the intense interest generated by Enron's role in the crisis, however, we still do not have a full accounting of what went wrong. We need that information. States that may still wish to pursue the once-bright promise of electricity deregulation will require instruction on how to avoid California's errors.
 Congress and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which are best positioned to do this job, are preoccupied with Enron's market manipulation. The danger is that California will be seen as just one part of the Enron story --the work of one rogue company instead of a complicated mess created by many different players. 
 The run-up of California energy costs in 2000 and 2001 bankrupted one utility, led to rolling blackouts and may yet cost Californians $30 billion in excess electricity charges. In the absence of a full accounting, people have constructed explanations that advance their own agendas. Vice President Dick Cheney first blamed the whole thing on the environmentalists, as well as shortages in natural gas. Gov. Gray Davis blamed the administration for its reluctance to impose controls on wholesale prices and to investigate market manipulation. Economists said things would have worked fine had politicians not meddled with their grand design. What's needed is for someone to cut through the explanations du jour and get at the truth.
The one thing everyone agrees on is that the power crisis was in large measure a crisis of underinvestment -- a booming state economy undone by the failure to build the power plants necessary to sustain that boom. Few plants were built in the 1990's when prices were low. Producers withheld new investments until they better understood the brave new era of deregulation -- which, as it turned out, nobody understood very well, least of all California. 
In deregulating its power system, the state seems to have made every mistake possible. For starters, it forced utilities to buy power at market rates while capping what they could charge their retail customers. This devastated the utilities. It also sent exactly the wrong signal to consumers, who had no incentive to conserve. In addition, bedazzled by the prospect of allowing the free market to set wholesale prices, California refused to let its utilities sign long-term contracts to buy power from the generators. The utilities were thus left at the mercy of an extraordinarily tight spot market that, in turn, was highly vulnerable to manipulation by the clever lads at Enron.
On top of all that came a perfect storm of unforeseen events that hit with calamitous force. These included a drought in the Pacific Northwest that reduced California's hydroelectric power, a rise in the cost of certain pollution credits and a spike in natural gas prices. Mr. Cheney was certainly right about that one. What remains unexplained is why the rise in gas prices was so much higher in California than it was anywhere else.
Suspicions that some natural gas companies deliberately withheld supplies in anticipation of still higher prices have never been fully explored. Nor has the question of why one-third of California's available power mysteriously went off line in the winter of 2000-2001. Was it because older plants shut down for repairs? Or was it simply another instance of power providers gaming the market?
To everyone's great relief, the crisis eventually receded. Federal regulators summoned the courage to impose price controls, thus reducing incentives for manipulation. California's politicians summoned the courage to lift the caps on retail prices, which, together with a vigorous program of energy conservation, reduced demand. Yet the fact remains that the state has been badly and perhaps needlessly battered.
It is Washington's duty to find out why, and to devise the necessary safeguards. Electricity is a public necessity that must be managed wisely, not entrusted blindly to the market.

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
Game makers explore new entertainment and information services for home video sets.

BYLINE:  By John Markoff

 BODY:
ARE they video-game consoles or Trojan horses?
 At the Electronic Entertainment Exposition, which ended in Los Angeles last Friday, the talk was all about gaming. Yet inside Sony's PlayStation 2, Microsoft's Xbox and Nintendo's GameCube lurk powerful computers capable -- in principle at least -- of browsing the Web, recording television shows, sending e-mail messages and generally serving as the hub of the much-ballyhooed "digital lifestyle." 
 The possibility of expanding the uses of ever less-expensive game machines became obvious at this year's game convention as all three companies announced plans to hook their systems to the Internet. Once the machines are connected to a high-speed, or broadband, network connection, then all manner of new entertainment and information services might be offered. 
Just as the personal computer has pushed its way into dozens of industries, a chameleonic video-game player could infiltrate the cable and satellite television industries, play CD's and DVD's and even take over some of the functions of an Internet-connected PC.
To varying degrees, though, Sony, Microsoft and Nintendo are being circumspect about their plans to push beyond gamers to reach the entire family in the living room. One fear is that by demonstrating additional nongame features they might alienate their mainstay audience of dedicated gamers. But such hesitancy might well be overcome by the allure of the great untapped revenue seen to be awaiting new forms of interactive media in the home. 
Ken Kutaragi, the chief executive of Sony Computer Entertainment, acknowledged just such a role for the PlayStation. Already, the company is exploring new functions for the machine in Japan, its home market. 
He pointed out that there was room in the PlayStation for a computer hard disk and said the company had developed a version of the machine with a personal video recorder. But he was coy about when such a feature might be offered in the United States. 
Nintendo officials, meanwhile, are the most openly skeptical about expanding the uses of video-game systems. "The people who say multifunction devices are the best solution are technical people," said Satoru Iwata, director and general manger of Nintendo's planning division. "These people aren't familiar with real users." 
For its part, Microsoft seems to be conflicted about how to proceed. During the development of Microsoft's game console, top executives of the Xbox division originally fought off Bill Gates's desire to base the video-game player on a version of the Windows software operating system, according to "Opening the Xbox," a recently published book by Dean Takahashi, a journalist. 
Instead, the Xbox uses a stripped-down operating system that comes with each game disk bought. By using a tiny operating system instead of the bulkier Windows, the Xbox can achieve performance speed and efficiency that is crucial to the gaming market. Nevertheless, the Xbox is a personal computer in video-game clothing, despite the public disavowals by the Xbox team that "we do video games," and nothing else. 
Earlier this year Microsoft announced its eHome initiative, another in a series of efforts to thrust Microsoft into the living room. The eHome project includes personal computer software called Freestyle that turns Windows into a digital video recorder and another program, Mira, that is intended to make it possible to remotely operate a PC using a tabletlike device.
"There is a great deal of pressure to bring eHome to the Xbox inside Microsoft," said Richard Doherty, president of Envisioneering, a Seaford, N.Y., computer industry consulting firm. 
That pressure may grow if Microsoft does not show signs of catching up with Sony. Despite having a one year technical lead over the Japanese consumer electronic giant the Xbox has not yet begun to show a significant performance advantage, and Sony has sold nearly 30 million PlayStation 2's, compared with only about about 3.5 million Xboxes. 
Microsoft's problems may be compounded by a growing perception in the video game industry that Sony is well positioned to continue to dominate the current generation of game devices, at least through 2004 or 2005. 
But if one of the contestants appears to be losing ground, they may try to catch up by changing the ground rules. 
"Sony and Microsoft are locked in a titanic battle in a steel cage," said Steve Koenig, an analyst at NPD, a video game market research firm. 
At the electronics exposition it was apparent that Microsoft was beginning to overcome its shortcomings in game software. The company was showing dozens of new titles in its booth. The company was also aggressively promoting a multibillion-dollar online game system for Xbox users, called Xbox Live, as a way of differentiating its systems. 
Still, it may be hard for Microsoft to gain much market share in video games alone. Last week both Microsoft and Nintendo were forced to cut the price of their video game systems in response to a price cut by Sony.
"The machines have gotten powerful enough that the average player can no longer tell the difference," said Shigeru Miyamoto, director and general manager of Nintendo's entertainment analysis and development division. 
Inside Microsoft itself there is great confidence that the business model it used to such great effect in the PC industry -- continually adding new features and functions -- is also applicable to the video-game business. Earlier this month at a San Francisco dinner for journalists held by Microsoft, Richard F. Rashid, the head of the company's research division, insisted that the company would be able to outpace Sony technologically.
The problem, of course, is that such a view of the business clashes directly with the video game industry's "razors and razor blades" marketing model. In the video-game business, both the software and hardware makers want the hardware design (the razors) to stay frozen for as long as possible. Most of the money is made from sales of software (the razor blades) sales and from hardware licensing fees. Typically, it is not until the final two or three years of the cycle that the hardware makers start to make money from selling the boxes themselves. 
But the PC model of the world is embedded deeply into Microsoft's corporate DNA. For the past decade, in each of the company's forays beyond the PC desktop -- whether to hand-held computers or television set-top boxes -- Microsoft has attempted to push into new markets by using the PC software model. 
That is why that there will continue to be growing pressure on the Xbox division from Microsoft's top executives to make the device much more than a video game console -- like a Web browser, or a digital video recorder or even a home "media server." Or whatever it takes to move from the den to the living room.

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section A; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1280 words

HEADLINE: At Ground Zero, Uneasy Agreement on Final Rite 

BYLINE:  By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
The pit where the World Trade Center once stood would be empty soon, with no more human remains to find. The moment would mark such a profound shift in the sad continuum of ground zero, from recovery to rebuilding, that formal commemoration was required. And so weeks of planning began.
 Perhaps a bald eagle could soar from the pit to symbolize the rise of souls and the resolve of a country. Maybe people should hold candles. And instead of the usual parade of speakers, how about letting silence say what already seems beyond words? 
 The suggestions came from construction workers, firefighters, victims' relatives and anyone else with a direct link to the disaster site; they helped inform Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's final decision to hold a ceremony on Thursday, one that seeks dignity through simplicity. No spectacle, no speeches, no eagle. Just an empty stretcher, a truck carrying the last girder, a little music and a lot of silence. 
But the psychic terrain of ground zero is fraught with mines, as Mr. Bloomberg discovered in choosing the date. Some family members have accused the mayor of increasing their pain by choosing to hold the ceremony on a weekday, rather than on a weekend. Some have even suggested that he simply did not want his weekend disrupted.
The city is learning, again, that the months since the collapse of the twin towers on Sept. 11 is but a blink of an eye, and that there is nothing tidy about mass grieving. That is why high-level discussions continue about the logistics of a ceremony just three days away, with every gesture and moment being evaluated for how it might be interpreted.
For example, the invitation list may be long -- it includes former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the entire City Council, and the governors and Congressional delegations of New York and New Jersey -- but families of victims are to be treated with particular deference. Even the possibility of a huge turnout is being addressed. City officials are citing the funeral of John F. Kennedy as an example of an event at which many people could not get close enough to see the procession, but still felt as though they had participated in the solemn ceremony.
Sociologists say that the difficulty in arranging some kind of final commemoration at ground zero is as understandable as the need for having one. The many victims came from myriad cultural backgrounds and left thousands of survivors who have different beliefs in how to honor the dead -- all in a country with no specific rite worked out for such immense tragedy.
"When a parent dies, we race home and make arrangements," said Harvey Molotch, a sociology professor at New York University. "But this is unprecedented. The fact that there are so many victims doesn't mean that there is only a multiplication of death's tragedy; there is also a multiplication of notions of what is proper to do."
The idea to commemorate the end of recovery efforts -- and to honor those who dug through and hauled away 1.8 million tons of debris -- came from down in the pit. Maybe it was a firefighter, or perhaps a construction worker, but someone at some point said that the removal of the last steel beam should be done in formal fashion.
Beginning in April, the city's Office of Emergency Management began holding meetings to discuss ideas, including many that were forwarded by e-mail. "It was a wonderful dialogue with a lot of give and take," said Jennie Farrell, the sister of a victim, James M. Cartier, and a leader of a support group called Give Your Voice.
People agreed on several central themes. "We knew that there needed to be a symbolic piece of steel brought out," said Jonathan Greenspun, the director of the city's Community Assistance Unit. "We knew that the piece of steel should be driven out, and behind the truck there should be members of all the relevant parties: families, rescue workers, recovery workers, emergency-services workers."
It also had to be noted that so far only about 1,000 of the more than 2,800 victims have been identified, he said. "In order to symbolize that fact, there would be a stretcher that would be empty."
Another important criterion also emerged: no speeches. "We came in with no speeches, and we leave with no speeches," said the Rev. Brian Jordan, a Roman Catholic priest who has served as a chaplain at the disaster site. "The economy of expression is the best resource we have to do a respectful and profound ceremony."
Ms. Farrell said that several family members emphasized that the ceremony should be on a weekend to better accommodate the thousands of people with ties to the victims. The idea, she said, was to "make it as easy as possible for them."
But when Mr. Bloomberg revealed plans for the ceremony two weeks ago, he surprised Ms. Farrell and a few others by announcing that it would be held on May 30, a Thursday that also happens to be the traditional Memorial Day. He explained that a weekend ceremony would disrupt religious services: Muslims worship on Fridays, Jews on Saturdays and Christians on Sundays.
Some people were particularly offended by how the mayor defended his decision last week. "No matter what day you pick, some people will find it inconvenient, but we are going to have it on May 30," he had said. "Watch it on television if you can't be there, and in your mind, just try to remember those that we lost."
To which Ms. Farrell responded: "Go watch it on television? This isn't a ballgame. This isn't the World Series."
"People make it sound as though all we do is complain and whine and cry," she added. "But you know what? It's about what happened to us."
City officials emphasized that Mr. Bloomberg was trying to be both sensitive and practical about the ceremony. They also say that other family members, particularly those who are not as vocal or as organized as Ms. Farrell, do not share in the anger over a weekday commemoration.
Nikki Stern, whose husband, James E. Potorti, was killed in the disaster, said that given what family members struggle with every day, the weekday-weekend quarrel is not a battle worth fighting. "I don't think anyone wanted to hurt anyone or offend anyone," she said. "It's tricky to try and accommodate everyone."
Jeffrey K. Olick, a sociology professor at Columbia University, agreed. "The commemorations have to be open enough to include a wide variety of purposes and interests," he said. "But they can't reach the point of being so vague that they do no good for anyone."
Mr. Greenspun said the city tried its best to accommodate everyone. "All I can tell you is that a tremendous amount of work and planning has gone into this in order to make sure that we do this right," he said.
As of now, the plan calls for bells to toll at 10:29 on Thursday morning to mark the moment when the second tower collapsed. An empty stretcher, covered with a flag, will be placed in a waiting ambulance. The ambulance and a truck carrying a single girder will slowly drive up the ramp that leads out of the pit, followed by the representatives of all the groups and agencies and trades that played a role in the sorrowful drama of ground zero. Trumpeters will sound taps, and bagpipers will play "God Bless America."
The procession will march north along West Street before ending at Canal Street. It will pass the local dignitaries, the government employees, other spectators -- and, of course, the family members, who will have gained access to a prominent viewing area by indicating the case number that the city assigned to the matter of their lost loved one.
Some family members have talked of boycotting the event. But Ms. Farrell said that even though she is upset, she feels it is only right that she attend.

HEADLINE: ON VISIT TO PARIS, BUSH TRIES TO EASE CONCERN IN EUROPE 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: PARIS, May 26 

 BODY:
Arriving here in the capital of European skepticism about how the United States exercises its power, President Bush sought today to play down his many differences with European leaders over trade, the environment and Iraq, while seeking France's help in defusing the conflict between India and Pakistan.
 On a day of heavy diplomacy, Mr. Bush also said he would soon be sending an envoy to the Middle East and urged Iran to open itself to nuclear inspections. 
 The president, looking tired and confessing that he was jet-lagged after a whirlwind tour through Berlin, Moscow and St. Petersburg, insisted to reporters here that European protests against his policies left him unconcerned, saying, "There's a heck of a lot more that unites us than divides us." 
Still, France's president, Jacques Chirac, while warmly welcoming Mr. Bush to Elysee Palace, was quick to enumerate his government's many differences with the United States. He told reporters that he had told Mr. Bush that there was "a very real risk in going on consuming more of our planet than the earth can really produce," a not-so-subtle swipe at Mr. Bush's energy policies.
For his part, Mr. Bush seemed to enjoy playing the part of the Texas ranch-owner coming to the center of European style and cuisine. "He's always saying that the food here is fantastic," Mr. Bush said, nodding toward Mr. Chirac with a half-smile. "And I'm going to give him a chance to show me tonight."
For all the banter, concerns elsewhere held Mr. Bush's attention today. He again sought to calm the India-Pakistan conflict, and chastised Gen. Pervez Musharraf for the second time in two days, saying the Pakistani president had to "show results in terms of stopping people from crossing the Line of Control, stopping terrorism," a reference to Islamic insurgents crossing into Indian-held Kashmir.
Both Mr. Bush and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell warned India and Pakistan publicly that there were American forces in the region that could be harmed in either a conventional or nuclear exchange. Administration officials said they were not considering having those forces intervene. Rather, they were making the point that both sides had to exercise extraordinary care.
"I'm just worried that they have a history of miscalculating," a senior administration official said in an interview. "In dealing with the old Soviet Union, we all knew the rules. We worry that the Indians and the Pakistanis don't have any rules."
Turning to another leader who has often ignored administration calls to control militants who commit terrorism -- Yasir Arafat -- Mr. Bush said he would send an envoy to the Middle East, as early as this week. Other administration officials said it would be George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, who had delayed his trip to the region. Mr. Tenet is hoping to work out security arrangements that would pave the way to a cease-fire and political talks, but the administration has been locked in a debate over whether and how to deal with the Palestinian leader.
This morning, seeming to turn up the heat on Mr. Arafat, Mr. Bush told reporters that he believed that "you're beginning to see talk of reform" in the Palestinian Authority, and that Arabs were beginning "to question out loud" why the authority had not delivered peace and prosperity to its people. It was unclear whether Mr. Bush was seeking to undermine Mr. Arafat's power by noting that the Palestinian leader's own people were calling for change, or whether he was trying to give him yet another chance to perform. He said Mr. Arafat has "had a chance to fight terror, and he hasn't."
After days of wrangling with Russia on its nuclear exports to Iran, Mr. Bush also said for the first time that President Vladimir V. Putin had offered a way of resolving those differences with Washington. Mr. Putin, he said, raised the possibility of putting pressure on Iran to allow international inspectors into the country to determine whether it was diverting Russian commercial nuclear technology to military projects.
The administration fears that Iran's military is diverting the technology in an effort to develop a nuclear bomb. On Friday, Mr. Putin said there was no evidence to support that. But Mr. Bush's concern became more urgent last week when American officials said Iran had carried out a successful test of the Shahab-3 missile, which has a range of roughly 800 miles. That means that it could reach Israel, or American troops stationed in Saudi Arabia, Afghanistan, Pakistan and parts of Turkey.
But while juggling those concerns, Mr. Bush was arriving for the first time as president on French soil -- only to discover a drizzly Paris whose side streets had been barricaded in case of demonstrations on the scale of those that greeted him in Berlin last week. The precaution was unnecessary: save for a few hecklers, there have been no organized demonstrations in Paris.
Nonetheless, the barricades underscored one of the oddities of the trip: Mr. Bush received his warmest reception in Russia, the old cold war enemy now happy at the prospect of aid and trade with the United States, and the coldest in the capitals of his European allies. 
Asked today about his poor image in Europe, Mr. Bush said, "Look, the only thing I know to do is speak my mind, to talk about my values, to talk about our mutual love for freedom and the willingness to defend freedom."
"I don't view hostility here," he added. "I view the fact that we've got a lot of friends here."
One of them, he said, was Mr. Chirac, who was clearly reveling in his role as host at the palace after his recent re-election. But Mr. Chirac by turns celebrated the French-American friendship and its alliance against terrorism, while reminding Mr. Bush of the reasons that, in Paris's view, his administration was putting strains on it. He mentioned the farm bill that Mr. Bush signed two weeks ago, which gives billions of dollars in new subsidies to American farmers at a time when the United States is telling European nations to cut subsidies to their farmers.
But then Mr. Chirac said, "These diverging views only account for 5 percent of the trade between the E.U. and the U.S.," adding, "The United States and Europe are the two major economic powers in the world." (That may come as news to Japan, the world's second-largest economy.)
Mr. Bush committed a faux pas of his own: He announced today that his planned visit Monday to Normandy to mark Memorial Day on the site of the D-Day invasion almost 58 years ago would be historic. "For the first time ever, if I'm not mistaken, the president of the United States will not be in the United States on Memorial Day." 
It turns out he was mistaken: the last president to commemorate Memorial Day outside the United States was his own father, in Italy 13 ago.
"It was my fault," Condoleezza Rice, the president's national security adviser, said by telephone. She had gotten "a little ahead of my fact-checkers," she said, and fed the president incorrect information.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 29, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Monday about President Bush's visit to France was incorrect in suggesting that President Jacques Chirac was wrong to have said, "The United States and Europe are the two major economic powers in the world." He was correct: although Japan indeed has the second-largest national economy, after that of the United States, it is smaller than that of the European Union, which comprises 15 countries.

HEADLINE: New Drug for Malaria Pits U.S. Against Africa 

BYLINE:  By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: GENEVA 

 BODY:
With resistance to old malaria drugs spreading, African officials want to start using a relatively new Chinese remedy so powerful that some experts consider it a miracle drug. Because more than 2,000 African children die of malaria each day, doctors there are clamoring for the drug, and the World Health Organization recommends it.
 But the United States generally opposes using it in Africa yet. 
 An adviser to the Agency for International Development in Washington, Dennis Carroll, said the medicine, artemisinin, probably represented "the best long-term option." But, he added, the drug is expensive and hard for poorly educated people to take correctly. It needs, he said, more testing in infants and is "not ready for prime time." 
Other experts say delays will cost too many lives because the drugs now in use are rapidly losing their effectiveness.
Artemisinin was first refined 30 years ago in China from the qinghaosu plant, used in fever remedies for 2,000 years. The raw material comes from China and Vietnam, although the source plant, Artemisia annua, known as sweet wormwood or Chinese wormwood, grows wild even in the United States.
In Vietnam, according to W.H.O., the death toll from an epidemic was reduced 97 percent from 1992 to 1997 using bed nets, indoor DDT spraying and artemisinin. In a study under way in rural South Africa, malaria deaths dropped 87 percent in a year.
"It really is a marvelous drug," said Dr. David Nabarro, executive director in the director general's office at W.H.O. "It's not only a treatment, but the treated person then contains a sterile form of the malaria. So it reduces the intensity of the epidemic."
Many African countries want to switch to it now, arguing that resistance to chloroquine and sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine, the usual front-line drugs, is rapidly spreading. 
Most of those countries cannot buy drugs without help from donors or World Bank loans. Some public health officers complain that A.I.D. quietly pressures them not to even request artemisinin.
Mr. Carroll denied the pressure but said the agency believed that artemisinin had not been tested enough on infants and that sulfadoxine/pyrimethamine, or S/P, had some years of usefulness left. For that reason, the agency officially suggests saving artemisinin for cases not helped by first-line drugs.
That infuriates malaria specialists like Dr. Fred Binka, a professor of epidemiology at the University of Ghana. "I couldn't believe my ears," Dr. Binka said after American officials defended that view at a conference here in February. "In poor countries like ours, children have only one chance. They struggle just to visit a health service, and if they get the wrong drug the first time, they are then found dead."
Dr. Bernard Pecoul, director of the Doctors Without Borders campaign for cheaper medicines, called the American position "frankly, very difficult to understand."
Senior W.H.O. officials are careful to say just that the United States is "sounding useful notes of caution," in the words of Dr. David J. Alnwick, manager of the Roll Back Malaria project in the agency.
"It's wrong to polarize it and say the U.S. is anti-artemisinin," he said.
But Dr. Kamini Mendis, another official at Roll Back Malaria, said applying pressure not to seek the best treatment would be disturbing.
"It's not logical," Dr. Mendis said. "Resistance is a huge problem, and there are not many drugs in the pipeline because it's not a rich man's disease."
A study in 1996, underwritten by the Wellcome Trust, a British foundation that researches medical issues, found that $42 per malaria death was spent on research, compared with $840 per death on asthma research and $3,360 per death on AIDS research. 
Malaria is in 90 countries, with more than 300 million cases a year, more than a million of them fatal.
Rural African children suffer up to six bouts a year. The disease is often poorly treated, meaning that the children die slowly of anemia. Survivors may be mentally stunted.
The disease also drains national economies. W.H.O. studies show that families affected by malaria clear 40 percent of the land for planting that healthy people do. The disease also scares off tourists and foreign investors. Most African countries have used chloroquine as their first-line drug since 1970. But resistance is up to 90 percent in some areas.
Sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine, under brand names like Fansidar, succeeded it. But pockets of resistance have been found from South Africa to Burundi, sometimes running as high as 60 percent of the cases.
"If you had such resistance levels to a drug in the West," Dr. Binka of of Ghana said, "you know there would be an outcry."
Experts now agree that treatment has to be mixtures of drugs, or cocktails, like those used for AIDS, to fight resistant strains.
Chloroquine and S/P are extremely cheap, as little as 20 cents for an adult treatment. Chloroquine usually has to be taken three times over three days. S/P is a one-time dose.
Artemisinin compounds, by contrast, can be 100 times as expensive. Novartis, the Swiss multinational, sells its cocktail of an artemisinin drug and lumefantrine as Riamet for $20 in rich countries and as Coartem to W.H.O. for poor countries for $2. Using Chinese or Vietnamese suppliers, Doctors Without Borders says it believes that it can obtain a similar combination for $1.30 a dose.
But price is not the sole factor. Africans obtain virtually all AIDS and tuberculosis medicines by prescription. But 80 percent buy malaria pills where they buy detergent, matches or aspirin.
Those small stores and peddlers are de facto pharmacists and, Dr. Binka said, have to be retrained somehow to give sound advice.
Artemisinin drugs have drawbacks. Up to 12 pills have to be taken over three days, preferably with milk. They rapidly stop the aches and fever, so patients who cannot afford 12 pills or milk may stop. That lets the most resistant parasites survive, to be transferred by mosquito to the next victim. Nonetheless, many doctors in Africa are worried enough to want the drugs now.
The public health director in Zambia, Dr. Rosemary Sunkutu, said malaria was the No. 1 killer there. Chloroquine is nearly useless, Dr. Sunkutu said, and S/P resistance is reported at 16 percent. With an additional $8 million, she said, Zambia could switch to Coartem "and substantially reduce the number of children who would die." The American Embassy's aid representative in Lusaka asked her to keep using the cheaper drugs, she said.
Mr. Carroll of A.I.D. and Dr. Richard W. Steketee, chief of the malaria epidemiology branch of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, defended the reluctance to endorse artemisinin for Africa. 
"In the vast majority of Africa, S/P remains effective," Mr. Carroll said, although he acknowledged that it would not be for long.
