HEADLINE: Sky Is Falling on Prairie Chicken, Sacrifice of a Rite of Spring 

BYLINE:  By E. VERNON LAUX 

DATELINE: CASSODAY, Kan. 

 BODY:
A roadside sign proclaims this town the Prairie Chicken Capital of the World. But the prairie chicken is experiencing a catastrophic decline here in the Flint Hills, the core of its range.
 On a recent spring day, it was easy to see why. Vast stretches of tallgrass prairie were engulfed in fire. Heat and smoke had turned the vast grassland into a sterile, stinking black inferno, a prairie Armageddon. 
 This burning has become an annual event on much privately owned grassland. The lush grass that comes up after the fire dies is ideal for cattle, which gain weight faster than than they do when grazing on older grasses. And cattle ranching is big business here. 
But the effects are devastating for the region's plants and animals, many researchers who study the tallgrass prairie say. The greater prairie chicken (Tympanuchus cupido), the species found here, is a case in point.
The burning and intensive grazing remove the vegetative cover and wipe out insects, reptiles and small mammals -- the suite of animals associated with this ecosystem. And the fires often force female prairie chickens off egg-filled nests.
As a result, ecologists, conservationists, ranchers and others have joined forces here to devise ways to preserve the ecosystem while allowing cattle to thrive.
Prairie chickens are a species of grouse that is much admired by birders, known to travel great distances to see the birds' extraordinary mating displays here.
Up to 40 male birds gather at dawn here, some 50 miles northeast of Wichita, on a display ground or lek, perhaps half the size of a football field, to perform their outrageous mating antics. They hoot, jump and shake their wings, all to impress the females watching the show.
The birds inflate normally invisible yellow-orange air sacs on the sides of their necks and their long ornamental feathers, called pinnae, stand up on their heads, drastically changing their normally drab look.
But the greater prairie chicken has suffered serious declines over its range, from North Dakota and Minnesota to Missouri and Oklahoma. Attwater's prairie chicken (Tympanuchus cupido attwateri), a subspecies that once occupied what is now the intensively farmed land of southern Texas, has been reduced to 22 males in 2001 from a million or more in the early 1900's.
A close relative, the easternmost form of the greater prairie chicken, a subspecies known as the heath hen (Tympanuchus cupido cupido) is extinct. The last one, a male, was seen in 1932 on Martha's Vineyard.
An increasing number of experts fear that if land use patterns continue, the remaining prairie chickens are in danger of going the way of the heath hen. Only in Nebraska and South Dakota, where burning is less intense, are populations steady or slightly increasing.
"Fire is a very necessary component in the Flint Hills as it is in other grasslands," said Brian Obermeyer, director of the Flints Hills Initiative, a project of the Kansas chapter of the Nature Conservancy.
Fires set by lightning, or more recently by people, help grasslands stay free of woody vegetation and restore vitality and species diversity. But, he said, "The key is having enough residual vegetation to meet the needs of native wildlife."
Naturally occurring fire was an important natural part of the prairie ecosystem, said Mark B. Robbins, an ornithologist at the University of Kansas Natural History Museum. "Burning on this scale, every year, at the same time, is not."
The Flint Hills, which run from northern Oklahoma through eastern Kansas almost to Nebraska, contain the largest remaining expanse of tallgrass prairie in America. By some estimates, less than 2 percent of the tallgrass prairie remains. What is left is highly fragmented.
Pressure on the Flint Hills landscape intensified in the 1980's when landowners began managing privately held land here under a fire and grazing regimen called intensive early stocking, which allows ranchers to double the size of their herds.
This involves annually burning large parts of the prairie in the spring. Once the new grass emerges, 10 days or so after a burn, cattle are trucked in to feed on the new growth for three or four months. Ranchers can feed twice as many head of cattle as they can on land that is not burned, researchers at the Kansas State Agricultural Experiment Station say. But the grazing leaves the Flint Hills devoid of grass more than an inch or so high until at least mid-July.
Since 1982, the number of birds killed in the state hunting season has fallen drastically, reaching 19,300 in 2000 from about 109,000 in 1982, according to data from the Kansas Department of Wildlife and Parks. 
Mr. Robbins and Dr. A. Townsend Peterson, ornithologists at the Natural History Museum and Miguel A. Ortega-Huerta from the department of geography and the Kansas Applied Remote Sensing Program, all at the University of Kansas, attribute the precipitous declines in Kansas and similar drops in Oklahoma to the annual spring burning and the double-stocking regimen.
In Nebraska and South Dakota, where rotational burning is the rule and double stocking is not done, the populations are holding their own.
But people like Mr. Obermeyer do not advocate eliminating cattle grazing here to save birds. "The best and most realistic way to save the Flint Hills and species like the prairie chicken is to keep the rancher on the land," said Mr. Obermeyer. "They keep the woody vegetation from encroaching, care deeply about their responsibilities as stewards of the land and understand the problems." 
Alan Pollom, director of the Kansas chapter of the Nature Conservancy, said a way must be found to help ranchers and conservationists work together. "The Flint Hills will never be a national park," he said. "They are privately owned and will be dedicated to some type of economic activity. Conservationists have to be serious about working with the ranching community to come up with creative ideas that are both economically and biologically sustainable."
Dr. Samuel D. Fuhlendorf, a professor of rangeland ecology at Oklahoma State, and his colleagues are working on a rotational approach, patch burning, in which the prairies will be burned every three or four years, a span they say is sufficient to maintain grasslands. Animals would be free to graze on burned or undisturbed parts of the landscape.
Dr. Fuhlendorf said: "We have three years of data from three sites along an east-west gradient across the Great Plains. We compare the patch burning approach to typical management of each area. So far, we have not been able to find any differences in livestock production but we have documented increased habitat diversity with patch burning. Greater diversity in habitat with the patch burning approach leads to an increased diversity in insects, small mammals and grassland birds, so it proceeds through the food chain."
Ranchers, conservationists and agency representatives are cooperating to solve these problems through a new group, the Tallgrass Legacy Alliance, or T.L.A. Its goal is figuring out the best way to preserve the tallgrass prairie and its biodiversity and making it feasible for ranchers to make a living.
"Having a group like T.L.A. has been a great help to me," Mr. Obermeyer said, "because it helps bring together all the folks really serious about saving the tallgrass prairie. I see this group as a national model."

HEADLINE: Juneau Journal; 
Push to Move Alaska's Capital Has Central Theme

BYLINE:  By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: JUNEAU, Alaska, May 26 

 BODY:
Plenty of state capitals are not centrally or conveniently located. But Juneau takes the prize.
 It is in Alaska's panhandle, way down in the southeast corner of the state, on a sliver of land that can be reached only by boat or plane, providing the weather cooperates. If you travel by road, you simply can't get here from there -- too many mountains, glaciers and rain forests. 
 Many Alaskans say the capital should be more centrally located. But every time they have tried to make a change -- and they have tried a half-dozen times over the past 40 years -- Juneau has headed them off, arguing that moving a governor, the Legislature and state agencies would be too expensive and would leave Juneau a ghost town.
Now, still another effort is under way. But this one is different.
Instead of proposing an outright shift of the whole capital to a more central site, the relocation forces are proposing that only the Legislature move, preferably to the Matanuska-Susitna Valley, which lies about 40 miles north of Anchorage -- and 900 miles northwest of Juneau -- and is one of the fastest growing regions in the state. Enough signatures have been gathered to put the proposal on the fall ballot.
"Three-fourths of the state's people live within a tankful of gas of the valley," said Uwe Kalenka, a mini-mall manager from Anchorage and one of the leaders of Alaskans for Efficient Government, the citizens' group that collected the signatures. "They could travel by road to get their legislative business done in as little as a day -- no boats, no planes, no weather delays, no expensive three-day overnight stays, no hassle. And it won't cost all that much to make the switch because there's not all that much to be done."
The Juneau defense effort is being led this time, as it has been before, by the Alaska Committee, another citizens' group. Its president, Win Gruening, a member of a family long involved in Alaska politics, contends that the relocation forces are trying to "slip in through the back door" by focusing on the Legislature.
"If the Legislature were to be moved, it would be only a matter of time before the rest of the government would go," Mr. Gruening said. "And that would be a disaster for Juneau. Government accounts for close to 40 percent of the city's economy. You eliminate that and you don't solve a problem. You create one, because one of the three largest population centers in the state would be devastated, and at the same time the state would have wasted millions it doesn't have on a pure folly." 
Juneau became the capital in 1900, when Alaska was a territory and the great gold rush was on. This is where the most people were then.
But now, the heaviest concentration of Alaskans is in the central part of the state, around Anchorage, in particular. Anchorage has a population of more than 260,000, compared with just over 30,000 for Juneau. 
State Senator Randy Phillips of Eagle River, a community near Anchorage, argues that the only real issue is "access, access, access" for the people of Alaska, not moving costs, or Juneau's economy or accommodating legislators who do not like to travel.
"You can't put a price on access," he said. "This isn't about what Juneau wants. It's about what the people of Alaska want." 
Beth Kerttula, a state representative from Juneau, concedes that traveling to the city is difficult. But she contends that if the capital is moved -- given Alaska's huge size, harsh climate and wildly beautiful but exceptionally rugged terrain -- the same factors will remain a problem for many residents and legislators seeking to reach it.
"It you live way out in some place like Dutch Harbor in the Aleutians -- halfway to Japan and with some of the worst weather on earth -- you've got access problems no matter where you're headed," she said. "Alaska is full of those places. But in recent years we've done a great deal to make things easier, some of it really cutting edge for any legislature. Most of what we do is now on cable television or available on our Web site, both in print and audio. Our airport now has state-of-the-art bad-weather equipment. And every citizen can get one reduced fare each year to fly to Juneau for legislative business."
The Alaskans for Efficient Government will not say how much money it may devote to its campaign. But the Alaska Committee says it plans to spend "whatever it takes" to defend Juneau's status, with much of the money coming from the city.
"We spent over a million bucks to beat the last effort in 1994 and won 55 to 45" percent, said Jim Powell, a committee member and a Juneau city councilman who is married to Ms. Kerttula, the state legislator. "They keep coming back at us, and we're in a tough fight, as usual. But we've got some allies elsewhere. There are plenty of people in this state who don't want to see more power concentrated in the Anchorage area."

HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD; 
Corporate Conferences With Saddles and Spurs

BYLINE:  By Joe Sharkey 

DATELINE: TUCSON, Ariz. 

 BODY:
DUDE ranches tend to attract very congenial people as a rule, which is why the strange foreigner whom we quickly began calling Black Bart stood out here at the Tanque Verde Guest Ranch. 
 A grouchy man who said he was Swiss but sure sounded English Midlands to me, Black Bart insisted on always riding at the head of the pack, and he'd glower and rein his horse to cut off anybody trying to edge in. But beyond his unfriendliness, he was most remarkable for his attire. 
 Every morning, as the 7 o'clock lope ride saddled up, Black Bart, who appeared to be well into his 60's, would arrive at the corral wearing a different cowboy outfit. Now when I say cowboy outfit, I am not talking denim shirt, faded Wranglers, dusty boots and sweat-stained Cattleman hat. I am talking the full nine yards: satin and spangles and spurs, a black hat, chaps and a fringed black silk shirt with a silvery star pinned on the chest. I am talking a guy dressed for the chorus of a road-show production of the Aaron Copland ballet "Rodeo." 
My wife and I like riding in the Sonora desert, and are regular visitors to the Tanque Verde ranch, which sprawls over the foothills of the Rincon Mountains east of town. Black Bart, we learned, is also a regular, though our visits had never before overlapped. The only reason I am telling you about Black Bart is that on this trip, he, as we did, noticed something slightly different at the ranch. He, for one, did not much like the looks of it.
"Bloody corporate people," Black Bart, lip curled, snarled to no one in particular as a group of about eight of us set off for a fast ride down a desert wash one sunny morning.
This was clearly a reference to a jolly group of guests who remained standing back at the corral, where they waited to be loaded onto horses for a 90-minute ride at a leisurely walking pace into the saguaro-studded hills. Most of them had on the big straw cowboy hats that the ranch hands out to guests. They were joshing each other and having a ball at the prospect of starting their work day winding around desert cactuses on the back of a horse.
As I said, dude ranches attract sociable people, so the regular ranch vacationers, our crotchety electric cowboy manque aside, were actually happy to share the place with the amiable corporate folks, some with spouses and children in tow, who were there to attend business or professional meetings -- with riding, tennis, swimming and desert nature hiking thrown in.
The corporate exhibition, trade show and meetings businesses all have been clobbered in the last year by a soured economy that took hold a year ago and by the terrorist attacks in September. The highest-cost end of those businesses, the trade shows and exhibitions that are mostly held in convention centers in 15 or 20 major cities, is still reeling. 
But as the hotel industry itself began coming back with unexpected strength this spring, so, it appears, has a part of the corporate meetings business that relies on smaller company gatherings of 200 attendees or fewer in intimate hotel or resort settings.
But a dude ranch?
"This year, our May has been the best May ever because of the corporate meeting business we've been bringing in," said Bob Cote, the soft-spoken owner, whose father bought the place in the 1950's. "June looks just as good, even though we're in the off-season," he said. 
Tanque Verde started as a cattle ranch in 1868 and became a dude ranch in 1928. In the past year, a new conference center and desert nature-exhibit center have been opened and a sales staff expanded to attract more corporate meeting business to the 640-acre spread. 
Part of the attraction is that a dude ranch is strikingly different from the standard golf resort long favored for corporate meetings, with activities that can be enjoyed by a wide range of people who may not be golfers.
"We're having success because people are overwhelmed by the uniqueness of the setting," Mr. Cote said. "Also, meeting planners find that with a smaller setting'; away from urban distractions "the in-mix within their groups is much stronger," he said. In an environment like a ranch, communal dining, horses, and riding at all levels tend to be social equalizers that can break down stiff corporate hierarchical boundaries and enhance the business part of the gathering.
During our stay, there were about 30 leisure guests at the ranch, which draws visitors from all over the world. Another 100 or so guests were split between a corporate meeting and a gathering of executives and academics (including a contingent of astronomers) sponsored by the Cornell Adult University division of Cornell University. Their six-day program featured tours and lectures on desert ecology and on the night skies, which are strikingly vibrant in the Tucson area because of local initiatives to reduce ambient municipal lighting.
"The real bonus was being able to take advantage of riding when there was any free time," said Bill Froelich, a retired Wall Street executive who lives on the Caribbean island of Saba and who was with the Cornell group. "The riding trails in the desert made some of the ecology lectures more meaningful," said Mr. Froelich, who hadn't been on a horse in years but soon was yelping with joy as he cantered over the sand in a cloud of dust. 
David Larkin, the chief executive of TSNN.com, a Web site that publishes data on the corporate trade show and exhibition industries, said that many of the top show and meetings locations were now "totally hurting for business" and saddled with overcapacity. At the same time, hotels and resorts that have expanded and modernized their meetings and conference facilities, and offer unique experiences, are positioned to profit from the trend toward "smaller, more focused events," he said.
"There are so many great places to have a meeting now," he added. "Why have it in Cleveland if you can go to Arizona?"

HEADLINE: Colombian President-Elect Softens Tone on Rebels 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, May 27 

 BODY:
He won the presidency promising to crack down on leftist rebels, but today President-elect Alvaro Uribe Velez struck a conciliatory tone, holding out the possibility of negotiating with guerrilla commanders under United Nations mediation.
 He told foreign journalists today that he hoped to set up a meeting with Secretary General Kofi Annan to discuss the possibility of initiating talks with the United Nations. Mr. Uribe also said that negotiations with a right-wing paramilitary group, bitter enemies of the rebels, were possible, a proposition his predecessors had declined to consider because of the widespread rights abuses perpetrated by the organization. 
 "We are going to look for general support for that initiative, and ask that the mission be completed by the United Nations," Mr. Uribe said. 
"What mission?" he added. "The mission of establishing communications with the insurgent movement."
A United Nations official said the world organization was "following with great interest Mr. Uribe's statements regarding a future role for the United Nations in a new peace process."
Mr. Uribe's vice president-elect, Francisco Santos, said the idea was to "open the door" to the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, the country's largest and most powerful guerrilla organization.
Talks with the group were broken off by President Andres Pastrana in February, as a result of a wave of rebel aggressions.
The guerrillas did not have an immediate response to Mr. Uribe's victory on Sunday or his comments today.
But analysts who have closely followed Colombia's conflict saw Mr. Uribe's remarks today as an effort to assuage concerns in the United States and Europe about his hard-line reputation by casting himself as a moderate willing to talk peace.
The analysts noted that the rebels were virtually sure to turn down any chance to negotiate under Mr. Uribe's demands: that they first declare a cease-fire and end hostile actions like kidnappings.
The rebels would be further alienated by Mr. Uribe's proposal to include the paramilitaries in talks.
"This to defuse his critics who say, based on his campaign, that he is a warrior, not a peacemaker," said Larry Birns, director of the Council on Hemispheric Affairs, a Washington policy research group. "He has to communicate to the world that he is not Dr. Strangelove, that he's not going to blow up the country in the process of exterminating the guerrillas."
Mr. Birns, however, said there was little reason to believe that Mr. Uribe -- who cast himself as the candidate of the "hard hand" during the campaign -- would be committed to ensuring that negotiations reopened.
"He has to go through a pro-forma performance," Mr. Birns said, "so he will be able to say, 'I've tried the negotiating card and it was not picked up."' 
To be sure, the president-elect's main plank -- to double the size of both the army's combat force and the National Police and create a million-member civilian force of informers -- is seen by human rights groups as a dangerous plan that could lead to a wider war and increased rights abuses. 
Mr. Uribe, however, says that Colombia is locked in a war against terrorism and should have the support of the international community. "Any country in a democratic world needs to have solidarity with the democratic society of Colombia, which is suffering this violence that is just terrorism," Mr. Uribe said in halting English.
During his campaign, Mr. Uribe was highly critical of President Pastrana's peace talks with rebels, which were held in the midst of a spiraling conflict and ultimately ended in failure. Mr. Pastrana did not ask for United Nations mediation during the talks, instead using peace negotiators from the organization as advisers to the two parties.
In the day since Mr. Uribe's election victory, congratulations have flowed in from the American ambassador, Anne Patterson, and other foreign officials. For many of them, Mr. Uribe's victory, by a margin that avoided a runoff for the first time in a decade, demonstrated unequivocal support for his proposals.
"The desire of the majority of the Colombian people has been to support the candidacy of Mr. Uribe," said Jose Salafranca, a Spaniard who led a mission of election observers from the European Community. "After yesterday's election, it is evident that he has enormous democratic legitimacy." For Mr. Uribe, remaining legitimate in the eyes of the world is crucial if his administration is to improve a slow-growing economy and receive the loans necessary to embark on various government programs.
Mr. Uribe, 49, who has studied at Harvard and Oxford, said he was counting on continued support from the United States to eradicate illegal drug crops and to deal with the rebels. The United States already helps Colombia on the drug war, but the Bush administration is trying to expand aid for counterguerrilla operations.
"We need the help of the United States in order to preserve our democracy," Mr. Uribe said. "And to preserve our democracy, we can no longer suffer from terrorism." 
The president-elect also stressed the need to work closely with Colombia's neighbors on security issues.
Drug trafficking and the conflict often spill over Colombia's borders, particularly into Venezuela and Ecuador, with guerrillas and drug traffickers crossing frontiers.
"If this is not resolved, this conflict has the dangerous potential of destabilizing Latin America," he said.

HEADLINE: Layoffs at Bayer Plant Are Seen as Blow to West Haven Economy 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WEST HAVEN, Conn., May 27 

 BODY:
Residents and business leaders are looking warily to the future after last week's announcement that the city's largest employer, the international drug maker Bayer, was laying off 150 of its 2,300 local employees immediately and would eliminate 500 jobs by the end of next year.
 The layoffs announced last Wednesday are among 1,200 the company will make from its worldwide pharmaceutical business in the wake of last year's withdrawal of the drug Baycol from the market. Baycol was packaged at West Haven's Morgan Lane plant, which straddles the city's line with suburban Orange. 
 Most of the people who are losing their jobs are West Haven residents, and West Haven businesses that have been Bayer suppliers are also facing serious losses. It is a severe blow to a small, struggling industrial city of 52,000 people trying to come back from years of economic decline. 
"It's obviously devastating for the city and the region," Mayor Richard Borer Jr. of West Haven said. "Having your largest employer reduce one quarter of the work force has sent shock waves through the greater New Haven area."
Mr. Borer is worried about more than the layoffs and Bayer's international reorganization, which will mean elimination of manufacturing and packaging at the West Haven plant. For years it has been the company's North American pharmaceutical headquarters and the city's top employer and taxpayer.
Despite assurances by Bayer that other operations at the West Haven site are secure, Mr. Borer and other economic and community leaders need only look to the past to be worried. They said the situation was reminiscent of a move by another top taxpayer and employer that was a mainstay in West Haven for more than half a century: the former Armstrong Rubber and Tire Company, which made similar promises more than 30 years ago, when it moved its manufacturing operations out of West Haven in the early 1970's. The final vestiges of the company, a small storage center, closed down during Mr. Borer's first term in office in the early 1990's.
"This is all part of the new fiscal realities we are now facing in corporate America today," he said. "There was a time when people worked for 25 or 30 years in one place and retired. Now, the challenge we have is to help train these people for new positions."
By the end of 2003, manufacturing and packaging of drugs will cease at Bayer's West Haven plant, with those operations moving to plants in Kansas and Germany, said Meredith Fischer, a vice president of communications for Bayer. But she said Bayer remained committed to keeping a significant presence in West Haven, structured mostly around research and development as well as sales and marketing operations. 
"We're doing innovative work in the area of oncology and with other areas of research, and West Haven will continue to be an important part of that," Ms. Fischer said. "Bayer has no intention of leaving West Haven."
Still, city and regional economic leaders said they were taking nothing for granted.
Ferdinand Messore, executive director of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said, "One of the keys to the city's economic revival could be its richest resource: our seven miles of shorefront and two miles of public beaches," which represent a large slice of the state's Long Island Sound shoreline.
Promoting tourism with the vast public beaches, trying to develop a 100-acre technology campus off Route 34 and attempting to draw large retail operations to West Haven are among the ways the city can diversify its economic base, he said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Europeans Press Fight in W.T.O. Against American Tariffs on Steel

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, May 27 

 BODY:
Pressing ahead with efforts to overturn the Bush administration's protective tariffs on steel imports, the European Union has taken a significant step in the long process of challenging the tariffs in the World Trade Organization's dispute resolution system. 
 The 15 European Union nations are the first of the W.T.O.'s 144 members to have their tariff complaints formally considered by the organization, but they are not expected to be the last. Japan and South Korea have said that they will join in the complaints if the tariffs are not withdrawn, and Brazil, China, New Zealand, Switzerland and Norway have taken preliminary steps to follow suit. 
 All these nations say that the tariffs, introduced by the Bush administration in March to help the depressed American steel industry, flout global trade rules. American officials defend the measures, which impose duties up to 30 percent on certain categories of steel imports, as permissible under a "safeguard" exception built into the rules when a harmful flood of imports occurs. 
The European Union has announced its own safeguard measures to stave off cheap steel diverted from the United States market by the American tariffs. And it has threatened to retaliate against selected American exports under a separate, faster World Trade Organization procedure covering safeguard measures.
But a bigger fight over the legality of the American steel tariffs is expected to play out more slowly in the W.T.O.'s dispute resolution system. The Europeans started the process earlier in the month by demanding the establishment of a panel of experts to examine the tariffs. The United States refused to agree, but under the organization's rules it has no veto, only the power to delay the panel's creation for a short time. The panel is expected to be set up next Monday.
The European trade negotiator, Carlo Trojan, told the W.T.O. there was no evidence that steel imports had been increasing in the United States before the Bush administration acted, a requirement under the safeguard rules.
In a sign of how contentious the tariff issue has become, Mr. Trojan accused the United States of trying to make other countries pay for its failure to restructure its steel industry. Speaking in a closed-door session, he said similar protective measures imposed by Washington had been overturned six times before, and the new tariffs would not pass muster either.
The Bush administration insists that its action complied with global trade agreements, and says it will eventually prevail at the trade organization.
The Europeans have claimed $2.2 billion in compensation to offset the injury they say their steel industries have suffered from the American tariffs, and have filed plans with the W.T.O. to retaliate. Last Tuesday, they released a list of products potentially subject to about $300 million in punitive tariffs, including cigarettes produced in American states that could be pivotal in November's Congressional elections. The punitive tariffs are to take effect on June 18, but Washington has asked for a delay; trade diplomats say the United States may want more time to negotiate a settlement involving compensation. 
In Washington, a spokesman for the American trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, criticized the Europeans for taking unilateral action against steel imports destined for the United States.
"When others threaten unilateral actions, they undermine the rule of law in W.T.O., and risk unraveling the multilateral trading system," the spokesman, Richard Mills, said. "We continue to urge others not to take these unilateral actions, and we hope that reason will prevail."
China followed the European Union on Friday by imposing its own measures to exclude steel diverted from the United States by the new tariffs. The action brings China into its first trade dispute since entering the W.T.O. in November.

HEADLINE: Handling Sinners and Victims of Domestic Hell; 
Sad Hallways and Broken Lives in an Overburdened Family Court System

BYLINE:  By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

 BODY:
Family Court is perhaps the saddest place in New York.
 It is where society gathers the child abusers, juvenile delinquents, deadbeat dads, bickering parents, wife beaters and the Cains and Abels. 
 There have been some significant changes in the system over the past five years. Proceedings have been made open to the public. Judges now specialize in specific family problems. Referees deal with custody and visitation matters, and hearing examiners deal strictly with paternity and financial support cases. Night courts opened in Brooklyn and the Bronx a few years ago and there are now satellite court offices in Harlem, Red Hook and Long Island City. A new Queens courthouse will open in the fall. 
But despite this, the hallways of Family Court grow more crowded every year as people turn to the system to solve their problems and the government steps in to prevent cruelties. Consider: there were 190,430 new cases filed in Family Court in 1990; 198,989 in 1995 and 240,709 in 2000. Officials don't expect the numbers to drop.
Most every type of family feud is dealt with at Family Court except, paradoxically, the dissolution of the family itself. (Divorces are handled in State Supreme Court.)
The crowds at the city's family courts are thick, the attitudes are often bad and some stories fall over the cliff of the cockamamie. Recently, one parent told a judge in Manhattan that she slipped in a moment of anger and her hands accidentally wrapped around her daughter's windpipe. The judge could only roll her eyes.
"This is not family court, it's a disaster court," said Paul Cooper, a lawyer who is representing a mother at Queens Family Court who is accused of starving her infant with a strict vegetarian diet. "You pull the roof off of this building and you're looking into the bedroom of America. The family is crumbling, the bedroom's on fire and we're asking the judges to be the grandparents here. It gets worse every year."
To say that the system is overburdened is to put it mildly, lawyers, judges and unhappy citizens agree. About two million New Yorkers walked through the metal detectors of Family Court last year as defendants, character witnesses and the like. Sometimes the visit is a good occasion. Three thousand adoptions are consummated here each year. But most of the 750,000 appearances in family court last year meant bad news for someone. 
Some Legal Aid lawyers, who among other things represent children against their abusive parents, handle as many as 110 cases at any one time.
"In some cases we as a society are failing our kids," said Kim McLauren, the attorney in charge of the Queens Legal Aid Society, who stopped to speak for a moment the other day, balancing an armload of manila files. "The system is overtaxed. We should be investing in children, not cutting back programs."
Money cannot be the prime motivator for this job: a first-year Legal Aid lawyer is paid about $43,000 a year and gets a raise to $53,257 after five years. Private lawyers paid by the state to represent battered and indigent women have not gotten a raise in 16 years. On most cases they earn $25 an hour out of court and $40 in front of a judge, rates among the lowest in the nation. Children's advocates criticize the system while applauding its judges, court officers and lawyers, describing their work as herculean.
"The courts are understaffed, caseloads are really high, the buildings are inadequate for the amount of people going through there," said Gail B. Nayowith, executive director of Citizens' Committee for Children of New York, an independent advocacy group. "The backlog for these cases are weeks and months. The workloads are incredible considering that we are making life and death decisions for kids."
The system was devised before the days of crack and the divorce epidemic. Add to that a more litigious society, a greater willingness to report abuse and no compunction about airing arguments in the post-Jerry-Springer world, and you have the modern Family Court.
"People use family court to play out their animosities, and it clogs it up," said Joseph M. Lauria, administrative judge of New York City Family Court. "You get to know some of these families. The good part is we can help with long-term resolutions of family problems."
Family Court is not a tribunal of instant gratification. While you are guaranteed that you will see the judge the day you are called to court, the chances are better than good that you will see the judge again for many more days over the span of many more years.
In civil matters, the courts can attract a surly, frivolous element, since there are no filing fees and the government not only obliges but instructs the do-it-yourself lawyers who gum up the system.
These kitchen-table counselors seem to think the definition of justice is "give me what I want" and the process of discovery is something like "Yo, the guy in the hallway don't have to pay child support because he don't have a Social Security number, so why should I have to sign over my unemployment check?"
The current family courthouse in Queens is a former public library retrofitted in the early 70's. It is an old rundown building with municipal smells and filthy windows and rows of plastic chairs on each floor. The walls are papered in admonitions: no smoking, no caustic chemicals, no entry, no, no, no. 
The referees hear cases in offices no bigger than a broom closet. People -- former confidants and lovers -- bicker, scream, throw fists. The waiting rooms are snake pits of accusation and recrimination. A woman got stuck between floors in the elevator and when service resumed, her ex-husband was waiting on the third floor to laugh at her.
Take the case of Leon v. Gallo, a couple who got along famously until their daughter was 4. Then, according to court papers filed by Anthony Gallo, things fell apart between him and Ana Tapia-Leon, the mother of his daughter, Gabrielle, and the woman he now refers to as his former paramour.
"For reasons known only to the respondent," his affidavit for visitation rights said about Ms. Tapia-Leon, "and over what appeared to be a very short time, her feelings for me dramatically changed." While the root of their problem lies in this phrase somewhere, neither could explain where the anger began. They have been in court a dozen times over three years bickering about custody.
As if proof was needed of his love for his child, Mr. Gallo, 38, recently showed a tattoo of "Gabrielle" on his chest. In support of his character, he dressed in new shoes and a tie, and carried letters of reference from his barber and a local deli clerk.
He wept. "I miss my daughter and that monster won't let me see her."
On the other end of the grubby waiting room, Ms. Tapia-Leon sat alone with her tears. She maintains that Mr. Gallo abused their daughter, although court-mandated investigations have revealed no evidence to its truth.
Ms. Tapia Leon carried many papers, among them a drawing by Gabrielle that read "no." 
"You see, my daughter doesn't want to see that man," she said, and to that effect she vowed to fight Mr. Gallo to her dying day.
"I'm an educated woman," she said. "I went to university and I keep an immaculate home. I thought these kind of things happened to drug addicts and alcoholics. I never thought I'd be in a place like this, and I blame him for it."
The former lovers eventually got to see a judge near the end of the afternoon. The outcome? Come back in two weeks. Just in time for Father's Day.

HEADLINE: Restaurants On Other Rows Are Suffering 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
A little more than three years ago, Mark Henegan opened a restaurant in a gentrifying Brooklyn neighborhood, an area of black middle-class workers who had long been east of the East River and white professionals who had just begun migrating from the other side.
 It was a gamble for Mr. Henegan, a successful chef at the South African Consulate and at Il Buco, the Greenwich Village Mediterranean bistro for the gold-card crowd. Several dozen permits and $150,000 later, Mr. Henegan, now 34, opened a South African restaurant, Madiba, which takes its name from the clan of Nelson Mandela, and is on what was a struggling stretch of DeKalb Avenue in Fort Greene. 
 The bet more than paid off, and as DeKalb Avenue challenged Smith Street in Boerum Hill and Carroll Gardens as the Restaurant Row of Brooklyn, Mr. Henegan's fortunes seemed on the rise. 
It should come as no surprise that the Sept. 11 terrorist attack changed all that. The attack did not cause Mr. Henegan to close his doors or cause customers to stop coming by. Diners still come, but they spend less. Banks, nervous about restaurants that went under after the attack, will not increase his credit a penny. Unlike his competitors in Lower Manhattan who received financial assistance after the attack, the only thing Mr. Henegan says he has ever received from the government is a couple of fines for sidewalk-cafe-permit violations.
"We have struggled a lot," he said. "People are worried about the economy falling, and people are worried about the unknown. People are worried about keeping money on the side, just in case."
In the city's restaurant industry, places outside Manhattan are among those suffering the most from the recession and from Sept. 11. This is particularly true in neighborhoods like Fort Greene that were undergoing a renaissance before the economic boom ended.
The problems are not limited to Fort Greene. Along Arthur Avenue in the Bronx, restaurateurs report similar problems. The same complaints can be heard in Harlem, one of the neighborhoods other than Lower Manhattan hurt the most by the sharp drop in tourism dollars. And the fish-and-chips joints of Long Island City, Queens, are not immune.
Tim Zagat, chairman of Zagat Survey, the restaurant guide, and former chairman of the city's convention and visitors bureau, NYC & Company, said that while leading suburban restaurants had record sales in the weeks after Sept. 11 as commuters ate close to home, those in the city outside Manhattan's core suffered a twofold loss.
Unlike the suburban restaurants, those in the city's outlying neighborhoods relied a great deal on the tourist trade, and more people in those areas were also being laid off and thus eating out less, or at least eating out more cheaply, than in the rest of the city.
"Part of the problem," Mr. Zagat explained, "is that there were substantial layoffs in restaurants, hotels and retailing, and I think a lot of those people live in places like Harlem and Fort Greene."
Hotels, restaurants and many other businesses in the city's $25 billion tourism industry were already in a slump before the attack, because of the softening economy. After Sept. 11, at least 30 restaurants in the city closed and 40 more in Lower Manhattan had to shut down temporarily.
By October, industry officials said, more than 15,000 restaurant workers in the city had been laid off, 5,000 of them outside Manhattan south of 96th Street.
In the months that followed, many New Yorkers seemed to heed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's call to go out and spend. And state and federal agencies offered economic assistance packages to the small businesses near ground zero that suffered the most.
But the problem for people like Mr. Henegan was that restaurants like Madiba, four miles from ground zero, were not eligible for assistance, and the patriotic dollars were being spent mostly in Midtown and in Lower Manhattan.
In neighborhoods outside Manhattan south of 96th Street, where layoffs of restaurant workers grew to an estimated 7,500 by January, restaurants suffered less than those in Lower Manhattan, but were left to fend for themselves, according to the hotel and restaurant union.
Looking back, Mr. Henegan said he considered his restaurant's opening in 1999 a monumental challenge. "You need a good architect, a good lawyer, someone to expedite the permits," he pointed out. "You need lots of money, real estate savvy, good suppliers, a crystal ball and a good idea. Restaurants, after all, are the small businesses with the highest rates of failure."
Before the attack, the restaurateurs along DeKalb Avenue were talking about forming a neighborhood merchants' association. Madiba and other restaurants in the neighborhood, like the Buttercup Lounge and Chez Oscar down the block, have since done that, creating the DeKalb Avenue Merchants Association. But instead of taking up the task of adding lights to a local basketball court or planning a summer food festival in Fort Greene Park or hanging holiday lights, the group is focused on keeping the avenue's once-vibrant small businesses alive. 
"Our goal is to keep the cultural and culinary renaissance in this neighborhood -- one that took hard work -- alive," said Jean-Baptiste Caillet, a former manager at Balthazar who is co-owner of A Table, a French bistro on Lafayette Avenue, a few blocks from Madiba.
Those efforts have not been enough to offset the damage from the downturn. Several restaurants decided to jettison their sidewalk cafes because city fees and permits for them cost $3,000 a year. Some decided not to contribute food to school and other neighborhood events. Others say they are simply bouncing many more checks and hiring fewer employees lately.
The rub for Mr. Henegan, who came to New York from South Africa in 1987 with the dream of starting his own restaurant, is that "even though more people have moved into the neighborhood, some trying to get away from Lower Manhattan, it has become much harder for us because people are spending less."
As Zulu dancers performed in Madiba one recent night, Mr. Henegan tried to put a bright note on the restaurants' troubles. "It has really made us take care of our business more, not take things for granted, and understand how blessed we are," he said. "It's easy to give up sometimes, but sometimes you have to look and see what all you have, even if you are in debt."
Raising a jug of passion fruit and rum, he added, "It's all good, man."

HEADLINE: State Senator, Elected in '65, Won't Return 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 27 

 BODY:
Senator Ronald B. Stafford, the second-longest-serving member of the State Senate and the chairman of the powerful Finance Committee, announced today he would not seek re-election in the fall, ending an almost four-decade-long career for the Adirondack Republican.
 The senator's decision is not likely to alter the balance of power in the upper house, because Republican voters are in the majority in his sparsely populated district in the northeastern part of the state. But his departure will leave the Senate without one of its staunchest and most candid conservatives. 
 Two Republican members of the Assembly, Elizabeth O'C. Little of Queensbury, and Chris Ortloff of Plattsburgh, have already expressed an interest in running for Mr. Stafford's seat, Republican party officials said.
Senator Stafford, 66, survived a bout with cancer 15 years ago, but he said today that his health was not a factor in his decision to step down. He said he wanted to retire to spend more time with his family and pursue his law practice, teaching and business interests. "I'm not going to really retire but it's time to shift gears," he said in an interview. "I'm not tired of it. I think it's really more realizing you have done it for 37 years and it's time to move on and do something else."
The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, praised Senator Stafford as a "guardian up there in the Adirondacks," and a pragmatic legislator who had made sure his district received its share of state aid. He was instrumental in bringing the Olympics to Lake Placid in 1980 and in securing millions of dollars in state aid for Plattsburgh's economy after a nearby Air Force base was closed in 1995. He was also the sponsor in the Senate of the state Tuition Assistance Program, which provides scholarships to college students.
"I think his legacy will be that he has really just looked after his constituency in every respect," Senator Bruno said. "Nothing happened in the Adirondacks without his input and his guidance."
The senator often butted heads with environmentalists, as he pushed for policies within Adirondack Park that, in his view, balanced environmental concerns with the economic needs of residents.
But he was also a friend of the environment in other respects. In the 1980's, he spearheaded a move in the Senate to pass changes to tort law allowing people poisoned by pollution more time to file suit, a bill the Senate leadership opposed. He also was pivotal in passage of an important bond act to pay for toxic-waste cleanup and other environmental programs in 1996 even though it was unpopular with his constituency.
Mr. Stafford was first elected to the Senate in 1965 and has headed the Finance Committee since 1993.
Senator Bruno said a decision on who would become the Finance Committee chairman would probably be made after November's election.

HEADLINE: Confidence In Germany Helps Stocks In Europe 

BYLINE:  By Agence France-Presse 

 BODY:
European share prices edged higher yesterday after a surprise jump in the key German Ifo confidence index indicated a strengthening recovery in Europe's largest economy.
 The absence of direction from the United States markets, closed for a federal holiday, left European markets to focus on themselves, where volumes were slim, dealers said. 
 The Frankfurt DAX 30 index added 1.27 percent to reach 4,961.54 points, while the Paris CAC 40 index climbed 0.54 percent, to 4,360.71 points. 
In London, the FTSE 100 index ended 0.63 percent lower at 5,136.3 points.
The euro briefly nudged up to 92.16 United States cents after Germany's Ifo research institute said that its business climate index for western Germany had risen to 91.5 points in May from 90.5 the previous month, as opposed to an expected rise to 90.8. The euro fell back to 92.07 cents in late London trading.
Dealers said that while the survey had helped European markets shrug off the negative influence from the United States, where stocks closed disappointingly lower on Friday, enthusiasm was limited.
The British mobile phone giant Vodafone was off six pence at 107 -- a 5 percent fall -- ahead of today's full-year results.
In Frankfurt, Deutsche Telekom shares jumped 4.18 percent, to 12.45 euros, after the German government said it would not sell any more of its stake in the financially troubled group until market conditions had improved. Dealers said the stock was benefiting from a technical rebound and reports of job cuts.
A bomb threat at the Frankfurt exchange, which led to the evacuation of all floor traders for about an hour in the afternoon, only initially, and slightly, upset share prices, according to dealers.
In Paris, Vivendi Universal closed up 1.64 percent, at 34.04 euros, as momentum continued to gather ahead of the company's board meeting tomorrow, when investors expect the company to announce plans to dispose of part of its 63 percent holding in Vivendi Environnement.
Asian stock markets were mostly lower yesterday in lackluster trading. Singapore, Kuala Lumpur and Bangkok were closed, but of the markets that remained open only Tokyo, Taipei and Jakarta were in positive territory.
Japanese share prices ended only fractionally higher, finishing just below the symbolic 12,000-point level where they had been drifting all day, led by domestic stocks and technology issues, brokers said.
The Nikkei 225-stock average of the Tokyo Stock Exchange closed up 0.07 point at 11,976.35, marking a nine-month high. 
In Hong Kong, share prices fell 0.5 percent after losses on Wall Street late last week. The Hang Seng index lost 62.05 points, to close at 11,564.73, with dealers saying that many investors chose to sit the session out as sentiment was cautious.
Marty Chan, a Polaris Securities analyst, said the market had been fairly directionless throughout the day, with a lack of corporate news to push it in one direction or the other.
South Korean share prices fell 1.6 percent, as concerns developed that the won's sharp gains against the dollar would have a negative impact on exports. The composite index closed down 14 points, at 840.57.
Taiwan share prices closed 0.4 percent higher as bargain hunting and apparent support from government funds offset the negative impact of Saturday's jetliner crash on China Airlines and insurance stocks. The weighted index closed up 23.5 points, at 5,729.90, off a low of 5,623.88 and a high of 5,733.97.

HEADLINE: A Busy Legislator Who Hopes to Challenge Torricelli 

BYLINE:  By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: MOORESTOWN, N.J. 

 BODY:
State Senator Diane Allen's mother had warned her that a college degree in philosophy was not exactly a ticket to full employment, and she turned out to be right, more or less. 
 The best Ms. Allen could do when she graduated from Bucknell University in Lewisburg, Pa., was a job reading public-service announcements over WJJZ in Mount Holly, a 500-watt farm station here in South Jersey that only broadcast during the daytime. 
 Yet her inauspicious start in broadcasting led to a career in television broadcast news that made Ms. Allen something of a household name in South Jersey. 
That visibility paved the way for her to enter state politics and put her on a path that Ms. Allen hopes will now lead to a victory over two other Republicans in the June 4 primary, and the chance to face the Democratic incumbent, Robert G. Torricelli, in the election for the United States Senate.
The other candidates in the Republican primary are State Senator John Matheussen and Douglas Forrester, a wealthy businessman and the former mayor of West Windsor.
Until 1994, Ms. Allen, 54, was a news anchor on WCAU-TV, the NBC outlet in Philadelphia. That is where she developed her interest in public affairs, she says, and her desire to escape the constraints of journalistic impartiality.
"I could help by telling you about problems that you had to watch out for, but I couldn't solve those problems," Ms. Allen said in addressing the Moorestown Republican Club's annual lunch at the Riverton Country Club. 
"But when I was able to move on to the political world, I found the answer: that's where you solve the problems, that's where the public service really makes a difference."
Winning election to the Assembly once and the Senate twice, Ms. Allen became a tireless drafter of legislation. 
She has introduced 196 pieces of legislation in the current legislative session alone, vastly more than the 30 or 40 bills that seem to be the norm for a senator. 
In her rush of bills for such diverse aims as lowering electrical rates for volunteer fire companies, strengthening the prosecution of firearms crimes, exempting recreational safety helmets from the sales tax and prohibiting deceptive advertising practices, Ms. Allen appears to embrace an activist role for government that is in keeping with her reputation as a liberal on social issues.
Polls have indicated that her relatively liberal positions could help her in the general election. The polls taken so far show her running the strongest of the three Republican candidates against Mr. Torricelli, perhaps because New Jersey's broadly moderate electorate has tended to favor activist, problem-oriented candidates. 
In a Fairleigh Dickinson University poll released May 22, she ran 15 percentage points behind Mr. Torricelli in a hypothetical matchup, as 45 percent of registered voters favored Mr. Torricelli and 30 percent chose Ms. Allen. In contrast, Mr. Matheussen and Mr. Forrester each ran 20 points behind Mr. Torricelli.
The poll did not match the Republican primary contenders against each other, but other polls have shown Mr. Forrester leading Ms. Allen among Republicans in a hypothetical matchup.
New Jersey Republican primaries tend to be dominated by members of the party's conservative wing, and in this race, Ms. Allen has de-emphasized her support for abortion rights and her opposition, as a Quaker, to the death penalty. 
Instead, she talks about her sponsorship of the state's no-early-release law requiring violent criminals to serve 80 percent of their sentence before becoming eligible for parole, and about two real estate tax rebate initiatives, the New Jersey Saver program and the Homestead Rebate program. 
In presenting her conservative side, Ms. Allen has had to battle the perception among some of her colleagues that her chief interests are in traditional women's issues like health care, child safety and education.
"I'm a fiscal conservative," she told the Moorestown Republicans. "I voted to cut taxes more than 40 times in the State Legislature, and I have never voted for a tax increase. We don't need to, because we can live within our means."
In an interview after that speech, she said: "I really have a record of accomplishment, and they can look at it and they will see that I brought more money into my district than anyone else brought into their district for economic revitalization. I've done more along those lines than anybody, which is why it just tickles me when I hear, 'Oh yeah, she's women's issues.' "
Ms. Allen was born in Newark and grew up in Burlington County, where her father was an engineer and her mother a Republican town committeewoman. 
She said that she always considered herself a Republican, and that when her career in television ended, after winning Emmys and a Peabody award, she was quickly recruited to run in the Seventh District, covering parts of Burlington and Camden Counties, where Democrats have long dominated.
With her TV-driven name-recognition and determined campaign style, Ms. Allen defeated a Democratic incumbent in the Assembly and two years later, in 1997, the district's Democratic senator. She won re-election last year by a margin of 10 percentage points.
Without a presidential or gubernatorial race on the ballot, leaders of both parties expect the June 4 primary turnout to be well below the 348,000 votes cast in last year's primary, perhaps as low as 200,000. With her base in South Jersey, her strategists believe she can win a three-way split, and she has so far reported having just under $300,000 in her campaign fund, though $95,000 of it is her own money. 
It is a fair-sized amount for a low-turnout campaign without the heavy television expenses of a general campaign, but Ms. Allen admitted being worried about Mr. Forrester, who reports putting $3.1 million of his own money into the race. In a comment that referred to her fund-raising but that could also speak to the general state of her campaign, Ms. Allen said, "If I didn't have somebody blanketing the state with millions of dollars, I'd be doing really well.

HEADLINE: New York Philanthropy Embraces a Charismatic French Executive 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
In France, Jean-Marie Messier, the embattled chief executive of Vivendi Universal, is under attack over many of his management decisions and accusations that he is abandoning his French cultural roots for life as an America-centric media mogul. 
 But in New York City, where he and his family moved from Paris eight months ago, the handsome, charismatic Mr. Messier, 45, has received a much warmer reception in the glittering world of cultural philanthropy, where the breadth of his growing involvement is rare, even for the most civic-minded corporate titan. 
 Mr. Messier has been welcomed onto the board of the Whitney Museum of American Art and has become a vice chairman of the Museum of Television and Radio's new media center. He is being considered for the board of the Metropolitan Opera. His wife, Antoinette Messier, recently joined the board of the New York Philharmonic. 
Over the next few months he will be honored at large fund-raising dinners by the New York Public Library and the Appeal of Conscience Foundation, an interfaith group that promotes tolerance. This Thursday, the Messiers are also vice chairman and vice chairwoman of the annual dinner of the Robin Hood Foundation. The group supports antipoverty programs in the city. And after receiving a humanitarian award from the Simon Wiesenthal Foundation and Museum of Tolerance in Los Angeles earlier this month, Mr. Messier committed himself to helping build a Tolerance Center on 42nd Street.
With each commitment comes the understanding that the Messiers will make significant corporate donations, and attached to each award is the assumption that the Messier name and involvement will help raise additional funds.
Mr. Messier's smooth entree into New York is one of the clearest examples of how an outsider with financial resources, status and connections can penetrate the city's inner circle of culture and philanthropy, even as his corporate leadership comes under severe attack. 
With economic uncertainty affecting charitable giving, a potential big donor like Mr. Messier with a major company bankrolling him is a prime target for nonprofit institutions. And for Mr. Messier, getting on boards and receiving awards offers a way to anchor himself in New York and gain access to the city's channels of power.
David Resnicow, president of Resnicow Schroeder, a consultant that matches museums and corporate sponsors, said Mr. Messier's charitable involvement was crucial to a French company trying to establish itself as a global company. "They need to Americanize the company," he said. "It's important to have a presence in New York and Los Angeles. What better way to integrate yourself into the political, social, business and cultural leadership than by getting involved in museums and other cultural institutions?"
Mr. Messier has transformed his former utility company into the world's second-largest media giant -- trailing AOL Time Warner -- largely by buying Seagram and its Universal media operations in 2000 for $34 billion and adding on several other purchases. 
But the transformation has often been rocky, and over the last few months the company's stock has plummeted and its credit rating has dropped. Some shareholders are campaigning for Mr. Messier's resignation.
On the cultural front, despite his financial support of institutions like the Pompidou Center and leading roles with the Orchestra of Paris and the Aix-en-Provence Festival, Mr. Messier's firing of Pierre Lescure last month as chief executive of Vivendi's pay television unit, Canal Plus, set off protests. Canal Plus is a major financier of French films, and the dismissal was seen by many in France as one of several indications of a tilt by Mr. Messier away from supporting French culture.
In New York he has set up his office in the Seagram Building, and his family (he and his wife have five children) has moved into a $17.5-million Park Avenue apartment paid for by Vivendi.
Through a spokeswoman Mr. Messier declined to comment. In a statement the company said, "Vivendi Universal's philanthropic activities reflect the commitment of the company to support social missions and improve the welfare of the communities in which we live and work."
At Vivendi, Patsy Glazer, the vice president for public affairs, who handles the company's North American philanthropy and was formerly Seagram's public relations director, refused to comment.
Mr. Messier's professional difficulties in Paris seem remote on the New York cultural scene, where leaders of several organizations said they welcomed his involvement and did not focus on his current battles. He has inherited relationships that Seagram and Universal nurtured for years with various charities, and much to the liking of culturati on this side of the Atlantic he genuinely seems to like American culture.
"I'd like to think that his professed enthusiasm for things American is directly tied to his joining our board at the Museum of American Art," said Maxwell L. Anderson, director of the Whitney.
What in effect was Mr. Messier's coming-out party here took place at the World Economic Forum at the Waldorf-Astoria last January when Vivendi was the host at a concert that featured Bono and Peter Gabriel and became the hottest ticket in town.
But the seeds of his involvement in New York were planted long before. 
At a May 2000 dinner party in New York City given by Anne Cox Chambers, who serves on the Whitney's national committee -- a by-nomination-only group of patrons from across the country -- Mr. Messier met Mr. Anderson. "I had the chance to talk to him over cocktails about the Whitney," Mr. Anderson recalled. "He has an appetite for contemporary photography and modern painting." 
The two saw each other again at last July's opening of the Whitney's show, sponsored by Vivendi, on Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, who designed the Seagram Building with Philip Johnson.
Leonard A. Lauder, the cosmetics magnate, who is chairman of the Whitney, and Mr. Messier then had lunch at the Four Seasons after being introduced by Edgar Bronfman Jr., who was chairman of Seagram and its Universal media unit before they were sold to Vivendi.
Mr. Messier joined the Whitney board last February.
The unspoken expectation is that Whitney board members will contribute or raise at least $100,000 a year. Some may contribute more -- by underwriting an exhibition, donating works of art or making capital gifts, for example -- or less, depending on their means. 
Already, Mr. Messier has committed his company to a six-figure sponsorship of the museum's fall gala on Oct. 21, Mr. Anderson said, at which the Whitney hopes to raise between $1 million and $1.5 million. "He jumped in feet first," Mr. Anderson said.
At the Philharmonic Zarin Mehta, the executive director, said that his old friend Marie-Josee Kravis, wife of the financier Henry Kravis, approached Mr. Messier about joining the Philharmonic board after learning that they were coming to New York. Mr. Messier referred her to his wife, a physics teacher, and she joined the board last December. "She's been very involved," Mr. Mehta said. "She comes to all the meetings." Board members are expected to donate upward of $50,000 a year, one Lincoln Center official said.
Robert M. Batscha, president of the Museum of Television and Radio, met Mr. Messier in 1999 at an annual meeting of the museum's International Museum Council in Paris. There, the two discussed the museum's hopes of creating a new media center, now being formed, as a forum for international business leaders in media and technology. 
"He was challenged and stimulated by the idea," Mr. Batscha said. Mr. Messier is now a vice chairman of the new media center's board of governors. 
At the Public Library, Elizabeth Rohatyn, a former chairwoman, suggested Mr. Messier as an award recipient, having known him through her husband, Felix Rohatyn, who served as ambassador to France during the Clinton Administration and had worked with Mr. Messier at the investment bank Lazard.
"When new top people come to New York, everybody wants them," she said. 
After the family moved to the city, she took Ms. Messier on a tour of two of the most impressive library facilities, the Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center and the Science, Business and Industry Library on 34th Street. "She was very interested in both," Ms. Rohatyn said.
The award dinner for Mr. Messier will take place on June 10.
Samuel C. Butler, chairman of the New York Public Library, said the honoree and co-chairmen are each expected to give between $50,000 to $100,000. Companies then provide the names of their friends, clients and customers to invite. "We twist their arms" to get them to buy tables, Mr. Butler said, at a price of $10,000 to $50,000.
Will Mr. Messier's award lead to a board position? "That has not been discussed," Mr. Butler said. "That's down the road."
Joseph Volpe, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, said there had been preliminary discussions about Mr. Messier joining the Met board. Mr. Volpe said he met Mr. Messier in Italy at a dinner after Luciano Pavarotti's 40th anniversary performance at the Modena opera house last spring. "He said he was coming to New York," Mr. Volpe said. "He's been busy. My hope is someday he'll become involved." (The Met's board members contribute on average about $250,000 a year.) 
After having lunch at Daniel restaurant with Mr. Messier two days after Sept. 11, Rabbi Arthur Schneier, president of the Appeal of Conscience Foundation, invited him to receive his organization's annual award, to be given this year on Oct 1. 
"What impressed me was he is a man of faith," Mr. Schneier said (though Mr. Messier told Vanity Fair recently that he goes to Mass just a few times a year). 
People who have been approached by the foundation as potential honorees said they were asked to guarantee $300,000 to $500,000 worth of tables. But Mr. Schneier said of honorees, "You cannot buy this award."
"Had he not shown a commitment to the objectives the Appeal of Conscience stands for he would not have been considered," Mr. Schneier continued. 
Earlier this month, Mr. Messier received the annual humanitarian award from the Simon Wiesenthal Center and Museum of Tolerance in Los Angeles. Rabbi Marvin Hier, the center's founder and dean, said Mr. Messier has committed himself to help establish a New York Tolerance Center, to open in January on East 42nd Street in the old Daily News building. 
And at the award dinner Mr. Messier announced that he would also try to build a European Museum of Mutual Respect in Paris, modeled largely on the Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles.
Mr. Hier said there was no obligation that an honoree participate financially, but he acknowledged that, of course, they have an interest in filling tables. "Honorees are smart people," Mr. Hier said. "They want the dinner to be successful."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
First Atlantic to Sell Berry Plastics Holding
First Atlantic Capital, a New York leveraged-buyout firm, is planning to announce that it has sold its biggest holding, Berry Plastics, for $837.5 million to the private equity arm of Goldman, Sachs.
 For First Atlantic Capital and its founder, a former McKinsey & Company partner, Roberto Buaron, the sale of Berry Plastics is the end of a decade of effort to turn around and build Berry Plastics' business. Page C2. 

Hugo Boss Says Profit Will Fall
Hugo Boss, the large German apparel company, said mistakes in the way it had accounted for inventory last year at its operations in the United States would cause 2002 profit to fall short of expectations. C4.

Fiat Nears Accord With Its Banks
Fiat appeared to be inching toward an accord with its major creditor banks tonight on an injection of fresh capital as part of a plan to curb its losses and reduce debt. C4.

Lukoil Trims $100 Million in Costs
Russia's largest oil producer, Lukoil, said it will have trimmed about $100 million in costs by the end of the second quarter, reaping the first rewards from a corporate overhaul. C4.

U.S. Markets Reopen
Financial markets in the United States are open today; they were closed yesterday in observance of Memorial Day. European share prices edged higher after a surprise jump in a key German confidence index. But Asian stock markets were mostly lower amid lackluster trading. C13.

Tariffs Protest Gains Support
The European Union is pressing ahead with efforts to overturn the Bush administration's tariffs on steel imports. Japan and South Korea have said that they will join in the complaints if the tariffs are not withdrawn, and Brazil, China, New Zealand, Switzerland and Norway have taken preliminary steps to follow suit. C4.

Europe Opens New Microsoft Inquiry
The European Commission said it had begun an inquiry into Microsoft because of concerns that its .NET Passport system violated privacy rules. C4.

Securities Firms Warned in Seoul
South Korea's highest-ranking financial regulator, in a veiled warning to securities firms, called for strict guidelines on "the professionalism" of investment advisers responsible for analyzing the merits of companies. C4.

HEADLINE: Amid Concern Over Ethics, Chretien Shifts His Cabinet 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: TORONTO, May 27 

 BODY:
Prime Minister Jean Chretien has shaken up his cabinet for the second time in four months in an effort to deflect growing criticism of his government's ethical standards and challenges to his leadership of the governing Liberal Party.
 Mr. Chretien, who has governed since 1993, has been coy about whether he intends to retire or lead the Liberals for a fourth parliamentary election, presumably in 2004. 
 But first he may face opposition to his party leadership at a Liberal gathering next February from Finance Minister Paul Martin, who has won high marks for reviving the economy in recent months. 
Mr. Chretien was stung two weeks ago when the Liberals lost two supposedly safe parliamentary seats in by-elections, and opposition parties have exploited the growing public perception that cronyism has crept into government contract decisions.
Mr. Chretien is known for his stubborn loyalty to aides under attack, even when he is forced to take political heat to protect them. But he moved quickly on Sunday afternoon to fire Defense Minister Art Eggleton after Mr. Eggleton appeared on a news broadcast to defend his granting of a $36,500 contract to a former girlfriend to prepare a 14-page report on post-traumatic stress disorder in the Canadian military.
Mr. Eggleton, a former mayor of Toronto and longtime Liberal leader, had come under criticism in recent months in the House of Commons. Critics said he was slow to draw up plans to revamp the Canadian military and misled the Parliament in January about details surrounding the taking of prisoners by Canadian forces fighting in Afghanistan.
"Perhaps after almost nine years, people got a bit too comfortable," Mr. Chretien told reporters. "So that will teach a lesson to all of us." He added that he told Mr. Eggleton that the credibility of the government had been hurt by his favoring of the former girlfriend, Maggie Maier, an Ottawa consultant.
Mr. Eggleton has been replaced by John McCallum, a former bank executive with little experience in military affairs. Mr. McCallum will face the challenge of reviving a military that critics and Bush administration officials say is seriously under financed and ill equipped to face international terrorist threats.
Mr. Chretien also removed Public Works Minister Don Boudria after it was revealed that he had held a family reunion at a luxury cottage owned by the president of a Montreal public relations firm that does business with the government.
Mr. Boudria was shifted to a parliamentary leadership post, and Mr. Chretien said he had not technically broken any conflict of interest rules.
But Ralph Goodale, Mr. Boudria's successor at the Public Works Ministry, made it clear that he intended to operate under stricter standards. The ministry has been a virtual revolving door over the last year because of a string of allegations of cronyism and inefficiency.
"It's very important for all government departments to conduct themselves according to the standards that Canadians expect," Mr. Goodale said. "Today we turn the page."
Opposition politicians were quick to characterize the cabinet shifts as window dressing. "It's the rules of the game, not just the players, that need to change," said Alexa McDonough, leader of the left-of-center New Democratic Party.
Similar comments have come from the government's auditor-general, who recently criticized public use of Quebec advertising firms that favor the Liberals in that province.
Mr. Chretien and his party have several strong issues running in their favor against a divided opposition. After a brief recession late last year, unemployment has eased and the Canadian dollar has rebounded strongly. Separatist currents have ebbed in Quebec Province. And Mr. Chretien has managed to keep relations with the Bush administration on an even keel despite growing disputes over trade.
But political columnists and other analysts say the perception of ethical lapses could produce more political upheaval. 
"His government is unraveling," wrote Edward Greespon in a front-page column in today's Globe and Mail. "And it is doing so on the very issue that helped propel the government to office integrity."
