PERSON: Carol Willis 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
Putting Skyscrapers Back Into the Bigger Picture

BYLINE:  By JOYCE WADLER

 BODY:
DARN those news people. 
 Carol Willis, founder, director and curator of the Skyscraper Museum, has been hearing from them constantly since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, and they want the same thing: a sound bite, as Ms. Willis seems to explain it, though she does not use the words. They are too short and sweet, one suspects, for Ms. Willis. She is of the academic tradition, a student of history. She takes the long view. Also the long answer. But let us go back to those annoying reporters. 
 "They all ask the same questions: 'What did they represent?' " Ms. Willis says, talking a mile a minute and referring, of course, to the trade center towers. "They want to hear, 'icon of capitalism.' That's too simplistic, too empty a description. They were not commercial. They were not speculative office buildings. Most skyscrapers are built by private investors; these were built by government. They want to hear about height, the hubris of height. The World Trade Centers were only briefly the tallest buildings in the world, though it was, by far, the world's largest office building." 
It will take a while longer to get to this news reporter's query, and as we wait you might want to check out the view from Ms. Willis's temporary 13th-floor office near Wall Street. Not much of a view and not much of an office: two little rooms.
Or perhaps you might contemplate Ms. Willis. Age 53. Face seemingly free of makeup. Blond hair pulled back with two clips, giving her the look of a schoolgirl who can't be bothered with fuss. A fuchsia blouse, suggesting somewhere in this serious architectural historian and author ("Form Follows Finance: Skyscrapers and Skylines in New York and Chicago") there is a sense of fun.
But wait, what is this, a verbal space opening up ahead?
In we zoom with our query: is there a future for skyscrapers given the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center? As a student of skyscrapers whose organization co-sponsored a talk on the World Trade Center earlier this spring, does Ms. Willis feel such buildings are safe?
"If you tried to build a building that could withstand that, I think the reports from FEMA and others are showing this, nothing could have," Ms. Willis says. "It's not the skyscrapers' fault for being there. What if the attacks had been on the Super Bowl stadium on Sunday? Would we say, 'How can we get together in public spaces again?' "
Into the theme song, and you better believe it is a positive one, of the Skyscraper Museum.
"We shouldn't ban or blame skyscrapers. They make sense as an urban building type. They're part of the culture, the lore of New York -- its density, its diversity, the energy that attracts us here. When people around the world picture New York, it's the skyline." 
Were you even aware that there was a Skyscraper Museum in New York?
Do not be ashamed if you were not. Ms. Willis herself admits the majority of visitors have been tourists who have stumbled upon it. The Skyscraper Museum, for the six years of its existence, has not had a permanent home. It has depended on the kindness of landlords; bouncing, rent-free, from 44 Wall Street to 16 Wall Street to 110 Maiden Lane. The stipulation with rent-free, Ms. Willis explains, is having to vacate within 30 days.
There is also another problem: the attacks of Sept. 11 have left the Skyscraper Museum homeless. It will, finally, have a permanent home at the end of this year, on the ground floor of the 38-story Ritz-Carlton hotel and condominium apartment tower, at Battery Park City. This will also be rent-free.
Ms. Willis must write a heck of a proposal, she is told.
She breaks into a grin.
"I think what I'm good at is not selling people who just aren't interested, but people who have a little glimmer in their eye. Those people I can do it within zero to 60, to use drag-racing terms."
Does Ms. Willis race cars? "No, but I'm from the Midwest."
Ms. Willis grew up in the small town of Bratenahl, Ohio, on the outskirts of Cleveland. Her father was a graphic designer, her mother a dress designer. They divorced when Ms. Willis was small, and Ms. Willis does not like to recall this part of her life. She does remember seeing her first skyscraper, Terminal Tower, in downtown Cleveland, and her pleasure in urban life. She majored in art history at Boston University, working her way through college. She had kind of an interesting job, Ms. Willis blurts out, as a go-go dancer. There is immediate post-blurt regret. It paid better than waitressing, she says. She was modestly dressed. That is to say, she wore the same short skirts everybody wore then. 
TODAY, Ms. Willis and her husband, Mark Willis, a banker, live in a skyscraper with a view of the Empire State Building.
Does she believe there is now fear about skyscrapers?
Anecdotal evidence suggests some skittishness, Ms. Willis says, but she thinks vacancies have to do with the economy and a surplus of office space. And in time, she says, there will be less nervousness. San Francisco, after all, was "leveled" in the earthquake of 1906. People rebuilt. 
In history, you take the long view.

HEADLINE: Shortage of Nurses Hurts Patient Care, Study Finds 

BYLINE:  By DENISE GRADY 

 BODY:
In hospitals with low numbers of registered nurses, patients are more likely to suffer complications like urinary infections and pneumonia, to stay in the hospital longer and to die from treatable conditions like shock or gastrointestinal bleeding, researchers report today.
 "I estimate that hundreds or, perhaps, thousands of deaths each year are due to low staffing," said Dr. Jack Needleman, an economist at the Harvard School of Public Health and the lead author of a study on staffing published today in The New England Journal of Medicine. 
 The nation has a serious nursing shortage, with 126,000 jobs unfilled, 12 percent of capacity, says the American Hospital Association. The shortage is a result of hospital mergers, layoffs and heavy workloads. Many hospital nurses shifted to other work. The average salary, $46,000 a year, has not increased much in a decade. Even though hospitals are trying to hire again, nurses are no longer available. 
The new study, paid mostly by the government, is one of the largest to look at care in relation to staffing. The findings were based on a computer analysis of the discharge records of more than six million patients at 799 hospitals in 11 states in 1997. Five million had medical problems. One million had surgery.
The research sought to find out whether there was a correlation between how patients fared and the levels of registered nurses and two other types of workers with less training, licensed practical nurses and aides. 
Registered nurses receive several years of training and usually hold associate's or bachelor's degrees. Practical nurses usually have high school diplomas and a year of training. Aides have less training. 
The researchers found that for some aspects of care registered nurses made a difference. In hospitals with higher nurse staffing, stays were 3 to 5 percent shorter, and complication rates 2 to 9 percent lower than in hospitals with lower staffing. No relation was found between patients' well-being or length of stay and the levels of aides or practical nurses.
Registered nurses, Dr. Needleman said, are "the eyes and ears of the hospital" for judging whether a patient is recovering normally. 
"If something is going wrong," he said, "they can catch the signs early, before the problem gets worse." 
But problems cannot be spotted early, he added, if nurses do not have time to observe their patients.
The president of the American Nurses Association, Mary E. Foley, said, "We're very pleased that another large set of research data has validated what the American Nurses Association has been saying since the mid-90's, that there is a direct effect on the outcome of patient care when you have enough nurses."
As an example, Ms. Foley said, pneumonia and blood clots in hospitalized patients often result from immobility, and nurses help prevent such complications by turning and repositioning bedridden patients, encouraging them to exercise and cough and helping others to get up and walk around. Even if nurses themselves do not do those things for patients, they have the training and experience to know when such help is needed and to ensure it is provided. 
A senior vice president for policy at the American Hospital Association, Carmela Coyle, said: "The study suggests that registered nurses are key and critical to insuring good patient care. This is something that hospitals and patients have known for some time."
Ms. Coyle said she feared that the study would lead some people to assume that health care problems could be solved by laws that require specific staffing ratios, a move that hospital trade groups have long resisted. She called such a reaction overly simplistic.
"What you really need to look at," Ms. Coyle said, "is much more than the number of nurses and the number of patients. How many of the nurses have 20 years of experience or more, and how many are right out of school? What technology is there to support them? How sick are the patients?"
Dr. Needleman said his group made its study because the government sought to fill a large research gap on the connection between nurse staffing and quality of care. In the early 1990's, nurses testified to Congress that patients in some hospitals were endangered by managed-care companies that were trying to save money by replacing registered nurses with less skilled and lower paid workers. Congress asked the Institute of Medicine to study the issue. In a report in 1996, the institute said there was not enough data to draw conclusions and called on the government to finance studies.
Dr. Needleman's is one of those. It measured staffing two ways, by the proportion of nursing hours provided by each type of worker and by the number of hours a day the types of workers devoted to each patient. 
For registered nurses, the average number of hours a day per patient came to eight. The hours included not only time at the bedside, but also time spent preparing medication, writing chart reports and consulting colleagues or family members.
The averages include intensive care units, with one nurse for every one or two patients around the clock.
"There were some hospitals, that if I were going to them as a patient, I would be very concerned," Dr. Needleman said. "The hospitals at the very low end of our sample had as little as two hours, and some at the high end had 16 hours."
When the study compared the hospitals in the top quarter with those in the bottom quarter on the proportion of nursing time from registered nurses, it found that the medical patients, as opposed to surgical patients, in the bottom quarter had stays 3.5 percent longer, 9 percent more urinary infections, 5.1 percent more gastrointestinal bleeding, 6.4 percent more pneumonia and 9.4 percent more shock or cardiac arrest. 
In addition, the death rate was 2.5 percent higher for "failure to rescue," meaning that the patients died from conditions that might have been reversed if they had been treated in time. Those conditions include pneumonia, shock or cardiac arrest, upper gastrointestinal bleeding, sepsis or a blood clot.

HEADLINE: Bosnia Tries to Stitch Its Unwieldy Fabric Back Together 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL SIMPSON 

DATELINE: NOVI SEHER, Bosnia and Herzegovina, May 26 

 BODY:
When classes break at the two elementary schools in this ethnically mixed village in central Bosnia, children from both schools play on the same strip of gravel. But not with each other.
 Ten years ago, before Bosnia's brutal war set neighbors at each other's throats, they would have shared the same classrooms. Now, Novi Seher's schoolhouse has been split in half -- one building for Croatian children, another for Muslims -- and there is no immediate prospect of reuniting it. 
 "What has happened here is a tragedy," said Mehmet Meckic, principal of the Muslim school, whose pupils come from families that have returned to the village after fleeing Croatian militiamen in 1993. "I don't know how to resolve it. It's going to be very difficult and very slow."
The rest of Bosnia has not fared much better since the peace accords brokered in Dayton, Ohio, in 1995 divided the Balkan country of about 3.6 million down wartime front lines, creating a Muslim-Croatian federation and a separate Serbian republic.
That the Serbian part was carved out by systematic killings and the eviction of its Muslim inhabitants has made cooperation between the two entities virtually unthinkable so far. The search for compromise is further burdened by Serbian and Croatian intransigence born of the feeling that they, too, were victims of "ethnic cleansing," though in far fewer numbers.
Yet despite the prevailing gloom among many impoverished Bosnians, there are at last signs of progress in the vast Western project to forge a multiethnic democracy from the failed state sustained since 1995 by a drip-feed of $5 billion in foreign aid and tens of thousands of NATO-led peacekeepers.
"In three or four years this country should be able stand on its own feet," said Wolfgang Petritsch, the Austrian diplomat who spent three years administering Bosnia as high representative. His successor, the British politician Paddy Ashdown, assumed the job on Monday. 
The progress is slower than many, particularly the United States, would like. But Mr. Petritsch, who under the Dayton accords has sweeping powers to enact laws and remove officials, has begun to build the institutions needed to keep a state going.
He has cajoled Western-backed coalitions that won elections in 2000 in both the Bosnian-Croatian Federation and the Bosnian Serb Republic into passing reforms that were unfeasible under the rule of nationalists, who fomented and fed off Bosnia's ethnic divisions for a decade as Yugoslavia was ripped apart.
Under considerable pressure, all parties have backed constitutional changes designed to guarantee equal rights, and public sector job opportunities, for all three ethnic groups in both parts of the country.
In the short term, the need to represent Serbs, Croats and Muslims proportionately in each layer of government will bloat Bosnia's already unwieldy political structure.
But diplomats stress that the mere act of persuading sworn enemies to cooperate could generate momentum -- provided the politicians credited with showing initiative are not punished in elections next October for failing to bring down the unemployment rate, which is 40 percent in the federation, and even higher in the Bosnian Serb Republic.
A crackdown by Mr. Petritsch on the main Croat nationalist party, the H.D.Z., has stripped it of funds and influence. But the process has not been mirrored in the Bosnian Serb Republic. The S.D.S. party of Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb leader who remains on the run after being indicted for war crimes, is popular among disillusioned Bosnian Serbs.
The S.D.S. is likely to regain power this fall, and although the downfall of Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav leader, has deprived it of support from Belgrade for folding part of Bosnia into a Greater Serbia, it could still have a destabilizing effect.
"We could be back to square one or worse come October," warned Mark Wheeler of the International Crisis Group, an influential private research institute based in Brussels.
The risk of election violence means that NATO's plans to cut its Stabilization Force of 19,000 foreign soldiers by a third will not be carried out until later this year. Their number has fallen steadily from the 60,000 sent in to police the peace that NATO powers brought about by force.
Patrols have helped restore freedom of movement, making possible the return of considerable numbers of the two million refugees created by a war that claimed 200,000 lives.
Some 200,000 people have returned to areas where they are an ethnic minority, although few Muslims have settled in the hostile mountains of eastern the Bosnian Serb Republic, whose lush slopes are littered with abandoned fire-bombed houses. Refugees often reclaim such homes only to resell them.
There are occasional surprises, however. In Srebrenica, synonymous with the worst massacre in Europe since World War II, a 12-year-old named Dzeneta said she was happy in her school even though she is the only Muslim there. "I love my friends here and they love me," she said.
But efforts to restore multiethnicity to this corner of Bosnia have come at a price.
Years after bullets and shrapnel tore holes in many of Srebrenica's buildings, repair work has barely begun; in part because international officials withheld reconstruction aid until the municipality did more to encourage Muslims to return. Resentment runs deep among many of its Serbian inhabitants, who question why anyone would want to.
"I wouldn't come back here if I had the choice," said Drago Tesic, a 52-year-old Serb who works for the local council. "People here are scavenging through garbage bins, no matter what their origin. I've seen it with my own eyes."
Jobs are what is needed most to persuade people to return from the cities and to give those who live in outlying areas a sense of future.
To create them in an economy still recovering from Communism and war, Bosnia needs foreign investment. But it will have to work hard to attract it.
Mindful of this, and the objective of using eventual European Union membership for Bosnia as the new tool of international influence, Mr. Ashdown has made strengthening the rule of law and attacking organized crime his priorities.
If all goes according to plan, he will be the last foreigner to administer Bosnia before handing power to its citizens. But that would still not spell an end to the West's engagement here.
"For Bosnia, as a classic weak state for quite some time to come, we should talk more about an entry strategy into European integration processes rather than an exit strategy for us," Mr. Petritsch said.

HEADLINE: The G.O.P. Is Confident, Maybe Too Confident, About the Race 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
The consensus among Republicans as they wrapped up their convention yesterday is that George E. Pataki is a juggernaut on course to become the fourth New York governor in a century to win a third term. His approval ratings are higher than ever, even among Democrats, and his war chest is brimming with at least $16 million, twice what either of his two Democratic opponents has raised.
 But the race this year differs greatly from the contests he won in 1994 and 1998. Even his most confident supporters acknowledge that the governor can take nothing for granted in a state where registered Democrats outnumber Republicans five million to three million. 
 Not only has the state grown even more Democratic in the last eight years, but also the economy, particularly upstate, has not rebounded and continues to limp along, giving his opponents a fat target. Democrats also hope the governor might be vulnerable in the city's suburbs, where school property taxes are expected to rise significantly this fall, in part because of a drop in state aid.
In 1994, Mr. Pataki won because of a recession and public fatigue with former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, polls showed. A huge turnout upstate among Republican conservatives and an apathetic showing from New York City liberals gave him a narrow victory. By 1998, the governor was riding one of the greatest economic booms in history and faced a weak candidate from the Democrats. He won with 54 percent of the vote.
This year, though, the two Democrats seeking to oppose Mr. Pataki are attractive candidates -- state comptroller H. Carl McCall, the first black man to hold statewide office, and a former federal housing secretary, Andrew M. Cuomo, the son of the former governor and a sharp-elbowed campaigner.
What's more, the state economy has just begun to come back from a recession that started last year and worsened after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. State revenue has shriveled. The governor and Legislature patched together a budget that only averted deep cuts by spending $3 billion in savings and one-time revenue, money that will not be there next year.
Against that backdrop, G.O.P. politicians and consultants at the Republic State Convention yesterday, while cocky, were not crowing about victory yet. "It's the third inning of a baseball game, so we can't say we are going to win," one of the governor's advisers said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "But you can say we are winning 13 to 1."
Democratic strategists, on the other hand, say Mr. Pataki's position is not as secure as it seems. They maintain that recent college polls giving the governor sky-high approval ratings and saying he would trounce either Democrat by a 2-to-1 ratio do not reckon whether those polled are likely to vote. More sophisticated surveys of likely voters would show a tighter race, they say.
In addition, like most elected officials, Mr. Pataki has enjoyed a bounce in popularity since the terrorist attacks, as New Yorkers have rallied around their elected leaders. That effect may fade as voters start to focus on issues closer to home, among them property taxes, the poor performance of some schools and a lack of well-paid jobs.
"Elections are not decided in May," said a spokesman for Mr. McCall, Steven Greenberg. "Voters don't start paying attention to the election until it gets closer."
For the Democratic candidate, there are two key questions: how big will the Democratic margin be in the five boroughs, where the party has a five-to-one advantage, and how badly will they lose in the suburbs? The Democrats need to pull as many urban voters out to the polls as possible and hold their own in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties. They also need to break even in Buffalo and Erie County.
For Mr. Pataki, the task is not only to get upstate Republicans to come out in great numbers once again, but also to persuade Democrats in the city to cross over and support him. His strategists believe that if he can capture a third of the vote in the city, he will win overall. "What you always had to do as a Republican in this state is compete for Democratic votes," an adviser to Mr. Pataki said.
The governor has labored hard to do that in the last year, courting Spanish-speaking voters of New York City and securing the support of several important Democratic labor leaders. On the stump, he talks as much about providing health insurance to the poor and revamping harsh drug laws as he does about cutting taxes and welfare rolls. "He's come more to the center," said Robert Davis, the Erie County Republican chairman. "That plays well in urban communities."
In addressing the convention yesterday, Mr. Pataki avoided any blatantly partisan attacks and emphasized the "unity" that has characterized politics since the terrorist attacks. After his speech, the governor said, "I think people who have not, in the past, traditionally, been willing to look at Republican candidates are now taking a look." 
Mr. Pataki runs a slight risk of losing the conservative wing of his party. Gun enthusiasts are angry with him for passing a ban on assault rifles. Fiscal conservatives say he has borrowed too much and allowed government spending to grow faster than inflation. Those voters might choose to stay home or cast a protest vote for a third-party candidate.
Still, the leaders of the Conservative Party are likely to give Mr. Pataki their endorsement at their convention next week. The party chairman, Mike Long, said, "There are more things we agree with than we disagree with him on."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Hispanic networks hone an edge in a race for TV ad dollars.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
AS advertisers begin deciding where to spend more than $7 billion for commercial time ahead of the fall television season, some networks are feeling less anxious than their competitors, and not because they have prescriptions for extra-strength Xanax.
 Executives from the two big networks that cater to Spanish-speaking viewers -- Telemundo and Univision -- say they think that new demographic data and a revamping of how the Latino TV audience is measured will help them outperform their English-language counterparts in what is known as the upfront market. 
 Wall Street analysts estimate that the two networks could sell $800 million to $900 million in commercial time before the 2002-03 season starts, far above the estimated $700 million to $725 million they sold during last year's upfront. That would equal the estimates for upfront ad sales for the two smallest mainstream broadcast networks, UPN and WB. The expected increase -- between 12 and 28 percent -- would significantly outperform the increases of 3 percent to 6 percent anticipated by the English-language broadcast networks, which also include ABC, CBS, Fox and NBC. 
"Some may still continue to ignore the market, but there are enough who could stand to spend more on advertising to Hispanics: retailers in larger markets, makers of packaged goods, companies that sell to younger families," said Michael J. Russell Jr., an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York who follows the advertising and broadcasting industries.
"Hispanics have a tendency to be more brand loyal," he added, referring to research findings, "so advertising to them could be more effective." That is an important consideration in tough times, when ad dollars are scarce.
Marketers are increasingly getting the message about Hispanic purchasing power.
"We have been, I guess you could say, a little bit slow to the gate, but our goal is to build a long-term relationship with this consumer," said Michelle Fedurek, vice president for media services at Wendy's International in Dublin, Ohio. For the first time, Wendy's is devoting part of its national ad budget to campaigns in Spanish.
"We are involved in the upfront as we speak," Ms. Fedurek added. "Conversations have begun with both the big networks."
Previously, Wendy's advertised to Hispanic consumers by running ads in 27 local markets. Now, the company is spending an estimated $10 million on national television and radio commercials as well as on ads in stores, all created by the Vidal Partnership in New York.
Wendy's is sponsoring two campaigns for the Hispanic market. One serves "to introduce our brand to this consumer," Ms. Fedurek said, "because research showed us Hispanics don't really know who Wendy's is, but once they do they're willing to try us, and like us." The other campaign is centered on the 2002 World Cup and the matches to be broadcast by Univision.
Telemundo and Univision, however, still face formidable obstacles in grabbing a larger share of ad dollars. Many mainstream national advertisers remain reluctant to speak directly to a market that they perceive as linguistically and culturally complicated. And the overall upfront market, which will begin in earnest as soon as this week, could prove to be a sluggish one for all networks as they worry whether the uneven economy will discourage marketers from spending more than they did last season.
This year, the Spanish-language networks have three new negotiating chips. The 2000 census has provided their sales forces with detailed analyses of demographic data elaborating on the rapid growth of the Hispanic population, which increased to 12.5 percent of the total from 9 percent in 1990.
In addition, the company that measures TV ratings, Nielsen Media Research, is putting in place methods that are meant to measure the Latino viewership more effectively. The hope among executives at Telemundo and Univision is that the refinements will increase ratings for their shows, making them more desirable to advertisers.
Finally, the recent acquisition of Telemundo by NBC, which is part of General Electric, is expected to stimulate interest among advertisers that until now confined their pitches to English-language networks.
"There is still a need for learning about what the market is," said Steve Mandala, executive vice president for sales at Telemundo in New York, because "the only way our market gets percentage and dollar-volume growth is through that educational effort being successful."
"There are no guarantees," he added, "but we feel very confident" about the fall season.
NBC is seeking to interest its client roster in Telemundo with cross-network ad packages and promotions. For instance, Maria Celeste Arraras, a well-known personality on Hispanic television, was hired as the anchor of a new newsmagazine show on Telemundo, "Al Rojo Vivo," and is being asked to contribute to NBC News programs like "Dateline."
Ms. Arraras and her show are "a focal point" of the Telemundo upfront sales initiatives, Mr. Mandala said.
Joe Mandese, the editor of Media Buyer's Daily in New York, a newsletter published by Primedia, said: "The Hispanic market is still somewhat of its own market, but it is making a bridge into the general marketplace." That shift would substantially help Telemundo and Univision, he added.
"Agencies were not used to buying this because they didn't know how to evaluate Spanish-language television alongside 'Anglo' television," Mr. Mandese said. "But the Hispanic networks have done a great job marketing themselves by saying, 'These are the demographics who buy your clients' products, and in some instances they're more important than the general market' " because many Latino families tend to be younger and larger than other American families.
Univision, which is the leader in both ratings and revenue in the Latino TV market, is intensifying its efforts to counter Telemundo's aggressive game, aiming at categories like computers, financial services and prescription drugs that have spent relatively little for Hispanic television.
"Our job is to deliver the information, to prove what we're saying," said Tom McGarrity, co-president for Univision network sales in New York for Univision's owner, Univision Communications. 
"We've had upfronts in the last four or five years where we've been able to outperform our English-language counterparts," he added. "We don't see any reason why we won't be able to do that this coming year."
In addition to the Univision network, Univision Communications also owns a smaller broadcast network, TeleFutura, and a cable network, Galavision. The company also operates online media and a music division, the Univision Music Group, which "we may be putting into our upfront deals," Mr. McGarrity said.
One sign of the growth in the Spanish-speaking consumer market is that 5 of the 30 pages in this week's issue of the trade publication Brandweek carry articles describing Hispanic campaigns by marketers like American Honda Motor, the California Milk Processor Board, Coca-Cola, PepsiCo and Wal-Mart.
"The Hispanic consumer is important for all of us going forward," Ms. Fedurek at Wendy's said. "Now that we have begun this relationship on a national basis, we're looking to continue."

HEADLINE: Down to Raucous Wire, Osbournes in MTV Deal 

BYLINE:  By BILL CARTER 

 BODY:
The Osbournes, stars of the most surprising success on television this year, agreed to terms of a new contract with MTV yesterday that will extend for at least 20 more episodes the real-life adventures of the raucous, crude-talking family headed by the longtime rocker Ozzy Osbourne.
 But the deal did not come easily. In fact, the negotiations over "The Osbournes," MTV's biggest hit series ever, turned out to be every bit as bizarre as the series itself, featuring such plot developments as demands by the Osbournes for a new house and lifetime psychotherapy for the family's herd of cats and dogs; promises by the Osbournes to sign the contracts in blood; and offers from competing networks looking to steal the show away from MTV. 
 In the end, the deal, the biggest for a series in MTV's history, is being valued at $5 million to $7 million by MTV and more than $20 million by agents representing the Osbournes. It left all parties satisfied that they will be able to cash in on the latest reality television show to redefine what success means for a television network. The new episodes will begin in the fall. 
Over several months of negotiations, the Osbournes and their representatives played a game of hardball -- combined with elements of three-card monte -- that MTV executives said no one at the network had seen before, even with MTV's long experience dealing with unconventional talent.
MTV executives said the Osbourne camp changed the terms of the deal almost daily. Different representatives appeared on several occasions, all claiming to speak for the Osbournes. "We had three different sets of negotiations going on at various times," one senior MTV executive said.
The network's executives were so exasperated at some points that even the show's spectacular success seemed to have a downside.
A month ago, at a lunch meeting of MTV executives in Miami, an aide delivered the best ratings news of the show's first year. More than eight million viewers had seen the eighth episode of "The Osbournes," the biggest audience for a cable show this year. But when the eye-popping figures were placed in front of one senior MTV executive, he responded with a single word: "Ugh."
Thrilled as they were with the show's success, the executives knew that the huge ratings would only create more leverage for the Osbournes.
The battle for leverage led MTV to respond in some unusual ways, at one point blocking the show from beginning its run on MTV's outlet in Britain and thus preventing Mr. Osbourne from gaining publicity when he was about to embark on a concert tour there. MTV insisted later that until a new deal was signed, it would not begin playing a music video by the Osbournes' teenage daughter, Kelly, in which she sings a slickly produced version of the Madonna song "Papa Don't Preach."
The ban on the video was meant to send a message to Sharon Osbourne, the family matriarch and business manager, who had set a goal of creating a music career for Kelly. The message, as explained by one MTV executive, was: "She has to sign the deal."
Indeed, securing a signature from Ms. Osbourne, by all accounts a master of unpredictable brinkmanship -- and extraordinary chutzpah -- throughout the negotiations, became an almost quixotic quest for MTV executives. The reason was understandable: MTV relied on what it called an agreement but never actually had a signed deal with the Osbournes for the first season, leaving the network open to bigger demands during the recent negotiations because of the show's unanticipated success.
Almost daily, Ms. Osbourne promised to sign a deal for next season but repeatedly put off doing so. "I don't think she's ever going to sign," one executive said last week.
Van Toffler, the president of MTV, made it clear that she would have to. "I told her: 'Sharon, I love you, but we're not doing handshakes anymore,' " he said.
He added that when he pressed Ms. Osbourne, she playfully replied that she would indeed come through. "She told me she was going to sign in blood," Mr. Toffler said.
Several executives said they thought for a time that there might not be a second season of "The Osbournes."
One executive said of the talks, "I did fear the world would not see any more episodes because it would just at some point self-destruct."
MTV faced a changing roster of Osbourne representatives. Creative Artists Agency, which had handled the Osbournes in the first season, began the negotiations for the second season.
In the midst of those talks, Ms. Osbourne told MTV she was sending in Colin Newman, her longtime British accountant. Then things changed again as the family's lawyers took over.
Finally, Ariel Emanuel, the head of the Endeavor Agency in Hollywood, called MTV to say that he was taking over the deal.
Mr. Toffler said before the deal was finished: "It was confusing because of the bevy of representatives who were all declaring that they knew what Sharon wanted. At this point we don't know which end is up."
Mr. Emanuel, one of the most aggressive agents in Hollywood, said that Ms. Osbourne had called him and that he told her he could make a "precedent-setting deal."
A short time later, MTV got word that the next season of "The Osbournes" was being shopped around to the broadcast networks. "We contacted every network," Mr. Emanuel said. "They were all interested."
At least two broadcast networks were interested enough to commission extensive research into how "The Osbournes" would play as a weekly prime-time series. One network was convinced. "It would have been huge," a senior executive there said. "We were definitely bidding on it. We were led to believe it was available. We had a real plan for how we would put it on."
One plan the Osbourne side suggested would have allowed MTV to run episodes after they had first run on a network.
Infuriated, MTV's lawyers responded with a letter to the networks saying it held the legal rights to the show and would sue to keep them if the networks persisted. MTV agreed that the ultimate card the Osbournes held was to stop production on the series; according to the initial agreement, they always had the right to do that, if, for example, the family thought that the children were being upset in some way.
But no one really wanted the show to stop production, not with MTV getting its biggest price ever from advertisers on the show and the Osbournes looking at what some people were telling them was an opportunity to become "the MTV version of the Cosby family."
Mr. Emanuel said he intended to create a new economic model, with the Osbournes becoming the equivalent of a studio in controlling all rights to their show. He called for MTV to allow the show to go up for sale in syndication almost immediately, years before a television series normally would.
In fact, the deal struck yesterday will permit the Osbournes to begin selling episodes to local stations for first use in the fall of 2004. But the show made only 10 episodes last season and only 20 more are guaranteed so far for the next. Syndication typically requires 88 to 100 episodes.
The Osbourne camp won the novel right, however, to carve out new episodes from outtakes. MTV agreed to that arrangement, convinced that the real value of the show is in the initial broadcast of the episodes. Reality shows typically do not do well in syndication because the intense interest in them wears out quickly.
Even with the syndication issue mostly resolved, the deal was still hung up for weeks as new wrinkles emerged. Earlier, the network had turned down the demand for pet therapy. But the Osbournes suddenly asked to be able to appear three times a year on shows on other networks. MTV resisted because any show in which the Osbournes appeared as themselves would compete with the MTV show.
Mr. Toffler admitted to be being "at wits' end" on several of these occasions. Still, he never lost his affection for the woman at the center of the talks.
"You've got to love Sharon," he said. "There's something very lovable about her. She has several sides of her brain going at once."
Lovable to an extent. Last week, in negotiations over breakfast at the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan, Ms. Osbourne, who is no fan of delicate language, unleashed enough colorful and loud invective that she drove all other patrons out of the restaurant, one customer said.
Ms. Osbourne was in England yesterday and her press representative did not respond to requests to speak with her. In her official comment on the settlement as quoted in a MTV release, Ms. Osbourne said, "It's been absolutely bleeping amazing."
And she did in fact finally sign the new deal, Mr. Toffler said, along with the other members of the family, including Ozzy, who used his real name, John Michael Osbourne.
"But it's a faxed copy of the deal," Mr. Toffler said. "So I can't tell if it's signed in blood."

HEADLINE: Oil Prices Drop as Gasoline Supplies Swell 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Oil prices in the United States fell late yesterday after an industry supply report showed another jump in spare gasoline supplies at the outset of the summer driving season.
 July crude oil futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange jumped 49 cents, to $25.76 a barrel, in the regular session, ending a five-day losing run that had taken prices $4 below the eight-month highs struck earlier in May. 
 Prices then slid more than 60 cents in after-hours trading after the American Petroleum Institute reported that national gasoline stocks rose 3 million barrels, to 218.4 million, in the week ended Friday.
Gasoline stocks are 6 percent higher than this time last year, providing ample supplies to meet the summer holiday driving demand, which was due to hit full stride over last weekend's Memorial Day holiday.
After peaking just below $30 two weeks ago, oil prices have drifted lower as fears ease that simmering violence between Israel and the Palestinians could disrupt supplies from the Middle East, which pumps a third of world oil.
Gasoline futures prices have fallen around 14 percent since early April as strong imports from Europe and sluggish demand for other fuels in a fragile economy have created a large surplus.
Retail gasoline prices, which increased 20 percent from mid-February to mid-April, fell a penny a gallon last week to average $1.39 -- down 32 cents from a year ago and the lowest level for a Memorial Day weekend in three years, the Energy Department said on Tuesday.
This year the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries cartel has been producing at its lowest level in a decade to keep spare supplies from building up. Officials have indicated that the cartel is unlikely to increase supplies when ministers meet next on June 26 in Vienna.

HEADLINE: BOXING; 
Going Where Vegas Wouldn't

BYLINE:  By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

DATELINE: MEMPHIS, May 26 

 BODY:
To a national identity that comes from Elvis Presley, the blues and barbecue, local political and business leaders are hoping to add something new: boxing.
 People in Memphis have embraced the heavyweight championship fight between Lennox Lewis and Mike Tyson, which will take place here on June 8. And they do not mince words about the reasons. 
 "It will be the largest-grossing match in the history of boxing and it will bring international attention to us," Mayor Willie Herenton of Memphis said. "It will show America that we can host this kind of event." 
The fight at the Pyramid, a gleaming downtown arena covered by eight and a half acres of stainless steel, is expected to bring more than $30 million in spending to the city. It is likely to fill thousands of hotel rooms here and in the nearby casino-hotels in Tunica, Miss., as well as bring people to local restaurants and generate millions in tax revenues.
This is a bout that even Las Vegas disavowed. Authorities in Texas, Colorado and Georgia also spurned the fight after Tyson bit Lewis's thigh during a melee at a news conference in January in Midtown Manhattan.
Herenton, a lanky former Golden Gloves flyweight champion, chooses not to weigh the morality of playing host to a Tyson fight. "This is primarily a business decision," he said.
Tyson has caused trouble or committed crimes from Las Vegas to Indianapolis to Glasgow. But his notoriety also means that big money follows him.
"Mike Tyson is an industry, like Michael Jackson and Michael Jordan," said Joe Towns Jr., a Tennessee state legislator, who helped steer the fight to Memphis and guaranteed that Tyson would "get a fair shake" if he sought a boxing license.
"We didn't want to have any talk about morality," Towns said.
Neither does the Tyson camp. "Mike knows there's support for him and he will behave 100 percent," said Shelly Finkel, Tyson's manager. "Mike knows he's a business."
To many of the 1.1 million people in the Memphis area, Tyson is less a boxing outlaw than a one-man economic jolt. 
"This is something Memphis deserves," said Demetrius Granderson, assistant manager of a Beale Street gift shop. "You can't say Tyson shouldn't come. You can't judge a person. Nobody really knows what he did."
To be sure, Tyson cannot accelerate the long-planned resurrection of a section of Main Street that is blighted by empty stores. But his appeal is expected to fill the Pyramid's nearly 20,000 seats at a high of $2,400 a ticket. 
Gate receipts at the Pyramid are expected to be $23 million, 15 times more than the arena's previous highest-grossing event, a Rolling Stones concert that produced $1.5 million in sales. 
Like many midsize American cities, Memphis has craved greater renown by pursuing major league sports. Over the last 30 years, a dozen professional teams have come and gone. Two years ago, John Calipari was hired to coach the basketball team at the University of Memphis, and last year, the city lured the National Basketball Association's Grizzlies, formerly of Vancouver.
Many city leaders hope the Lewis-Tyson fight will finally put Memphis on the global sports map. But if Tyson gnaws at Lewis's extremities or throws a punch at Eddie Cotton, the referee, Memphis's leaders hope their city's name will not be sullied.
"Hockey doesn't stop when someone hits someone with a stick," Towns said. "There's violence on television. Mike Tyson is nothing but antics and trash talking. You can't stop the man from working."
The Tyson-Lewis fight may be the biggest sports event ever in Memphis, but history has been made here. The Union army occupied the city during the Civil War. Yellow fever in 1878 killed half the populace. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated at the Lorraine Motel. Elvis died at Graceland.
Memphis, which had a population of 650,000 in the 2000 census, has never been a boxing hotbed.
"Memphis was generally fundamentalist Christian," said Charles Crawford, a history professor at the University of Memphis. "Memphis was a center of sports and entertainment until early in the 20th century, until the passage of the Tennessee Prohibition Act in 1909, and there was a reaction against sports like horse racing and boxing that involved gambling."
Never before has Memphis been the site of a heavyweight title bout, and the city has been unlucky in pro sports. Its World Football League Southmen and United States Football League Showboats went belly up, as did the leagues. Memphis's franchise in the American Basketball Association (the Pros, then the Tams, then the Sounds) lasted from 1970 to 1975. For nearly three decades, Memphis sought a National Football League team.
Four years ago, after losing the Class AA Memphis Chicks baseball team to Jackson, Tenn., Memphis persuaded the St. Louis Cardinals to move their Class AAA Redbirds club here. In 2000, the Redbirds moved into a gem of a stadium, Autozone Park, which last year had the highest attendance in the minor leagues.
Also last year, the Grizzlies arrived from Vancouver. "Getting the Grizzlies was one factor in showing the city has reached a certain stature, that it can attract significant industry," said J. R. Hyde, who founded Autozone, a chain of automobile repair stores, and who helped lead the pursuit of the Grizzlies.
Unlike the N.B.A.'s orderly transfer of the Grizzlies to Memphis, there was nothing systematic about finding a site for the Tyson-Lewis fight.
"I started reading that California, Florida, Texas and Georgia were going for it, and I thought, 'Why not Tennessee?' " said Brian Young, a local promoter. 
Young assembled a group of investors to raise the $12.5 million site fee. He wanted the fight to be in Nashville, at either the Adelphia Coliseum or the Gaylord Entertainment Center. But Bud Adams, the Tennessee Titans' owner, rejected the fight as inappropriate for Adelphia, and Young eventually decided that the arena would not generate enough revenue.
While Young pursued Nashville, Towns, the state legislator, called Young to suggest Memphis. "People thought I was from Pluto when I had the idea," Towns said. "But I couldn't figure out why not."
He interested Herenton in the idea, although the mayor was skeptical. "I thought we were going to be used to get a better deal elsewhere," said Herenton, who was persuaded to support the fight after meeting with Young, Finkel and Gary Shaw, who runs Main Events, Lewis's promoter.
Finkel praised Herenton but said only one factor swayed him to Memphis: money.
The arrival of the fight signifies the maturing of the Memphis market, said Andy Dolich, the Grizzlies' president for business operations.
"You wouldn't just look at Memphis and say, 'big-time sports,' " he said. "But add it up and it's powerful. It's part of the larger picture that says, 'Why not us?' "
There are at least a few dissenting voices in Memphis. Paula Casey, a women's rights activist, wonders why the city is so eager to accept Tyson.
"I'm just appalled," Casey said. "Boxing attracts an element I don't want to see. I've watched the Ku Klux Klan riot downtown. I don't want to see this. I'm going to Baltimore."
This is not only a Memphis deal. Thirty miles south lies Tunica, with its 10 hotel-casinos on land where cotton and soybeans once grew. 
Tunica provides the bout with the gaming element common to Las Vegas fights. Eight casinos bought thousands of tickets to distribute to their high rollers. The Tunica hotels will also provide a crucial 6,000 rooms, which, when added to the 20,000 rooms in Memphis, offer enough lodging for the mostly out-of-town fans and news media representatives. (Only about 3,000 tickets were sold locally.) 
Fitzgeralds, which looks like an Irish castle outside but a modest Poconos lodge inside, is Tyson's official camp hotel in Tunica. The more lavish Sam's Town, with its Wild West motif, is where Lewis's camp will stay.
"Everybody wanted to host Lennox Lewis, but I wanted Tyson," said Domenic Mezzetta, the general manager of Fitzgeralds, which is providing $1 million in free hotel rooms and services for Tyson's camp and tickets for gamblers. "Everybody hates him, but this will be the biggest gate in boxing history, because everyone wants to see him fight."
Sam's Town has plastered Lewis's name and image everywhere, down to the place mats used by diners beneath their $8.95 buffet meals.
"The Lewis camp was perceived as being the most desirable," said Rick White, the senior director for marketing at Sam's Town.
So far, there is little in Memphis that heralds the arrival of Tyson and Lewis. On a recent afternoon, the blues wafted from the clubs on Beale Street. A long line awaited the arrival of B. B. King at his club. The Pyramid's exhibition hall displayed czarist treasures. A bejeweled Elvis impersonator sang "Kentucky Rain" in an alley. 
And five ducks made their daily journey from the fountain in the Peabody Hotel lobby to a waiting elevator before hundreds of adoring tourists.
On June 7 and 8, Brown & Williamson, the tobacco company, is paying more than $100,000 to rent the Gibson Beale Street Showcase, an enormous guitar factory, for soirees with 2,500 guests. The nearby New Daisy Theater will play host to the official post-fight party.
But those hoping to cash in on the fight by renting their homes for several nights for huge sums seem headed for disappointment. Bill Harlow wanted $100,000 to rent his four-bedroom suburban home.
"I ain't got any commitments," he said. "I got nibbles, but they want to negotiate. Can you imagine?"

D1); Mayor Willie Herenton eventually backed the fight in the Pyramid. (Troy Glasgow for The New York Times); A long line formed in Memphis when tickets for the fight went on sale. Nonetheless, most of the tickets went to fans from out of town. (Associated Press)(pg. D2)

HEADLINE: New Jersey Details Plan To Raise Tax On Business 

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 29 

 BODY:
As state tax revenue continues to drop, even below Gov. James E. McGreevey's pessimistic projections, his administration today spelled out the details of a tax plan that would lean heavily on large corporations to close the budget gap.
 The long-awaited proposal to overhaul the business tax system, outlined today by State Treasurer John E. McCormac, would increase projected collections by nearly $800 million in the 2003 fiscal year, which begins July 1. 
 Testifying before a State Senate committee today, Mr. McCormac took up the theme that Governor McGreevey has sounded since he took office in January: that corporate taxpayers have escaped their fair share of the tax burden, as their proportion of total revenues dropped to about 5 percent from 15 percent over the last two decades. 
More than three-quarters of New Jersey businesses pay only a minimum corporate tax of $200 a year, Mr. McCormac said. "The corporate business tax has become the corporate optional tax," he said. 
State Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr., the Republican state chairman, immediately labeled the plan an "employer tax," and added in a statement, "A tax hike in the middle of an economic recession is horrible public policy."
Nonetheless, the Republican chairman of the Senate Budget Committee is joining Democrats in sponsoring the legislation, which must be signed by June 30, the end of the current fiscal year. The State Senate is evenly split between the parties, so the governor will need some Republican support.
Mr. McGreevey proposed to change the business tax in his budget address in March, but then stymied opposition by putting off a decision on the details.
Despite Mr. McGreevey's insistent references to "closing loopholes," which he said would not violate his earlier promise not to raise any major taxes, business leaders protested that the result could only be higher taxes and fewer new jobs.
Many legislators, including Democrats, were also perplexed, complaining that they could not move budget legislation without knowing the governor's plans as the June deadline approached. 
The governor's proposal recasts the minimum tax formula to prevent multistate corporations from shifting assets to other states, and so avoid New Jersey business taxes. The change is expected to raise $240 million to $275 million.
The other key components in the plan, expected to yield $250 million to $300 million, are a new fee on partnerships and other unincorporated businesses and improved collection of taxes owed to New Jersey by partners who live in other states.
The governor's plan also eliminates tax exclusions for interest expenses and some dividend income, and compels multistate corporations to report certain sales in New Jersey that they now claim in states where they are tax-exempt.
Philip Kirschner, the executive vice president of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, said today that the plan "is designed to touch the larger companies, and it does." 
Very small businesses may benefit from the plan, which exempts a company's first $1 million in sales from the minimum tax and cuts the tax rate for companies with profits of less than $50,000.
Mr. Kirschner said it was not clear yet how the tax changes would affect medium-size companies. He said the association would seek assessments from a sampling of members as soon as the legislation becomes available on Thursday. 
On Tuesday, the treasurer's office announced that its estimate of tax collections for the current fiscal year would be $589 million less than the projection in Mr. McGreevey's original budget. Today, in testimony before the Senate Budget Committee, Mr. McCormac said he now expected revenue for the 2003 fiscal year to be $628 million below the March projections.
He estimated that the treasury would collect $700 million less in the current fiscal year than it did last year.

HEADLINE: U.S. Fund for Tower Victims Will Aid Some Gay Partners 

BYLINE:  By JANE GROSS 

 BODY:
Some of the gay men and lesbians who were partners of Sept. 11 victims are poised to collect substantial awards from the federal fund set up to compensate bereaved families, according to Kenneth R. Feinberg, special master of the fund, and lawyers familiar with the process.
 Those who present claims to the Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund in cooperation with the next of kin of the deceased are all but assured of awards, Mr. Feinberg said. But even situations in which the victim's family is not supportive will be reviewed case by case, Mr. Feinberg said, with state law as the guiding principle. 
 New York State does not recognize same-sex unions. But an executive order by Gov. George E. Pataki in the wake of the terror attacks extending spousal benefits to gay partners under the State Crime Victims Board was intended to give Mr. Feinberg room to exercise discretion. 
"If the next of kin is supportive and there's no dispute, it's a nonissue," Mr. Feinberg said in an interview. "If the personal representative, say a parent, comes to me and says, 'Cut a check for the same-sex partner,' there will be no problem. Then it's a ministerial function. What do I care?" 
In less clear-cut situations, Mr. Feinberg added, he will take into account that New York's leaders, in a variety of post-9/11 actions, "have tried to improve the likelihood that I can exercise my discretion and I will do my best." He added that cases involving heterosexual domestic partners will be reviewed in the same way.
The federal awards process unfolds in the context of decisions by the state and city government and by the Red Cross that are supportive of the claims of the 22 known gay surviving partners of the terror attacks. These actions are not meant to be a wholesale push to expand the rights of same-sex couples. Rather they are a demonstration, halting and tentative, of how a national tragedy can result in policy that would not have occurred otherwise. It is too early to say whether any of the emergency benefits made available to survivors of Sept. 11 will be extended to others. 
"Clearly the momentum is specific to this event and won't necessarily be replicated," said Lee. M. Miringoff, the director of the Marist College Poll, commenting on the significance of the poll results. "But it does change the political climate and it's hard to imagine totally turning back the clock."
The legalizing of gay marriage remains unpopular, opposed by a majority of Americans. But polls show that most people support individual spousal benefits for gay partners, whose unions are recognized by law only in Vermont and Hawaii.
Gay rights organizations, like the Empire Gay Pride Agenda and the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, have made inclusion in Sept. 11 relief efforts, and especially the federal fund, a major priority, for the sake of the partners and the political precedent it could set. 
Still, recognition of survivors of gays is a polarizing issue for politicians. Republicans in the House of Representatives shelved a Senate bill, opposed by the Department of Justice, that would have provided death benefits to the survivors of the Rev. Mychal Judge, a New York City Fire Department chaplain, who was gay, and estates of nine other gay public safety officers who died at the the World Trade Center. Father Judge's survivors were his sisters.
The loudest public outcry against assisting gay partners of Sept. 11 victims has come from conservative organizations, like the Traditional Values Coalition in Anaheim, Calif. Its founder, the Rev. Louis P. Sheldon, has said that charitable organizations "should be giving priority to those widows who were home with their babies" and that government agencies should not be swayed by advocates "capitalizing on a national tragedy to promote their homosexual agenda."
But New York's elected leaders have supported the extension of aid. Mr. Pataki's executive order to the Crime Victims Board entitles domestic partners to awards up to $600 a week, to a total of $30,000, a benefit otherwise limited to husbands or wives. The lesbian partner of a civilian Army employee who died at the Pentagon, by contrast, was denied benefits by the comparable agency in Virginia.
The governor also opened the state's Sept. 11 charitable fund to gay partners. Along with other state and city elected leaders, Mr. Pataki petitioned the Bush administration to define relationships, for the purposes of the federal fund, by the "totality of circumstance," including "emotional and financial commitment" and "exclusivity and longevity," not by the existence of marriage licenses. In addition, in a recent 9/11 relief act passed unanimously by the State Legislature, the preamble states that it is the lawmakers' intent that domestic partners be recognized by Mr. Feinberg. 
New York City joined the Pataki administration in its appeal to the federal government and similarly made its Sept. 11 charity available to gay partners. Yesterday, the City Council held a hearing on the difficulties faced by surviving domestic partners, both homosexual and heterosexual, who are ineligible for a safety net of government benefits, including Social Security, Workers Compensation, military and uniformed service pensions and inheritance rights in the absence of a will.
In addition, the Red Cross strengthened its policy of defining family in a "broad and inclusive" way by adding guidelines and oversight. Faced with reports of gay partners turned away by workers at the Family Assistance Center at Pier 94, the charity issued 16 criteria for determining a "financially interdependent" couple; trained volunteers to interview same-sex partners; and appointed an ombudsman to oversee their cases.
The emergency funds made available after Sept. 11 came too late for Mike Lyons of Jersey City, who saw his partner of 18 years, John Keohane, killed by falling debris as the two fled the collapsing towers. Mr. Lyons, unemployed and suffering from multiple sclerosis, was slow to apply for financial assistance, and was running out of money when he committed suicide on March 1.
Emergency aid kept Margaret Cruz afloat after the loss of her partner of 18 years, Patricia McAneney. Ms. McAneney's brother and sister-in-law filed for both government and charitable funds. By law, they are entitled $50,000 in Workers Compensation. But Ms. Cruz documented her financially interdependent partnership and prevailed with the Crime Victim's Board, the Red Cross and the New York State charitable fund. A total of $80,000 went to Ms. McAneney.
No decisions will mean more financially than those made by Mr. Feinberg, who supervises a fund created by Congress, as part of the airline bailout package, to compensate survivors of the terrorist attacks in return for their promise not to sue. Awards are expected to average $1.85 million per family; the calculation depends on the number of people entitled to money, among other criteria, and could grow if next of kin and a domestic partner jointly apply. 
"Some, I can't say most, will get generous awards," said Larry S. Stewart, a Miami lawyer who is the president of Trial Lawyers Care, a consortium of more than 1,200 lawyers offering free representation to the more than 3,000 eligible families, including some of the gay partners. "And that will create positive pressure for change." 
Many of the 22 surviving gay partners have not been accepted by the next of kin, seriously complicating their cases. William Randolph, for one, a part-time organist at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, lived in Harlem for 26 years with his partner, Wesley Mercer, vice president of corporate security at Morgan Stanley. Mr. Mercer helped save all but 2 of the company's 3,300 employees.
Mr. Mercer never divorced his wife, Mr. Randolph said, so she will receive his Army pension, Social Security and Workers Compensation. The Mercers had two children, one deceased and the other grown and financially independent. Mr. Randolph received a gift of $100,000 from Morgan Stanley, which was aware of the men's long-term relationship, and he also received help from the Crime Victims Board and the Red Cross.
Others, like David O'Leary of Yonkers, have the full backing of his partner's family and thus fit Mr. Feinberg's definition of an easy claim to adjudicate. Mr. O'Leary has tentatively begun the process by gathering documents as personal as birthday cards and family photographs and as bureaucratic at joint bank statements and utility bills.
Mr. O'Leary and Michael Lepore had lived together for 18 years and combined their assets in every way. Mr. Lepore's mother, Jean Carlucci, has already signed over her $50,000 lump sum payment from Workers Compensation. The youngest of Mr. Lepore's three brothers, Anthony, the executor of the estate, has given Mr. O'Leary momentos the survivors have greatly prized: the commemorative urn and flag from the city and choice seats at ground zero ceremonies, which he would otherwise have been denied.
"That's just how they have been," Mr. O'Leary said. "They look at me as Michael's spouse, and think everything should go to me."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 31, 2002

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about federal compensation awards to the same-sex partners of Sept. 11 victims referred imprecisely to legislation shelved by Congress that would have guaranteed compensation to survivors of the public safety officers who died without immediate next of kin. The legislation would have provided death benefits to the estates of 10 officers who died without spouses, children or living parents; it made no mention of their sexual orientation.

HEADLINE: The Body Scan, for Good or Ill 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 As a cardiologist who receives frequent panicked calls as heart scans have flourished, I must point out important problems created by the direct marketing of these scans (front page, May 27). 
 Driven by lucrative economics, many scans are performed ignoring a principal tenet of biostatistics, which considers pretest probability of disease. 
This approach minimizes falsely positive and negative results by recommending screening tests only to patients who are of moderate risk.
Bypassing the patient's doctor often leads to the panic witnessed by many cardiologists when a heart scan is labeled abnormal. Most of these centers do not have cardiologists available to make clinical sense of the results.
Whatever role research helps to define for heart scans as a screening test for coronary disease, the critical decisions of patient selection, test interpretation and patient counseling should be made by the patient's doctor or cardiologist, not initiated by the patient through an advertisement on TV or a highway billboard.

JONATHAN SCHARFSTEIN, M.D.
Shaker Heights, Ohio, May 27, 2002

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: Charges Dismissed In January Protest

BYLINE:  AP (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez)

 BODY:
 A judge yesterday dismissed charges that were filed against five protesters at the World Economic Forum in January. The police said they arrested the five demonstrators, all women, shortly after 7 a.m. on Jan. 31 and charged them with trespass and unlawful posting. 
They said the women had climbed a ladder to the roof of a Lower Manhattan building with a banner that read, "Bush and big biz agree that people with AIDS drop dead." Judge Gregory Carro of Manhattan Criminal Court said he dismissed the charges because they included no declaration from the landlord that the women had no right to be there and because the unlawful-posting count was not applicable to an abandoned building that is not owned by the city.

HEADLINE: Cuomo's False Start 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Andrew Cuomo, whose tone of voice has become almost a replica of his father's, would like his words to convey a sense of idealism -- the great things that can be accomplished with a life dedicated to public service. His frequent references to the Kennedys (he's married to Robert Kennedy's daughter Kerry) is in the service of that effort.
 But so far in Mr. Cuomo's campaign for governor of New York, it is not the idealism that has been thrust into the foreground, but the much less wholesome quality of cynicism. 
 The latest example was the way in which Mr. Cuomo turned his back last week on the state Democratic Party's nominating convention. He did it at the last minute after courting delegates for more than a year. Suddenly, as Carl McCall was about to pull off his expected huge victory at the convention, Mr. Cuomo announced that he would boycott the gathering and take his campaign "to the people" by collecting nominating petitions to get on the ballot for the Sept. 10 primary.
There was nothing wrong with what Mr. Cuomo did. He could have gotten on the ballot, even in a losing effort, by drawing 25 percent of the votes at the convention. And he can get on by collecting 15,000 signatures from voters around the state. It was his call.
But Mr. Cuomo has tried to give the impression that by going the petition route he is some kind of outsider who is distancing himself from the grubbiness of power politics so he can lead a reform movement that will transform politics and government in New York.
And that won't wash. For one thing, Mr. Cuomo would gladly have accepted the state party's nomination if he had been able to win it. Secondly, the idea that Mr. Cuomo is an outsider is silly. He's not just the son of Mario Cuomo, who was governor for three terms, he was Governor Cuomo's campaign manager and chief troubleshooter. He's married to a Kennedy. He's a former cabinet officer in the Clinton administration. He's a skilled fund-raiser. Power politics is Andrew Cuomo's natural environment.
Moreover, even as Mr. Cuomo is sprinting away from the state Democratic Party, he's welcoming the endorsement of the Liberal Party, an increasingly disheveled organization that worships at the shrine of patronage and shudders at the mere mention of reform.
Even Mr. Cuomo acknowledges that this might be problematic. He told me yesterday, "I understand the point that people believe the Liberal Party has used patronage in the past. That's not going to be my relationship with the Liberal Party."
Mr. Cuomo has not been playing his best cards in this campaign. I can recall the Andrew Cuomo who, in 1999, when he was secretary of the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, traveled the country to bring attention to those areas that, despite a booming economy, were still poor and still suffering. These included places like Guadalupe, Ariz., and Kasigluk, Alaska, and chronically depressed regions like Appalachia and the Mississippi Delta. 
This was a time when it took some courage for a major politician to talk seriously about fighting poverty. Mr. Cuomo would spotlight places that had been "left behind in the new economy," and he would argue that it was precisely when the economy was surging and the budget surplus was huge that the U.S. should find creative and effective ways to invest in those sections of the country that were hurting. 
"If not now," he asked, "when?"
That tone, and something close to that message, would likely play well in New York right now. The upstate economy is hurting. And New York City is still suffering from the combined effects of an economic downturn and the terrorist attacks. The national economy is no longer the bulwark it was, but that just means there is more of a need than ever to come up with answers that are creative and effective.
The missteps in the Cuomo campaign, and there have been others not mentioned here, undermine the idealism that the candidate sees as an essential part of his message.
If Mr. Cuomo is going to invoke the memory of Robert F. Kennedy, which he does, and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., which he does, then he has an obligation to run a campaign that is worthy of their legacies. 
He's got some time. The better Andrew needs to step forward.

HEADLINE: The Most Dangerous Place in the World 

BYLINE:  By Salman Rushdie; Salman Rushdie is the author of "Fury: A Novel" and the forthcoming essay collection "Step Across This Line."

 BODY:
The present Kashmir crisis feels like a deja vu replay of the last one. Three years ago a weak Indian coalition government led by the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party had just lost a confidence vote in India's Parliament and was nervously awaiting a general election. At once it began to beat the war drums over Kashmir. Now another coalition government, still led by the B.J.P. and deeply tainted by B.J.P. supporters' involvement in the massacre of hundreds of Muslims in Gujarat State, may be about to lose another general election. So here goes the government again, talking up a Kashmiri war and asking India to stand firm behind its leadership. 
 Three years ago in Pakistan, the equally weak government of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif had bankrupted the national economy and was facing well-documented corruption charges. Mr. Sharif, too, had much to gain from war fever -- fed by the various Muslim terrorist groups operating in Kashmir. The hawkish Pakistani general then responsible for communicating with and training those terrorist groups was one Pervez Musharraf. (By the way -- just so we're clear on who Mr. Musharraf, now Pakistan's president, really is -- some of these groups were almost certainly sent by Pakistan's intelligence service to Qaeda training camps in Afghanistan.) When Nawaz Sharif succumbed to American pressure and promised to rein in the terrorists, General Musharraf was furious. A few months later he overthrew Mr. Sharif in a coup and seized power. 
 Will the outcome also be a replay of three years ago? Will the conflict be contained again?
This time President Musharraf is the one being pressed by the United States to stamp out Kashmiri terrorism. He has been playing a double game, arresting hundreds of members of the groups he once fostered but quietly freeing most of them soon afterward. Caught between two necessities -- placating his major international sponsor and playing to the home audience -- he may well in the end follow his deepest political instincts: to support (overtly or covertly) the Islamist radicals who have terrorized the once idyllic valley of Kashmir for well over a decade.
Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee of India, with his talk of a "decisive battle," clearly feels that direct military action, resulting in the reconquest of some if not all of the Kashmiri territory now under Pakistani control, is the only way of preventing attacks like the atrocity this month in which women and children were slaughtered at an Indian army base. Mr. Vajpayee knows that Indian rule is unpopular in the valley, that the Indian army looks to many Kashmiris like an army of occupation. But he will also have calculated that in the opinion of the international community, and also of many fearful, near-destitute Kashmiris, Pakistan's protracted sponsorship of terrorism has damaged its claims to moral legitimacy.
Would a war between India and Pakistan, if it came, go nuclear?
Pakistan, with its suggestively timed missile tests, its refusal to adopt a policy of not being the first to use nuclear arms and its hawkish talk, is trying to give the impression that it would have no compunction about using its nuclear arsenal. India's military leadership has said that if attacked with nuclear bombs it would respond with maximum force and that in such a conflict India would sustain heavy damage but survive, whereas Pakistan would be destroyed utterly.
Is it really likely, however, that Pakistan would, so to speak, strap a nuclear weapon to its belly, walk into the crowded bazaar that is India and turn itself into the biggest suicide bomber in history?
Mr. Musharraf doesn't look like martyr material. Ah, but if he were losing a conventional war? If India's overwhelming numerical superiority on land, at sea and in the air won the day and Pakistan lost its prized Kashmiri land, would reason be swept aside? Worst of all, if Pakistani fury at a military defeat by India were to result in Mr. Musharraf's overthrow by Islamist hard-liners, Pakistan's nuclear warheads could fall into the hands of people for whom martyrdom is a higher goal than peace, people who value death more highly than life.
Pakistan is calling on the international community to intervene, but this call must be heard with caution. For half a century Pakistan has sought to internationalize the Kashmiri dispute while India has consistently described that effort as interference in its internal affairs. Both sides are locked into old language, old strategies and an old game of chicken that's currently playing itself out across the Line of Control. Like two aged wrestlers fighting on a cliff, India and Pakistan are locked together, rolling ever closer to the edge.
But their ancient hatred is no longer a matter only for them. The risk of a nuclear battle, however improbable, makes Kashmir everybody's problem. Right now it's the most dangerous place in the world. These pathetic old fighters must be pulled apart, and soon. Yes, that probably does mean intervention by the West, though Russia seems eager to help as well, which is useful.
This should not, however, be the intervention that Pakistan wants. The point is not to restrain Indian "aggression," but to make the world safer for us all. The situation can only be stabilized if India and Pakistan are both forced to back away, preferably to outside of Kashmir's historic, unpartitioned borders. This "hands off Kashmir" solution will have to be externally imposed on the reluctant principals and will require that a large peacekeeping force be sent to the region to support Kashmir as an autonomous area. But who in the West wants that -- it's just the old colonialist-imperialist power trip, isn't it? And who's supposed to pay for all this peacekeeping, anyway?
The answers to those questions are also questions: What's the alternative? Do you have a better idea? Or shall we just stand back and keep our postcolonial, nonimperialist fingers crossed? Will it take mushroom clouds over Delhi and Islamabad to make us give up our ingrained prejudices and try something that might actually work? In the immortal words of the Spice Girls, "Will this deja vu never end?"
