HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
In numbers we trust, provided they're safe from political meddling.

BYLINE:  By Alan B. Krueger; Alan B. Krueger is the Bendheim professor of economics and public affairs at Princeton University and editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. E-mail: akrueger@princeton.edu.

 BODY:
FEW people have heard of the Office of Management and Budget's Statistical Policy Directive No. 3, but it affects the way economic news is discussed and is a cornerstone for trust in federal statistics like the unemployment rate and Consumer Price Index.
 Among other things, the directive prevents political appointees from publicly commenting on sensitive economic indicators until at least an hour after the professionals who produce the data have had a chance to explain the findings. It also restricts those within the government who can receive sensitive data early. 
 The directive was initially put in place in the early 1970's, after the Nixon administration commented that a drop of two-tenths of a percentage point in the unemployment rate was significant, only to be contradicted by a career employee of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, who pointed out that the drop did not cross the threshold for statistical significance. 
The goals of the directive are laudable: to "strike a balance between timeliness and accuracy, prevent early access to information that may affect financial and commodity markets, and preserve the distinction between the policy-neutral release of data by statistical agencies and their interpretation by policy officials." The practices it establishes prevent political meddling.
Some officials have found that the directive makes it difficult to spin the numbers for political advantage -- exactly as intended. 
President Bill Clinton occasionally found it hard to resist commenting on the numbers before an hour had lapsed. 
Last year, the labor secretary, Elaine L. Chao, sent a memo to the White House budget director, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., openly requesting a change in policy "to address the contemporary political climate." 
"The advent of the 24-hour news cycle, known as the 'CNN Effect,' " she argued, "has rendered this policy obsolete. Reporters from each network cover the announcement live at 8:30 a.m., and pundits begin to offer their interpretations immediately after the data has been made public.
She added: "Preventing the executive branch from presenting its point of view in the first hour has become a distinct disadvantage, as the tone of the analysis and debate is often already determined by the time an hour has passed." 
Ms. Chao requested that senior administration officials be permitted to comment on federal data immediately after their release to "clarify the issues," and that they be given access to data a day early to "formulate a coherent policy." (Ordinarily, the labor secretary is briefed on the unemployment rate by the Bureau of Labor Statistics half an hour before the data are released, but Ms. Chao has opted not to participate in such briefings.) 
The budget office wisely decided not to change Directive No. 3. 
The issue of who gets what when is of critical importance for economic statistics, as well as central intelligence. The procedures specify that the Council of Economic Advisers receives principal economic indicators as soon as they are available. 
The council passes the information on to the president; the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan; and the Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill. 
Mr. Greenspan also has an agreement with the Bureau of Labor Statistics to receive monthly employment data for manufacturing, mining and public utilities two or three days early, ostensibly so the Fed can produce its industrial production statistics on a timely basis, though those figures are not released until 10 to 17 days later. Surely, the chairman's reason for wanting the data early is a ruse; he wants an advanced hint at where the economy is headed. 
It is an interesting question whether it makes sense for the Fed chairman and Treasury secretary to receive the information before everyone else. Providing prerelease data may make the chairman seem omniscient and help the Fed and Treasury outfox the markets, but it is unclear whether these advantages increase or decrease market volatility and raise economic growth.
In a paper presented at the Fed's symposium in Jackson Hole, Wyo., last summer, Michael Woodford, a Princeton macroeconomist, argued that "monetary policy can be even more effective" when information is more rapidly disseminated to the private sector. 
In addition, privileged access raises the level of cynicism by market participants. 
With hundreds of billions of dollars of government spending and tax receipts directly tied to federal statistics, the hurdle to persuade the public that the numbers are free from political meddling is high.
The statistical agencies take many precautions to inspire confidence in government data. Virtually all the agencies' work is done by career employees protected by the civil service system; the Bureau of Labor Statistics has only one political appointee; the Census Bureau, four; and the Bureau of Economic Analysis, none. 
Nevertheless, trust in federal statistics is low. Robert Shiller of Yale found in a 1996 public opinion survey that slightly more Americans agreed than disagreed with this statement: "An important reason not to trust contracts indexed to inflation is that someone in the government might deliberately falsify the inflation numbers to take advantage of people like me."
Although such concerns are ludicrous to anyone who has observed the dedication, nonpartisanship and professionalism of the employees of federal statistical agencies, public cynicism toward government statistics runs deep.
The word "statistics" originally meant "state arithmetic." Objective, credible statistics are essential for government, business and personal decisions -- and for the operation of democracy itself. It is important that strong safeguards be maintained to prevent even the appearance of political meddling with the data, and that senior government officials appreciate the justification for such safeguards.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook; 
Playing the Bad Cop on the African Tour

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 29 

 BODY:
In his 16 months as treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill has developed a reputation as a straight shooter, in the view of his admirers, or a loose cannon, as his detractors see it.
 Either way, he has been true to form as he has traveled through Africa for the last 10 days on a fact-finding trip with Bono, the rock star and social activist. 
 He has bluntly questioned whether decades of aid from rich nations has done much to alleviate poverty, and he has voiced suspicions that much of it has been lost to inefficiency and corruption.
"Where does the money go?" he asked in exasperation during a discussion of World Bank programs in Uganda the other day. 
After just a few days in Africa, he began offering prescriptions for dealing with two issues that governments and relief organizations have been grappling with for decades. Everyone should have access to clean water more or less immediately, he said, and every school should have at least one book per child.
In both cases, he suggested that substantial progress could be made within a year or two and waved off warnings from people with long experience in Africa that the problems were more complicated than he was making them out to be.
"I know how to buy a book," Mr. O'Neill told representatives of poverty-fighting groups in Uganda, explaining that he was a "systems guy" who knew how to make things happen. "So I'm going to take away the excuse of books. Right now. End of subject. I'm going to take away the subject of water. No more conversation about it."
For the first week of the trip, his appearances with Bono tended to follow a pattern. Bono, the lead singer of U2, would note the success of whatever internationally financed project they were visiting -- a school, a well, a health clinic -- and press the United States to make a further commitment to direct aid and debt relief. Mr. O'Neill would then ask why more had not been accomplished in the past and why programs were not moving more quickly and effectively now.
The trip is being covered by everyone from MTV to The Economist. Stories about the trip have tended to highlight the debate, and the occasional tension, between the two men.
Treasury officials started complaining to reporters that Mr. O'Neill was being portrayed as opposing aid, when in fact the administration was supporting substantial increases. Flying into Ethiopia on Tuesday night, Mr. O'Neill even vented his anger directly at the press corps over how he was being cast.
But today, Mr. O'Neill had apparently decided that he was not presenting his views as clearly as he had intended. So at a news conference here this morning, he made a straightforward statement.
"Programs are working, aid is helping and standards of living are improving," he said. "But more needs to be done, and it needs to be done right and it needs to be done right now."

The Star, as Opening Act
Bono is the main media attraction on the trip. But ordinary Africans and their leaders appear much more interested in Mr. O'Neill, the man who controls the American checkbook, or at least is perceived to do so.
Mr. O'Neill arrives with some theater of his own, a dozen-vehicle motorcade that screams down dusty streets with a police escort.
There is potential political benefit for the administration from images of Mr. O'Neill meeting some of the world's most disadvantaged people in the company of one of the world's best-known rockers. That may explain why the administration sent Mark McKinnon, who was George W. Bush's media and image consultant during the 2000 presidential campaign, to stage-manage the photo opportunities. 
Bono is well known among grass-roots activists in Africa, many of whom he has visited quietly over his years of involvement on the continent. But most ordinary Africans do not seem to have a clue who he is, even when he sings for the crowds that the duo encounters.
Asked by a worker at a Ford factory in South Africa who he represented, Bono replied that he was C.E.O. of the U2 Corporation.

Wells From Heaven
Mr. O'Neill says he is in Africa to listen and learn. But he has spent much of the trip making back-of-the-envelope calculations of what it would cost to ensure that every African has access to clean water.
In Uganda, he calculated, less than $25 million would solve the problem for 10 million people.
Representatives of poverty-fighting organizations said they were grateful for Mr. O'Neill's interest -- but they accused him of a tendency he derides in others, of jumping to conclusions based on incomplete or anecdotal information.
Thomas Overton, of Save the Children, told Mr. O'Neill that he had failed to take into account the costs and difficulties of maintaining wells in countries where there are few skilled workers to look after them and a shortage of spare parts.
"It's not enough," Mr. Overton said during lunch with Mr. O'Neill, "just to drop a well down in the middle of a community."

HEADLINE: Libyan Money For Flight 103 Isn't Remorse, U.S. Says 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29 

 BODY:
An offer by Libya to pay $2.7 billion to the families of those killed in the bombing of Pam Am Flight 103 was thrown into doubt today when the United States rejected a key part of the deal and the Libyan government reportedly denied that it had anything to do with the offer. 
 United States government officials and a lawyer representing families of 118 victims said the Libyan government had offered to pay $10 million for each of the 270 people who died in the 1988 bombing. 
 But payment of the money is conditional on the lifting of United Nations and United States sanctions and the removal of Libya from the State Department's list of countries that sponsor terrorism. 
Today, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell called the reported offer a "step in the right direction." But he added: "We are waiting to see what the actual Libyan offer is. It's not yet formally put on the table, and we'll examine it when we see all of its elements."
The the State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said the offer fell short of what was needed to end the sanctions. 
"U.N. resolutions require the Libyans to satisfy four requirements related to the Pan Am 103 bombing before the sanctions are lifted," Mr. Boucher said. "Paying adequate, appropriate compensation is one of these requirements. The other requirements relate to responsibility -- acceptance of responsibility, disclosing information and renouncing terrorism."
Mr. Boucher added that until the sanctions were lifted, Libya could not be removed from the list of states that sponsor terrorism. 
The United States has imposed sanctions on Libya since the 1980's. After American investigators said Libya was responsible for the Pan Am bombing over Lockerbie, Scotland, Washington successfully petitioned the Security Council to impose additional economic and diplomatic sanctions, which went into effect in 1992-93. 
Last year a Scottish court convened in the Netherlands convicted Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al-Megrahi, a Libyan intelligence official, of murder for his role in the bombing. He is serving a life sentence.
The Libyan government, which has denied any role in the bombing, made Mr. Megrahi available for trial as part of an arrangement that included a suspension of the United Nations sanctions. But the Libyans are still pressing for their permanent removal. 
But today, JANA, the Libyan government news agency, quoted a Libyan spokesman as saying: "Libya is not part of this issue. As far as the Libyan state is concerned, it has not been accused in this issue and it has nothing to do with any accords." 
JANA quoted the spokesman as saying that all Libya knew was that Libyan business executives, joined by legal experts, had met with families of the victims but did not inform Libya officially of the outcome.

HEADLINE: Mexico Misses Deadline for Water-Debt Plan 

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, May 29 

 BODY:
President Vicente Fox will not meet a deadline for a plan to pay Mexico's enormous water debt to the United States, Mr. Fox's aides said today.
 Mexico owes 456 billion gallons under a 1944 treaty, a debt run up over a decade. Mr. Fox promised President Bush two weeks ago that on May 30, he would announce a strategy to pay off the debt. But today there is no plan to divide the waters of the Rio Grande, which divides Texas and Mexico along a 1,250-mile border, and there will not be one tomorrow, the aides said. 
 The Rio Grande valley is a semiarid place where millions depend on other people's water for their economic existence. Severe water shortages are creating social and political strains on both sides of the river.
Mr. Fox's aides now say it will take five years or more to pay the debt. To honor it by this summer, as Texas has requested, is impossible, said Alberto Szekely, the national water secretary. "Not even draining all the reservoirs would satisfy that demand," he said.
The United States ambassador, Jeffrey Davidow, acknowledges that Mexico is a thirsty land but says it could begin paying its some of its due tomorrow. "Let's share the water that there is," he said. "The suffering has to be shared."
There is enough suffering to go around, to be sure, but not enough water. Thousands of farmers on both sides of the border, gripped by an eight-year drought, stand to lose their crops, in part because Mexico has not allowed enough water to flow to the Rio Grande. Texans are especially aggrieved because Mr. Fox now has twice promised to pay the debt, accumulated by two past Mexican presidents.
Mr. Fox's close relations with Washington will be hurt if he cannot come up with a plan. His inability to deliver quickly on his personal pledge to Mr. Bush to solve the water crisis is raising questions about his ability to govern.
"Vicente Fox is trying to pay an accumulated debt of corruption, environmental degradation and administrative negligence," said Sergio Aguayo, a leading political analyst in Mexico.
But, he added, "one of this president's flaws is that he announces things before he accomplishes them." The water debt, left unpaid, "will contaminate his other problems" with the United States, including an impasse over immigration and economic development issues, Mr. Aguayo said.
Mexico wants the United States to help finance millions of dollars in improvements to its irrigation and wastewater treatment facilities to help meet its debt. Beyond that, farmers and politicians alike are facing the fact that drought and demand may alter the way people live along the river.
Since the 1944 treaty, irrigated agriculture has flooded the dry lands of the Rio Grande basin, feeding thirsty crops like citrus and sugar cane in a semidesert.
"There must be fundamental change in the ways water's being used on both sides of the border," said George Kourous, an expert on border issues at the Interhemispheric Resource Center, a research group in New Mexico.
Those changes should include both governments "sitting down together and working on a plan," said Mary Kelly, executive director of the Texas Center for Policy Studies, an environmental group in Austin. "Times change. Economies change. And water management policies have to change with them."

HEADLINE: Wrong Way on Energy 

 BODY:
An administration staffed with aggressive corporate executives might normally be expected to embrace cutting-edge solutions to the country's energy problems -- especially when those solutions are accessible and affordable. Yet such is the Bush administration's ideological suspicion of anything resembling top-down government that it recoils from using timely federal regulation to encourage technological advance. The obvious example has been its reluctance to pressure Detroit for more fuel-efficient vehicles. A more recent example is its decision last week to roll back Clinton-era energy efficiency standards for air-conditioners. Seven states have sued to reverse the decision, and one of them, California, is seeking to impose its own, stricter standards. That is a course that New York's governor, George Pataki, should consider. 
 At the end of his term, after six years of consultation, President Bill Clinton approved a regulation requiring a 30 percent efficiency increase for central air-conditioners (not the window units most New Yorkers are familiar with). The Bush administration put the rule on hold and then last week imposed its own, lesser standard of a 20 percent increase. That's more of a difference than it seems, economically and environmentally. By 2020, the lower standard could cost consumers an extra $1 billion a year to run their air-conditioners. It could also result in extra greenhouse gas emissions, equivalent to the annual output of 1.7 million cars. 
 Most manufacturers have the ability to produce the more efficient units. But except for the second-largest maker, Goodman Manufacturing, none of the big companies wanted to proceed with the Clinton rule. They argued, and the Bush administration agreed, that the Clinton standard would make air-conditioners too expensive for low-income families and discourage others from replacing older systems. In actual fact, the up-front cost difference between the 20 and 30 percent standards is about $100 per unit -- an amount that could be recovered through electricity savings in three to five years.
Many states had hoped that Congress would come to their rescue by mandating the 30 percent increase. But a provision requiring such an increase lost narrowly in the Senate. California has thus decided to proceed on its own to the higher standard, which will require a federal waiver. Attorneys general in a half-dozen other states, including New York's Eliot Spitzer, have chosen to sue on grounds that federal law prevents government from rolling back existing standards. We hope they prevail. In some parts of the country, air-conditioners of all kinds account for nearly one-third of the electricity consumed during peak demand periods. The highest possible standards are clearly in order.

HEADLINE: U.S. MAY BUY BACK FLORIDA OIL RIGHTS 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER and CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29 

 BODY:
President Bush vowed today that the federal government would spend $235 million to buy back oil and natural gas rights in the Everglades and off the white-sand beaches of the Florida Panhandle.
 Administration officials said the agreement, if approved by Congress, would ultimately protect about 765,000 acres in three preserves in the Everglades, the Big Cypress National Preserve, Florida Panther National Wildlife Refuge and Ten Thousand Islands National Wildlife Refuge. 
 Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida said the action made sense for the environment but acknowledged that it was also likely to help his re-election campaign. 
As the two Bush brothers sat side by side in the Oval Office, the president announced a proposal to pay the wealthy Collier family of Florida about $120 million for mineral rights under the three preserves, which are home to several endangered species. President Bush also announced an agreement to pay $115 million to three oil companies, including the ChevronTexaco Corporation, to buy out offshore oil and gas leases, effectively preventing drilling about 25 miles south of Pensacola.
Florida politicians of both parties have joined state voters to fiercely resist drilling off the coast for nearly two decades, setting the state apart from Gulf states like Texas, Alabama and Louisiana, which have welcomed offshore drilling.
Facing a similar outcry over the prospect of drilling near the Florida Keys off southwestern Florida, the Clinton administration in 1995 bought back 73 leases for about $200 million.
"Florida is known worldwide for its beautiful coastal waters and the Everglades," President Bush said in a statement issued after a 20-minute meeting in the Oval Office. "Today we are acting to preserve both."
Environmental groups praised the president's plan, but some said it was politically motivated. 
"It's a great move for Florida, but it's essentially a $235 million campaign contribution from the taxpayer's pocket to re-elect Jeb Bush," said Philip Clapp, the president of the National Environmental Trust.
Other environmentalists said the president's decision reflected a double standard, particularly when the Bush administration has moved aggressively to open up the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska to oil and gas drilling, a policy rejected last month by the Senate.
"We hope this signals a change in the administration's approach to energy security," said Lisa Speer, a policy analyst at the Natural Resources Defense Council in New York. 
Both Jeb Bush and administration officials said today that there was nothing inconsistent about a White House that was effectively opposed to drilling in Florida and in favor of it in Alaska.
"I find nothing ironic about it at all," Jeb Bush said. "Each one of these cases needs to be looked at in terms of the balance -- to preserve the natural environment or the economic interests of a state." 
Governor Bush made no effort to dispute the political benefits. Asked if his 2002 campaign would benefit from his brother's action, he replied, "I hope so."
Then he added, "But more importantly, it is good public policy, and when here's a convergence of good politics and good public policy, I don't think we should be ashamed about it."
Representative Mark Foley, Republican of Florida, said today that there was "no question" that today's action would help the president's re-election chances in Florida, which he won by only 537 votes in 2000. 
The White House said the president had based his decision on community opinion.
"The president believes it is important to work closely with states and local communities and listen to their concerns," said Scott McClellan, a White House spokesman. "In Alaska, there is strong state and local community support for opening a small portion of ANWR to environmentally responsible exploration."
David B. Struhs, Florida's secretary of environmental protection, said Jeb Bush did not have to lean hard on his brother to oppose drilling in Florida.
"Let's put it this way," Mr. Struhs said. "There were 16 million Floridians all leaning in the same direction. Jeb Bush was 16 million and one."
Congressional aides said today that approval of the agreement on the Everglades was not assured, suggesting that there could be resistance on both fiscal and political grounds. 
Under the proposal, the Colliers, a pioneer Florida family with vast landholdings in the state, would transfer mineral rights on about 347,000 acres that it could have explored for oil in exchange for $120 million in cash or credits for future oil bids.
The deal was negotiated between the administration and descendants of Barron Gift Collier, who used a fortune built in streetcar advertising in the early 1900's to buy 1.3 million acres of southwestern Florida that eventually became Collier and Hendry Counties. The family has over the years turned over 260,000 acres to the government through swaps, sales and donations, including the original 76,000 acres for Big Cypress. Family members have made contributions to President Bush and Republican causes but have also supported Democratic candidates.
The payment to the three companies will settle a suit brought in July 2000 by Chevron, Conoco Inc. and the Murphy Exploration and Production Company, a unit of the Murphy Oil Corporation. The companies said they were being blocked from extracting oil and natural gas from tracts that the federal government sold them in the 1980's. Two of 11 leases in a geologic formation known as the Destin Dome would be reserved for possible exploration by Murphy after 2012 but only if the state and federal governments agreed.
Longtime opponents of drilling welcomed the agreement.
"We think this is a fantastic victory for Florida's coast," said Mark Ferrulo, director of the Florida Public Interest Research Group. While he said the opponents would have preferred that all 11 leases be relinquished, he said the group could "live with" the suspension of the two leases until 2012 as long as the state had veto power over drilling.
Fred R. Gorell, a spokesman for ChevronTexaco, said the payments would allow the company to recover its expenses on the project.
"While we are very disappointed that we will not be able to develop the Destin Dome resource, this settlement address the concerns of the parties involved and reimburses us for the investment we have made to date," Mr. Gorell said, adding that his company's share of the money would be $46 million.
According to the suit filed in 2000, the companies acquired the leases for $10.5 million but spent heavily on exploration activities, increasing their investment to an estimated $100 million.

HEADLINE: Labor Dispute to Halt Most Aer Lingus Flights 

BYLINE:  By BRIAN LAVERY 

DATELINE: DUBLIN, May 29 

 BODY:
The drastic plans of a management trying to stave off bankruptcy and the resolve of a union determined to hold its own are set to collide Thursday, largely grounding Aer Lingus, the state-owned Irish airline.
 At stake, besides the travel plans of 20,000 passengers a day, is the airline's future as a viable business that the Irish government badly wants to sell, with possible repercussions for other planned privatizations of enterprises like the national electric and gas utilities. 
 The unionized pilots at Aer Lingus will stage a one-day strike on Thursday, grounding the airline's fleet and forcing the cancellation of most of its 180 flights, including those due to carry thousands of Irish soccer fans to Japan and South Korea for the start of the World Cup soccer tournament on Saturday.
Aer Lingus has hired outside aircraft and pilots to provide a skeleton service on the airline's most important routes that day, including the daily trans-Atlantic flight to New York and shuttle flights to Heathrow Airport in London. 
But it has canceled all flights on Friday and Saturday and has said it will consider daily the restarting of operations after that, with the board meeting on Thursday to discuss options for Sunday. The move took the union by surprise and introduced an aggressive new tone to Irish labor relations.
"Clearly, the company has set itself the goal of breaking the union in this dispute," said Michael Landers, assistant general secretary and pilots' representative at the union, known as Impact. "It's intimidation and bully-boy tactics of the highest order."
Willie Walsh, a former Aer Lingus pilot who last fall became the airline's fifth chief executive in three years, has so far played a quiet role in the conflict, and he is not well known in business circles here. "He likes to win," Mr. Landers said. "And I don't think he thinks he has won unless you've lost."
The pilots object to new scheduling arrangements that cut the required rest between flights from 12 to 10 hours. Seven pilots have been suspended without pay for refusing to fly after 10 hours off, and a pilots' association has placed large advertisements in newspapers arguing that the reduced rest period threatens passenger safety. 
The scheduling change is one of many measures in a drastic survival plan adopted earlier this year after a disastrous 2001. The hoof-and-mouth outbreak in England and the terror attacks on Sept. 11 both caused sharp declines in Aer Lingus's passenger loads; by December the airline was hemorrhaging nearly $2 million in cash a day. It lost 140 million euros ($130 million) for the year.
The airline says the survival plan is now nonnegotiable, because a government labor relations mediator has already brokered sacrifices and compromises for various parts of the company that have been accepted by every employee group except the pilots. "That is something that we will not compromise on," said Dan Loughrey, Aer Lingus's group corporate affairs director. "It's just very, very clear that we must get this implemented if the company is to have a viable future." The pilots have accepted some other steps, like a two-year wage freeze.
According to Mr. Loughrey, flights had to be canceled for Friday and Saturday because the strike on Thursday will have effects that last into the middle of next week, in particular by disrupting staffing for the trans-Atlantic routes.
"I don't think the management are bluffing," said Colum McCarthy, economist with DKM, consultants in Dublin. "A one-day strike is very destructive to an airline."
In years gone by, the Irish government would have stepped in like a heavy-handed parent to manage a conflict like this. But European Union rules now strictly limit the financial aid that national governments can give airlines, even state-owned ones, and the government minister who oversees Aer Lingus lost her seat in Parliament in the election two weeks ago; her successor will not be appointed for at least another week.
Industry experts say that shutting service on the national airline will be devastating for tourism, a crucial industry here. "This is a very bad message that we're sending out, that you can't get in or out of the country," Tony Brazil, president of the Irish Association of Travel Agents, told RTE Radio.
Aer Lingus has suffered in recent years at the hands of new entrants like Ryanair, especially on short-haul routes. Ryanair, Europe's biggest discount airline, carries 10.5 million passengers a year with just 1,500 employees, while Aer Lingus employs 6,000 people to carry 6 million passengers, according to Sean Barrett, an economics professor at Trinity College, Dublin. Aer Lingus has already shed more than 2,000 jobs, but "there is no doubt that it is still a substantially overmanned operation," he said.

HEADLINE: Western Companies Warm to Russia 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 29 

 BODY:
The seals of approval are coming thick and fast for President Vladimir V. Putin's Russia these days.
 Today, the European Union said it would recognize Russia as a market economy, an upgrading of its status under the union's trade regulations and a designation that Moscow had sought for years. In a statement, Romano Prodi, president of the union's executive body, the European Commission, called it "fit and proper" that the 15-nation union "reward the considerable efforts" Russia has made to remake its economy. 
 Just last week, President Bush was spreading smiles and handshakes in Moscow and talking approvingly of expanding commercial ties and American investment in Russia. 
These developments both ratify and give new impetus to a business trend that has been gathering speed recently: American and other Western companies doing business in Russia as if it were part of Europe and not outer space.
"For investors, it's very important to feel comfortable with the country as a whole," said Kiril Dmitriyev, an investment manager at Delta Capital Management, with $200 million invested in Russia. Recent events "raised confidence," he added. "Russia is becoming integrated into the world economy instead of staying alien."
Beyond confidence, there are also practical pluses of improved trade status. With more access to foreign markets, Russia is a more desirable place to invest. Fewer trade barriers would allow multinational companies to use Russia, where labor is cheap, as a production base for exporting to Europe. So far, however, foreign companies are setting up shop here to sell to the undeveloped Russian market with its 147 million people.
The Frito-Lay unit of PepsiCo is tending new acres of green potato fields just south of Moscow. General Motors and Ford Motor are each due to complete work on new car plants in Russia this summer. The American candy maker Mars recently bought a factory near Moscow to expand its food lines. Even Wal-Mart Stores has sent executives to look around, though the company is silent about particulars.
"We have far more meetings now," said Andrew Somers, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Moscow, adding that he recently helped Nike, Dow Chemical and even a midsize American kitchen fixtures maker get the lay of the land here. 
"They were looking at Russia not as an exotic planetary phenomenon but as an integral part of the European market," Mr. Somers said. "It was a refreshing change."
How fast the new era of good feeling will turn into big investment and trade numbers is another question. Russia is not yet an important export market or supplier to the United States directly -- it accounts for less than 1 percent of American trade annually -- and it has received only $5 billion in direct American investment over the last decade, one-eighth of the figure for China.
American businesspeople who have come to firsthand grips with the many petty frustrations of doing business here know why. 
Intel, for example, has been attracted to Russia for years, because of the large pool of capable programming talent available. But obstacles ranging from restrictive capital controls and irritating customs snags to poor copyright and contract-law enforcement have deterred the company from taking any equity stakes in local ventures.
"When we import computers for work, it takes an enormous amount of money," said Stephen Chase, president of Intel's Russian branch. "In this day and age, that is ridiculous. We see countries like China and India with their arms open. Russia is moving in the right direction, but will it take five months or five years?"
The same obstacles face European companies investing here, but many of them have the advantage of long experience and contacts stretching back to Soviet times, especially companies from nations like Sweden that were neutral in the cold war. Proximity also simplifies their dealings with Russia somewhat, especially in Russia's biggest export industry, energy.
Some of the investment that is beginning to flow into Russia is off the official statistical radar. Since January, according to Roland Nash of Renaissance Capital, a Moscow-based brokerage firm, foreign companies have made five major investments in Russia totaling more than $1 billion. But most of that went untallied because, technically, the deals were done and the assets transferred between entities incorporated outside Russia. 
"It's clear that it's happening, but the official figures aren't really picking up on it," Mr. Nash said.
Another sign of the changed climate is the flurry of new private equity funds that have set up shop here over the last six months. These funds buy stakes in companies that are not publicly traded, hoping to sell the holdings later at a profit to a multinational company or in a public offering.
"Russia stands out globally as being a hot place for raising private equity funds," said Michael Calvey, co-managing partner at Baring Vostok Capital Partners, which finished putting together a new $205 million fund in December.
A prime target for American investment. which President Bush mentioned last week, is Russia's vast energy sector, where foreign involvement has so far been fairly scarce. Last fall, Exxon Mobil broke the ice for big American companies by pledging $4 billion to begin developing oil fields off Russia's eastern coast, and BP, despite some bitter early experiences, increased its stake in a Russian oil company.
The industry sector that has attracted the largest share of the $20 billion or so in direct investment is food processing. As Russians' incomes rise, their habits change. More people have more money for snack foods and less time for food preparation. Also, the new choices are a welcome change from decades of Soviet central planning that paid little attention to people's needs.
"Russia is a great opportunity; the upside potential is huge," said John Stevenson, president of Frito-Lay in central Europe and Russia, where it spent $40 million on a potato chip factory. "It's not an effortless process. If you look like you're in a hurry, you're prone to be taken advantage of."
The Russian government says it will not be long before the hurdles and snags are ironed out and the biggest multinational companies will find Russia an easy and hospitable place to invest. But analysts and investors say the Russian economy will not be fully restored to health until there are ample opportunities for smaller companies as well, and that day may still be some time away.
"Russia needs more than the Fortune 500 companies to thrive," Mr. Stevenson said.

HEADLINE: HAVENS; 
WeekenderNew London, Conn.

BYLINE:  By JENNIE GREEN 

 BODY:
 ONE of the best things about New London, beyond its location on the shore of Long Island Sound at the mouth of the Thames River, is its total lack of congestion and pretension compared with the nearby towns of Stonington and Mystic. While they are primarily tourist destinations, New London is a city, with all of the benefits and drawbacks that cities have to offer. It is a complex place with ethnic and economic diversity, with both low-income housing and exclusive enclaves that have restricted access to pristine beaches and spectacular waterfront views. These days, New London appears to be in the process of reinventing itself, partly as a result of Pfizer's new global research and development headquarters on a previously abandoned 22-acre brownfield peninsula.

Beaches and Landmarks

Established in 1659, New London is a traditional waterfront community, with historic landmarks like the Nathan Hale School House (1755) and the New London Harbor Lighthouse (1801). The city is also home to the Coast Guard Academy and to Connecticut College. New London covers approximately 5.5 square miles, with a population of about 22,300. Weekend residents have plenty of malls, movie theaters, coffeehouses, and bookstores to visit on rainy days. But the city's most compelling resources are still the beaches, the quiet shady streets that smell like salt water and freshly cut grass, and the low tone of the foghorn on overcast days.

Free Time

At New London's crescent shaped Ocean Beach, you can wade in the sound, swim in an Olympic-size pool, or take the children to the state-of-the-art playground that was reconstructed last year. Ocean Beach Park also has a large water slide as well as a new nature walk along Alewife Cove. Boating is another popular activity, although owning is the way to go, because renting is difficult. The vehicle-free trail from Connecticut College to Fort Trumbull State Park is ideal for walking, running and biking. Harkness Memorial Park, which is pastoral and lush, is the site for evening music concerts throughout the summer. The Eugene O'Neill Playwrights Conference continues to thrive; so does the newly renovated Guard Theater, home to both plays and movies. Ferry service to Block Island, Foxwoods Casino and Eastern Long Island is regular.

Looking for Houses

New London real estate tends to be divided into two categories: waterfront, with private beach rights, or not. An idyllic place to buy is within the Neptune Park Beach Association, where residents share four private beaches along a winding seawall that is contiguous to Ocean Beach. Currently, there is one five-bedroom house for sale in that neighborhood for $695,000, according to Re/Max Property Consultants in Groton. Along Pequot Avenue, which runs along the water and where the houses also have private beach rights and lighthouse views, a three-bedroom, two-bath, 1,700-square-foot home is on the market for $350,000; a three-bedroom, four-bath, 3,678-square-foot house with a deck is $580,000. Go a block or two inland, however, and you can buy a 2,000-square-foot colonial-style house for $179,900 -- just a short bike ride from Ocean Beach.
Traditionally, New London has drawn weekend residents from Hartford and Springfield, Mass., while New Yorkers have gravitated toward quaint, rural towns like Essex, Old Lyme and Stonington. "But that's beginning to change," said Cynthia Clegg, a representative of the Chamber of Commerce. "As New London evolves, it becomes increasingly recognized as this funky town. It is also part of the last preserve along the New England shoreline." 

Shops and Galleries

Manhattanites who rarely get the chance to zip into vast parking lots might find the expansive Crystal Mall a refreshing change, as well as the nearby Target and the Wal-Mart in Groton. There are also small shops and galleries like the Alva Art Gallery and Yah-Ta-Hey Gallery, and a farmers' market every weekend. Specialty food shops include Jacques Fruit Store, Lee's Oriental Market and Saeed's International Market.

Pizza and Seafood

If you like New England-style pizza -- with a thicker crust that's crispy on the bottom -- go directly to the Ocean Pizza Palace on Ocean Avenue. Eat fried seafood or grilled hot dogs outside at Captain Scott's Lobster Dock or Fred's Shanty. Timothy's is an upscale choice for American food, while Schooner's is nice for surf and turf with water views. The Lighthouse Inn has a new owner and a chef who once worked for Clint Eastwood. Ethnic restaurants include Bangkok City Thai Cuisine, Little Tokyo, Zavala (a Mexican restaurant) and Golden Wok.

Getting There
The toughest thing about getting to New London is getting out of Manhattan. Once you pick up I-95 in the northeast Bronx, it's a straight, two-hour shot north to Exit 75. The bus from Port Authority and the train from Penn Station on Amtrak take two hours to downtown New London.

GRAPHIC: Photo: SIGHTS AND SAND -- The city, which offers both urban style and pristine beaches, is seen here from Fort Trumbull, a state historical park built during the Revolutionary War to defend the harbor. (C. M. Glover for The New York Times) Map of Connecticut highlighting New London.

HEADLINE: ON STAGE AND OFF 

BYLINE:  By Jesse McKinley 

 BODY:
New Ideas For Next Season
While the bigwigs of Broadway will spend the weekend celebrating the end of this season, producers Off Broadway are completing plans for the next one.
 It has been a rough year for many downtown troupes; beyond the effects of Sept. 11 and the lingering recession, several also lost their homes. One of those was the MCC Theater, which lost the lease on its space at 120 West 28th Street in Chelsea, where the company had been since 1990. 
 Its 2002-03 season will be spent uptown, at the brand new Shubert 42nd Street theater complex, at 410 West 42nd Street in Clinton, on the refurbished Theater Row. Once the company settles in, it plans to continue its mission of producing challenging new plays by new writers. 
One of those writers, Kate Robin, may be familiar to fans of HBO's "Six Feet Under"; she is the executive story editor of that show. Ms. Robin is also the author of "Intrigue With Faye," a new play about a paranoid urban couple who decide to videotape each other's every move to encourage a sense of trust. (What a great idea.) Without giving away the ending, things go awry. MCC will stage "Faye" next season, though exactly when is uncertain.
At the Atlantic Theater Company, meanwhile, the artistic director Neil Pepe has signed the acclaimed Irish writer Conor McPherson ("The Weir") to direct Mr. McPherson's 1999 play, "Dublin Carol," which will be receiving its New York premiere. The story of a middle-aged undertaker with personal troubles (the family, the bottle), this three-character drama had been expected to come to New York this season, but was delayed by scheduling problems. Those have cleared up. Mr. McPherson arrives in September for casting; rehearsals begin in January.
Mr. McPherson, 30, has just finished directing a film, "The Actors," starring Michael Caine as an unemployed actor who seeks alternate, and nefarious, streams of income. (It's not waiting tables.) 
"I never know where my ideas come from," Mr. McPherson said yesterday, speaking from Dublin. "I'm just grateful when they come."
"Dublin Carol" will be presented with David Richenthal, the Broadway producer who holds the play's commercial rights. 
Also on the Atlantic agenda for 2002-03 is George S. Kaufman's 1925 comedy "Butter and Egg Man," about a Midwestern rube who decides to become a Broadway producer. (What a great idea.) The show, to be directed by David Pittu, had been planned for this season, but was bumped to make room for a revival of "Hobson's Choice."
New York Theater Workshop in the East Village also delayed a production this season, Caryl Churchill's "Far Away," which wowed London critics when it opened in November 2000 but was pushed back because of the busy film schedule of the director, Stephen Daldry. Now, it will lead off a season that will include adaptations of two best-selling novels,
'Cavedweller," by Dorothy Allison, and Michael Cunningham's "Flesh and Blood."
A couple of details on both plays: "Cavedweller," about a rock star who returns to her Southern home, will be directed by Michael Greif ("Rent"); "Flesh and Blood," about a big Greek family, will star Cherry Jones. 
Two other productions: Amy Freed's comedy "The Beard of Avon" and an updated take on Shakespeare's "Merchant of Venice" by the Hungarian director Robert Alfoldi. 
Liev Schreiber, who played a mean Iago in a production of "Othello" at the Joseph Papp Public Theater last year, is a candidate for Shylock. Which, it seems, would be a great idea.

Ka-ching!
Who needs the Tonys? The producers of "The Graduate," which got a whopping zero Tony nominations, said yesterday that their show had recouped its $1.8 million investment after 10 weeks of performances. 
The play, adapted from the classic 1967 movie, also has $4 million in advance sales. Even better news for the producers: Kathleen Turner, who seems to love playing the seductive Mrs. Robinson, has decided to stay on; she will appear in the production through Nov. 17. Alicia Silverstone, who plays Mrs. Robinson's daughter, Elaine, also looks likely to stay until then.
It is not the only show to recoup this week -- "Metamorphoses," which featured exactly no stars, did as well, returning its $1.65 million capitalization to its investors. Unlike "The Graduate," "Metamorphoses" garnered Tony attention; it received three nominations, including one for best play.
And then there's that minor hit "Mamma Mia!," which has also recouped its investment on Broadway. The capitalization: $10 million. The time it took to recoup: under 28 weeks. The overriding emotion of pretty much every other producer on Broadway: envy.

Revival? Resuscitation
The opposite of love, it is said, is not hate; it's neglect. That, at least, is the idea behind the missions of two Off Off Broadway companies that specialize in rescuing forgotten plays. 
The most noted is the Mint Theater on West 43rd Street in Clinton; it has done admirable work in recent years unearthing plays like last year's production of "Rutherford and Son," Githa Sowerby's 1912 drama about a tyrannical glassworks boss and his suffering family.
Up next for the Mint is "The Charity That Began at Home," an early 20th-century comedy by St. John Hankin, a buddy of George Bernard Shaw. The play involves a genteel British family that invites a rogue's gallery of scoundrels to its country estate.
Jonathan Bank, the company's artistic director, said that he had found the play in a collection of Hankin's work, which he discovered -- where else? -- on the Internet. 
"This is as obscure as they come," he said.
A more recently forgotten work, John O'Hara's 1961 melodrama, "Veronique," will be part of the Peccadillo Theater Company's season at the Bank Street Theater (155 Bank Street in the West Village). Kevin Kennedy, the general manager of the Peccadillo, said the production would be the New York premiere of the play, which is about a gang of 1920's bohemians whose fun is interrupted by a blunt object. It runs from June 11 to Aug. 4.

HEADLINE: HAVENS; 
House Shares: Dysfunction On the Beach

BYLINE:  By KIMBERLY STEVENS 

 BODY:
AFTER just one weekend at his summer share house in Spring Lake, N.J., Matt Brown fired off a corporate-style memo to the other 16 members of the house, alerting them to a meeting.
 "We had our first weekend out there, and let's just say, we already have all sorts of issues that need to be ironed out," said Mr. Brown, a 30-year-old financial adviser. 
 The season of sharing has begun. People who are accustomed to living alone during the year, or perhaps with one other person, have started making weekend treks to houses that are occupied by dozens -- some friends and many strangers, connected only by their desire to flee their regular lives and fulfill a "beach blanket bingo" fantasy. And what happiness means to one person is definitely not what it means to another. 
As the house manager, Mr. Brown decided who would be allowed to spend between $1,500 and $3,000 a summer for space in his house, and now he's the one who will have to orchestrate things so that people get along. It's like being a cross between a chief executive and a therapist. After just one weekend, he said, there were three obvious issues to be addressed:
* Couples who go to bed at midnight awakened by singles who stay out until 4 a.m. and then return to the house to party until sunup.
* Mooching food.
* Lawn chairs tossed into the bushes.
"It's a tough job, but someone's got to do it," he said. "I think it feeds into my perfectionist streak." Mr. Brown, like his fellow house managers, will have to find ways to resolve these and other issues, which may seem small but can loom very large over the course of a summer when people are paying thousands of dollars for their rooms. Dramas worthy of soap operas are most likely to ignite in the kitchen or at the barbecue.
"Last summer the biggest personality clashes happened over the groceries," said Sara Walker, a 26-year-old TV producer in Manhattan who had a share on Fire Island. "There was the group that wanted to shop at Garden of Eden and stock up on things like olives and brie, and then there was the group that only cared about having the ingredients for mudslides and tequila shots," she said. "It was the foodies versus white trash America," she added. The house manager, she said, was crucial in mediating the conflicts, and set up a system for shopping for food. "It was a pain, but it saved us all from a lot of arguing," she said.
When managers do their job, the summer share becomes a bonding moment that can lead to lifelong friendships. "If a manager is well organized and meets his end of the agreement, that's when you get a great house," said Russell Terlecki, 32, an actor. "But I've heard of so many places that sound more like the Enron scandal than a beach house."
Unpaid bills, overcrowded houses, no rules, bounced checks and lawsuits can all result from an inept manager.
They are the C.E.O.'s of summer, running shares in the Hamptons, on the Jersey Shore and in Martha's Vineyard, among other places. They rent or buy the house, pick the people who will share it, handle the cash flow and most difficult of all, deal with the mix of personalities.
Some do it not to make money or to get a free summer for themselves, but simply because they like the role. Lisa Lowenthal, who has run a successful house in Quogue, on Long Island, for four years, said the job of house manager suited her perfectly. "There's always one in every crowd," she said. "Yes, I was the student government dork in high school, and I was the president of my sorority. I guess running a summer share house just comes naturally to me."
The lucky house managers will spend the next few weeks trying to form a functioning group out of a mass of people. The unlucky ones are still struggling to sell shares, to find bodies to fill the houses so they don't lose thousands of dollars. 
A glance at the back page of New York magazine offers plenty of share opportunities. Most house managers say the share house market is down, and they blame it on the economy. According to Zachary Tunick, 37, owner of Hampton Real Estate and Development, the share house market is down, but the rental market has been hit even harder.
"Property owners who are willing to rent to share-house managers have a much better chance of renting than those who hand their property over to a broker," he said. "Especially if the property is not A list, and it's B or C list," he added.
Even if the house has vacancies, house managers have to be careful about who they let in. Mr. Brown said he mainly lets friends in the house, and he checks people's references very carefully, ever since a particularly bad experience a few years ago.
"I actually had to call the police about a guest in the house. She drank too much, screamed and yelled, and refused to listen when members of the house politely asked her to settle down," he said.
In some towns, the house manager has to offer much more than an organized setting for the people taking shares. He has to provide entree to the hot clubs and restaurants. Mr. Terlecki said people who join certain share houses want to be guaranteed social opportunities. Many house managers establish relationships with club promoters for exactly this reason. 
Left on their own, summer visitors may be excluded from the trendiest places. "Let's face it. If you show up at a hot club with three of your guy friends, you're not getting in," Mr. Terlecki said.
Likewise, house managers want their people to live up to a certain standard. Mr. Terlecki said many managers require a photo as part of the screening process. "The Hamptons can be a very shallow place, and I've noticed that many managers just care about how many hot chicks you can bring to the table or how many clubs you are connected with."
House managers have a lot to lose if they fail to organize a house properly. Some of them buy houses as investments, and if they don't rent them, paying the mortgage can become a problem.
Phillip Alfus, 53, who has his own recruiting firm in New York, has shared management responsibilities for a house in Westhampton for more than 10 years. He and his business partner fill the house each summer with people who have bought shares. There are about 30 people that split weekends, so typically there are about 15 people staying at the house on any given weekend. 
He still has vacancies, and last week he put an ad in New York magazine looking for more people. But protecting his investment means interviewing people carefully about their likes and dislikes. He tells people there are no drugs allowed, and that it's not a party house. 
"We try to find people that are like us and enjoy the same types of things," he said. "And we're not alone. There are houses for smokers, people in A.A., tennis players, lawyers -- God forbid -- singles only and the list goes on and on," he said.
Even when a group of people gets along, there can still be drama and anxiety. "A share house can easily turn into one big group-therapy session," said Mr. Alfus. "It's up to the managers to kind of set the tone." Most New Yorkers who share houses in the summer, he said, live alone during the year, or with just one other person. 
"We've had people leave after the first weekend, because it was too much to share a beach chair, or chip in for a group dinner," he said. "For many, the summer share house is their entree out of isolation, and it can be tougher than they expect. A good manager will try to ease this stress, and for most, everything is fine after a few weekends."

HEADLINE: JOURNEYS; 
The Factory Tour Redrawn With a Box Of 64 Colors

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
IT is a little after noon on a cloudy Sunday and my son Samuel, who is 4 1/2 years old, is nearly finished with his masterpiece. Drawing with markers on a projector slide, my little Jackson Pollock has created a riot of colorful squiggles -- a bold cobalt line intersecting with razor-thin slashes of green, golden and orange -- and is now projecting an oversized image on the opposite wall.
"Look, Mom," he yelled. "It's my rainbow." 
 So thrilled was he with his creation that he began demanding that an older girl standing at the light table next to him look up as well. She, sensibly enough, ignored him while she put the finishing touches on her own pastoral scene. 
 We are in the Light Zone room of the Crayola Factory in Easton, Pa., a place I have to admit I was slightly embarrassed to be visiting. 
As parents go, my husband and I are pretty deaf to the siren song of most toy marketers. We read Pooh in the A. A. Milne original and ignore the Disney rewrite. We have no "Toy Story" or "Star Wars" action figures. The kids sleep in plain pajamas -- no Tweetie Bird imprints for us.
Still, when we heard other parents talk about taking their kids to the Crayola Factory (which bills itself as "a hands-on discovery center") and how much fun they had, we felt our resistance melting, particularly since Sam loves drawing with his Crayolas and Joe, our 1-year-old, likes eating them.
After all, what could be more American than Crayolas? Manufactured by the Binney & Smith Corporation for nearly 100 years, these crayons are an undeniable childhood icon. (According to the company, the average American child has gone through 730 crayons by his or her 10th birthday.) So we headed to Easton to witness the miracle of modern crayon manufacturing.
We pictured giant vats of steaming waxy liquids and rows of naked sticks awaiting their paper jackets, with names like "Timberwolf" and "Macaroni and Cheese." We were curious to see how 164 colors got organized into a single box and how the little sharpener was inserted.
But our experience didn't quite match our expectations. 
That is because the Crayola Factory's name is a misnomer. Few Crayolas are actually manufactured at the Easton facility; the bulk of the grimy and occasionally dangerous work of dyeing, molding and packaging 13 million crayons a year is done six miles away on a real shop floor. The shiny new Crayola Factory is the result of a partnership between Binney & Smith and the town of Easton.
In the 1800's, Easton, which sits at the confluence of the Lehigh and Delaware Rivers, was a major coal shipping center. By the 1990's, it was just another economically depressed Rust Belt town. That is when Binney & Smith offered to help develop Two Rivers landing, a brick-and-glass complex that houses the Crayola Factory in a former department store. 
Visitors to the Easton attraction (for which anyone over 3 must pay $8 to enter) are treated to a re-enactment of the crayon manufacturing process. Noses pressed to the glass, children watch as crayons are made in a single batch, labeled, sorted by color and stored in the Binney & Smith's signature yellow-and-green boxes. There are few sounds, and even fewer smells; the process has been sanitized and stripped of messy elements. While adults may be disappointed to see such a modest display of machinery, the children are thrilled by the show.
EXCEPT for the ticket counter on the first floor (and the nearby McDonald's, the only on-site source of food), most of the Crayola factory is spread out over the second floor. There, visitors find a series of rooms -- the Creative Studio and Dreamscapes -- that flow into each other and form a circle of about a dozen activity stations beginning and ending at one central staircase to the outside. The Easton Press & Bindery highlights different types of printing and is well-equipped from start to finish, with everything from stationery cards to small sinks for cleanup.
The passage then narrows and darkens to heighten the experience of the Light Zone that Sam found so fascinating. Other exhibitions, like Wax Works, a tight circle of tall Crayolas that each holds melted wax that can be daubed on cards for decoration, are tucked into their own intimate spaces.
At the height of the day when crowds were thickest, traveling the circuit was uncomfortably like negotiating a maze. Sam wondered off, as he is wont to do, and as I began to shout his name I could barely hear my own voice over the rising cacophony of crying babies and shrieking pre-schoolers.
I took off in the direction I had last seen him meandering, but it was only after elbowing through a crowded narrow corridor and poking my head into several dark but unoccupied corners that I found him again, back in the Light Zone, of course, obliviously penning a new masterpiece.
Though the average exhibition seems best suited to children ages 4 to 8, there is also mercifully the Crayola Color Garden an enclosed area for toddlers, where Joe happily spent more than an hour dumping plastic tomatoes and oranges into barrels and "planting" corn ears into a play soil bed. Meanwhile, Sam walked by the Chalk Walk -- floor-mounted blackboards for drawing on with chalk -- without so much as a nod of interest.
But the Sculpture Station really did get his attention. The room is furnished with big irregularly shaped tables, short stools -- enough for about 100 kids -- and ample supplies of molding clay.
Sam quickly settled in and began intently molding a creature of his imagination: a bee bus. A very intent 45 minutes later he had a vehicle with wings and yellow pipe-cleaner antennae, which has become a regular fixture of his beloved and motley collection of odd modes of transport.
Clearly, he was pleased with his day's work.

IF YOU GO
Getting to Crayola
Easton is direct from New York on Route I-78. Take the first exit in Pennsylvania and follow the signs to the factory. Visitors from Philadelphia should take Route 476 north to Route 22 east. Take the Fourth Street exit, turn left at the end of the ramp and right on Third Street. Crayola is on the right of the traffic circle.
At Crayolafactory.com, you can obtain information on local lodging options and also buy tour tickets ahead. We bought ours at the door, entailing a 20-minute wait.

(Photographs by Emile Wamsteker for The New York Times)(pg. F4); PROOF -- The world of crayons is on display at the Crayola Factory in Easton, Pa. HEADLINE: Quebec Pension Agency Is Juggling Two Roles 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO, May 30 

 BODY:
For most of its 36 years, the Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec has seen no conflict between its role as a government agency promoting economic independence for Canada's French-speaking province and its obligation to seek the highest returns for millions of Quebecers who entrust their retirement savings and auto insurance premiums to government-sponsored plans.
 But the juggling act has become increasingly difficult to defend as the Caisse has moved beyond its Quebec roots in a quest to become a global asset management powerhouse. 
 Spurred by criticism over some investments and recent lackluster performance, the Quebec government this week named Henri-Paul Rousseau, president of the Laurentian Bank of Canada, which is based in Montreal, to replace Jean-Claude Scraire as the agency's chairman and chief executive.
Just two weeks earlier, Mr. Scraire suggested that the two jobs be split as part of a plan to put more distance between the Caisse and its political masters and said that he would soon be leaving, after 21 years at the Caisse, seven at its helm. 
In its carefully worded news release on the changeover, the Caisse board praised Mr. Rousseau's abilities and thanked Mr. Scraire for his "outstanding contribution." 
Even though criticized, the agency has played a crucial role in Quebec's economy, especially in helping it to recover from the flight of businesses and capital from Montreal to Toronto after the separatist Parti Quebecois first took power in 1976.
The Caisse "has been an extremely sophisticated backer of growth sectors," said James de Wilde, a venture capitalist who works in Montreal and Toronto. "It's been a center of investment banking and venture capital expertise for decades."
Benoit Labonte, president of the Board of Trade of Metropolitan Montreal, said the Caisse was "a big player" in wooing investments in the pharmaceutical, telecommunications, biotechnology and software industries, which have transformed the city's economy in the last 15 years.
The Caisse has become Canada's biggest institutional investor and real estate owner, with total investments of 115.2 billion Canadian dollars ($75 billion) at the end of 2001, almost triple its holdings a decade earlier. Assets under management have grown to more than 140 billion Canadian dollars.
Now, it is setting its sights even higher. "We want to be in the club of the 10 best and biggest in the world," Mr. Scraire said in an interview last week.
The agency's investments outside Canada have grown to 40.3 percent of its total last year from just under 15 percent in 1992. In recent years, it has opened 12 offices around the world, in cities that include Los Angeles and Seattle. It has bought seven big buildings in Manhattan and, according to Mr. Scraire, has recently been a big investor in distressed real estate loans in Japan.
In another leg of its expansion strategy, the Caisse is looking to manage money for institutions outside Quebec. Among those it has signed up are an infrastructure fund in Thailand; Stabilitas, a pension plan in Hungary; and the Samsung Life Insurance Company of South Korea. Last year, the Caisse conducted an actuarial study for Saudi Arabia's pension fund and set up a venture capital fund with local partners in Morocco.
Mr. Scraire said the Caisse now oversees 17 billion to 18 billion Canadian dollars worth of funds for investors outside Quebec. Reflecting the more cosmopolitan nature of its business, the agency last year renamed its investment arm CDP Capital.
But the growth has been punctuated by controversy over the Caisse's dual mandate. Stephen Jarislowsky, a fund manager in Montreal, said, "The mission to do things for Quebec has sometimes been confused with the mission to make money."
For instance, in the run-up to a referendum on Quebec independence in 1995, currency traders disclosed that the Caisse was buying unusually large amounts of Canadian dollars. This fueled suspicions that the province's separatist government had corralled the agency to reinforce the argument that a yes vote would not roil financial markets.
And in 2000, the Caisse threw its weight behind a hostile takeover bid by Quebecor, a media group based in Montreal, for Groupe Videotron, the province's biggest cable TV operator. Videotron had favored a rival offer by Rogers Communications, a cable TV group based in Toronto. The takeover has been costly both for Quebecor, which is struggling with a heavy debt load, and for the Caisse, which has written off half its investment of 2.2 billion Canadian dollars.
In one sense, such interventions are in line with the mission set by the Caisse's founding fathers. The agency was started at the height of Quebec's "Quiet Revolution," which created a new generation of assertive French-speaking entrepreneurs and politicians.
Jean-Claude Delorme, the agency's chief executive before Mr. Scraire, said in an interview last week that while suspicions of government intervention were unfounded, "there is a sort of collective determination on the part of Quebecers to develop the Quebec economy, and that does not exclude a convergence of goals, without anyone suggesting anything to anybody."
Still, pressure for change has grown. Claude Castonguay, a former Quebec cabinet minister, wrote recently in The National Post that controversies like the Videotron investment "undermine the credibility of the Caisse with respect to its independence from political influence."
Adding to its problems, the Caisse reported a 5 percent drop in the value of its investments last year, its second-worst annual performance.
Earlier this month, Mr. Scraire proposed several measures that would put more distance between the agency and its political masters. In a document titled "Modernizing to Ensure a Stronger Future," he suggested that the jobs of chairman and chief executive should be split, with the latter being appointed by the Caisse's board, not the government. (In its news release, the Caisse board said that if the posts of chairman and chief executive were split, Mr. Rousseau would continue as president and chief executive.)
Mr. Scraire also proposed that the board have a majority of independent members. To give the reforms a jump start, Mr. Scraire, 55, gave notice that he planned to quit, even though his term of office still had three years to run.
Mr. Rousseau, an economist by training, has strongly backed the independence movement. He directed research in the early 1990's for a government commission that concluded that an independent Quebec would be economically viable.
He said this week that, while he favored some of the changes proposed by his predecessor, the Caisse's dual mandate had served it well. On the other hand, Mr. Rousseau, 53, said he had a clear mandate to modernize the agency, and pledged to be apolitical in his new job.
What that means for the Caisse is not yet clear. In any case, it is unlikely to be the last word on the matter. In announcing Mr. Rousseau's appointment, Pauline Marois, the province's finance minister, said that she favored a public debate on the Caisse this fall.

HEADLINE: Who Wants to Buy Stock? Not the Insiders 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
BY and large, most Americans appear to be bullish on the economy and at least neutral on the stock market. Mutual fund sales are going well, and housing and consumer spending statistics show an economic recovery that is on track.
 But there is one interesting group that has turned more bearish than at any time in years: corporate insiders. 
 "There has been huge, huge insider selling," said Phil Roth, the veteran technical analyst at Miller Tabak, referring to legal sales by corporate officers and directors, not to illegal trading on inside information. He noted that over the last eight weeks, there had been 4.2 insider sales for every insider purchase reported. There are usually more open-market sellers than buyers, since insiders get a lot of their stock by exercising options, but this ratio is higher than it ever was in the 1990's bull market. 
That is a sharp turnaround from last fall, when insiders suddenly stopped selling when the market reopened after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. That may have reflected patriotism, or at least a concern that insiders who sold stock would look bad when their transactions were made public. Or maybe they just thought prices were unreasonably cheap. If so, that opinion has changed.
Whatever their motivation in October, insiders who bought stock generally did well as the market made a dynamic charge in the fourth quarter. Now some of the same insiders are selling the shares they bought then. Others who did not buy are selling, too.
Just what is causing the selling is worthy of speculation. On the benign side is the suggestion that a lot of insiders have learned from Enron's 401(k) debacle how unwise it is to concentrate one's wealth in any stock, particularly that of one's employer. The selling would therefore simply reflect a desire to diversify.
Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company, offers a more cynical Enron lesson, this one based on the rapid rise in the number of accounting investigations being started by the Securities and Exchange Commission. "If you believe people cooked the books, then right now the cooks should be selling," he said. In fact, he added, executives who acted properly may also be concerned. "We are now at a point where accepted accounting principles of the late 1990's that were used in a great many companies can be seen as aggressive," he said. "If you are an insider who knows you were as aggressive as the next guy, you've got some anxiety."
Or maybe a lot of insiders simply think their stocks are expensive. Reported profits rose more in the 1990's than did real earnings, thanks to that aggressive accounting. But over the next couple of years, as auditors enforce more conservatism, reported profits may not do as well as real earnings. Will investors be willing to pay higher price-earnings ratios to reflect that higher quality? Or will they be scared that there are more problems yet to be uncovered?
David Coleman, the editor of the newsletter Vickers Weekly Insider Report, which compiles the insider statistics, points to one exception to the trend. Form 144 filings, which must be made by insiders selling shares they owned before the company went public, are flat. Evidently, shares of initial public offerings of recent years have fallen so far that few insiders want out. He suggests that could mean some of these companies are getting to be cheap.
Insiders do not know everything, of course. As a group, they failed to anticipate the bursting of the bubble in early 2000. But they rightly turned negative before last summer's market swoon, which began months before Sept. 11. That selling came as companies felt the economy weakening around them. This wave may reflect fears that the recovery will not live up to expectations.

GRAPHIC: Graph tracks ratio of insider sales to purchases, eight-week moving average from 2001 through 2002.
