HEADLINE: String of Diplomats Begin Arriving for New Mideast Effort 

BYLINE:  By JOHN KIFNER

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, May 30 

 BODY:
A covey of diplomats began arriving here today in renewed efforts to find a way out of the deadly impasse between Israel and the Palestinians, as the Israeli Army continued what have by now become nearly daily raids into Palestinian territory. 
 The first to arrive was William J. Burns, the American assistant secretary of state for Near Eastern affairs, who flew in today from Cairo and met with the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, in Ramallah. On Friday he is to see the Israeli foreign minister, Shimon Peres, and the prime minister, Ariel Sharon. 
 Mr. Sharon, riding huge poll numbers, won another victory today when the scrupulously religious Shas Party said it would rejoin his government and vote for a belt-tightening economic package. Last week, Mr. Sharon dismissed Shas ministers when the party opposed the package, though the 17 seats the party holds in the fragmented Parliament are crucial to holding a majority. 
The Palestinian Authority, meanwhile, formally announced today that Yasir Arafat had finally signed the Basic Law, a kind of constitution, that had been voted by the Palestinian legislature and had sat, unapproved, on his desk for the last five years. The step was interpreted as a nod to the pressure for reform.
Even as the Sharon government continued to tighten security measures, the authorities, in an announcement certain to unsettle Israelis, said tonight that they had arrested a Palestinian man and his Jewish Israeli wife as prime suspects in helping organize the May 22 suicide bombing in Rishon le Zion. 
They were identified as as Ibrahim Sarahana, 33, from the Bethlehem area, and Marina Pinski, 26, who immigrated here from Russia 11 years ago. They were said to have driven the 16-year-old suicide bomber to the mall, which Mr. Sarahana choose as a target.
"Such complicity on the part of Israeli Jews is almost unheard of," Reuters quoted the Israeli police spokesman as saying. 
Before dawn, Israel sent tanks and dozens of armored personnel carriers and jeeps into the West Bank city of Hebron, where they arrested four Palestinians. They included an Islamic Jihad leader, Muhammad Sider, who Palestinian officials said had been the target of two Israeli assassination attempts. 
The army pulled out of Hebron by midday, and it left Bethlehem tonight, after four days of undertaking house-to-house searches and maintaining sniper positions around Manger Square.
At the same time, the army said it had detained six Palestinians in a village near Tulkarm, and had gone back into Jenin and imposed a curfew on the city. At least one explosion was heard there. There was also skirmishing in Gaza, with 11 Palestinians reported wounded. 
 Early Friday, dozens of Israeli armored personnel carriers and several tanks thrust into the Balata refugee camp on the outskirts of Nablus, where they met heavy Palestinian fire, Reuters reported Palestinian witnesses as saying. 
"Humanitarian problems, the daily humiliation that ordinary Palestinians suffer under occupation are getting worse every day," Mr. Burns told reporters during a stopover in Cairo, where he met with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt before arriving in Israel.
One aspect of what Palestinians see as that humiliation -- roadblocks -- has become increasingly evident. All week there have been long lines at the two checkpoints leading from Ramallah to Jerusalem, and new roadblocks have been set up in the northern districts of the city.
Also, An Israeli human rights group charged today that Israeli soldiers had killed a 17-year-old Palestinian in their custody in Ramallah during the army's raid earlier this spring, and demanded an official investigation. The right's group, B'Tselem, said that the Palestinian, Murad Awaisa, was taken away from other detainees on March 31 and was later found with one bullet near his heart and another in his knee.
Mr. Burns is to be joined here on Monday by the director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet, who is tasked with reforming the Palestinian Authority and its hydra-headed security forces. 
Other diplomatic visitors include Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer of Germany and, in the coming days, the European Union's foreign policy chief, Javier Solana, and Osama al-Baz, the Egyptian presidential adviser, who is to arrive here ahead of a visit to Washington by Mr. Mubarak.
Mr. Arafat apparently signed the Basic Law Tuesday night, officials said, but it was not formally announced until today. His spokesman, Nabil Abu Rdeneh, said the law was part of the reforms that Mr. Arafat had promised in a speech to the legislative council two weeks ago.

HEADLINE: Just How Far Can Trading Of Emissions Be Extended? 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
For once, Washington secured a bargain.
 The 1990 amendments to the Clean Air Act set up a market-based system in hopes of reducing pollution from power plants more efficiently than regulation alone would, but no one thought the cuts would come cheap. The government estimated that eliminating emission of 10 million tons of sulfur dioxide -- which causes acid rain -- would cost companies up to $15 billion a year. Yet left to their own devices, the generators cut emissions for a fraction of that amount. 
 "The Congress and Environmental Protection Agency estimated that the acid rain program back in 1990 would be 5 to 10 times more expensive than it has been," said S. William Becker, executive director of an organization of state and local air pollution officials, who called the program one of the most effective pieces of environmental legislation ever put in place. 
Now the White House wants to expand that approach, replacing existing air quality controls and applying "emissions trading" to other pollutants.
But environmentalists and economists alike warn that the Bush administration's "Clear Skies" initiative, while generally promising improvements, threatens to intensify pollution in certain "hot spots," and could create poor incentives for businesses.
"If all you had was emissions trading, you could pile up all the pollution in one place," said David D. Doniger, a former E.P.A. official who now sets policy at the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental advocacy group.
In the 1990's, sulfur dioxide levels fell broadly but they barely changed in the swath from Columbus, Ohio, to northern West Virginia; companies simply paid to pass on their obligations to reduce pollution in some of the worst spots. Mr. Doniger warned that abandoning existing safeguards would not only encourage concentrations of other pollutants it could even allow some plants to increase harmful emissions.
Environmentalists also lament Mr. Bush's failure to focus on greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide. Even those in the emissions trading business argue that carbon dioxide controls could help companies plan better, but Mr. Bush says they would raise electricity prices. Perhaps most important, no one seems to agree on how to dole out the right to pollute.
Emissions trading was just becoming popular in the late 1980's, when Congress set out to cut air pollution by power generators. Instead of ordering across-the-board reductions, though, lawmakers heeded economists who had long urged a focus on companies that could reduce emissions most cheaply. But the government had no easy way to identify those companies.
So Congress set up a trading system in which power companies can buy and sell "allowances" to emit sulfur dioxide. Each year, the number of allowances drops, with the goal of halving emissions by 2012.
At first, the companies worked with the government to divvy up 30 years' worth of allowances, to be traded on spot and futures markets. Russ Gillespie, managing director for environmental compliance at Duke Energy North America in Charlotte, N.C., knew he had a choice: keep Duke's allowances and keep polluting, or install expensive "scrubbers" to clean exhaust from plants. 
Mr. Gillespie knew cutting pollution would be expensive -- especially for Duke, because its exhaust was relatively clean already. Duke buys coal with about a pound of sulfur in each ton, but many Midwestern plants use coal with three times that amount. At one plant in Indiana, he added, the scrubbers would cost just as much, "but they would remove 90 percent of a much higher number" of sulfur dioxide particles.
As a result, it made sense for Duke to leave big pollution reductions to other generators. Mr. Gillespie said it might cost Duke $300 to collect a ton of sulfur, but it might cost other generators only $100. "They would be willing to meet in the middle," he said, by selling Duke an allowance for one ton at $200. "They would make $100, and Duke would save $100."
For monitoring, the E.P.A. required power generators to put electronic monitors on smokestacks. Companies that pollute too much pay $2,000, plus inflation, for each extra ton. The results have been better than even the program's original backers had predicted. Congress initially withheld 25,000 allowances a year to be sold for $1,500 each, plus inflation. Allowances now trade for $150 to $200.
"The United States sulfur dioxide system is a shining example of what worked," said Andrew O. Ertel, president of Evolution Markets, which completed more environment-related transactions than any other brokerage firm last year. "The reason it's worked is that the regulators put together a good system -- a basic and simple system."
Mr. Becker, of the local officials' group, also heaped praise on the program. "It has been implemented with almost 100 percent compliance," he said. "It has achieved generally what Congress sought."
So why not extend the sulfur dioxide market to nitrogen-oxygen compounds and mercury? Most policy makers are in favor of expanding emissions trading, but some worry that Clear Skies relies on it too much. The program would eliminate some safeguards against local hot spots and could increase pollution at certain plants. A poor area could be especially vulnerable to finding itself on what Mr. Becker calls "the receiving end" of emissions trades.
A few sulfur dioxide hot spots have persisted east of Erie, Pa.; west of Kingston, N.Y. in Catskill Park; and around Oswego, N.Y., and Oak Ridge, Tenn., according to the National Atmospheric Deposition Program. Since 1995, a study by the United States Public Interest Research Group reported, 300 of the 500 dirtiest plants actually increased sulfur dioxide emissions. An administration official pointed out that many other hot spots had been "cooled" by the 1990 program, but admitted that there had been exceptions.
The 1990 amendments prohibit generators from using allowances bought from other businesses if air quality in their local area would fall substantially. In addition, "new source review" clauses prevent plants from adding generating capacity without controlling overall pollution. This combination helped to prevent even more hot spots, Mr. Doniger said.
That could change. "Emissions trading with the safeguards in the acid rain control program still brought down the cost of meeting the sulfur dioxide targets," Mr. Doniger said. "What the Clear Skies proposal tries to do is to wipe away all of those provisions and replace them with a cap-and-trade system that would be the sole mechanism out there for meeting national targets." 
The administration, Mr. Doniger added, has already relaxed enforcement of new source reviews. But the administration official argued that such reviews were more trouble than they were worth.
"New source review has this perverse incentive for the dirtiest, oldest plants -- the ones from the 1940's and 50's -- to change nothing, to not modernize in any way," he said. "If they modernize, then they trigger a new source review that creates millions and millions of dollars in new investments. The whole reason why we want cap and trade is we want those plants to clean up."
An alternative proposal offered by Senator James M. Jeffords, a Vermont independent, would keep protections against hot spots in addition to capping carbon dioxide emissions and speeding up the elimination of other pollutants. 
Mr. Becker's group is also trying to persuade power plants to uphold minimum local standards of air quality. It is no easy task. "The industry looks at the program on a macro scale," Mr. Becker said. "They say, 'Things are going to get better, so why do we have to look at local impacts?' "
Senator Jefford's demand for carbon dioxide caps has some industry supporters but it has also raised hackles. Companies that run newer, cleaner generators want to know what investments will be necessary for the long term. "If you're paying top dollar for a power plant," Mr. Ertel said, "you're going to want to make sure that it's going to have the best available technology to run for the next 20 years."
But dirtier coal-fired plants want to avoid carbon dioxide controls as long as possible. "The only way to get cheap carbon dioxide reductions is a fuel switch away from coal towards natural gas," said Dallas Burtraw, a senior fellow at Resources for the Future, a nonpartisan environmental economics institute. "If Clear Skies passes in its current form, the industry would seemingly be justified in crying bloody murder if it was followed by new carbon controls."
Any new market-based plan will also have to deal with the issue of allocating new allowances. Because many utilities' profit margins were regulated in 1990, the distribution was a less contentious issue when Congress set up the acid rain program. Today, Mr. Burtraw said, "there is a potentially tremendous transfer of wealth in the initial distribution of emission allowances," running into billions of dollars.
At least three possible methods have surfaced in Washington. One, grandfathering, would give the most allowances to producers that have already spent the most to cut pollution -- favoring what were once the dirtiest plants.
A second would allot allowances every year or two, giving more to bigger power generators but fewer to bigger polluters, thus rewarding the cleanest plants. Mr. Burtraw said this strategy could distort the power market, but Mr. Doniger said it would lower prices for consumers.
The third, an auction, is also controversial. In the acid rain program, the E.P.A. withholds 3.8 percent of allowances for an annual auction. Businesses initially liked the auction. "There was uncertainty about what these things would cost, and the auction really helped firms to settle on their investment plans," Mr. Burtraw said. But now, some see it as an annoyance.
"E.P.A. takes weeks to actually execute this auction," Mr. Ertel said. "It should be able to do this auction in an hour." Still, economists prefer the auction because it always sells the allowances to the companies that value them the most.
Mr. Doniger suggested a fourth alternative: give customers the allowances, and make companies buy from them.
"It's the public's air that's being used as a waste dump," he said. "There's a good argument that you ought to pay to use the dump."

HEADLINE: The Odds Improve for an Increase in the Minimum Wage 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Last year and the year before, the New York State Assembly voted to increase the state minimum wage by $1.60 an hour, but those efforts died quietly in the Senate.
 But this year, many lawmakers say, the chances of an increase in the minimum wage have improved because the State Assembly has again approved it and for the first time the Labor Committee in the Republican-controlled State Senate has done likewise. 
 The bill would raise the state's minimum wage to $6.75 an hour on Jan. 1, $1.60 more than the current $5.15-an-hour state and federal minimum wage and comparable to the $6.70 an hour in Connecticut and $6.75 in Massachusetts.
"It's time New York caught up with the other states," said Guy J. Velella, a Bronx Republican who is chairman of the Senate Labor Committee. "This is one of the bills that is getting a lot of attention right now." 
The bill has certainly gotten the attention of business groups, like the New York Farm Bureau and the Business Council of New York State, which are lobbying senators this week to vote against the bill.
But the bill also has many supporters who are lobbying hard, including the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O., the Working Families Party and 1199/S.E.I.U., the giant health care union.
Nicholas A. Spano, a Westchester Republican and the bill's main sponsor in the Senate, said he hoped to persuade Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno to have the full Senate vote on the legislation over the next few weeks. 
"In past years we had hoped the federal government would move forward on its own on the minimum wage," Mr. Spano said. "It's clear that that will not happen, and we need to show leadership in New York State."
Several lawmakers and lobbyists said they thought that the Republican Senate would be more willing to vote on the bill in this election year than in past years because some Republicans in swing areas like Nassau County are eager to shore up their support with labor.
Gov. George E. Pataki has been noncommittal on the bill. Some lobbyists predict he will sign it, if the Senate approves it, to take away an issue from his Democratic challengers, H. Carl McCall and Andrew M. Cuomo.
But several opponents of the bill said that the governor wanted to prevent a Senate vote because he feared that a higher minimum wage would hurt the state's economy.
Mark Alesse, New York State director of the National Federation of Independent Business, which represents 26,000 small businesses, predicted that a raise in the minimum wage would increase unemployment for low-wage workers.
"You increase the cost of hiring a person who has rudimentary skills and little experience, and you make that person harder to hire," he said.
Joseph Conway, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki, said, "We're supportive of an increase, but we believe it should be done at the federal level in order to ensure a level playing field and to prevent New York from being placed at a competitive disadvantage with other states."
But Mr. Conway declined to say whether Mr. Pataki would sign or veto a higher minimum wage sent him by the legislature.
The Fiscal Policy Institute, a liberal research group, estimated that 612,000 workers in New York earn less than $6.75 an hour and would have their wages raised by the bill.
Mr. Velella said he would not be surprised if the Senate ultimately approved a minimum wage lower than $6.75, a move that would require negotiating with the Assembly in a conference committee.
Hoping to avoid a conference committee and ease the bill's passage, Catherine Nolan, a Queens Democrat and the Assembly's chief sponsor of the bill, amended the Assembly bill yesterday so that it parallels the Senate version, which says that beginning in 2004 the state minimum wage would be pegged each year to the rise in average weekly earnings. The Assembly bill had called for pegging the increase to the consumer price index.
Ms. Nolan said one factor helping the bill was that several moderate Republicans in the Senate appeared to be angling for endorsements from the Working Families Party, a distinctly liberal party that has made a higher minimum wage its No. 1 issue in Albany.
Bob Master, co-chairman of the Working Families Party, said: "A political party has a lot of clout in an election year, and we're obviously looking to use that clout to advance the agenda of the party. The gap between the rich and poor has been one of the driving concerns of our party."

HEADLINE: New U.S. Allies, the Uzbeks: Mired in the Past 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: TASHKENT, Uzbekistan 

 BODY:
Two years ago, Poul Jahn employed 140 people as an importer of products like candy from Germany and Legos from Denmark. 
 Today, he is all but out of business, because the government stopped allowing him to convert his sales revenue from Uzbek som into dollars. 
 His difficulties are just one example of how hard it is to foster economic or other development in Uzbekistan and other Central Asian states that have become the newest United States allies because of their proximity to Afghanistan and the usefulness of their bases to American troops.
Under President Islam Karimov, a Soviet-era ruler here who has just extended his term until 2007, Uzbekistan has displayed little appetite for either democracy or open markets. Political repression is intense, corruption is widespread and economic policy owes more to Stalin than George W. Bush. 
American leaders are eager to pump economic and military aid into Central Asian states, but the sort of bureaucratic thicket and isolationism encountered by Mr. Jahn makes it difficult to see how the World Bank will dispense the $1 billion earmarked for the region over the next three years.
Yet without economic reform to improve the prospects for people here, the attraction of radical Islamic movements to the poor and disaffected may continue to grow. Mr. Karimov has used the existence of such movements as the pretext for an often brutal clampdown on any expression of Islam, jailing thousands of people in sweeps across the country that have been repeatedly criticized by rights groups.
Every economy in Central Asia is smaller today than it was before the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1990. Poverty is intense, with average annual income of about $610 here and less than half that in neighboring Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan.
Although leaders like President Karimov have vowed to support economic and administrative reform, the progress is at best uneven.
"Leaders are finding that they are getting a very different reception now than they got on Sept. 10," said James D. Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank, who himself made his first trip to the region only after the Sept. 11 terror attacks transformed the geopolitical realities of formerly forgotten Central Asia.
But, Mr. Wolfensohn added, "If they are going to take advantage of this opportunity for funds and support, then change will be necessary."
Uzbekistan illustrates how hard that change will be. Despite heavy pressure from the International Monetary Fund, it has yet to abandon its currency restrictions. Policy often seems to be set mainly to buttress Mr. Karimov's hold on power.
Meanwhile, a crazy quilt of new borders has disrupted trade and routine travel throughout the region.
Many people are trapped in enclaves, a few square miles of Uzbek or Tajik territory surrounded by Kyrgyzstan. Traders who once roamed freely across borders now need to wait in long lines, show visas and often pay bribes. 
"People are trapped," said Natalia Ablova, director of the Bureau on Human Rights and Rule of Law, in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan. "They cannot travel, cannot trade, cannot create business. Just travel through the region, and you will see the intolerable conditions that each country has created for its own citizens." 
Uzbekistan is hardly alone. Turkmenistan, which has big oil and gas reserves, has become so autocratic and isolated that World Bank officials have all but stopped offering aid.
Tajikistan, ravaged by civil war through much of the 1990's, remains plagued by organized crime, heroin smuggling and violence. Few foreign companies venture to do business there, and the average yearly income is only about $200.
The new isolationism has greatly increased tensions throughout Central Asia. Uzbekistan is critically short of water, and constantly accuses Kyrgyzstan of hoarding it upstream. Kyrgyzstan says it needs to store water for hydroelectric power, because its neighbors will not supply it with enough electricity. 
"You have this shadow play going on between leaders, whether it is about problems in the Aral Sea or about trade," Mr. Wolfensohn said. 
The difficulties become abundantly clear on a trip through the Fergana Valley, a region that is just 200 miles long but is home to 10 million people and a big share of Central Asia's industry and agriculture. 
A one-hour trip between the Kyrgyz cities of Osh, an ancient trading post, and Jalalabad now takes four hours -- the main road cuts through Uzbek territory, and side roads are winding and small. 
The enclave of Sokh, claimed by Uzbekistan but surrounded by Kyrgyz territory, is virtually fenced off from the outside world. Uzbek leaders argue that strong borders are essential to preventing attacks by militant Islamic groups, notably the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan, which has roots in the Fergana Valley and launched several attacks from Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan in 1999 and 2000. 
Economics is also partly a factor in the Uzbek behavior -- to keep prices for basic commodities like flour, cotton and gasoline artificially low, the government has imposed a mind-numbingly complex scheme of currency and trade controls.
At a checkpoint near the Uzbek city of Kuvasai, border police put the finishing touches last month on a massive new station that looks like the entrance to a palace.
The new station has multiple rooms for interrogation and searches; animal pens for the guard dogs; the latest in X-ray and bomb-sniffing equipment, and a canteen and recreation room for off-duty guards. Police officials boast that the "Welcome to Uzbekistan" sign can be seen from Kyrgyz mountainsides 50 miles away.
"You can see that there is nothing like this in Kyrgyzstan or even Kazakhstan," boasted the station's director, Col. Alisher Amanbaev. "This has everything you need for a really civilized process." 
But not necessarily an easy one. There are no buses or trains that go straight across the border. Anyone driving a car from Kyrgyzstan will have to pay $45 for insurance, prohibitive for people in a country where the average annual income is $270. 
"It would be good if we could just drive across," said Micha, a Kyrgyz hairstylist who waited along the railroad for a ride to Kuvasai. "Before, we would just go up to the border, stop and then drive through." 
Economic life has been disrupted in scores of places. At a brick factory in Kuvasai, managers were told they would have to pay steep new tariffs on clay from a quarry just over the border in Kyrgyzstan. Factory managers located another source on their side of the border, but the land belonged to a collective farm. Local Uzbek authorities then ordered the farm collective to hand over the quarry land on a 50-year lease at no cost.
Although factory managers say they are selling more bricks than before, they are not selling any at all in Kyrgyzstan. A rival Kyrgyz brick factory is not selling anything here, either. 
Uzbek attempts to control exchange rates have created an even bigger set of barriers. A handful of privileged companies, like the Daewoo automobile assembly plant, are allowed to purchase dollars at about 700 som to the dollar. Individuals are allowed to change limited amounts of money at 1,450 som to the dollar. The real exchange rate, available on the black market, is about 1,500 som to the dollar. 
The effect is to wreak havoc in trade, swamping neighboring countries with artificially cheap Uzbek products and making most exports to Uzbekistan artificially expensive. 
"We are a country with a majority of the population living below the poverty line," complained one top Kyrgyz official. "But trade with our Eurasian neighbors dropped 20 percent last year." 
Mr. Jahn, owner of an importing company called Jahn International, built a thriving business here through much of the 1990's. But then the Uzbek government cut in half the amount of Uzbek som he could convert to dollars. 
Then it reduced him to a quarter, and then it cut off his "allocation" entirely.
To stop him from changing money on the black market, Uzbek authorities limited bank withdrawals to little more than the amount needed for wages. To make sure Mr. Jahn did not cheat by selling products out the back door, they sent inspectors to check his warehouse inventories. 
"I don't want to do business illegally," Mr. Jahn said. "Right now, I am basically out of business." 
Under pressure from the International Monetary Fund, change may be under way. Last month, Uzbek authorities announced that citizens would no longer have to show them airline tickets and travel documents in order to exchange Uzbek som for dollars. It was a limited offer -- no more than $1,000 per person every three months. 
By Uzbek standards, it is a major reform.

HEADLINE: Another Call for an Overhaul of Air Fares 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
Airlines have to narrow the gap between walk-up fares and leisure fares that has widened in the last several years and has driven more business travelers to buy cheap tickets, the chief of US Airways said yesterday. 
 The fare gap has deepened the airline industry's crisis, the executive, David N. Siegel, said in an interview yesterday afternoon. "The gap is so large," he said, "we're trying to figure out a fare structure that's more rational and more consumer friendly," 
 The goal, he said, is to create fares between the last-minute tickets that cost thousands of dollars and the advance-purchase tickets that cost hundreds. He added that US Airways was looking at a couple of different fares that it might introduce. 
He did not go into details about them. Federal law prohibits airlines from publicly discussing such matters because of fears of collusion. But Mr. Siegel joins a growing chorus calling for an overhaul of the complex air fare system that most of the major carriers have adopted.
Business travelers have traditionally accounted for about 40 percent of revenue in the airline industry. But with the economic downturn, and with the increased perception of security delays at airports after Sept. 11, many business travelers have chosen to use alternative transportation or not to travel. 
A survey of 184 companies and large organizations, released by the Business Travel Coalition in April, showed that 74 percent of participants said their travel budget cuts were permanent.
The number of passengers taking the US Airways shuttle between New York and Washington dropped 30 percent between the first quarter of 2001 and the first quarter this year. Many business travelers in the Northeast have flocked to the high-speed Acela Express train. The Acela is much slower than flights, but is also much cheaper. Other travelers are buying tickets on low-cost carriers like Southwest or JetBlue.
"At a certain point, if you don't price your product not only fairly but what the customer perceives as fair, you will fail," said Joe Brancatelli, an advocate of lower fares for business travelers. "You can't sustain losses like this forever. And you can't sustain a system like this forever. The market has said no."
Mr. Siegel's comments about air fares came the same day that Continental Airlines raised most of its round-trip leisure fares by $20. It is the third time this year that a major carrier has tried to lead a leisure fare increase. On the previous occasions, Northwest Airlines refused to go along with the increases, forcing the other airlines to revert to lower prices. --------------------

Raise for Attendants
(By Bloomberg News)
 CHICAGO, May 30 -- Flight attendants at United Airlines, a subsidiary of UAL, will receive pay raises totaling $48 million, which will make their compensation better than the average of four rivals, the company said.
An arbitrator called for the pay increase after an annual review stipulated by the workers' contract, according to the airline and the attendants' union, the Association of Flight Attendants. The raise will be retroactive to April 1.
The increase comes as the airline is seeking to reduce its labor costs, the industry's biggest expense, through concessions from its worker groups. So far United's attendants have said they are not willing to provide concessions. The pilots are discussing pay reductions.

HEADLINE: Japan's Jobless Rate Unchanged 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, May 31 

 BODY:
The unemployment rate in Japan remained unchanged at 5.2 percent in April, the eighth consecutive month the rate has hovered above 5 percent, as signs of a healing economy failed to trickle down to the labor market.
 About 3.75 million people were unemployed in April, up 270,000 from the previous month, the Labor Force Statistics Office said today. 
 Though the number of people with part-time jobs rose, the number of full-time jobs decreased. Other figures indicated that the number of people out of work for more than a year was also on the rise.
"The number of people with jobs has dropped since September of last year," said Masato Chino, the labor office director. 
Among those unemployed, 1.08 million were heads of households -- the highest level ever for salaried breadwinners. The previous high was last month, with 1.01 million.
Figures from January to March also indicated that it was taking longer to find jobs, especially for older job seekers, the government said.
The number of people without jobs for more than a year rose to a bit more than 30 percent of the total unemployed, compared with 26 percent for the same period last year. At the same time, older people who were rehired settled lower pay.
The Japanese government said in a report this month that the economy was starting to bottom out, although officials cautioned against too much optimism.
Industrial output and exports improved recently on the back of recovery in the rest of Asia and in the United States. Profits are edging up at companies, and inventories are being adjusted.

HEADLINE: Sheriff Battles Budget Cuts In Los Angeles 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: MONTEREY PARK, Calif., May 30 

 BODY:
The sheriff of Los Angeles County said today that he would start to cut critical programs and release hundreds of inmates if the County Board of Supervisors did not increase his budget by $100 million.
 At stake, Sheriff Leroy D. Baca said, is public safety in the 470-square-mile county that includes the largest county jail system in the nation, with more than 20,000 inmates. 
 "I do not raise this as a hollow threat but as a harsh reality," he said at a news conference. "Public safety needs to remain a priority, but you tell me how I can provide services with $120 million less than this department had in 1992." 
The sheriff's budget for the fiscal year that begins on July 1 is $1.6 billion, the largest part of which, $648 million, comes from the county, with the rest paid by state and local governments. The county's share represents an increase of $13 million over the current fiscal year but, according to Sheriff Baca, is not nearly enough to cover rising salary and worker compensation costs.
Sheriff Baca conceded that he hoped to whip up public concern over the consequences of the department budget, as proposed. He said that without more money, as many as 400 inmates could be released, starting July 1, and programs like the hate-crimes unit, gang units and the Asian crime task force would have to close.
Earlier this week, he said the release of inmates could start as early as Friday. But he delayed it, he said, in hopes that the public would press the board to give him what he seeks. 
That is not likely to happen. Yvonne Brathwaite Burke, a supervisor whose district includes a large part of Los Angeles, said every county agency was suffering as a result of the state's shortfall, projected to be $23.6 billion by the end of the 2003 fiscal year.
"There's a recession in California and a recession in Los Angeles," she said. "Every agency has to take responsibility for operating with a smaller budget."
In 1995, Sheriff Baca's predecessor, Sherman Block, also threatened to release inmates as part of a battle over budget cuts, but only a few inmates were released before some of the money he sought was restored.

PERSON: Patricia J. Lancaster 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
Bronco-Buster for an Errant Buildings Department

BYLINE:  By ROBIN FINN 

 BODY:
DON'T fall for that demure strand of pearls looped around the neck of Patricia J. Lancaster, the authoritative architect just sworn in as commissioner of the chronically derelict and defamed New York City Department of Buildings. She does not possess the pair of kid gloves to match the necklace. A pair of steel-toed work boots and a hard hat are more like it. 
 She does admit to knowing, after two decades spent tramping around construction sites and scaling half-built skyscrapers, how to avoid the headache of on-the-job hat hair: "You keep the ratchet loose," she explains, a little self-conscious that this hard hat tip, along with her reluctance to spill her age ("Just say late 40's; I like to fudge it") may make her come off as superficial. Not likely. 
 Prissy she isn't, or she would not have been recruited. The Buildings Department is responsible for setting the city's construction standards, already stringent, and now charged to be terrorist-proof as well as natural-disaster-proof; regulating the construction trades, 19; and taking the heat when anything goes awry, often. The abundance of $250 bribes passed to expedite the city's draconian permit process is, according to her, a sad fact of life.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said this moribund agency required an enforcer type: the operative word was "tough." Sure enough, within two weeks of her appointment, she dealt with a building explosion, a toppled crane, an indictment of three people in a bribe case, a collapsed scaffolding and 14 structural emergencies related to a spring northeaster. Her hard hat and two firefighter's jackets, one in her office and one in the car, took precedence over the pearls. 
There was also some required reading: the results -- it's safe to call them damning -- of an 18-month investigation ordered by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani into corruption allegations in the 791-member department.
"There are big issues out there," she says, "and it's all well documented. If I'm the building department, I'm corrupt, I'm inept, and I'm too slow. There is no question this is broken; the question is, could I succeed where others have failed." And now for the good news. "This agency is not a figurehead. The mayor wants it to change, and change it will, but it's a very heavy lift."
Is she tough enough to hoist it?
"Absolutely," says Ms. Lancaster, beaming in her overheated but spartan Hudson Street headquarters. She says two years as deputy commissioner for design and construction in the Giuliani administration honed her management strategy. Accountability is more than a buzzword with the first woman to head the Buildings Department. 
Long before she learned more about focus during her 1994-96 City Hall stint managing a staff of 600 and a construction budget of $600 million, she was, no joke, a horse tamer, which was all about focus. Taught by a cowpoke who was taught by an old Indian man, she grew up wrangling horses in the foothills outside her hometown, Calgary, Alberta, and appears to be taking the same tough-love attitude to the Buildings Department that she used to reform broncos into diligent merry-go-round mounts.
"I don't know if you can directly compare running this agency to riding a bucking bronco, but I've got to say it's a pretty heady ride," she says. She still slips out on Central Park's bridle paths twice a year. Otherwise, she is work-obsessed; the book she wrote, "Construction in Cities: Social, Environmental, Political and Economic Concerns," and the book on her desk, "Designing Dynamic Organizations," say it all. She also helped innovate the curriculum for a master's in construction management for the Real Estate Institute at New York University. She was six months into running her own management firm, the Lancaster Group, when Mayor Bloomberg called.
THE first thing she did after becoming commissioner of, arguably, the city's most black-eyed agency (the Buildings Department has competition from the Finance Department) was head for the office of the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau. Her intention was to pick his brain on the proper care and handling of a corruption-racked monolith nobody else seemed ambitious enough to want to run, much less fix. He advised her to concentrate on "deterrence" and "transparency," so she compiled a list of dos and don'ts, held a series of Town Hall meetings to let the rank-and-file vent, and is pushing to make the permit process less opaque, even traceable on the Internet.
"Somebody told me you'd have to be a little nuts to take on this job," she says, "and I said, 'O.K., then I'm qualified.' " Ms. Lancaster discovered her planning inspectors couldn't even look up the building code the way the public can. Why? Because their computers aren't up to speed. She shakes her head. "So I add it to the list and say to myself, 'That's why you're here.' "
Ms. Lancaster left home at 18 for college in Oregon, where she worked as a potter and painter and waited to be discovered. When that didn't happen, she went to graduate school at the University of Washington, earned an architecture degree and moved to New York in 1982. She worked for architecture firms during the day and painted at night; one of her works hung in the lobby of the Chelsea Hotel, her home for the first four years she lived here. Now Ms. Lancaster lives on the Upper East Side; she returns to Calgary only to visit family.
"It's beautiful there," she says, "but it was too Zen."

HEADLINE: SOCCER; 
New Location, But Favorites Are Familiar

BYLINE:  By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, May 30 

 BODY:
Security is heavy, the ball is light, schools here are closed and pubs in England are open early as the world's largest sporting event comes to Asia for the first time.
 France will begin its World Cup defense against a former colony, Senegal, here on Friday as soccer's global championship opens its monthlong tournament with 32 teams divided equally between the host countries, South Korea and Japan. 
 Billions of people are expected to watch the World Cup on television, with 1.5 billion expected to view the final match, on June 30 in Yokohama, Japan. The location of the tournament is new, but the favorites are familiar: France and Argentina, which is hoping that soccer can distract a nation despairing over a financial collapse. So severe is the economic crisis in Argentina that only 30 reporters of an expected Argentine contingent of 400 are here to cover the championship. 
Brazil could capture its fifth World Cup if the three R's -- Rivaldo, Ronaldinho and the resuscitated Ronaldo -- can mesh in their attack to create the beautiful game. Italy is always a threat with its strangling defense, and Cameroon's Indomitable Lions are poised to advance farther than any African team that has come before. 
A number of teams, however, have been hit by injuries, and many of the top players are tired after long club seasons in Europe. France, trying to become the first team in 40 years to repeat as champion, will be without its hobbled midfielder, Zinedine Zidane, widely considered the best player in the world, for at least Friday's game, and perhaps all three matches in group play.
Fatigue, and the relatively short period that national teams have had to prepare, could lead to a number of early-round upsets, predicted the American coach, Bruce Arena. He does not believe, for instance, that both Argentina and England will emerge from a group that also includes Sweden and Nigeria.
The United States will be the last team to open play, next Wednesday against skillful, and elegant, Portugal. First-round matches will also be played against South Korea on June 10 and Poland on June 14. The Americans will most likely need a draw and a victory to finish at least second in their group and advance to the Round of 16. In any case, the team appears far more capable and cohesive than the distressed side that finished last at the 1998 World Cup in France.
"There is no fear within this team," the assistant coach Dave Sarachan said. "They feel they can make some history here."
The most intriguing question concerning the Americans -- who will start at goalkeeper? -- may have been answered today, when Kasey Keller missed practice with a sore left elbow. He sustained a bruise in a collision Wednesday with defender Carlos Llamosa. X-rays proved negative, team officials said. Michael Kammarman, a team spokesman, said that Keller was feeling significantly better and that "we don't expect it to be an issue."
However, Brad Friedel is in top form, having played brilliantly with Blackburn in the English Premier League and in subsequent World Cup tuneups. Arena had said he was considering playing both goalkeepers in the first round, and this latest injury might have made up his mind about who gets to start the opener. Playing Friedel would give Keller extra days to mend his sore elbow and would prevent Friedel from becoming frustrated with a lack of playing time, as he did during last summer's qualifying matches. Arena said he would make a decision Sunday, but would not announce it publicly.
All the goalkeepers in this tournament will have to contend with a lighter ball, manufactured by Adidas, that is designed to produce more speed and spectacular goals. It has already generated much criticism from those who will stand in the nets. The ball, made of gas-filled micro bladders and enhanced cushioning, is said to knuckle and create a difficult trajectory when kicked in the sweet spot.
"Terrible," Keller called it. A "ridiculous kiddies' bouncing ball," is how Italy's Gianluigi Buffon described it.
When the World Cup opens Friday, the South Korean military will be on high alert in an effort to thwart any terrorist attacks at an event that draws the entire world's attention. Antiaircraft missiles will be deployed at the 10 stadiums being used here, along with fighter jets and helicopters, military officials have said. No-flight zones will be enforced during the matches.
Security measures, however, are not expected to dampen the enthusiasm of the spectators, particularly the South Korean fans, who are hoping for advancement after the national team played impressively in recent friendlies against England and France. The most enthusiastic Korean fans are known as the Red Devils and they can be spotted throughout Seoul wearing T-shirts that say "Be the Reds" and "Korea Team Fighting." The South Korean team has never won a game in five previous World Cup appearances, and a victory in any match here is certain to set off jubilant celebrations.
In England, the pubs have been granted early-morning opening privileges so that the World Cup can be enjoyed with a stout pint or two. The British have been consumed for two months with the condition of the team captain, David Beckham, who is recovering from a broken bone in his left foot. He is now expected to play in the opener against Sweden. So engulfed was the country in his recovery, fans were asked to place their healing hands on a photograph of Beckham's foot that appeared on the cover of a tabloid newspaper.
"Thank God it wasn't a groin injury," mused Terry Venables, the former national team coach.
Just as the tournament is set to open, the rainy season has arrived in this smoggy capital. Asked how his American team was preparing to play in rainy conditions, the curmudgeonly Arena said, "We take a shower every day."

HEADLINE: G.M. Rises and Nissan Falls in J.D. Power Quality Survey 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 30 

 BODY:
General Motors rose to third place in this year's quality ranking surveys by J. D. Power & Associates, the best performance for a domestic manufacturer since the study's methodology was changed in 1998. 
 The Ford Motor Company also rose in the closely watched initial quality survey, which examines how cars perform in their first 90 days, as did DaimlerChrysler, the parent of the Chrysler Group. Ford moved from seventh place to fifth in the survey. DaimlerChrysler moved from fifth to fourth. 
 Nissan Motor, meanwhile, tumbled from third to a tie for sixth place in the overall rankings, according to several people who received copies of the results. Nissan was the only one of the major automakers to show a decline in its overall initial quality score. J. D. Power releases data on the best-performing individual car and truck lines to the public, but the corporate-level data is kept private and sold to automakers. 
"No matter how you cut it, it's remarkable to have each of the Big Three with better quality than one of the major Japanese players," said John Casesa, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. 
Quality rankings have long favored Asian automakers and highly favorable exchange rates have given them more ammunition to make improvements recently. Mr. Casesa added that too much should not be read into a one-year blip in the rankings for Nissan, since the company had a prominent redesign in its Altima sedan in the last year, usually a source of trouble, and it is also "in the midst of a massive, high-speed restructuring."
But the company, which is led by a demanding French chief executive, Carlos Ghosn, was clearly not happy.
"We did slip," said Jed Connelly, a senior vice president for Nissan's North American operations. "We're disappointed."
While Toyota Motor and Honda Motor continue to dominate the rankings, the most striking data was G.M.'s quality improvement, which moved it from fourth place to third, and was evidence of a manufacturing overhaul years in the making.
Surprisingly, G.M., which makes its money in pickups and sport utility vehicles, had its best individual performances in passenger cars, belying the conventional wisdom that domestic automakers cannot compete in passenger car quality. G.M.'s Chevrolet Malibu was the most improved car over the last five years and its Buick Century and LeSabre also took best in their categories, as did the Chevrolet Corvette. 
"G.M. is learning about quality and how to improve its quality, and when it does, it applies those lessons to all the products they produce," said Brian Walters, director of product research at J. D. Power.
"It also suggests they are designing better products from the get-go," he added. "We found roughly three quarters of the problems we see in initial quality go back to the design and engineering stage."
Mr. Casesa said, "G.M.'s performance has a lot to do with what happened in the early '90's, when they implemented its version of the Toyota production system." 
The company, which operates a joint venture plant with Toyota in Fremont, Calif., has made no secret of adapting Toyota's efficient system. This included making sure its production lines run at more constant speeds, increasing the flexibility of plants to accommodate more types of vehicles and cutting down on mistakes that require fixing before vehicles are shipped to dealers. 
G.M. has also tried to use fewer parts, including cutting the number of different glove compartment latches from 16 in 1998 to 6 today, and aims to have just one by 2006. 
Because of such progress, G.M. was the only one of the Big Three to make a profit last year. 
Gary Cowger, the president of G.M.'s North American operations, said: "The improvement in quality basically drives the elimination of waste. You don't pay for repair, you don't pay for nonproductive overtime that doesn't build cars and trucks. These costs are in the millions."
This year, Toyota's dominance showed particularly in larger vehicles -- it came in first in five of seven light truck categories, including best compact minivan, compact and full-size pickup, and its Lexus division won a sixth category, luxury S.U.V.
The initial quality survey is only one measure of success, if a well publicized one promoted loudly in industry advertisements. The company sent out random questionnaires to people who had recently bought or leased cars, asking about various problems like wind noise, paint chips and scratches, noisy brakes, doors that are hard to open and poor lumbar support. They received responses from 65,000 people.
Another survey, conducted earlier in the year by Consumer Reports magazine, examines up to the first eight years of ownership, and the Big Three did not fare nearly as well. 
"I.Q.S. is geared more to auto manufacturers than the consumer," said David Champion, director of automobile testing at Consumer Reports, referring to the initial quality survey. 
"They get the initial quality right, but I don't think the cars are robust enough to last over time," he added. "The consumer is looking at one, two or three years of ownership."
David Healy, an analyst at Burnham Securities, said "some cars do well on the 90-day survey and fall apart after three years."
"From my point of view," he added, "how it lasts over seven years is more useful."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Deal for Miller Brewing May Be First in a Series
South African Breweries agreed to buy the Miller Brewing Company from Philip Morris for $3.6 billion in stock, moving a step closer to surpassing Anheuser-Busch as the world's largest brewer.
 Miller Brewing, ranked eighth by volume, has a small international presence and has been focused on turning around its United States business, which remains a distant second to Anheuser-Busch. South African Breweries ranks fifth. Page C2. 

G.M. Rises in Survey on Quality
General Motors rose to third place in this year's quality ranking surveys by J. D. Power and Associates, the best performance for a domestic manufacturer since the study's methodology was changed in 1998. Ford also rose in the survey, as did DaimlerChrysler. C4.

US Airways Examines Varied Fares
Airlines have to narrow the gap between walk-up fares and leisure fares that has widened in the last several years and driven more business travelers to buy cheap tickets, the chief of US Airways said. The fare gap has deepened the airline industry's crisis, David N. Siegel said. Mr. Siegel said that US Airways was "looking at a couple of different air fares" that it might introduce. C5.

Claim for Electricity Refunds Denied
Federal regulators examining whether companies overcharged for electricity during the California power crisis rejected an attempt by California officials to expand their claim for electricity refunds by up to $2.8 billion. C4.

Two Enron directors who joined the board in 1999, Frank Savage and John Mendelsohn, have resigned. C4.

Accountant Testifies on Shredding
A senior Arthur Andersen accountant testified that he first learned last fall about its policy requiring the destruction of certain records and was uncomfortable with the idea of destroying Enron-related memos. C4.

Shares Close Mostly Lower
Stocks closed mostly down as energy shares fell with oil prices. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 11.35 points, or 0.11 percent, to 9,911.69. The Nasdaq composite index rose 7.53 points, or 0.46 percent, to 1,631.92. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 3 points, or 0.28 percent, to 1,064.66. C7.

Number of Jobless Claims Declines
For a second week, fewer people filed new claims for unemployment insurance, but the level of claims still indicated that the job market remained sluggish. Claims dropped by a seasonally adjusted 12,000, to 410,000 -- the lowest level since the middle of March -- for the week that ended Saturday, the Labor Department said. C2.

Moody's Cuts Qwest Credit Rating
The credit rating of Qwest Communications International was cut to junk by Moody's Investors Service, which said the phone company had too much debt. C6.

The Navy and Marines Join Forces
For two centuries the United States Navy and the Marine Corps have worked as a joint fighting force, but despite their long history they have always advertised separately -- until now. Since February, the Pentagon has been promoting the Navy and Marine Corps together to imprint the "Power of Teamwork" on a more patriotic America. Advertising. C5.

Challenge to Boeing Is Dismissed
The Seoul District Court rejected a suit by the French manufacturer Dassault Aviation demanding disqualification of Boeing as the winner of a contract to build 40 fighter planes for South Korea. World Business, Section W.

Airport Indicates Korea's Ambitions
Rising up like a rolling cloud of glass, marble and steel, the main terminal of the new $5.6 billion Inchon International Airport will clearly convey South Korea's economic ambitions to the visitors expected for the World Cup soccer games. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: Heart of Cheapness 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Poor Bono. He got stuck in a moment, and he couldn't get out of it.
 In one of the oddest enterprises in the history of development economics, Bono -- the lead singer for the rock band U2 -- has been touring Africa with Paul O'Neill, secretary of the treasury. For a while, the latent tensions between the two men were masked by Bono's courtesy; but on Monday he lost his cool. 
 The pair were visiting a village in Uganda, where a new well yielding clean water has radically improved the villagers' health. Mr. O'Neill's conclusion from this, as from the other development projects he saw, was that big improvements in people's lives don't require much money -- and therefore that no big increase in foreign aid is required. By the way, the United States currently spends 0.11 percent of G.D.P. on foreign aid; Canada and major European countries are about three times as generous. The Bush administration's proposed "Millennium Fund" will increase our aid share, but only to 0.13 percent.
Bono was furious, declaring that the projects demonstrated just the opposite, that the well was "an example of why we need big money for development. And it is absolutely not an example of why we don't. And if the secretary can't see that, we're going to have to get him a pair of glasses and a new set of ears."
Maybe the easiest way to refute Mr. O'Neill is to recall last year's proposal by the World Health Organization, which wants to provide poor countries with such basic items as antibiotics and insecticide-treated mosquito nets. If the U.S. had backed the proposed program, which the W.H.O. estimated would save eight million lives each year, America's contribution would have been about $10 billion annually -- a dime a day per American, but nonetheless a doubling of our current spending on foreign aid. Saving lives -- even African lives -- costs money.
But is Mr. O'Neill really blind and deaf to Africa's needs? Probably not. He is caught between a rock star and a hard place: he wants to show concern about global poverty, but Washington has other priorities.
A striking demonstration of those priorities is the contrast between the Bush administration's curt dismissal of the W.H.O. proposal and the bipartisan drive to make permanent the recent repeal of the estate tax. What's notable about that drive is that opponents of the estate tax didn't even try to make a trickle-down argument, to assert that reducing taxes on wealthy heirs is good for all of us. Instead, they made an emotional appeal -- they wanted us to feel the pain of those who pay the "death tax." And the sob stories worked; Congress brushed aside proposals to retain the tax, even proposals that would raise the exemption -- the share of any estate that is free from tax -- to $5 million.
Let's do the math here. An estate tax with an exemption of $5 million would affect only a handful of very wealthy families: in 1999 only 3,300 estates had a taxable value of more than $5 million. The average value of those estates was $16 million. If the excess over $5 million were taxed at pre-2001 rates, the average taxed family would be left with $10 million -- which doesn't sound like hardship to me -- and the government would collect $20 billion in revenue each year. But no; the whole tax must go. 
So here are our priorities. Faced with a proposal that would save the lives of eight million people every year, many of them children, we balk at the cost. But when asked to give up revenue equal to twice that cost, in order to allow each of 3,300 lucky families to collect its full $16 million inheritance rather than a mere $10 million, we don't hesitate. Leave no heir behind!
Which brings us back to the Bono-O'Neill tour. The rock star must have hoped that top American officials are ignorant rather than callous -- that they just don't realize what conditions are like in poor countries, and how foreign aid can make a difference. By showing Mr. O'Neill the realities of poverty and the benefits aid can bring, Bono hoped to find and kindle the spark of compassion that surely must lurk in the hearts of those who claim to be compassionate conservatives.
But he still hasn't found what he's looking for.

HEADLINE: State Warns About Risks Jeopardizing City's Budget 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
With just a week to go before New York City's not-very-set-in-stone deadline for passing its budget, a state oversight board warned yesterday that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's current plan to balance the budget "appears to be in jeopardy."
 The New York State Financial Control Board, which took over the city's finances during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's and now monitors its budgets and financial plans, reported that it had identified $1.7 billion in risks in Mr. Bloomberg's plan to close the city's roughly $5 billion budget gap for the 2003 fiscal year, which begins on July 1. 
 The control board's report warned that the "2003 budget balance appears to be in jeopardy" and added that "additional action on the city's part is necessary." 
The warning came as negotiations between the mayor's office and the City Council entered a new phase. The Council is trying to avert some cuts, arguing that they would hurt the city's poorest people. The mayor warns that the city simply cannot afford to do everything it wants to. The Council has wanted to raise taxes; the mayor does not.
Aides on both sides said that it now appeared unlikely that the city would adopt a budget by June 5, the budget deadline mentioned in the City Charter. But the June 5 deadline -- which falls on Wednesday of next week -- is not exactly hard and fast. The city has adopted a budget by June 5 only a few times since the charter was adopted in 1989. 
And the city is still waiting to see what budget actions the State Legislature will approve: the city needs the state's permission to raise the cigarette tax and parking fines and to get more flexibility in how it refinances its debt. Several officials said that it would be difficult to agree on a budget without knowing what help the state would provide.
The more serious deadline, by custom, is June 30, the last day of the fiscal year. The city has only failed to make that deadline once, in 1991, another tough fiscal year, when the Council did not pass the budget until 7:30 a.m. on July 2. 
Then there was 1998, when the Council passed its own budget over the objections of the mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, and the mayor impounded the funds. Their civil war dragged on for months, until they buried their budget hatchets in November. 
This year the Council and the mayor are working to negotiate a budget. But both sides have some cards up their sleeves. The Council is still holding out the threat of passing its own budget if the mayor does not give it more of what its members are seeking. The mayor's office is threatening to withhold its letter spelling out the amount of money the city expects to collect in revenue next year -- a figure needed to pass a budget. 
But both sides hold out hope that they will agree on a budget, and adopt it. 
Of course, in New York City, the adoption of a budget is merely the first step in what has become an essentially yearlong budget process with periodic modifications. 
Last June the city adopted a $40.2 billion budget. By the time it was modified last month, the budget had grown to $41.8 billion. It was, though, an unusual year: the recession and the attack on the World Trade Center certainly threw things out of balance, as tax revenues dropped precipitously and expenditures cropped up unexpectedly. 
But many of the unexpected expenditures were unrelated to the attack. Union contracts cost the city more than it had expected, health insurance costs for city workers rose steeply, and police overtime costs were higher than budgeted for antidrug initiatives, crackdowns on quality of life crimes, and security for unplanned events.
The financial control board found that the city would end this budget year, which ends June 30, without a deficit, but only after having made several changes during the year and going through a nearly $3 billion surplus built up in recent years. 
The report said that the city could end the current fiscal year with a surplus of as little as $22 million -- which would be $300 million less than the city projected, and nearly $3 billion less than it ended last year with. The smaller the surplus at the end of this year, the more difficult it becomes to balance next year's budget.
